b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Chicken Wings Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourOptional Refrigeration time: 6 hours\nThe baking powder trick yields super-crispy wings and is worth planning ahead. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll still have delicious wings without it: Omit the baking powder, but still season the wings with the kosher salt before air-frying them.\nIf you can\xe2\x80\x99t find gochujang, try another favorite sauce for chicken wings and use the same air fryer method.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the wings:\n3 pounds chicken wing drumettes and flats\n3 teaspoons baking powder\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\nFor the sauce:\n2 tablespoons gochujang\n2 tablespoons soy sauce\n1 tablespoon rice wine vinegar\n2 teaspoons sesame oil\n1 teaspoon sugar\n3 tablespoons butter, melted and kept warm\nFor the sesame mayonnaise dipping sauce:\n1 cup mayonnaise\n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil\n3/4 teaspoon sugar\n1/8 teaspoon sriracha\nTo garnish:\nThinly sliced scallions, for garnish\nToasted sesame seeds, for garnish\nThin spears of cucumber\nThin slices of radish\nSpecial equipment:\nAir Fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Season and rest the wings: Pat the wings dry, if needed. In a large bowl, add the wings and toss them with the baking powder and salt until evenly coated.\nSpread the wings around the bowl so they are in a single layer and refrigerate them, uncovered, for at least 6 hours and up to 24 hours.\n2 Air fry the wings: Heat the air fryer to 380\xc2\xb0F. Open the drawer and fit as many wings as you can in it without crowding them (for my 4.4-quart air fryer, this was 1-1/2 pounds of wings, or half the batch). Close the drawer. Cook for 25 minutes, shaking the drawer every 5 minutes to shuffle the wings around.\n3 Make the sauce: As the wings cook, make the sauce. In a medium bowl, whisk together the gochujang, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, sesame oil, and sugar. Set aside.\n4 Make the sesame mayonnaise: In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, sesame oil, sugar, and sriracha until smooth. Set aside.\n5 Increase the air fryer temp: Once the wings have cooked for 25 minutes, increase the temperature of the air fryer to 400\xc2\xb0F. Cook the wings for another 5 minutes. This gets them nice and brown and especially crispy.\n6 Sauce and serve the wings: Mix the melted butter with the sauce (it might solidify a bit, but the heat of the wings will re-melt it). Add the wings to a large bowl, pour over half the sauce and toss the wings in the sauce.\n7 Serve and eat: Transfer to a serving platter and sprinkle with scallions and sesame seeds, if you like. Serve immediately, accompanied by the cucumbers, radishes, and sesame mayonnaise for dipping.\n8 Cook the remaining wings: Reduce the temperature of your air fryer back to 380\xc2\xb0F. Repeat steps 2 and 4. Toss them with the remaining sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Fried Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: 10 pieces of fried chicken\nAlternative Pan Fry Method: If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have access to an air fryer, you can make this fried chicken using a traditional pan fry method. Add enough oil to a cast iron skillet so the oil is about 1 1/2 inches up the side of the skillet. Heat oil until it reaches 350\xc2\xb0F. Add chicken pieces and fry for 8 minutes. Flip, and fry for another 8 minutes until golden brown. Test temperature; you might need a few more minutes for the dark meat pieces (thighs and legs).\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken: \n1 4-pound fryer chicken, cut into 10 pieces (2 breasts cut in half, 2 wings, 2 legs, 2 thighs)\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 cups buttermilk\nFor the coating:\n2 cups all-purpose flour\n1 tablespoon seasoned salt\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon garlic powder\n1 tablespoon paprika\nSpray olive oil for cooking\nSpecial equipment:\nKrups Air Fryer\nThermapen Instant Read Thermometer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Season the chicken well with salt and pepper and then add it to a bowl with buttermilk. Chicken pieces should be covered with the buttermilk. Let it sit for at least an hour or up to overnight.\n2 Bread the chicken: To prepare the breading mixture, stir together flour, seasoned salt, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and paprika.\nRemove chicken pieces from buttermilk and shake off any excess; then dip in the flour mix and coat well. Transfer breaded chicken pieces to a clean plate or wire rack to rest.\n3 Air-fry the chicken: You will need to work in two batches if you are doing a full chicken. Spray the basket of your air fryer with nonstick spray. Place half of the pieces in the basket of your air fryer. Try to ensure the pieces don\xe2\x80\x99t touch. Air needs to circulate around them.\nSpray the chicken pieces lightly with spray oil. Place the basket in the air fryer and turn the air fryer to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cook for 14 minutes, then flip the fried chicken with tongs, spray lightly with oil a second time on the bottom side of the chicken, and cook for another 8 to 10 minutes.\nThe half-breast pieces and the wings will be done on the low end of that time range, and the dark meat pieces will need a full 24 to 26 minutes of time to be cooked through. The dark meat pieces should reach 175\xcb\x9aF.\n(NOTE: My method photo here only shows the temp at 148\xcb\x9aF to illustrate that the chicken can LOOK cooked but is actually not cooked through. A meat thermometer is vital.)\nDuring the air frying process, if you pull out the chicken and notice any dry flour spots on the chicken, spray those spots lightly with oil. The breading will never crisp up if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a tiny bit of oil to hydrate it. It will just burn.\n4 Serve: When the fried chicken is ready, let it rest on a plate for a few minutes before serving. Serve immediately with salad, coleslaw, mashed potatoes, or your favorite fried chicken sides!\nCooked fried chicken can be stored in the fridge for 5 days and reheated in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 8 to 10 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nAir Fryer Cranberry Brie Canap\xc3\xa9s Recipe\nCranberries are widely available this time of year, and you can use fresh or frozen for this recipe. And brie is mild in flavor, but when served with foods that are tart (such as cranberries), the creaminess is amplified. Don\xe2\x80\x99t concern yourself with removing the rind from your wheel of brie: it\xe2\x80\x99s completely edible!\nINGREDIENTS\nSpiced Cranberry Sauce\n1-inch piece of ginger, or 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger\n1 vanilla bean, or 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1 (12-ounce) bag (about 3 1/2 cups) fresh or frozen cranberries, rinsed\n1 3-inch cinnamon stick (or 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon)\n3 sprigs of fresh rosemary, divided\nJuice of 1 naval orange (about 1 /2 cup)\n1 tablespoon of orange zest\n1/4 cup maple syrup\nPinch of kosher salt\n1/2 cup packed light brown sugar\nCanap\xc3\xa9s\n8 ounces brie cheese, cut into 1\xe2\x80\x9d cubes\n2 (1.9 ounce) boxes fully baked phyllo shells (30)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1. Prep the ginger and vanilla: Peel and then thinly slice the ginger (using the edge of a spoon is the easiest way). Use a sharp paring knife to split the vanilla bean down its length.\nOpen the vanilla bean slightly to ensure the seeds are extracted during cooking.\n2. Make the Cranberry Topping: In a 3-quart saucepan, combine the ginger, vanilla bean, cranberries, cinnamon stick, 1 sprig of rosemary, orange juice and zest, maple syrup, and the salt.\nStir the ingredients together and heat over medium-high heat for 3 minutes, or until the mixture starts to boil.\n3. Reduce the topping: Reduce the heat to low, and allow the cranberries to cook until they begin to split open. Stirring frequently, cook the cranberries for 8 to 10 minutes, or until they've reduced a bit and thickened to a jelly-like consistency.\nRemove the pan from the stove and add the light brown sugar. Stir constantly to dissolve the sugar and coat the cranberries in a thick glaze.\nAllow the cranberries to cool to room temperature, leaving the spices in it.\n4. Prep your Air Fryer: Set your Cuisinart\xc2\xae Air Fryer Toaster Oven\xe2\x80\x99s function dial to Air Fry and the temperature dial to 300\xc2\xb0F. Remove both the Air Fryer basket and the baking pan from the oven, then turn the on/oven dial to 10 minutes to preheat the oven.\n5. Fill the phyllo cups: While your Air Fryer is heating, fill your phyllo shells with the pieces of brie. It\xe2\x80\x99s easier to leave the shells in the packaging while you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to fill them. Remove the shells from the plastic packaging and arrange them, a dozen at a time, in the Air Fryer basket.\n6. Bake the shells: Place the baking pan, with the Air Fryer basket nestled inside, into the oven in position 1. Bake the shells for five minutes.\nOnce the shells have finished baking, remove them from the Air Fryer Toaster Oven and carefully remove them from the basket. Repeat this step, baking the shells by the dozen, until they are all baked.\n7. Prep the rosemary topping: While the shells are baking, pick off the remaining rosemary leaves in clusters of two or three leaves. Set aside to garnish the canap\xc3\xa9s when you\xe2\x80\x99re done topping them with the sauce.\n8. Top with cranberry sauce and garnish: Once you have baked all of the brie-filled shells, top each with a teaspoon of cranberry sauce, leaving the cinnamon stick, vanilla bean (if you used one), rosemary sprigs and slices of ginger in the pan. Pull out any pieces of rosemary orAny remaining cranberry sauce may be stored in the refrigerator for up to one week.\nGarnish the top of each canap\xc3\xa9 with the sprigs of rosemary leaves you picked earlier.\n9. Serve! These canap\xc3\xa9s are best served immediately, but can be held at room temperature for up to 2 hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nHow to Make Crispy Air Fryer French Fries\nPrep time: 1 hour, 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 2 to 4 servings\nIf you want to soak these in the morning and air fry them for dinner, you can refrigerate the potatoes in the interim once they\xe2\x80\x99ve been soaked in cold water. Or soak them in the fridge all day in cold water.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds russet potatoes (peeled if you want)\n2 teaspoons canola oil or other vegetable oil\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh rosemary or 1 teaspoon dried rosemary\n1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt (or regular salt)\n1/4 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\nAir fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the potatoes. Scrub the potatoes clean and slice them long ways, 1/4 to 1/2-inch thick. Soak them in a bowl of ice water for at least an hour, or up to 24 hours (in the fridge) if need be.\n2 Preheat the air fryer: Preheat the air fryer to 390\xc2\xb0F for about 15 minutes.\n3 Dry and season potatoes: Remove the potatoes from the bowl and lay them out on a paper towel or clean kitchen towel. Dry them thoroughly, and then transfer them to a medium bowl and toss them with the oil, rosemary, salt, and pepper.\n4 Air fry the potatoes: Remove the air fryer basket and add the potatoes, positioning them as evenly as you can. Set the timer for 10 minutes and fry the potatoes.\nSlide the basket out, toss the potatoes to redistribute them\xe2\x80\x94you may notice some spots look more air fried than others.\nFry for another 10 to 12 minutes, until they start to look dry and crispy. (If any pieces seem excessively brown, remove them before you turn the fryer back on.)\n5 Serve: Remove from the fryer and place in a serving bowl. Let them cool for a few minutes (I know it\xe2\x80\x99s hard, they\xe2\x80\x99re French fries!) and taste. They should crisp up a little bit as they cool. Toss with additional rosemary, salt, and/or pepper if desired.\nIf for some reason you find yourself in a situation with leftovers, you can refrigerate them, covered for a few days. Simply reheat them in a little oil in a hot cast iron pan or skillet and they\xe2\x80\x99ll perk right back up.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nCrispy Air Fryer Chickpeas Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 2 cups; 2 to 4 for snacking\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chickpeas:\n1 (15-ounce) can chickpeas, drained and rinsed\n1 tablespoon canola or vegetable oil\nZa'atar seasoning:\n2 teaspoons fresh thyme, minced\n1 teaspoon za\xe2\x80\x99atar seasoning\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\n1/4 teaspoon cracked black pepper\nSpicy seasoning:\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\n1/2 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon paprika\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne\nFrench herb seasoning:\n1 teaspoon Herbs de Provence\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\nItalian seasoning:\n1 teaspoon finely grated Parmesan or Pecorino Romano cheese\n1 teaspoon Italian seasoning or equal parts oregano, thyme, basil, and marjoram\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\nAir fryer, such as the Phillips Air Fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the air fryer to 390\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes, or according to the manufacturer's instructions.\n2 Prep the chickpeas: Dry the chickpeas thoroughly on a paper towels or a clean kitchen towel. You can even dry them in a salad spinner, but you might lose a few depending on the design of your spinner. Discard any skins that come off of the chickpeas during this step.\n3 Season the chickpeas: Combine the oil and spice mix in a bowl and whisk to combine. Gently incorporate the chickpeas until coated.\n4 Air fry the chickpeas: Transfer to the preheated air fryer and air fry for 8 to 10 minutes until crispy. Taste one of the chickpeas; if it's not as crispy as you'd like, then continue to cook for another 1 to 3 minutes.\nSome of the chickpeas may look as though they have \xe2\x80\x9cpopped.\xe2\x80\x9d Don\xe2\x80\x99t fret if that happens!\n5 Season and serve: Remove from the basket to a bowl, taste, and add more salt, pepper or seasoning to your liking. Serve immediately; the crispy chickpeas will not keep.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Bacon-Wrapped Figs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesSoaking the figs time: 20 minutesYield: 12 bacon-wrapped figs\nThis recipe is easily doubled or tripled! Just air fry in separate batches.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 dried Turkish or mission figs\n6 strips regular center-cut bacon (not thick cut)\nGoat cheese or blue cheese for stuffing, optional\nSalted, roasted almonds for stuffing, optional\nHoney, for serving\nNonstick spray, for air fryer\nSpecial equipment:\nAir fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Reconstitute the figs: Add the dried figs to a bowl filled with steaming hot water. Let them sit for 20 minutes to reconstitute. Drain the figs and cut off the stems. Cut a small slit in each fig and spoon in a little blue cheese or goat cheese, or half an almond, if desired. You could also do a mix of fillings.\n2 Wrap the bacon around the figs: Cut the strips of bacon in half and trim them down to about 1/2 to 3/4 inches wide. Wrap one bacon strip around each fig. Secure with a toothpick.\n3 Air fry the figs: Spray the basket of your air fryer with nonstick spray. Add bacon-wrapped figs in a single layer so they aren\xe2\x80\x99t touching. Air fry the figs at 350\xcb\x9aF for 8-9 minutes, flipping once halfway through.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have an air fryer, broil the figs on high for about 3 minutes per side.\n4 Serve the figs: Once the figs have cooled slightly, serve them drizzled with honey.\nLeftover figs (yeah right!) will keep in the fridge for up to 5 days. Reheat in a 350\xcb\x9aF oven, or reheat in the air fryer for a few minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Tostones Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesSoaking time: 20 minutesYield: About 20 Tostones\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dipping sauce:\n1 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 cup ketchup\n1/4 teaspoon garlic powder\nFor the tostones:\n3 green plantains\n4 cups cold water\n1 tablespoon kosher salt\n3 tablespoons neutral cooking oil (vegetable, peanut, or coconut oil)\ncoarse salt for sprinkling\nSpecial equipment:\nTostonera, optional\nAir fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare dipping sauce: Whisk together the mayonnaise, ketchup, and garlic powder. Store covered in the refrigerator until ready to serve. You can do this up to 48 hours in advance.\n2 Peel and cut the plantains: Remove the ends of the green plantains with a sharp knife. Score the plantain down its back side and use the fleshy part of your thumbs to push the peel up and away from the plantain.\n3 Preheat your air fryer to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Soak the plaintains: Combine 4 cups of cold water and 1 tablespoon of kosher salt. Slice the plantain into 1 1/2-inch-thick chunks and soak them in water for 20 minutes. (Soaking the plantains prevents browning and keeps the air-fried plantains from drying out while cooking.\n5 Dry then par-fry the plantains: Remove the plantains from the water and dry each one thoroughly. Toss the plantain slices in a bowl with 1 tablespoon of the cooking oil. Make sure each plantain is coated in a thin layer of the oil.\nTransfer the plantains to your air fryer\xe2\x80\x99s basket. Organize in a single layer, leaving a 1/2 inch of space on all sides of the slices to allow the air to circulate properly. Fry until the plantain offers no resistance when pierced with the tip of a knife. This can take anywhere from 3 to 6 minutes per side.\n6 Mash the plantains: Increase the air fryer\xe2\x80\x99s temperature to 400\xc2\xb0F. Carefully remove the plantain slices from the basket and smash each one in a tostonera or place your soft plantain between a piece of parchment paper (or a brown paper bag) and smash it with a coffee mug. The plantain should be a flat 1/4-inch thick disc that holds together.\n7 Air fry the smashed plantains: Return the smashed plantains to the air fryer basket (you may have to work in batches depending on the size of your basket).\nBrush a light layer of oil onto the top side of the tostones and fry for 3 minutes on the first side. Flip the tostones and brush once more with a light layer of oil, then fry for the final time for 4 minutes instead of 3 minutes.\n8 Season the tostones: Immediately after removing them from the air fryer. Serve the tostones with the mayo-ketch sauce while still hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nMexican Wedding Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 18 minutesChilling time: 1 hourYield: 24 to 30 cookies\nYou can substitute any other nut in place of the pecans. Times for toasting in Step 1 will vary based on the size of the nut you use.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cookie dough:\n1 cup (115 g) pecan pieces\n1 cup (225 g or 2 sticks) unsalted butter at room temperature\n3/4 cup (85 g) powdered sugar, sifted\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n2 cups (280 g) all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nTo roll the cookies:\n1 1/4 cup (145 g) powdered sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast the nuts on the stovetop: Place the nuts in a medium skillet and place over medium heat. Toast the nuts, stirring frequently, until they darken slightly and smell fragrant and nutty, about 5 minutes.\nRemove the pan from heat and let the nuts cool in the pan.\n2 Crush the nuts: Once the toasted nuts are warm to the touch, but not hot, pour them into a quart-size sealable freezer bag. Seal the bag, and then use a rolling pin to roll and crush the nuts until they are crushed into a chunky powder. Set aside until needed.\n(Alternatively, pulse in a food processor until powdery. Be careful of over-processing or the nuts will turn into nut butter!)\n3 Mix the butter and sugar: Place the butter and 3/4 cup powdered sugar in the bowl of stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Beat together on medium speed until the sugar is absorbed into the butter and the buttery paste clings to the side of the bowl. Add the vanilla and beat for an additional 30 seconds to incorporate.\n4 Add the flour and salt: Mix on low speed. As the dry ingredients start to absorb into the butter-sugar mixture, you can increase the speed back to medium. Once all the flour is mixed in and a dough has formed, stop the mixer.\n5 Empty the crushed nuts into the bowl with the dough: Mix on low speed to incorporate.\n6 Chill the dough: Scrape the dough onto a piece of plastic wrap and flatten into a disk about 1-inch thick. Wrap tightly with the plastic wrap and place in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour or until the dough is firm.\n7 About 10 minutes before you're ready to bake, preheat the oven to 350F. Line 2 baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicon baking mat.\n8 Roll the cookies: Place the 1 1/4 cups of powdered sugar for coating the cookies into a shallow bowl. Remove the chilled dough out of the refrigerator and form into 1-inch balls of dough. (If your dough chilled longer than 1 hour, you may need to let it soften for a few minutes at room temperature.)\nRoll the balls of dough in powdered sugar and place on the baking mat, spaced slightly apart.\n9 Bake for 17 to 19 minutes, or until the cookies start to brown slightly on top and are golden brown on the bottoms. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for 10 minutes after baking.\n10 While the cookies are still warm, roll each cookie in the powdered sugar again. Return the cookies to the cooling rack and let cool completely before serving.\nStore at room temperature in an airtight container. They will keep well for at least a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nAlmond Crescent Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2 1/2 dozen cookies\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup of butter, room temperature\n2/3 cup of sugar\n1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon of almond extract\n2 1/2 cups of flour\n1 cup of almond flour (can substitute ground almonds*)\n1/4 cup of powdered sugar for sprinkling\n*You can use slivered, blanched almonds and grind them up, but you will have a very crumbly, hard to work with dough. It\xe2\x80\x99ll still taste good though.\nMETHOD\n1 Beat the butter and the sugar together until light and fluffy. Add the vanilla and almond extracts and mix.\n2 Add the flour and almond flour. Mix thoroughly.\n3 Take generous tablespoons of the dough (it will be slightly crumbly) and roll it into a small ball, about an inch in diameter, and then shape into a crescent shape. Place onto a parchment paper lined baking sheet.\n4 Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 15-20 minutes or until a light golden brown.\n5 Dust with powdered sugar.\nFor added decadence let the cookies cool and dip one end of them into some melted chocolate, then let the chocolate harden.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nChocolate Florentine Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesBake time: 8 minutes per batchYield: 30 florentine cookies\nFlorentine cookies are crisp almond toffee-like cookies that are sandwiched with a layer of chocolate and then drizzled with more chocolate. They have a reputation for being difficult to make but I\xe2\x80\x99ve given some hints and tips on making them easier for you. Just make sure to watch them bake, as they can go from done to burnt fairly quickly.\nMaking these cookies goes more quickly if you have at least two baking sheets so that you can prep the next batch while the previous batch is in the oven.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cookies:\n2 1/2 cups (290 g) slivered almonds\n1/4 cup (35 g) all-purpose flour\n2 tablespoons natural cocoa powder (not Dutch-process)\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg (optional but recommended)\n3/4 cup (150 g) white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick or 115 g) unsalted butter\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n2 tablespoon honey\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nTo finish:\n8 to 10 ounces of dark chocolate, chopped\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nSilpat or other silicon baking mat\nThin, flat spatula\nWire cooling rack\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Chop the almonds: Place the slivered almonds in a food processor. Pulse until the almonds are broken down into smaller bits, about 1/4 inch in size. They should be the size of the chopped nuts you would sprinkle over an ice cream sundae.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a food processor, you can chop the nuts by hand or place them in a ziplock bag and crush them with a wooden rolling pin until they are the right size.\n2 Add the flour and cocoa powder to the food processor bowl. Pulse a couple of times to blend together.\n3 Make the cookie "batter" on the stovetop: In a medium-sized saucepan, place the sugar, butter, cream, and honey. Heat until the sugar is dissolved and the butter has melted. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla extract.\nAdd the dry almond mixture and stir until incorporated. Set aside to cool for 20 minutes.\n4 Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xbaF. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicon baking mat.\n5 Spoon out the cookies: Once the batter has cooled (it will still be warm), use a teaspoon measure to spoon out the cookies onto the prepared baking sheet (1 teaspoon per cookie). Space the cookies about 3 inches apart; they will spread a lot during baking. (On a 12 x 18 sheet, I found 6 cookies fit comfortably.)\n6 Flatten the cookies: Dip your finger in some water, then use it to spread the batter into a round circle, with the nuts in a single layer on the pan. This will encourage the batter to spread evenly in a circle.\n7 Bake the cookies: Bake the cookies in the oven for 6 to 8 minutes. If you are using parchment paper, the cookies will bake faster. If you are using a silicon baking sheet, the silicon insulates the heat and it takes a little long to bake (but they will bake more evenly).\nRemove the pan from the oven once the edges of the cookies start to darken and brown and transfer to a cooling rack. Be careful as the cookies go from done to burnt fairly fast.\nWhile the cookies are still warm from the oven, take a look at them and see if any of them are not quite round. If they are not as nicely shaped as you would like, use a spatula to carefully nudge the sides of the cookie into a round circle. You will have to work fairly quickly as the cookies firm up as they cool.\n8 Cool the cookies: Let the cookies cool on the pan for 10 to 20 minutes, until they are set. It\'s fine if they\'re still a little soft, but they should be able to be transferred in one piece without tearing or creating ripples in the cookie.\nIt helps to use a very thin, flat spatula so you can easily slide under each cookie. Also, if you have a wire rack that has crisscross wires, this is ideal for cookies like this since any under-baked cookie will slump a little bit on racks with more widely-spaced wires. Let the cookies cool completely.\n9 Continue baking the cookies in batches until all the batter has been used.\n10 Sandwich the cookies with chocolate: Once the cookies have all been baked and cooled, melt dark chocolate by placing it in a microwave-safe bowl and cooking it in 30 second increments, stirring between each increment. (You can also melt the chocolate on a double boiler, if you prefer.)\nOnce the chocolate has melted, pick two cookies that are roughly the same size and smear a thin layer of chocolate on the bottom of one of them. Place the matching cookie bottom on top and set the cookie sandwich on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or a wire rack.\nRepeat with the remaining cookies. Drizzle any remaining chocolate over the Florentines.\n11 Wait for the chocolate to firm up and harden before serving or packaging. Stored in an airtight container, these cookies will keep at room temperature for 3 days, or in the fridge for about 2 weeks.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nFlourless Lemon Almond Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 8\nIt helps to separate the eggs first, while they are cold, and then let them sit to come to room temperature as you prep the other ingredients.  Eggs are easier to separate when cold, and they perform better as leavening agents when at room temperature.\nWhen whipping egg whites, make sure your equipment is perfectly clean. Any fat (or even bits of egg yolk in the whites) can keep the egg whites from properly whipping up.\nIf almond flour is not available at your market, you can grind up blanched, slivered almonds in a food processor until very finely ground.  I would start with a little more than 1 1/3 cups. Our local Whole Foods carries a Bob's Red Mill brand of finely ground blanched almond flour which is what we used for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 eggs (large), separated into 4 egg yolks and 4 egg whites, room temperature (see how to separate eggs)\n2 Tbsp lemon zest, packed\n1/2 cup (100 g) white sugar, divided 1/4 cup (50 g) and 1/4 cup (50 g)\n1 1/2 cup lightly scooped (144 g) finely ground blanched almond flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder (make sure your baking powder is fresh!)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom\n1 teaspoon white or cider vinegar\nPinch of salt\nPowdered sugar for sprinkling\nSpecial equipment:\n8 or 9-inch springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175 \xc2\xb0C).  Place a round of parchment paper on the bottom of a 8 or 9-inch springform pan, and grease it and the sides of the pan with butter or cooking spray.\n2 Beat egg yolks, lemon zest, 1/4 cup sugar: In a large bowl, beat together with a wooden spoon the egg yolks, lemon zest, and 1/4 cup sugar until smooth.\n3 Whisk almond flour, baking powder, cardamom, beat into egg yolk mixture: In a separate bowl, whisk together the almond flour, ground cardamom, and baking powder. Add the flour mixture to the egg yolk mixture and beat until well combined. The mixture should resemble a thick paste.\n4 Whip egg whites to soft peaks: With an electric mixer with a very clean bowl and clean whisk attachment, beat the egg whites, starting on low speed and gradually increasing the speed.\nWhen bubbles start to form, add a pinch of salt and the teaspoon of vinegar (both the salt and the vinegar will help the beaten egg whites maintain better structure, as will the sugar in the next step).\nAs the egg whites begin to increase in volume, sprinkle in the remaining 1/4 cup of sugar, a little at a time, as you continue to beat the egg whites. Beat until soft peaks form.\n5 Fold beaten egg whites into almond mixture: Stir a third to a half of the beaten egg whites into the almond mixture to loosen it and make it lighter.\nThen gently fold the remaining whipped egg whites into the batter, a large scoopful at a time.\n6 Scoop batter into pan, bake: Gently scoop the batter into the prepared springform pan and place in the oven. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175 \xc2\xb0C) for 30 minutes.\nRemove from the oven and let cool. Run a sharp knife around the edge of the cake helping it to separate from the side of the pan.\nRelease the springform pan sides, and gently move the cake (on parchment) to a cake serving plate. Sprinkle with a little powdered sugar before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nAmaretti Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 4 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes about 30 cookies\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups of almond flour -or- 3 cups of blanched slivered almonds, finely ground up\n1 1/4 cup of baker's sugar (superfine sugar)\n3 egg whites\n1/2 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon of almond extract\nExtra sugar for dusting\nMETHOD\n1 Prepare oven and baking sheet: Preheat oven to 300\xc2\xb0F and line baking sheets with parchment paper.\n2 Make the dough: In a food processor pulse together the almond flour and sugar. Add the vanilla and almond extract and pulse for a few seconds. Add the eggs, one at a time, and continue to process until the dough is smooth.\n3 Dollop dough onto lined baking pan, dust with sugar: Place teaspoons of the dough on the parchment paper-lined baking sheet and dust with sugar.\n4 Bake: Bake at 300\xc2\xb0F for 24-30 minutes or until golden brown.\nCool completely before serving.\nThey will be slightly chewy at first, but they will be nicely crispy as a day or two goes by.\nStore in a cool, dry place. (Note: I usually under-bake mine since I like them chewy. If that's your preference, bake them for about 20-24 minutes.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nChinese Almond Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesDough chilling time: 2 hoursYield: Makes 4 to 5 dozen cookies\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/3 cups of almond flour, lightly packed\n1 cup of unsalted butter, chilled and cut into cubes\nPinch of kosher salt\n2 eggs\n1 teaspoon of almond extract\n1 3/4 cups of flour\n1 cup + 2 tablespoons of sugar\n1/2 teaspoon of baking soda\nThinly sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Beat almond flour, salt, butter: Place the almond flour, salt, and butter into an electric mixer with a paddle attachment and beat on medium speed for three minutes. The mixture will become coarse and chunky looking.\n2 Add one of the eggs, reserving the other for later, and the almond extract. Mix on low speed until just incorporated.\n3 Sift together the flour, sugar, and baking soda then add to the butter mixture at low speed. Mix until just combined.\n4 Chill the dough: Take the dough and flatten it into a disc and wrap in plastic wrap. Place it in the refrigerator for two hours to chill.\n5 Prep oven, baking sheet, egg: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Place the other egg into a bowl and beat it.\n6 Flatten balls of dough onto cookie sheet: Take pieces of dough and roll them into balls about three-quarters-of-an-inch wide. Place them on the sheet about an inch apart and then press them down slightly with your palm to make a coin shape.\n7 Place a slivered almond onto each cookie and lightly press it into place, then paint the surface of the cookie with some of the beaten egg using a pastry brush or your finger (this will give the cookie a lacquered appearance once it bakes).\n8 Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F for 13-15 minutes or until the edges just begin to tan. Cool on the sheet on a wire rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nCaramel Nut Tart Recipe\nYield: Serves 10\nINGREDIENTS\nCrust Ingredients:\n1 1/2 cups (200 g) all purpose flour\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (1 stick, 112 g) chilled unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch pieces\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n3-4 tablespoons ice water\nFilling Ingredients:\n1 1/4 cups (250 g) sugar\n1/4 cup (60 ml) water\n2/3 cup (160 ml) heavy whipping cream\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces\n1 tablespoon honey\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 cup (125 g) walnuts, coarsely chopped\n1/2 cup (62 g) pecans, coarsely chopped\n1/2 cup (55 g) slivered blanched almonds\nWhipped cream (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n9 1/2 inch (24 cm) tart pan with removable bottom\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the tart dough: Whisk together the flour, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg and salt. Add the cut up pieces of butter and use a pastry cutter to cut into the flour mixture until the butter pieces are no bigger than a pea. (You can use a food processor for this if you want.)\nSprinkle with vanilla and add 3 tablespoons of ice water. Use a fork to work the water and vanilla into the dough. (You can use a food processor.) Add up to a tablespoon more of ice water, just enough so that the dough easily sticks together when you pinch it with your fingers.\nForm the dough into a ball, kneading once or twice if necessary, and flatten into a disk. Wrap the dough disk in plastic and chill for 1 hour.\n2 Roll out the dough, place in tart pan, freeze: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C). Remove dough from refrigerator and let sit for 10 minutes. Place the dough on a lightly floured clean surface. Roll out the dough to a 12-inch round. Place the dough in a 9 1/2-inch-diameter tart pan with a removable bottom.\nPress the dough down and into the sides. Roll the rolling pin over the top of the tart pan to even off the top edges.\nPierce the bottom of the dough in the tart pan all over with fork. Freeze for 30 minutes.\n3 Pre-bake the crust: Bake the crust at 375\xc2\xb0F for 20 minutes, piercing the bottom with fork if bubbles form. Transfer to a rack to cool.\n4 Make the caramel nut filling: Put sugar and 1/4 cup water in heavy medium saucepan with high sides. Heat on medium-low heat and stir until sugar dissolves.\nOnce the sugar has dissolved, increase the heat to medium high. Boil without stirring until caramel is deep amber color, occasionally swirling the pan, about 10 minutes. Reduce heat to medium.\nSlowly stir in the cream. Be careful as the mixture will bubble up significantly (this is why we are using a high sided pot). Stir until the caramel is smooth.\nAdd the butter, honey and vanilla. Stir until the butter has all melted.\nStir in all of the nuts.\n5 Bake: Pour caramel mixture into the pre-baked crust. Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C) 20 minutes. Remove from oven to cool completely on rack.\nServe with whipped cream or vanilla ice cream (optional).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nHomemade Almond Roca Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutes\nUse an inexpensive chocolate such as Hershey's. It has low cocoa butter content. If you use a premium chocolate with a high cocoa butter content, unless you temper the chocolate first (look up directions online), the cocoa butter may separate into white streaks as the melted chocolate cools.\nYou can use other kinds of nuts such as pecans or macadamia and white chocolate.\nDo not attempt to make this on a humid or rainy day. Do not double the recipe, make one batch at a time.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup sugar\n1/4 cup water\n1 Tbsp light corn syrup\n1/2 lb butter (2 sticks - NO substitutes!)\n1/2 lb. slivered almonds (2 cups)\n1/2 lb. bar of regular Hershey's dark chocolate (7 oz okay)\nMETHOD\n1 Melt butter with sugar, syrup and water in a pan (such as a large non-stick frying pan) on medium to medium-high temperature. Stir continuously with a wooden spoon.\nWhen butter is melted, add the almonds.\n2 Cook until the mixture turns a warm amber color, and the boiling sounds like a crackle: When mixture comes to a rolling boil, set your timer for a minimum of 10 minutes and keep stirring (no more than 15 minutes). The mixture will thicken and turn darker in color. The almonds will roast.\nKeep stirring and cooking until you hear it crackle. If you don't cook it long enough it will not harden, so keep stirring and listen for the crackling sound.\nElise's note: I have found it very hard to distinguish between the boiling sound and the crackling sound in this recipe. A better guideline for me is by color. When the mixture turns a warm amber color, at about 11 or 12 minutes into the boiling, that's the time to pour it out. Wait too long and it will burn.\nIf you try to make this, please read all the comments listed below. It's actually trickier than one would think.\n3 Pour mixture out onto a large cookie sheet: When the mixture crackles, pour the mixture out onto a large sheet pan or cookie sheet and spread it as thin as possible with a fork.\n4 Spread chocolate over the top: While the almond mixture is still hot, break up the chocolate into chunks and distribute it over the almond mixture and let it melt. Spread it evenly on the top.\n5 Cool to room temp: Let the almond roca cool to room temperature. When cool you can lift the whole thing off the pan and break into small pieces.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nAlmond Shortbread Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesChilling time: 30 minutesYield: 12 to 16 cookies\nThis recipe makes 12 large or 16 small wedges\xe2\x80\x94the cookies are rich, so the small wedges are not too small if you want to have a greater yield.\nINGREDIENTS\nButter, for the baking pan\n1 stick (4 ounces, 8 tablespoons) unsalted butter, cut into 1-inch slices, at room temperature\n3/4 cup (148g) sugar\n1 cup (120g) flour\n1/2 cup (56g) cornstarch\n1/2 cup (48g) almond flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon milk\n1/3 cup sliced almonds\nPowdered sugar (for sprinkling)\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch pie pan, or tart pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xbaF. Generously butter a 9-inch pie pan, or a tart pan with a removable rim.\n2 Mix the dough: In a large bowl, use a wooden spoon to stir the butter and sugar until creamy.\nStir in the flour, cornstarch, almond flour and salt. Mix until combined. Stir in the vanilla and milk. Knead with your hands if necessary; the dough will come together in big clumps.\nAlternatively, use a stand mixer with a beater attachment to mix the dough. Once you've added the vanilla and milk, beat on low speed just until the dough comes together.\n3 Press the dough into the pan: Scrape the dough into the pan and press into an even layer into the bottom of the pan (it should not go up the sides).\nCover the bottom of a 1-cup dry measuring cup with a piece of plastic wrap and use it to smooth the dough evenly in the pan.\n4 Cut the dough into wedges and chill: With a paring knife, cut the dough into 12 or 16 wedges. Scatter the sliced almonds over the top and press them gently into the dough. Chill for 30 minutes, until firm, or up to 2 days. (If chilling overnight or longer, cover the pan with plastic wrap.)\n5 Bake the shortbread: Set the pan on a rimmed baking sheet, and bake for 25 minutes, or until the edges begin to brown.\nCover loosely with foil and continue to bake for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the dough feels firm and looks golden.\nRemove from the oven and let cool for 10 minutes. While the shortbread is still awrm, carefully cut the wedges again to make sure they're separated. Leave in the pan until completely cool.\n6 Store the shortbread: Store the shortbread in an airtight tin for up to 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 7 days. Sprinkle with confectioner's sugar before serving, if you like.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nHerb-Spiced Mixed Nuts Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 3 to 4 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 cups (283 to 354g) pecans, walnuts, and almonds\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, olive oil, or coconut oil\n1 tablespoon chopped rosemary\n1 tablespoon chopped sage\n1 tablespoon chopped thyme\n1/8 to 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n2 tablespoons maple syrup\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Toast the nuts: Place the nuts on an ungreased, rimmed baking sheet and toast them for about 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from the oven to cool slightly.\n3 Combine the butter, herbs, and maple syrup: Melt the butter over low heat in a small saucepan. Remove from the heat and add the rosemary, sage, thyme, cayenne, maple syrup, and salt. (If you are using oil, you should gently and briefly warm it as well.)\n4 Toss the nuts with the butter and herbs: Using a spatula, toss the warm nuts in a medium bowl with the melted herbs and butter until the nuts are coated.\n5 Serve! These are best consumed immediately, while warm. They may make your hands a little messy, but it\xe2\x80\x99s worth it. Trust me.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nAlmond Flour Waffles Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time per batch time: 10 minutesYield: 6 to 8 waffles\nFor a truly crispy waffles, I recommend transferring finished waffles to the oven to dry out a bit and ensure a crispy exterior.\nThis recipe is easily doubled.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups almond flour or almond meal\n1/2 cup tapioca flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon baking powder\nPinch of salt\n3 tablespoons sugar\n3 large eggs\n3 tablespoons coconut oil, warmed to liquid state\n1 cup almond milk, room temperature\n1 teaspoon almond extract\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nSpecial equipment:\nWaffle maker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat your waffle maker: Turn on your waffle maker and let it warm for 5 to 10 minutes, until hot enough that a flick of water evaporates on contact. Heat the oven to 250\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the waffle batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients in a medium bowl. In a separate bowl, whisk together the wet ingredients. Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and thoroughly whisk together.\n3 Rest the batter: Allow the mixture to sit for 5 minutes to give the flour time to absorb the liquid.\n4 Make the waffles: Grease the waffle maker and make waffles according to manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s instructions. After cooking, place the finished waffles in the oven for 5 to 10 minutes to stay warm and to crisp them up a little. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nGinger Almond Biscotti Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 50 minutesChilling the dough time: 1 hourYield: Makes about 36 biscotti\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup blanched slivered almonds\n3/4 cup (170 g) sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick) butter\n1/2 cup molasses (NOT blackstrap molasses, it's too bitter)\n3 large eggs\n1/4 cup minced fresh ginger\n3 cups (400 g) all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1 teaspoon cinnamon and nutmeg\n1/2 teaspoon each ground cloves and allspice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bake the almonds: Spread the almonds out on a sheet pan and bake them at 350\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes. Let cool, then roughly chop.\n2 Make the biscotti dough base: Beat together the sugar and butter until light and fluffy (about 3 to 4 minutes). Add the molasses and beat a minute more.\nAdd eggs one at a time, beating for 1 minute after each addition. Mix in the minced ginger.\n3 Mix in the dry ingredients and the almonds: Whisk together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, ground cloves and allspice.\nAdd the flour mixture into the butter and eggs mixture, one third at a time. Stir in the almonds.\n4 Refrigerate the dough for 1 hour.\n5 Shape into long rectangles: Turn the dough out onto a well-floured board, and divide in half. With floured hands, shape into long rectangles about 10-12 inches long, 2 1/2 inches wide and 1/2 inch high. Transfer to a parchment or silicone lined baking sheet.\n6 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until golden brown and firm to the touch in the center, 25 to 30 minutes. Remove from oven, and let stand until cool enough to handle.\n7 Cut diagonally: Transfer the rectangles to a cutting board. Using a serrated bread knife, cut the rectangles on the diagonal into 1/2-inch-thick slices.\n8 Bake again: Return pieces cut side down to baking sheet. Re-bake 15-18 minutes, turning the biscotti over half way through baking.\nCool on wire rack. Store in airtight container.\nDip in wine after dinner (classic Italian fashion) or coffee, tea, or hot cocoa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nAlmond Pound Cake with Orange Glaze Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Makes one loaf\nWhenever baking with eggs, you'll get more rise if you start with eggs that are at room temperature. If you want to quickly bring chilled eggs up to room temp, place them in a bowl of warm (not hot) water for 10 minutes.\nTip on using Odense almond paste\xe2\x80\x94grate it using the large holes of a box grater.\nThis recipe makes enough batter for one 5x9x3 inch loaf pan, which is a rather large loaf pan. If you have a 4x8x2 1/2 inch loaf pan, either make two loaves, or cut the recipe in half.\nINGREDIENTS\nCake:\n5 ounces (140 g) almond paste (we recommend Odense almond paste), grated\n1 1/2 cups (300 g) white granulated sugar\n4 ounces (1/2 cup or 1 stick) butter, room temperature\n4 large eggs\n1 teaspoon orange zest\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1/2 cup (120 g) plain (full fat) Greek yogurt (or sour cream)\n1 1/2 cups (200 g) all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt (if using unsalted butter)\nGlaze:\n1/3 cup (43 g) powdered sugar\n2 teaspoons orange juice\n1/2 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon orange zest\nSpecial equipment:\n5x9x3-inch loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare loaf pan: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Grease the inside of a 5x9x3-inch loaf pan with butter or with non-stick spray.\n2 Beat almond paste, add sugar, butter, eggs, zest, vanilla, yogurt: Using a stand mixer, beat the almond paste, starting at a low speed.\nSlowly add the sugar to the almond paste while beating, gradually increasing the speed, until incorporated.\nAdd the butter, and beat until fluffy, smooth, and almost white, about 5-6 minutes, on high speed.\nAdd the eggs, one at a time, beating a minute after each addition.\nBeat in the orange zest, vanilla, and Greek yogurt.\n3 Whisk dry ingredients: In a medium bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.\n4 Stir the flour mixture into the butter, almond paste, egg mixture, a third at a time, until well blended.\n5 Bake: Pour batter into prepared loaf pan. Place on lower middle rack of your oven.\nBake at 325\xc2\xb0F for 50-55 minutes, until golden brown, and if you press down lightly on the top it springs back at you, and a tester inserted into the center comes out clean. While it's baking, if you notice it getting too browned, tent it lightly with aluminum foil.\n6 Cool on a rack: Remove from oven and let cool on a rack for 5 to 10 minutes. Then carefully remove from the pan to cool completely on a rack.\n7 Make orange glaze: While the cake is cooling, make the glaze. Sift the powdered sugar through a sieve to remove any lumps and place in a medium bowl. Whisk in the orange juice and lemon juice. Stir in the the zest. Add more sugar if the glaze is too runny, add more juice if it is too thick for your taste.\n8 Drizzle cake with glaze: When the cake has cooled, place it on a serving plate and use a spoon to drizzle the glaze all over it.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nOatmeal Almond Butter Breakfast Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 18 minutesYield: 16 cookies\nThe almond butter will blend into the batter more easily if it's room temperature. If you forget, just warm it for a few seconds in the microwave to soften.\nPeanut butter or another nut butter can be substituted for the almond butter.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups rolled oats (not quick-cooking oats)\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1 cup whole wheat flour\n1/2 cup wheat germ\n2 teaspoons baking soda\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1 1/2 cups almond butter, room temperature (see Recipe Note)\n1 1/3 cups light brown sugar, packed\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n2 large eggs\n1/3 cup water\n1 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line a sheet pan with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.\n2 Mix the dry ingredients: Combine the rolled oats, flours, wheat germ, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon together in a large mixing bowl. Set aside.\n   3 Make the cookie dough: In the bowl of a stand mixer using the paddle attachment (or using a hand mixer), mix the almond butter, brown sugar, and vanilla extract at low speed until smooth.\nWith the mixer still on low, add the eggs, one at a time, to the bowl. Scrape down the bowl after each egg is blended into the batter. This helps the mixture to stay smooth and uniform.\nAdd the water to the bowl and mix on low until the batter no longer looks soupy. Gradually add the flour mixture to the batter, stopping the mixer to scrape down the sides of the bowl. Mix again for one minute to make sure the flour is completely blended in.\nGradually add the chocolate chips to the dough. Mix for 30 seconds more still on low speed.\n4 Scoop the cookies: Using a large (2 ounce) ice cream scoop, or a lightly greased 1/4 measuring cup, scoop the dough onto your prepared sheet pan.\nSlightly flatten each cookie with the back of your scoop or measuring cup.\n5 Bake the cookies: Bake for 15 to 18 minutes, or until the outer edges of the cookies are slightly browned and the centers are puffed.\n6 Cool and store the cookies: Remove the pan from the oven and allow the cookies to cool slightly (about 5 minutes) before enjoying. Store the cookies in an airtight container for up to 48 hours. (See headnotes for freezing instructions.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nChewy Almond Squares (Blondies) Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 9 squares.\nTo make the decorative almond halves, take a whole raw almond and pinch it between your fingers. Use a serrated bread knife to carefully cut the almond in half. The almond has a natural break-point so it should split easily once you start to cut it.\nNo need for a mixer for this recipe, all you need is a whisk and a strong spoon.\nYou can easily double this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup butter (1 stick, 112 g), melted, plus butter for greasing the pan\n1 cup tightly packed light brown sugar\n1 egg, lightly beaten\n1 tablespoon of almond extract\n1 cup (128 g) all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/8 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\n1/3 cup toasted, blanched almonds, chopped\nWhole almond halves for decoration\n  One 8x8-inch baking pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prep pan, toast almonds: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease an 8x8-inch baking pan with butter. Toast blanched almonds if you have not already done so, and when cool, roughly chop them.\n2 Mix wet ingredients: In a mixing bowl, whisk together the melted butter and brown sugar until there are no more lumps of brown sugar. Whisk in the beaten egg and almond extract.\n3 Whisk dry ingredients: In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and pinch of salt.\n4 Make batter: Add the dry mixture to the wet mixture and mix until smooth. Stir in the chopped almonds.\n5 Pour into baking pan, add almond halves: Pour into the prepared baking pan and smooth the surface. You can "cut" the surface with a knife to make it easier to see where you will want to make cuts once the squares are done. Place an almond half, cut side down, in the middle of each square.\n6 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20 to 25 minutes or until a tester comes out clean. Cool completely before cutting into squares.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nGinger Chicken with Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nIncluding a little cornstarch in the chicken marinade is traditional in many asian dishes. The cornstarch helps keep the chicken pieces from drying out when cooked. You can skip it if you want, but the chicken will be more tender if you use it.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 boneless, skinless chicken breast halves (1 1/2 - 2 pounds total)\n2 teaspoons ground coriander\n1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger plus \xc2\xbc cup julienned fresh ginger (see How to Peel, Chop, and Grate Ginger)\n4 teaspoons canola oil or vegetable oil\n2 teaspoons white-wine vinegar\n1 teaspoon of cornstarch\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\n4 large scallions (or 6 small), trimmed\n1/2 cup mango chutney, large pieces chopped\n1/4 cup chicken broth\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 cup sliced almonds, toasted\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slice chicken crosswise into \xc2\xbd-inch-thick pieces.\n2 Marinate chicken strips: Whisk the ground coriander, grated ginger, 2 teaspoons of the oil, vinegar, corn starch, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl, making sure there are no lumps of corn starch.\nAdd the chicken and marinate at room temperature for 15 minutes.\n3 Prepare scallions: Thinly slice white parts of scallions. Julienne green parts; set aside.\n4 Stir together chutney, broth, and garlic in a small bowl.\n5 Stir-fry: Heat remaining 2 teaspoons oil in a 12-inch nonstick skillet (or wok) over medium-high heat. Add scallion whites and julienned ginger; stir-fry 30 seconds.\nAdd chicken and stir-fry until thoroughly cooked, 4 to 6 minutes.\nAdd scallion greens and chutney mixture; cook, stirring, 2 minutes.\n6 Serve: Transfer to shallow bowls with hot cooked rice (or without rice, for low-carb version). Sprinkle with toasted almond slices and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCherry Almond Granola with Vanilla Crumbles Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: 6 cups granola and crumbles\nThe vanilla crumbles are an adaptation of Milk Crumbs developed by Christina Tosi of Momofuko Milk Bar in New York City. The original recipe is in her cookbook.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the vanilla crumbles (makes about 1 cup of crumbles):\n6 tablespoons instant nonfat dry milk (such as Carnation)\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n2 tablespoons sugar\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n3 tablespoons melted butter\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract, or the 1 vanilla bean, seeded and scraped\nFor the granola:\n3 cups old-fashioned rolled oats, divided\n3 tablespoons oil\n2 tablespoons maple syrup\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon almond extract\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup slivered almonds\n3/4 cup dried cherries\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 250\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Mix the crumbles: Whisk together dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the powdered milk through salt\xe2\x80\x94in a bowl. If using vanilla bean add the scraped seeds to the dry ingredients. If using vanilla extract add it to the melted butter.\nSlowly pour the butter over the dry ingredients while tossing with a fork until it forms clumps and all the dry ingredients have been incorporated. It will look like sandy gravel. Your largest pieces should be no larger than the size of a pea.\n3 Bake the crumbles: Scatter the crumbles evenly on a parchment-lined cookie sheet and bake at for 25 minutes until they are dry, but still pale in color. Cool completely on the cookie sheet.\nStore in an airtight container for up to one week, or cool and use stir into granola.\n4 Increase the oven temperature to 325\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Mix the granola: Combine oil, syrup, sugar, extracts, cinnamon, and salt in a medium sized bowl. Stir in oats and almonds making sure they are well coated. (Reserve the dried cherries for adding later.)\n6 Bake the granola: Spread mixture evenly onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake in the oven for 10 min. Stir and bake for 10 more minutes. Stir and bake for 5 to 7 minutes more. The granola should be dry and golden. Remove from oven. Let cool completely.\n7 Finish and store: Once the granola is cool, stir in cherries and vanilla crumbles. Store in an airtight container at room temp for 2 weeks. (Alternatively, store the vanilla crumbles separately at room temperature, covered, for up to two weeks, and the granola will keep for 1 month.)\nServe over your favorite yogurt with sliced bananas and a drizzle of honey.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nPeach Frangipane Puff Pastry Tarts Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 9 tarts\nPackage sizes of puff pastry vary but are usually in the 14- to 16-ounce range. Depending on the original size of the sheet, you will cut it into squares or rectangles. Remember, this is fancy but rustic, so the exact size of the tarts is flexible!\nINGREDIENTS\n1 sheet all-butter puff pastry (14 to 16 ounces), thawed\n1 cup almond flour\n1/2 cup sugar\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n5 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature, cut into slices\n1 large egg\n2 tablespoons all-purpose flour\n1 tablespoon amaretto or 1 teaspoon pure almond extract\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 pounds (about 4 medium) ripe peaches, cut into 1-inch wedges\n2 tablespoons turbinado sugar\n3 tablespoons apple jelly or apricot jam\n1 tablespoon water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: Line a baking sheet with parchment and preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Prepare the dough: On a lightly floured work surface, unfold the puff pastry. Lightly roll it with a rolling pin to even it out if there are any gaps or wrinkles. Transfer the dough to the parchment-lined baking sheet.\nWith a pizza cutter or knife, cut the dough into 9 pieces to make four-inch squares or similar size rectangles. The exact size depends upon the original shape of the dough. Spread them apart on the baking sheet. Refrigerate while you make the filling.\n3 Make the frangipane: In a food processor fitted with the metal blade, pulse the almond flour, sugar, and salt for a few seconds to mix. Add the butter pieces and pulse until the butter is incorporated with no large visible pieces.\nAdd the egg, all-purpose flour, amaretto (or almond extract), and vanilla and process until the frangipane is smooth. It should have the consistency of natural almond butter, thick but runny.\n4 Assemble the tarts: On each square of pastry, spoon about 1 tablespoon of the frangipane. It will spread out naturally on the pastry, and even further once you add peaches. If some spills over the edges that\xe2\x80\x99s fine. If your frangipane doesn\xe2\x80\x99t spread, feel free to push it around the tart with the back of your spoon. You may have some frangipane left over, depending on the size of your pastry squares.\nSet 5 to 6 wedges of fruit on top of each tart\xe2\x80\x94no need to be too fussy about their arrangement. Sprinkle each with the turbinado sugar.\n5 Bake the tarts: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the peaches are soft and the frangipane and pastry are golden.\n6 Glaze the tarts: In a small microwave-safe bowl, heat the jelly or jam and water for 30 seconds, or until liquefied. Brush the warm glaze over the peaches. Serve the tarts on the same day that they are made.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nAlmond Butter Date Balls Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesChill time: 30 minutesYield: 15 to 16 date balls\nI sometimes like to add a tablespoon or so of dried cranberries to give this a bit of a tart twist.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup walnuts\n1/2 cup pitted dates (about 4 to 5), cut into quarters\n1/2 cup cocoa powder, any kind (I usually use Hershey\xe2\x80\x99s Special Dark)\nScant 1/2 cup maple syrup\n1/2 cup almond butter\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 teaspoon fine sea salt\n1/2 cup whole almonds\nCooking spray (optional)\nFor topping/rolling the balls:\n1/2 cup unsweetened shredded coconut\n1/2 cup cocoa powder\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the date balls: Place the walnuts and dates into the bowl of a food processor fitted with the blade, and pulse several times until well combined. The pieces should look like a rough crumble.\nAdd the cocoa powder, maple syrup, almond butter, vanilla extract, and sea salt and pulse until the mixture is smooth and thick; it will start to peel away from the edge of the bowl.\nWhen this happens, stop the food processor; if it keeps whirring away, it may get stuck because these ingredients are, well, sticky! Keep a close eye on this, as it will come together quickly.\n2 Add the almonds: Add the almonds and pulse a few times to incorporate them. You want them sort of irregularly sized, so that some pieces are still pretty crunchy and offer a variety of textures.\n3 Roll the date balls: Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment or wax paper. Place the coconut in a small bowl and the cocoa powder in another bowl.\nUsing a cookie scoop measuring about 1 1/2 tablespoons (like this one) and sprayed with cooking spray for easy release, scoop out the mixture, roll it into golf-ball shapes, and roll in the shredded coconut or the cocoa powder. (I usually do some in coconut and some in cocoa powder, and leave some plain.)\n4 Chill and store the date balls: Transfer the date balls to the baking sheet and chill them for a few hours or overnight, if needed. Once they've firmed up, transfer to a plastic lidded container and keep in the fridge for several weeks, but I've never, ever, had them last that long. They are usually consumed too quickly.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nAlmond Flour Waffles Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time per batch time: 10 minutesYield: 6 to 8 waffles\nFor a truly crispy waffles, I recommend transferring finished waffles to the oven to dry out a bit and ensure a crispy exterior.\nThis recipe is easily doubled.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups almond flour or almond meal\n1/2 cup tapioca flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon baking powder\nPinch of salt\n3 tablespoons sugar\n3 large eggs\n3 tablespoons coconut oil, warmed to liquid state\n1 cup almond milk, room temperature\n1 teaspoon almond extract\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nSpecial equipment:\nWaffle maker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat your waffle maker: Turn on your waffle maker and let it warm for 5 to 10 minutes, until hot enough that a flick of water evaporates on contact. Heat the oven to 250\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the waffle batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients in a medium bowl. In a separate bowl, whisk together the wet ingredients. Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and thoroughly whisk together.\n3 Rest the batter: Allow the mixture to sit for 5 minutes to give the flour time to absorb the liquid.\n4 Make the waffles: Grease the waffle maker and make waffles according to manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s instructions. After cooking, place the finished waffles in the oven for 5 to 10 minutes to stay warm and to crisp them up a little. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nGrain-Free Apple Honey Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesCooling time: 45 minutesYield: 8 to 10 servings\nThis cake can be made up to a day ahead. Or, if you\xe2\x80\x99re in a big hurry to serve it, you can serve the cake warm, too.\nFor a more rustic cake, use almond meal instead of almond flour, and leave the apple unpeeled.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cake:\n1 1/2 cups (6 ounces) almond flour\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n3 large eggs\n1/4 cup honey\n2 tablespoons neutral-tasting oil (I use avocado oil)\n1 medium (7-ounce) Granny Smith apple, peeled and cut into thin matchsticks, or grated coarsely\nFor the glaze and topping:\n1/2 cup powdered sugar\n2 tablespoons honey\n1 tablespoon almond milk or water\n1/4 cup sliced almonds\nSpecial equipment:\n8-inch cake pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare a cake pan: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xbaF. Grease an 8-inch cake pan and place a round of parchment in the bottom of the pan.\n2 Make the cake batter: In a medium mixing bowl, whisk together the almond flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Make a well in the center of the flour, then add in the eggs, honey, and oil. Whisk wet ingredients together in the middle, then gradually whisk in the flour from the sides of the bowl. Continue whisking until the batter is smooth. Stir in the julienned or grated apple.\n3 Pour the batter into the pan and bake the cake: Pour the batter into the cake pan, taking care not to move the parchment around. Spread out the batter in an even layer using an offset spatula or butter knife, then tap the cake pan against the countertop to remove any air bubbles.\n4 Bake the cake: Bake the cake for 30 minutes, until it is browned around the edges and a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out clean. You may also use a probe thermometer to test for doneness\xe2\x80\x94the center of the cake should be 210\xc2\xbaF.\n5 While the cake is baking, make the glaze and toast the almonds: In a small bowl, stir together the sugar, honey, and almond milk. Cover the bowl and set it aside until needed.\nToast the sliced almonds in a skillet over medium heat until they are lightly browned, about five minutes. Shake the pan often so that the almonds are browned evenly. When they are done, immediately transfer to bowl to cool.\n6 Transfer the cake to a cooling rack: Allow the finished cake rest for 5 minutes, then run a knife around the edge of the pan to and invert the cake to a cooling rack. Peel the parchment off the bottom of the cake and flip it right side up.\n7 While the cake is still warm, pour the glaze over the top. Spread the glaze so that it drips over the edges of the cake. While the glaze is still wet, sprinkle the almonds on top.\n8 Let the cake cool to room temperature and serve. The cake can also be made and glazed up to a day ahead.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSpicy Paleo Pumpkin Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 12\nYou can substitute any hard winter squash or carrots for the pumpkin.\nTo grate the pumpkin, cut it into large pieces, scoop out the seeds, and grate the flesh on a box grater until you hit the skin. Alternatively, you can cut away the skin and grate in a food processor.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups almond flour\n3/4 cup tapioca starch\n1 1/2 tablespoons coconut flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 tablespoon smoked paprika\n1 teaspoon crushed chili flakes (I used chipotle chili flakes)\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n4 large eggs\n1/2 cup olive oil, melted ghee, or melted butter\n2 tablespoons honey\n1 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n1 packed cup grated raw sugar or pie pumpkin (avoid jack-o-lantern pumpkins)\n1/2 cup diced red bell pepper\n1/2 cup diced onion\n3/4 cups toasted pepitas or pumpkin seeds (divided)\nSpecial equipment:\n12-cup muffin tin\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350F. Line a muffin tin with muffin papers\n2 Sift together the dry ingredients: Sift together the almond flour, tapioca starch, coconut flour, baking soda, baking powder, spices, and salt. I like to sift at least twice with Paleo baked goods to make sure there are no clumps and everything is well-mixed.\n3 Mix together the wet ingredients: In a separate bowl, beat the eggs, then whisk in the oil, honey, and vinegar.\n4 Pour the wet ingredients into the dry and mix gently until combined.\n5 Gently stir in the grated pumpkin, bell pepper, onion, and 1/2 cup of pepitas. Save the rest of the pepitas for topping. Rest the batter for at least 10 minutes so that the flours can hydrate.\n6 Fill each muffin wells up to the top. Top each muffin with a few of the remaining 1/4 cup of pepitas.\n7 Bake for 18 to 20 minutes. When done, the muffins should look toasted around the edges, be dry on top, and a toothpick inserted in the middle will come out clean.\n8 Cool and serve (or store): Transfer the muffins to a cooling rack. Cool briefly before serving, or cool completely and store in an airtight container at room temperature for 3 days (or refrigerate for up to a week).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'

b'Save It Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nStrawberry Almond Oat Smoothie Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 2 (12-ounce) servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup uncooked old-fashioned rolled oats\n2 cups frozen strawberries\n1 cup plain yogurt (regular or Greek, any fat percentage)\n1 cup unsweetened vanilla almond milk (or milk of your choice)\n1/2 medium banana, fresh or frozen, sliced\n1/4 teaspoon pure almond extract\n1-2 teaspoons honey (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the ingredients: In a blender, combine the oats, strawberries, yogurt, almond milk, banana, and almond extract.\n2 Puree the smoothie: Starting on low speed, puree the ingredients.
