Feel free to leave out or swap with chocolate chips.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 to 3 ripe bananas, thoroughly mashed (about 1 1/4 cup mashed)\n1/3 cup melted butter (salted or unsalted)\n3/4 cup sugar\n1 large egg, beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 Tbsp strong brewed coffee or espresso, or a pinch of instant coffee granules mixed with a Tbsp of water (optional)\n1 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\n1 1/2 cup of flour\n1 cup chopped walnuts or pecans (toasted or raw)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prepare muffin pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line a muffin pan with paper liners.\n2 Combine wet ingredients and sugar: Thoroughly mash the bananas in a large bowl. Stir the melted butter into the bananas. Mix in the sugar, egg, coffee and vanilla extract.\n3 Combine dry ingredients: Whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.\n4 Add dry ingredients into wet, add nuts: Add the flour mixture to the banana mixture, a third at a time, stirring until it is just incorporated. (Do not over-mix! Over-mixing will result in dense, tough muffins.)\nFold in the chopped walnuts or pecans.\n5 Fill muffin cups, and bake: Lightly spoon the mixture into a prepared muffin tin. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20-25 minutes.\nCheck for doneness by pressing down on the top of the muffin. If it bounces back, it's done. You can also test by inserting a skewer or other tester into the center of a muffin. If it comes out clean, it's done.\nCool on a rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBanana Sheet Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 30 pieces\nHere's a tip, leave the cream cheese and butter for the frosting out while you make the banana cake, that way they will be softened by the time the cake is cooled and ready to frost. This banana cake is on the sweet side (it is a cake after all).\nIf you are trying to cut sugars, you may want to experiment dropping the sugar in the cake mixture by a half cup and cutting the amount of frosting in half.\nINGREDIENTS\nCake\n2 cups all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n2 eggs\nThe scraped insides of one vanilla bean, or 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 cup of mashed ripe bananas (2 large or 3 medium bananas)\n1/2 cup full fat sour cream\nFrosting\n6 ounces cream cheese, room temp\n4 Tbsp (1/4 cup) unsalted butter, room temp\n2 cups powdered sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) . In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.\n2 Beat together in a mixer the butter and sugars. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Mix in the vanilla and mashed bananas.\n3 Mix in half of the flour mixture, then the sour cream, then the other half of the flour mixture.\n4 Spread batter evenly in a greased 10x15 baking pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) for 20 minutes, or until nicely browned and the surface bounces back when you press it with your finger. Cool completely before frosting.\n5 To make the frosting, mix all of the ingredients together with an electric mixer. If too stiff to spread, add a teaspoon or two of water. Spread the frosting evenly over the cake and slice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nHummingbird Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 12 to 16\nThe cream cheese frosting recipe can be cut in half if you prefer less frosting. If so, apply sparingly so there is enough to cover the entire cake.\nFeel free to use any favorite liquor, such as Grand Marnier, Triple Sec, Cognac, Armagnac, Brandy or even Bourbon. Or, simply omit the liquor and use 2 tsp vanilla extract.\n  INGREDIENTS\nFor the cake:\n3 cups all-purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder (make sure your baking powder is still fresh!)\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg (optional)\n3 large eggs\n2 cups granulated white sugar\n1 cup canola oil\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1 (8 ounce) can crushed pineapple, with juice\n2 cups mashed bananas (from 3 to 5 bananas)\n1 cup finely chopped pecans\nFor the cream cheese frosting:\n1 pound cream cheese, softened\n1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, softened\n2 pounds (32-ounces) powdered sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon Cointreau or other liquor (see Recipe Note)\n1 cup roughly chopped pecans, for topping (optional, toasted)\nEdible flowers for garnish (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n3 9-inch cake pans\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0 F. Butter and flour three 9-inch round cake pans.\n2 Whisk together dry ingredients: In a large bowl, vigorously whisk together the dry ingredients: flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg (optional).\n3 Whisk together oil, sugar, eggs, then stir in pineapple, bananas, vanilla, 1 cup of pecans: In a separate bowl, whisk the canola oil, sugar, and eggs together until combined. Stir the pineapple, bananas, vanilla and one cup of the chopped pecans into the egg mixture and mix (do not beat).\n4 Fold wet ingredients into dry: Using a wooden spoon or spatula, fold the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients until just combined (do not over-mix).\n5 Pour into cake pans and bake: Pour the batter into the three prepared cake pans, taking care to divide evenly. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F on center racks of oven for 20 to 25 minutes, or until a toothpick or knife inserted in the center comes out clean.\n6 Cool: Allow the cakes to cool in the pan on wire racks for 10 minutes.  After 10 minutes, run a knife around the edges and remove the cakes from the pans.  Cool completely on wire racks before frosting.\n7 Make the frosting: Beat the softened butter and cream cheese in a large bowl with an electric mixer. With the mixer on low speed, add the powdered sugar in small amounts until all is incorporated, then add the Cointreau and vanilla and beat until the frosting is light and fluffy.\nNote: Do not add the powdered sugar while the mixer is set on a high speed, or you will create a snowy mess of sugar all over your kitchen. (Please do not ask me how I know this.)\n8 Frost the cake: Place one layer, top down, on a large plate or cake stand (this creates a smooth surface on the top and results in a more level cake). Spread frosting evenly over the first layer, then repeat with the second and third layers, then frost the sides.\n3 Sprinkle with chopped pecans: Sprinkle the top completely with the remaining cup of chopped pecans (toasted or un-toasted). Alternatively, press the chopped pecans onto the sides of the cake and leave the top simply frosted.\nThis cake is best served the day it's made and can be kept, assembled and frosted, for a few hours before servings. If you need to serve it the next day or if you have leftovers, cover the cake as well as possible and refrigerate it. Remove it from the fridge and let it come up to room temperature for an hour or two before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nCrunchy Banana Nut Granola Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: About 4 cups of granola\nI call for raw walnuts because they toast in the oven along with the granola, and nuts that have already been toasted can burn. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t find raw walnuts, you can sub raw almonds or pecans, or simply add toasted walnuts in the last 10 minutes of cooking.\nIf you like your granola in big clusters, spread the granola in a single, even layer on the baking sheets and do not stir during baking. This way, the granola will bake into one solid piece and you can break it up to clusters once cool.\nYou can store this granola in airtight containers for about a week, though it rarely lasts so long in our house.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup unsalted butter (If using salted butter, taste your mixture before adding salt)\n1/3 cup lightly packed light brown sugar\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon water\n3 cups old-fashioned rolled oats (Certified gluten-free, if needed)\n3/4 cup chopped raw walnuts (See recipe notes)\n1/4 cup chia seeds\n1 tablespoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 medium ripe bananas, diced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 275F with two racks placed in the upper and lower halves. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.\n2 Brown the butter: Slice the butter into small pats. In a small saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Once melted, the butter will start foam a bit, then it will begin to turn amber-colored and smell fragrant and nutty.\nWatch closely, as the butter can go from browned to blackened fairly quickly. This whole process should only take about 3 minutes.\nRemove the pan from heat immediately, and pour the melted butter into a small heatproof bowl.\n3 Melt the brown sugar: In the same saucepan used to brown the butter, add the brown sugar, vanilla, and water.\nStir over medium-low heat until combined, then cook until the brown sugar is thoroughly melted, 2 to 3 minutes. Remove from heat.\n4 Mix the granola: In a large bowl, mix the oats, walnuts, chia seeds, cinnamon, and salt until they are combined and the ingredients look well-distributed.\nAdd the melted brown butter and brown sugar mix and stir to combine. Then add the diced bananas and stir very gently.\n5 Bake the granola: Divide the granola between two baking sheets and spread into an even layer. Place into the warm oven and bake the granola for 45 minutes.\nHalf way through baking, stir the granola, then swap the top and bottom baking sheets and rotate the pans to avoid any hotspots. (If you want big clusters of granola, do not stir the granola.)\n6 Cool the granola: Remove the granola from oven and allow to cool for 20 to 30 minutes before stirring and serving. Store in airtight containers for up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBerry and Banana Terrine Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 envelopes (1/4 ounce each) unflavored gelatin\n2 cups white grape juice, divided\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar\n6 cups of mixed fresh berries and slices of banana (berries can include blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced or quartered strawberries)\nMETHOD\n1 Soften the gelatin: Put 1/4 cup of the white grape juice into a small bowl. Sprinkle the gelatin over the grape juice and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes while the gelatin softens.\n2 Make grape juice gelatin base: Put another 1/4 cup of the white grape juice and a 1/2 cup of sugar into a saucepan and heat on medium high heat until the sugar has dissolved.\nRemove from heat and stir in the gelatin mixture until it has dissolved. Stir in the remaining 1 1/2 cups of grape juice.\n3 Put fruit in loaf pan, cover with grape juice gelatin mixture: Put the berries and banana slices in a 4x8 loaf pan. Pour the grape juice mixture over the berries, and press down on the berries to submerge them into the juice/gelatin mixture.\n4 Chill: Cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator until firm, 3 hours.\n5 Un-mold: To un-mold, fill a basin half-way with hot water. Carefully lower the bottom of the loaf pan into the hot water and hold for 5 to 8 seconds. This will melt the gelatin at the edge of the pan, helping it to release.\nRun a dull knife around the edge of the pan as well.\nPlace a serving platter topside down on top of the loaf pan and turn the whole thing over. Shake gently to release the mold.\nSlice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBerries and Banana Fruit Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups hulled, roughly chopped strawberries\nA handful of raspberries\n1 cup blueberries\n1 apple, peeled, cored, roughly chopped\n2 bananas, peeled and thickly sliced\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon honey\nMETHOD\nPrep the berries before the bananas and apples, and add them to a large bowl.\nAs soon as you add the bananas and apples, sprinkle lemon juice over them to keep them from getting brown.\nAdd the zest and the honey and gently toss to combine.\nServe immediately. Or cover and chill for up to 2 hours before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'

b"Save It Print\nCoconut Banana Cream Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 10 minutesChilling time: at least 4 hours or up to 24 hoursYield: 1 9-inch pie, serves 8 to 10 people\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n12 whole graham crackers (about 200 g)\n6 tablespoons (85 g) unsalted butter\n3 tablespoons sugar\nPinch of kosher salt\nFor the custard:\n1/3 cup (66 g) sugar\n3 large egg yolks\n3 tablespoons cornstarch\n1 1/4 cup (295 ml) whole milk\n1 1/4 cup (295 ml) full-fat coconut milk\nPinch of kosher salt\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 cups sweetened shredded coconut, plus additional for the top\n2 medium ripe bananas\nFor the whipped cream topping:\n2 cups heavy whipping cream\n3 tablespoons powdered sugar\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\n9-inch pie plate\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the graham cracker crust: Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Break the graham crackers into a few pieces and place in the bowl of a food processor. Process the crackers until there are no large chunks left. The mixture should be sandy but not powdery.\nPour the crumbs into a bowl and stir in the melted butter, sugar, and salt. The mixture should be like wet sand and clump together when pinched.\nPress the crumbs firmly into the bottom and sides of a 9-inch pie plate to form a crust, using a measuring cup or glass to help you press firmly.\n3 Bake the graham cracker crust: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until the crust has started to turn a slightly darker brown color and smells fragrant. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool completely.\n4 Make the cream pie filling: Combine the sugar, egg yolks, and cornstarch in a medium saucepan. Whisk off the heat until they gain a little volume and turn a light yellow. Whisk in the milks and salt.\nPlace the pan over medium heat and whisk constantly until thickened, 15 to 20 minutes. (If this seems to be going really slowly, it's ok to nudge the heat up a little.)\nWhen the filling ready, the whisk should momentarily leave some visible trails on the surface before disappearing. Stir in the vanilla and shredded coconut.\n5 Transfer to pie crust: Spread half of the cream filling mixture into the cooled graham cracker crust. Slice the bananas and layer them on top, then cover with the remaining custard. Make sure to cover all the bananas (so they don\xe2\x80\x99t brown!).\nSmooth the surface and press plastic wrap directly on top.\n6 Refrigerate the pie at least 4 hours or up to 24 hours to set.\n7 Make the whipped cream topping: When ready to serve the pie, use a stand mixer or hand mixer to whip the cream until it holds soft peaks. Whisk in the sugar, and continue beating until the cream holds a medium peak. Generously dollop the cream over the top of the chilled pie. Sprinkle the top with extra shredded coconut.\nOnce assembled, the pie can be kept refrigerated for a few hours before serving. (Longer than a few hours, however, and the whipped cream can start to weep. It still tastes good, but is less visually appealing!)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nGluten-Free Chocolate Banana Cupcakes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 12 cupcakes\nIf your gluten-free flour blend does not contain xanthan gum in the ingredients, add 1/2 teaspoon xanthan gum to the recipe.\nNote that the FDA does list coconut as a tree nut, though many people with tree nut allergies are fine with coconut. If you're not sure if the person or people eating your cookies has a tree nut allergy that includes coconut, check with them before making this recipe, or substitute another fat in place of the coconut oil (we recommend butter if there are no dairy allergies, or vegan EarthBalance if there are).\nINGREDIENTS\n1 3/4 cups (240g) gluten-free flour blend (see Recipe Note)\n1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon (30g) unsweetened dairy-free cocoa powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (200g) granulated sugar\n1 large ripe banana\n1/2 cup coconut oil (or other your oil of choice), liquid at room temperature\n1 cup freshly brewed coffee, cooled to room temperature (use decaf if you\xe2\x80\x99d like)\n2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract\n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1/2 batch Vegan Chocolate Frosting\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F and prepare the pan: Line a 12-cup muffin tin with paper liners.\n2 Mix the dry ingredients: In a medium mixing bowl, whisk together the gluten-free flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, salt and sugar.\n3 Mix wet ingredients: In a separate medium mixing bowl, mash the banana with a fork or potato masher, and add the coconut oil, cooled coffee, vanilla and apple cider vinegar. Whisk until combined. (There may be small chunks of banana in the mixture, which is perfectly fine.)\n4 Mix the cupcake batter: Add the wet ingredients into the flour mixture and stir thoroughly to combine using a wooden spoon or rubber spatula. Portion out the batter into the cupcake liners, filling each almost to the top.\n5 Bake cupcakes for 18 to 20 minutes, or until cupcakes spring back ever so slightly when pressed in the center. Cool for 10 minutes in the pan, then transfer cupcakes to a wire rack to cool completely.\n6 Frost cupcakes: Once cool, frost cupcakes with Chocolate Fudge Frosting.\n7 Serve, or store: Cupcakes can be served immediately. Cupcakes can also be stored in an airtight container for up to 5 days if unfrosted, or for 2 days once frosted.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nQuick and Easy Green Smoothie Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Makes 2 servings\nIf you want to add coconut oil, be sure it\xe2\x80\x99s slightly melted when you add it so it emulsifies and blends well into the smoothie. Otherwise, it might be lumpy, especially if you are using frozen pineapple or if you add ice cubes.\nIf you use canned pineapple, you can add the juice, too, for a sweeter tasting smoothie.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 medium ripe banana\n1 cup of fresh, canned, or frozen pineapple\n3 large handfuls of fresh spinach (washed)\n1 cup of plain Greek yogurt\n6 oz. water\n1 teaspoon coconut oil (optional)\nMETHOD\nPut all ingredients in a blender, and blend until smooth.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nVegan French Toast with Caramelized Bananas Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nReprinted with permission from The Perfect Blend, copyright 2016 Tess Masters. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC. (Photography copyright 2016 by Anson Smart.)\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the French toast:\n1 cup (240ml) unsweetened almond or macadamia milk (strained if homemade)\n1 ripe medium banana\n2 tablespoons pure maple syrup, plus more to serve\n1 teaspoon natural vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon white (or black) chia seeds\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1\xe2\x81\x844 teaspoon natural salt\n8 slices gluten-free sandwich bread\n1\xe2\x81\x844 cup (60ml) coconut oil (in liquid form), plus more as needed\nFor the caramelized bananas:\n2 medium bananas, thickly sliced on the diagonal\n1\xe2\x81\x844 cup (37g) coconut sugar\n1 to 2 tablespoons coconut oil (in liquid form)\nPure maple syrup, to serve\nOptional boosters:\n1\xe2\x81\x844 cup (60ml) bourbon or rum\n2 tablespoons crushed raw pecans or walnuts\n1 tablespoon unsweetened dried shredded coconut\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHOD\n1 Set the oven to its lowest temperature or the \xe2\x80\x9cwarm\xe2\x80\x9d setting.\n2 Make the French toast batter: Combine the milk, banana, maple syrup, vanilla, chia seeds, cinnamon, and salt into your blender and blast on high for about 30 seconds, until well combined. Pour the mixture into a large shallow baking dish and let rest for about 5 minutes to thicken slightly.\n3 Soak the bread in the batter: In batches, place slices of the bread in the baking dish and let soak on one side for 8 to 10 seconds. Flip the slices and let soak for another 8 to 10 seconds, until evenly moistened.\n4 Cook the French toast: In a medium skillet (that fits two slices of bread) or on a large griddle (that holds all of the slices) over medium heat, warm 1 to 2 tablespoons of coconut oil per two slices of bread. (Resist the urge to use less coconut oil, or the bread won\xe2\x80\x99t get crispy.)\nAdd the bread and fry for 4 to 6 minutes on each side, until golden brown and crispy on the edges; you may need to add more coconut oil after you flip the bread. If cooking in batches, transfer the French toast to a lined baking sheet and place in the oven to keep warm, and repeat to fry the remaining bread, adding more coconut oil to cook each batch.\n5 While the last pieces of toast are cooking, make the caramelized bananas. Combine the banana slices and the coconut sugar in a zipper-lock bag, seal, and shake to coat evenly. In a skillet over medium-high heat, warm the coconut oil, add the coated bananas and the bourbon booster (if using), and fry for about 2 minutes on each side until nicely caramelized.\n6 To serve: Serve two slices of French toast on each plate, topped with one-quarter of the caramelized bananas, one-quarter of the crushed nut boosters, and one-quarter of the coconut booster. Pass maple syrup at the table.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nStrawberry Almond Oat Smoothie Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 2 (12-ounce) servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup uncooked old-fashioned rolled oats\n2 cups frozen strawberries\n1 cup plain yogurt (regular or Greek, any fat percentage)\n1 cup unsweetened vanilla almond milk (or milk of your choice)\n1/2 medium banana, fresh or frozen, sliced\n1/4 teaspoon pure almond extract\n1-2 teaspoons honey (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the ingredients: In a blender, combine the oats, strawberries, yogurt, almond milk, banana, and almond extract.\n2 Puree the smoothie: Starting on low speed, puree the ingredients. b'Save It Print\nVegan Banana Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 1 loaf (6 to 8 slices)\nIf you would like to make this recipe gluten free, swap out the all-purpose flour for equal amounts of a gluten-free flour blend.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons flaxseed meal\n1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons almond milk\n2 to 3 very ripe bananas, peeled\n1/3 cup walnut, coconut or avocado oil\n3/4 cup sugar (1/2 cup if you would like it less sweet, 1 cup if more sweet)\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\nSpecial equipment:\n4x8 inch loaf pan\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line a 4x8-inch loaf pan with parchment paper, long enough so that it hangs over the edges and creates a sling. (This will help facilitate easy removal.)\n2 Make the flax egg: In a small bowl, combine the flaxseed meal with the almond milk. Let rest until thickened while you measure everything else.\n3 Make the batter: In a large mixing bowl, mash the ripe bananas with a fork until completely smooth. Stir the oil into the mashed bananas. Add the sugar, flax egg, and vanilla. Finally, stir in the flour, baking soda, and salt.\n4 Bake the bread: Pour the batter into your prepared loaf pan. Bake for 50 minutes to 1 hour, until a toothpick or cake tester inserted into the center comes out clean.\n5 Cool and serve: Remove the bread from the oven and let cool in the pan for a few minutes. Then, using the excess parchment hanging over the edges as handles, remove the banana bread from the pan, and let cool completely before serving. Slice and serve.\nHello! b"Save It Print\nChocolate Banana Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes one 9x5-inch loaf\nUse very ripe or over-ripe bananas. The peels should be at least half browned, and the bananas inside squishy and browning.\nDo not use Dutch processed cocoa for this recipe, only natural unsweetened.\nMelted coconut oil can be used in place of the butter. The flavor will change a little and you may get a hint of coconut in the result.\nThere is only 1 egg and 1 teaspoon of baking soda in this recipe for leavening, so make sure your baking soda is still good! (See more info on baking soda and baking powder.)\nINGREDIENTS\n3 large ripe bananas (easily mashable)\n1/3 cup melted butter\n3/4 cup brown sugar (packed, light or dark)\n1 teaspoon salt (1/2 a teaspoon if using salted butter)\n1 large egg, beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 1/4 cup all purpose flour\n1/4 cup natural unsweetened cocoa powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/2 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips\nSpecial equipment:\n1 5x9-inch loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare pan and preheat oven:  Butter or spray with cooking spray the inside of a 5x9-inch loaf pan. Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) with a rack in the middle.\n2 Pur\xc3\xa9e bananas: Using a blender, food processor, or a fork, pur\xc3\xa9e the peeled ripe bananas until smooth. You should have 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 cups of banana pur\xc3\xa9e.\n3 Mix wet ingredients and sugar: Place the banana pur\xc3\xa9e into a large mixing bowl. Stir the melted butter. Stir in the brown sugar and salt. Whisk to break up any clumps of brown sugar. Stir in the beaten egg and vanilla extract.\n4 Mix dry ingredients: In a separate bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, cocoa, baking soda, and allspice.\n5 Add the flour mixture to the banana mixture and stir until just incorporated.\nStir in the chocolate chips.\n6 Bake: Pour batter into a buttered loaf pan. Place in a 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) oven and bake for 1 hour.\nNote that because of the chocolate chips that melt in the bread as it cooks, it's hard to check for doneness using a tester that you insert.\nOne way to test is to gently push the center top of the chocolate banana bread down with your finger. If it feels relatively firm and bounces back when you release your finger, that's a good sign that it's done.\n7 Let cool: Remove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes in the pan.\nGently remove the loaf from the pan and place on a rack to cool completely.\nSlice with a serrated bread knife to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBanana Nut Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 12 muffins\nNo need for a mixer with this recipe.\nDon't want the nuts? Feel free to leave out or swap with chocolate chips.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 to 3 ripe bananas, thoroughly mashed (about 1 1/4 cup mashed)\n1/3 cup melted butter (salted or unsalted)\n3/4 cup sugar\n1 large egg, beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 Tbsp strong brewed coffee or espresso, or a pinch of instant coffee granules mixed with a Tbsp of water (optional)\n1 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\n1 1/2 cup of flour\n1 cup chopped walnuts or pecans (toasted or raw)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prepare muffin pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line a muffin pan with paper liners.\n2 Combine wet ingredients and sugar: Thoroughly mash the bananas in a large bowl. Stir the melted butter into the bananas. Mix in the sugar, egg, coffee and vanilla extract.\n3 Combine dry ingredients: Whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.\n4 Add dry ingredients into wet, add nuts: Add the flour mixture to the banana mixture, a third at a time, stirring until it is just incorporated. (Do not over-mix! Over-mixing will result in dense, tough muffins.)\nFold in the chopped walnuts or pecans.\n5 Fill muffin cups, and bake: Lightly spoon the mixture into a prepared muffin tin. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20-25 minutes.\nCheck for doneness by pressing down on the top of the muffin. If it bounces back, it's done. You can also test by inserting a skewer or other tester into the center of a muffin. If it comes out clean, it's done.\nCool on a rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\n7-Layer Magic Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 24 bars\nThese bars are so rich and sweet, you can cut them into 24 small bars and still feel satisfied.\nI like to add a sprinkle of flaky Maldon salt on top to add some crunch and help cut the sweet richness. The salt is totally non-traditional, though, so omit if you want that nostalgic, ultra-sweet Magic Bar experience.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (225 g) graham cracker crumbs\n1/2 cup (115 g / 1 stick) melted unsalted butter\n14 ounces (396 g / 1 can) sweetened condensed milk\n1 cup (185 g) semi-sweet chocolate chips\n1 cup (185 g) butterscotch chips\n1 cup (115 g) chopped pecans\n1 cup (105 g) shredded sweetened coconut\n1 teaspoon flaky sea salt (like Maldon), optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350F. Spray a 9 x 13-inch baking pan with cooking oil then line it with parchment paper.\n2 Make the graham cracker crust: Place the graham cracker crumbs and the melted butter in a bowl. Toss with a fork until the crumbs are moist and hold together when squeezed with your hand.\nDump the crumbs in the middle of the pan and then press them into an even layer with your fingers or the back of a flat-bottomed cup.\n3 Pour the sweetened condensed milk over the graham cracker crust. Spread to edges of the pan with a spatula.\n4 Layer on the rest of the toppings: In this order, sprinkle the chocolate chips, butterscotch chips, pecans, and then sweetened coconut over the top of the condensed milk.\nGently press the ingredients down with your palm so they stick to the condensed milk.\n5 Bake in the oven for 30 to 35 minutes. Bake until the edges of the bars turn golden-brown and start to pull away slightly from the sides of the pan. Remove from the oven and sprinkle with the sea salt (if using).\n6 Cool completely before lifting the bars out of the pan using the parchment paper. (Stick them in the fridge for a few hours or overnight if needed to help firm up.) Cut into 24 pieces and store in an airtight container with wax paper or parchment paper between layers.\nThe flavor of the bars is even better the day after baking. Bars stored at room temperature will be fairly soft and are best eaten within 3 to 5 days. For firm and chewy bars, store in the fridge for up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBest Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 16 to 25 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n10 tablespoons (1 1/4 sticks, 140 g) unsalted butter\n1 1/4 cups (250 g) granulated sugar\n3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (85 g) unsweetened cocoa powder (natural or Dutch-process)\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n2 cold large eggs\n1/2 cup (65 g) all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup (90 g) pecan pieces\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven and line baking pan: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C), with a rack in the lower third of the oven.\nLine the bottom of an 8-inch square baking pan with foil or parchment paper in such a way as there is an overhang on two opposite sides to make it easy to lift the brownies out when they're done.\n2 Heat butter, cocoa, sugar, salt in a bowl over simmering water: Place the butter, cocoa, sugar, and salt in a medium-sized metal bowl. Fill a large skillet halfway with water and bring to a bare simmer. Set the bowl of the butter cocoa mixture in skillet of simmering water.\nStir the butter cocoa mixture until the butter has melted and the mixture is smooth and hot to touch.\nRemove the bowl from the skillet and let it cool down a bit, from hot to warm.\n3 Stir in almond extract, eggs, flour, beat with spoon, add pecans: Stir in the almond extract. Stir in the eggs, one at a time, beating strongly after each addition.\nOnce the batter is well mixed and shiny and thick, stir in the flour. Beat for 40 strokes with a wooden spoon.\nMix in the pecans.\n4 Pour batter into lined pan: Pour the batter into the prepared lined pan and smooth the surface evenly.\n5 Bake: Bake 20 to 25 minutes at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C), until a bamboo skewer or toothpick inserted into the center comes out still a little moist with the brownie batter. Cool completely on a rack.\n6 Cut: When cooled, lift up the sides of the foil or parchment liner to remove the brownies from the pan. Place them on a cutting board and cut into 16 to 25 squares or rectangles.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nFudgy Gluten-Free Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesCooling Time: 2 hours time: Yield: 16 small, 2-inch square brownies\nIf you\'ve never baked gluten-free before, we highly recommend using Bob\'s Red Mill 1:1 Gluten Free Baking Flour Blend for this recipe.\nIf you\'re using a different blend, double check the ingredients. If it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t contain xanthan gum (or another binding ingredient like guar gum or psyllium husks), we recommend adding 1/2 teaspoon of xanthan gum to ensure success.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons ground flax\n1 cup (148 grams) gluten-free flour blend, like Bob\'s Red Mill\n1/2 cup (40 grams) dairy-free cocoa powder\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 cup coconut oil at room temperature, plus more for the pan\n5 ounces (140g) bittersweet dairy-free chocolate, chopped\n1 1/2 cups (300 grams) sugar\n1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F and prepare the pan: Line an 8\xc3\x978 square baking pan with parchment paper, and grease the parchment paper and pan with a little coconut oil.\n2 Prepare the flax "egg": Combine the flax with 8 tablespoons of water in a small bowl. Let stand for 7 to 10 minutes to thicken. (This will be used as an egg replacer in this recipe.)\n3 Whisk dry ingredients: In a small mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt.\n4 Melt the coconut oil and chocolate: In a small saucepan over low heat, warm the coconut oil and chopped chocolate, stirring until the chocolate is completely melted, about 2 minutes.\n5 Add the sugar and vanilla: Whisk the sugar and vanilla into the chocolate mixture, stirring vigorously until combined. The mixture will be a little grainy at this point, which is perfectly okay.\n6 Make the batter: Pour the chocolate mixture into a large mixing bowl, scraping everything from the pan. Fold in the flax eggs.\nAdd the dry ingredients and stir well with a wooden spoon or rubber spatula until well combined. The batter will be quite thick and will gather into a ball\xe2\x80\x94it won\xe2\x80\x99t be loose and thin like many traditional brownie batters.\n7 Scoop the batter into the prepared pan, and use a rubber spatula or the palm of your hand to press it into the pan in an even layer.\n8 Bake the brownies for 30 to 35 minutes, or until the edges are set and no longer jiggly. The tops of the brownies will still feel very soft and may even be bubbling a little; they\xe2\x80\x99ll firm up as they cool.\n9 Cool: Let the brownies cool completely before slicing, at least 2 to 3 hours. Because these are so fudgy, they really will slice best if you allow them to fully cool.\n10 Slice, serve, and store: Using the parchment paper as a handle, lift the cooled brownies up out of the pan and onto a cutting board. Slice into a 4x4 grid (making 16 small squares). Leftover brownies can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nPeanut Butter Swirl Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 34 minutesYield: 16 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n6 ounces semisweet chocolate chips\n8 tablespoons (1 stick, 4 ounces) unsalted butter\n2 large eggs\n1/2 cup granulated sugar\n1/2 cup dark brown sugar\n1 tablespoon instant espresso coffee powder\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2/3 cup all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 cup smooth peanut butter\n2 tablespoons powdered sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xcb\x9aF. Line an 8-inch square baking dish with parchment paper; set aside.\n2 Melt the chocolate and butter: Set the chocolate and butter in a heat-proof bowl over a pot of simmering water\xe2\x80\x94the bottom of the bowl should not touch the water. Stir until the chocolate has melted. Remove from heat.\n  3 Make the batter: Whisk together the eggs, both sugars, coffee powder, and vanilla extract. Add in the flour, cocoa powder, salt, baking powder, and melted butter-chocolate mixture and stir until evenly combined. (The batter will be very thick, but don't worry! That's how it's supposed to be.)\nPress the brownie batter into the prepared baking dish in an even layer.\n   4 Add the peanut butter swirl. Warm the peanut butter in the microwave until it's loosened enough to drizzle, about 30 seconds on high. Stir the powdered sugar into the peanut butter, then drizzle over the top of the brownie batter.\nUse a butter knife to swirl the peanut butter mixture into the top of the brownie batter. Be careful not to over mix the peanut butter into the brownie mixture.\n5 Bake the brownies: Bake the brownies until a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out mostly clean, about 35 minutes. (The peanut butter will probably stick to the toothpick a little bit; that's fine.) Transfer to a wire rack to cool.\n6 Cool and slice: Let the brownies cool completely to room temperature before cutting them. For cleaner slicing with fewer crumbs, pop the pan in the freezer for a few minutes once it's cooled to room temperature to help with slicing to help keep them from sticking to the knife.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nChocolate Peanut Butter Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Makes 3 dozen bars.\nThese bars freeze well if you want to make ahead.\nINGREDIENTS\nPeanut butter layer:\n1 1/4 cup of graham cracker crumbs (use toasted matzo crumbs* or ground Passover crispy cereal if following the Passover dietary rules)\n1 1/4 cup of confectioner's sugar (use Passover-friendly confectioner's sugar** if following Passover dietary rules)\n3/4 cup plus 2 Tbsp of crunchy, natural peanut butter (no added preservatives or corn syrup)\n8 Tbsp (4-ounces) unsalted butter, melted\n2 Tbsp honey\nChocolate topping:\n9-ounces semi-sweet chocolate chips (1 1/2 cups) (use Kosher chocolate chips if making for Passover)\n1 Tbsp butter\nEquipment needed:\nA 9x9-inch square baking pan with straight sides (can also use an 8x10 or 8x11 baking pan)\nFood processor\nParchment paper or non-stick aluminum foil\n* Take 4 or 5 sheets of matzo, roughly break into chunks, toast in a hot dry skillet on high heat until the crumbs begin to brown and you can smell the matzo toasting. Remove from heat, let cool for a minute, place in a food processor or mini-chopper, and pulse until ground to the consistency of coarse bread crumbs.\n**2 cups of granulated sugar in a food processor or blender, and 2 Tbsp of potato starch. Process until very fine. Use 1 1/4 cups for this recipe. You'll have some leftover which can be used for other recipes for Passover.\n  METHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Line the baking pan with parchment paper or non-stick aluminum foil. Line the pan in a way so that you have an overhang on at least 2 opposite sides of the pan to make it easy to lift up the bars once they have set.\n2 In the bowl of a food processor place the crumbs and the powdered sugar. Pulse until well mixed. Add the peanut butter, melted butter, and honey. Process until well blended. The mixture should hold together, almost like a dough. If it's too dry, add a little more melted butter. If it's too wet, after you press it into the bottom of the pan in the next step, you can chill it in the fridge for 10 minutes to firm up a bit.\n3 Press the peanut butter mixture into the bottom of your lined pan in an even layer. You can use the flat bottom of a measuring cup, small saucepan, or smaller baking pan to press on the mixture to help make the surface more even.\n4 Place a metal bowl over a saucepan with simmering water (not boiling, but gently simmering). Place the chocolate chips and butter into the bowl.  Melt the chocolate chips, stirring occasionally, until smooth.\n5 Spread the melted chocolate evenly over the peanut butter layer in the pan. (An offset spatula is a good tool for this.) Refrigerate for at least an hour.\n6 Lift the contents from the pan onto a cutting board. Cut into 36 bars, 1-inch by 2 1/4 inches.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nFudgy Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 16 regular brownies or 25 brownie bites\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup (105 grams) all-purpose flour\n1/8 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n6 tablespoons (3 ounces) unsalted butter, cut up\n2 ounces unsweetened chocolate, broken into 1-inch pieces\n1 cup (200 grams) granulated sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 cup (6 ounces) mini bittersweet-chocolate chips, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n8x8 baking pan\nMedium saucepan, 2-quarts or larger\nHeatproof spatula\nWire cooling rack\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 350F and prepare the pan: Line an 8x8 baking pan with a sling of parchment, long enough so that the parchment hangs over the sides of the pan. Coat the exposed sides of the pan with cooking spray (also, a little cooking spray under the parchment will help it stick in place, if needed).\n2 Combine the dry ingredients: In a bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.\n3 Melt the chocolate and butter: In a medium saucepan over medium-low heat, melt the butter. It should not brown at the edges.\nAdd the chocolate and let it melt, stirring occasionally with a heatproof spatula, until the mixture is smooth.\n4 Set the pan on a cooling rack to cool until you can touch the bottom of with your hand comfortably.\n5 Make the batter: Using a rubber spatula, stir the sugar into the chocolate mixture until it combined. The mixture may look crumbly or smooth after mixing; either is fine.\nAdd the eggs, one at a time, followed by the vanilla. Add the flour mixture, and stir until no more white patches show. Stir in the chips until well distributed.\n6 Pour the batter into the pan. Use a spatula to spread it to the edges of the pan and smooth the top. Tap the pan once or twice hard on the counter to settle any air pockets; you can also poke the air pockets with the tip of a paring knife.\n7 Bake the brownies: Transfer the pan to the oven and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the top is slightly puffed and just set. If in doubt, it's better to under-bake these brownies a touch rather than over-bake. (The toothpick test doesn't work well for these brownies because the chocolate chips get melty!)\n8 Cool the brownies completely: Set the pan on a wire rack until completely cooled.\n9 Once cool, cover the pan and refrigerate for several hours or until firm and cold. This makes the brownies easier to slice cleanly.\nIf you're eager for brownies and can't wait for them to chill, skip this chilling step and serve them warm or just-cooled! They will be a little crumbly when you cut them.)\n6 Cut the squares: Run a thin knife around the edge of the pan to make sure the block of brownies is loose, then lift from the pan using the parchment paper sling. On a cutting board, slice the brownies into a 4x4 grid (to make 16 squares) or into a 5x5 grid (to make 25 mini-brownies).\nBrownies can be served right away. Leftovers can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for at least a week. (They will keep for longer, but may start getting dry and crumbly after a while.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nGuinness Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Makes 16 to 25 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (240 ml) Guinness Extra Stout\n10 Tbsp (1 1/4 sticks, 140 g) unsalted butter\n1 1/4 cup (250 g) sugar\n3/4 cup plus 2 Tbsp (85 g) unsweetened natural cocoa\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 teaspoons vanilla\n2 large eggs, lightly beaten\n3/4 cup (96 g) flour\n2/3 cup  (90 g) chopped pecans, optional\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line an 8x8 square baking pan with parchment paper or foil in a way that there is overhang over two sides of the dish making it easy to remove the brownies once they are baked. Brush with a little butter or baking spray.\n2 Boil Guinness, reduce by half: Place the Guinness stout in a medium saucepan (2-quart) and bring to a boil. Watch out for the stout bubbling up too much. Boil until the liquid reduces by half.\n3 Progressively add butter, sugar, cocoa, salt, cinnamon to the Guinness, then let cool: Stir the butter into the reduced Guinness until melted. Add the sugar and whisk until dissolved. Whisk in the cocoa, salt, and cinnamon.\nWhisk until smooth. Remove from heat and let cool until just lightly warm to the touch.\n4 Stir in the vanilla, eggs, flour, nuts: When the mixture has cooled until just lightly warm to the touch, stir in the vanilla extract and eggs. Stir in the flour until smooth. Stir in the nuts.\n5 Bake: Pour into the prepared lined baking pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 30 minutes. Cool on a rack. When completely cool lift the brownies out of the pan. Cut into 16 to 25 squares or rectangles.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGingered Lemon Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes 36 lemon bars\nINGREDIENTS\nThe Crust:\n1 1/2 sticks (3/4 cup) unsalted butter, softened\n1/3 cup powdered sugar\n1/2 teaspoon freshly grated lemon zest\n1/2 cup minced crystallized ginger\n3/4 teaspoon ground ginger\nPinch of salt\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\nThe filling:\n3 large eggs\n1 1/3 cups granulated sugar\n6 Tbsp fresh lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\n3 Tbsp all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n  METHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the crust batter: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Using an electric mixer, beat the butter. Add 1/3 cup of sifted powdered sugar, and beat until light and fluffy.\nBeat in half a teaspoon of the lemon zest, the ground ginger, the crystallized ginger, and a pinch of salt.\nAdd 1 1/2 cups of flour in batches, a 1/4 cup at a time, beating after each addition. Continue to beat the crust batter until it is well combined.\n2 Bake the crust: Spread the crust batter evenly over the bottom of a 13x9-inch baking dish. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 12 to 15 minutes, or until browned lightly around the edges.\n3 Make the lemon batter: While the crust is baking, whisk together the eggs, granulated sugar, lemon juice, 1/2 teaspoon of lemon zest, 3 Tbsp of flour, the baking powder, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt in a medium sized bowl. Whisk until well blended.\n4 Pour batter into pre-baked crust and bake: Pour the lemon batter over the pre-baked crust.\nBake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 15 to 20 minutes or until the top is golden.\nIf you want, sift a little additional powdered sugar over the top.\nLet the lemon bars cool in the pan on a rack. Cut it into 36 pieces.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Crumb Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 16 bars\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n2 1/2 cups (312 grams) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (198 grams) sugar\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (227 grams) cold unsalted butter, cubed\n1 large egg yolk\nFor the blueberry filling\n3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries\n3 tablespoon granulated sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Butter and line an 9x9 inch pan with parchment paper leaving an overhang on two sides.\n2 Make the dough: In a food processor, pulse the flour, sugar, lemon zest, and salt together a few times to combine. Add the butter and pulse until you get a fine, sandy texture\xe2\x80\x94all of the butter should be incorporated.\nAdd the egg yolk and pulse until it\xe2\x80\x99s combined, 10 to 15 times. The crumbs should hold together when squeezed in the palm of your hand. If they do not, sprinkle a tablespoon of water over top and pulse a few more times.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a food processor, you can cut the butter into the flour with a pastry blender or a fork. It will take longer, but work just fine.\n  3 Refrigerate the crumb topping: Scoop out about 1/3 of the crumb mixture and press it into a bowl, which helps to make larger clumps of crumbs for the topping. Cover and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes or until needed for the topping.\n4 Press the bottom crust into the pan: Firmly press the remaining 2/3 of the crumbs into the bottom of the prepared pan to create the base for the bars. I like to use a measuring cup to press the crumbs into the pan and really compact the crust.\n5 Make the blueberry filling and top with crumbs: In a mixing bowl, toss the blueberries with the sugar, cornstarch, lemon juice, and zest together to coat. Spread the berries over the crust.\nRemove the remaining crumb mixture from the fridge and crumble. Crumble it with your fingers and sprinkled over the blueberry filling.\n6 Bake the crumb bars: Bake for 1 hour and 5 minutes, or until the blueberries are bubbling and the crumb topping is golden. Remove the bars from the oven and transfer to a cooling rack. Cool completely in the pan, at least 2 hours, before lifting from the pan using the parchment and cutting into squares.\nOnce cooled and sliced, the bars can be transferred to an airtight container and kept at room temperature for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nPumpkin Cheesecake Bars with Streusel Topping Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesCooling time: 1 hourYield: 15 to 18 bars\nMake sure to let your cream cheese soften to room temperature before mixing the filling to avoid lumps.\nPrepare graham cracker crumbs by pulsing the crackers in a food processor, or placing the crackers in a zip-top bag and rolling over them with a rolling pin.\nINGREDIENTS\nGraham cracker crust:\n1 1/2 cup graham cracker crumbs (See recipe note)\n1/4 cup white sugar\n6 tablespoons regular salted butter, melted and cooled slightly so no longer hot\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon or pumpkin pie spice\nStreusel topping:\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup old-fashioned rolled oats\n4 tablespoons regular salted butter, room temperature\n1/4 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice\nPumpkin filling:\n2 8-ounce packages cream cheese, softened to room temperature\n2/3 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2 large eggs, room temperature\n2/3 cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)\n2 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice\nTo serve:\nCaramel sauce, homemade or store-bought, optional\nWhipped cream, optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 350F. Spray a 9x13 baking pan with non-stick spray and line with parchment paper, allowing the edges to hang over the sides of the pan. This will help remove the bars for slicing and keep the crust intact.\n2 Make the graham cracker crust: Combine all the ingredients for the graham cracker crust in a bowl. Stir the mixture together until it looks like wet sand. If it still looks dry, add an another tablespoon of melted butter. Transfer to the lined baking pan and press with your hand or the bottom of a drinking glass to form an even crust.\n3 Make the streusel topping: In the same bowl used to make the graham cracker mixture, combine the ingredients for the streusel topping. Mix the ingredients together, using your hands if needed, to ensure the mixture comes together evenly. The mixture should resemble large crumbles. Set aside.\n4 Make the pumpkin filling: In a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese, sugar and vanilla until smooth. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl. Add the eggs, one at a time, mixing for 30 seconds in between. Scrape the bowl down again. Add in the pumpkin puree and pumpkin pie spice, and mix until completely combined.\n5 Assemble the bars: Pour the pumpkin filling into the pan on top of the graham cracker crust. Smooth out evenly. Sprinkle the streusel topping over the pumpkin filling.\n6 Bake the bars for 45 to 50 minutes: Check the bars at 40 minutes to see how quickly they are baking. When done, a toothpick inserted in the middle should come out cleanly.\n7 Cool the bars completely and refrigerate: Let the bars cool to room temperature on a wire rack. Once cool, place in the fridge to chill completely.\nSlice and serve with caramel sauce drizzled over the top and whipped cream, if desired. Bars will keep, refrigerated, for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nKahl\xc3\xbaa Brownies Recipe\nINGREDIENTS\n1 \xc2\xbd pounds of 60% cacao chocolate\n1 cup of butter, cut into pieces and at room temperature\n6 eggs, room temperature\n2 cups of sugar\n1/4 teaspoon of salt\n1 tablespoon plus 1/4 teaspoon of Kahl\xc3\xbaa\n1/4 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 1/2 cups of all purpose flour\nMETHOD\n1 Lightly grease a 9x13 pan. Preheat the oven to 350 F.\n2 In a double boiler or using a bowl over a pot of simmering water, melt the chocolate and butter together.\n3 With an electric mixer, beat together the eggs, sugar and salt. Add the chocolate mixture and the vanilla extract and Kahl\xc3\xbaa. Mix until smooth.\n4 Slowly sift in the flour.\n5 Bake for 45-55 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. Place on a wire rack to cool for thirty minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nStrawberry-Rhubarb Crumble Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 18 to 24 bars\nThese Strawberry Rhubarb Crumble Bars are a snap to make. The crust doubles as the crumble topping. Just make sure to dice the strawberry and rhubarb in to small 1/4-inch chunks, so that they turn into a jammy fruit center filling. Larger pieces of fruit will lead to a chunkier filling.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust and crumble dough\n3 cups (420 g) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (200 g) white granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (225 g or 2 sticks) unsalted butter, cold\n1 large egg\nFor the fruit filling\n2 cups (250 g) diced 1/4-inch chunks) rhubarb (2 to 3 thick stalks or 5 to 6 thin stalks or a little over 1/2 pounds)\n2 cups (310 g) diced (1/4-inch chunks) strawberries (3/4 pounds)\n3 tablespoons white granulated sugar\n1 tablespoon cornstarch\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Spray a 9x13-inch pan with cooking oil. Line the pan with parchment paper with the one inch of extra parchment paper hanging over the sides.\n  2 Make the dough: Combine the flour, sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt in a medium-sized bowl. Cut the butter into 1/2-inch chunks and sprinkle over the dry ingredients. Using your fingers, squish the butter, breaking it down into small bits and mixing the dry ingredients together. The butter should be the size of small peas, but flat, not in chunks.\nAdd the egg and toss together with a fork at first, then massage into the dough with your hand. The dough will be crumbly.\n   3 Divide the dough and shape the crust: Scoop 1 cup (about 170 g) of the crumbly dough and set it aside.\nDump the remaining dough into the bottom of the lined pan and press down on it firmly with your hands or with the flat bottom of a cup, to form an even layer of dough at the bottom.\n  4 Make the filling and add to the pan: Combine all the ingredients in a bowl (you can use the same bowl you made the dough if you\xe2\x80\x99d like, no need to clean it). Spread it out evenly over the bottom crust.\n  5 Top with crumbles and bake: Sprinkle the reserved crumbly dough over the fruit filling. Bake in the oven 40 to 45 minutes, or until the top of the fruit is bubbling and the crumb topping is golden brown. Cool completely in the pan until it reaches room temperature.\n6 Cool and cut the bars: Use the side of the parchment paper to lift up and move the entire block carefully to a cutting board. Cut into bars. Serve at room temperature. Store in the refrigerator in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nPeanut Butter Pretzel Magic Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesCooling time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: 16 large bars or 25 small bars\nThese bars are quite rich and decadent. Cut into 25 squares if serving at a potluck or large gathering, or into 16 squares if you're in the mood for a bigger treat.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/3 cups (5 oz) mini pretzels, for the crumb crust, plus additional whole pretzels for topping\n6 tablespoons melted butter\n3 tablespoons sugar\n1 (14-ounce) can sweetened condensed milk (397g), divided\n1/4 cup (57g) smooth peanut butter\n3/4 cups (100g) peanut butter chips\n1/2 cup (100g) mini chocolate chips\n1 1/2 cups (75g) unsweetened coconut flakes\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line an 8x8-inch square baking pan with foil, allowing a couple inches to overhang down the side of the pan. Generously, coat with cooking spray or brush with melted butter. Set aside. If using a glass baking dish, lower the oven temperature to 325\xe2\x84\x89.\n2 Warm the peanut butter: Pour 1/4 cup of sweetened condensed milk into a small bowl and set aside. In another bowl small bowl, add the peanut butter and remaining condensed milk. When combined you should have about 1 1/4 cups. Microwave for 30 seconds. Stir the mixture until smooth. Set aside to cool.\n3 Make the crust: In the bowl of a food processor, add 3 cups whole pretzels and process for 15 seconds until the largest pieces are the size of small peas. Measure out 1 1/4 cups (120 g) pretzel crumbs and return them to the food processor bowl. (If you have extra crumbs save them to sprinkle on ice cream!)\nAdd the sugar and melted butter and process continuously for 20 seconds. The mixture will look like wet sand.\nPour the pretzel mixture into the prepared pan. Use a measuring cup or glass to press the mixture firmly into an even layer in the bottom of the pan.\n4 Bake the crust: Bake the crust until it feels firm to the touch and is slightly golden around the edges, about 10 minutes.\n5 Assemble the first layer: Stir the peanut butter and condensed mixture again, then pour 3/4 cup of the peanut butter mixture over the baked crust. Use a towel, or oven mitts to gently tilt the pan from corner to corner so the peanut butter mixture completely covers the crust. Top with half of the shredded coconut, half of the peanut butter chips and half of the chocolate chips.\n6 Finish assembling: Pour remaining 1/2 cup peanut butter and condensed milk mixture over the entire layer. Top with remaining shredded coconut, peanut butter and chocolate chips. Arrange whole pretzels on top and use your hands to gently press the bars down to ensure the layers are compact. Drizzle with the reserved condensed milk.\n7 Bake the bars: Bake on the center rack of the oven for 30-35 minutes until the edges are turning golden and the center is just starting to take on color. The center might be a little soft but the bars will firm up as it cools.\n8 Cool: Remove the bars from the oven and cool on a cooling rack for 1 1/2 hours. Take out of the pan and remove foil. Continue cooling on rack for an additional 1 hour. Once bars reach room temperature, wrap in plastic wrap and chill in refrigerator for 2 hours or overnight. This will ensure that the bars slice cleanly with the least amount of crumbling. You can cut them once they\xe2\x80\x99ve cooled to room temp, but the crust may crumble.\n9 Serve & store: Once the bars are chilled, slice into 16 squares and serve. Store leftover magic bars in an air-tight container in the refrigerator for 7 days or at room temperature for 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nClassic Lemon Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesBaking time: 30-37 minutesYield: 18 square cut bars\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n2 1/4 cups (284 g) all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup (152 g) granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, cold\nFor the lemon filling:\n4 large eggs\n1 egg yolk\n1 cup (219 g) sugar\n1/3 cup (43 g) all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup lemon juice (from 3 lemons)\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan and preheat the oven: Line a 9x13 pan with parchment paper, leaving enough parchment paper to overhang the sides on the long end of the pan. You will use this to lift the bars out of the pan and cut them at the end.\nPreheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0 F.\n2 Combine the dry ingredients: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, and salt.\n3 Add the butter: Cut the cold butter in cubes. Toss the cubes in flour. Pinch and smoosh the flour and butter together between your thumbs and fingers until the butter is coated with flour and broken into the flat butter pieces, between the sizes of smooshed almonds and peas. (Alternatively, you can blitz it in a food processor 6 or 7 times until the butter has a similar visual appearance.)\n4 Bake the crust: Dump the crust into your prepared baking dish, press it down firmly it into an even layer with your fingers, and place in the oven.\nBake for 20-25 minutes. The crust is ready when it looks dry and is slightly golden at the edges.\n5 When the crust only has about 10 minutes left to bake, make your filling: In a medium bowl, whisk together the eggs, yolk, and sugar. Whisk in the flour until you no longer see clumps. Whisk in the lemon juice and vanilla.\n6 Bake the lemon bars: When the crust has finished baking, remove it from the oven and pour the curd over the warm crust. Return to the oven.\nBake for 12 minutes in a glass pan or 10 minutes in a metal pan. The filling is ready when it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t jiggle and has lots of little bubbles on top. All ovens are different, so start checking 2 minutes before you think it\xe2\x80\x99s ready. Don\xe2\x80\x99t over-bake it, or the filling will be spongy.\n7 Cool and cut the bars: Remove from oven and let cool for 1 hour, uncovered, either on the counter or in the refrigerator. Use the parchment sling to lift the bars onto a cutting board. Cut into squares and dust with powdered sugar.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nShauna Sever\xe2\x80\x99s Frosted Snickerdoodle Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 2 dozen bars\nIs there anything more fantastically homey than that most marvelous of soft-baked cookies, the snickerdoodle. The name is thought to come from 19th century New England, deriving from the word Schneckennudeln, a type of snail-shaped German cinnamon roll. Snickerdoodles are famously associated with the Pennsylvania Dutch and the Amish communities of Indiana, which explains how they made their way to the Midwest and have long been a homespun favorite here.\nAnd, of course, if you can find a way to turn something, anything at all, into a recipe that can be crammed into a 9x13, it becomes extra midwestern. The swath of frosting on top gilds the lily here, but it\xe2\x80\x99s so worth it.\nExcerpted from Midwest Made by Shauna Sever. Copyright \xc2\xa9 2019. Available from Running Press, an imprint of Hachette Book Group, Inc.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the bars:\n2 3/4 cups (352 g) all-purpose flour, spooned and leveled\n2 teaspoons cream of tartar, sifted\n1 1/4 teaspoons fine sea salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon (Shauna Sever recommends Vietnamese cinnamon)\n1 cup (225 g) unsalted butter, at room temperature\n3/4 cup (170 g) light brown sugar\n3/4 cup (150 g) granulated sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n2 large eggs, room temperature\n1/4 cup (57 g) whole milk\nFor the frosting:\n3/4 cup (170 g) unsalted butter, room temperature\n1 1/2 cups (180 g) powdered sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon, plus more for dusting (optional)\n1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon whole milk\n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract\n1/4 teaspoon fine sea salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the pan and the oven: Position a rack in the center of the oven and preheat it to 325\xc2\xb0F.  Line a 9x13 light-colored metal baking pan with aluminum foil and spray it with nonstick cooking spray.\n2 Whisk together the dry ingredients: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cream of tartar, salt, baking soda, and cinnamon.\n3 Make the batter: In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy. Add the brown and granulated sugar and vanilla and beat until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, giving each about 30 seconds of beating to fully incorporate. Beat in the milk.\nReduce the speed to low and gradually beat in the flour mixture. Finish stirring the batter by hand to make sure every bit is incorporated.\n4 Bake the bars: Spread the batter in the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the top looks puffy and begins to turn golden. Rotate the pan 180 degrees, and while doing so, rap the pan on the oven rack until the bars deflate.\nBake for 5 minutes more, or until the bars have pulled away from the sides of the pan and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. The bars will still look quite soft.\nIf they\xe2\x80\x99ve puffed back up during the last minutes of baking, rap the pan on the countertop once again.\n5 Let cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack.\n6 Make the frosting: In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy. Add the powdered sugar, cinnamon, milk, vanilla, and salt, and beat until smooth. Raise the mixer speed to high and beat until very light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.\n7 Frost the bars: Spread the frosting over the cooled bars. Lightly dust cinnamon over the entire pan, if you wish. Store leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBarbecued Chicken on the Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 45 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nChicken thighs and legs will hold up better to long, slow cooking than will breasts which can more easily dry out. If you barbecue breasts, keep them on the coolest part of the grill (or follow this method).\nThis recipe assumes fairly large chicken pieces (like the main pieces from a 4 to 5 pound whole chicken). If you are working with smaller chicken pieces, they may require a shorter cooking time. If you are cooking wings, they too may be done before the other larger pieces.\nA note about the skin. Even if you do not plan on eating the chicken skin, it\'s still best to barbecue it with it on. The skin will protect the chicken pieces from drying out.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 pounds of your favorite chicken parts (legs, thighs, wings, breasts), skin-on\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil or vegetable oil\n1 cup barbecue sauce, store-bought or homemade\nMETHOD\n1 Oil and salt chicken pieces: Coat the chicken pieces with olive oil and sprinkle salt over them on all sides.\n2 Prepare grill: Prepare one side of your grill for high, direct heat. If you are using charcoal or wood, make sure there is a cool side to the grill where there are few to no coals.\n3 Sear chicken on hot side of grill, move to cool side: Lay the chicken pieces skin side down on the hottest side of the grill in order to sear the skin side well. Grill uncovered for 5-10 minutes, depending on how hot the grill is (you do not want the chicken to burn).\nOnce you have a good sear on one side, turn the chicken pieces over and move them to the cooler side of the grill.\nIf you are using a gas grill, maintain the flame on only one side of the grill, and move the chicken pieces to the cooler side, not directly over the flame. Reduce the temp to low or medium low (between 250\xc2\xb0F and 275\xc2\xb0F, no more than 300\xc2\xb0F).\nCover the grill and cook undisturbed for 20-30 minutes.\n4 Turn over and baste with barbecue sauce: Turn the chicken pieces over and baste them with with your favorite barbecue sauce. Cover the grill again and allow to cook for another 15-20 minutes.\nRepeat, turning the chicken pieces over, basting them with sauce, covering, and cooking for another 10-30 minutes.\nNOTE that timing will depend on your grill set-up, the size of your chicken pieces, and how cold your chicken pieces are to start with! If you are grilling smaller pieces of chicken on a charcoal grill, they may be done much earlier. The goal is to maintain a low enough grill temp so that the chicken cooks "low and slow".\n5 Finish with a sear or remove from heat when done: The chicken is done when the internal temperature of the chicken pieces are 160\xc2\xb0F for breasts and 170\xc2\xb0F for thighs, when tested with a meat thermometer.\nOr if you insert the tip of a knife into the middle of the thickest piece and the juices should run clear, the chicken is done.\nIf the chicken isn\'t done, turn the pieces over and continue to cook at a low temperature.\nIf you want, you can finish with a sear on the hot side of the grill. To do this, put the pieces, skin side down, on the hot side of the grill. Allow them to sear and blacken slightly for a minute or two.\n6 Paint with more barbecue sauce to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nThe Best Dry Rub for Ribs Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 1 1/2 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar (or 1/2 cup if you prefer a more savory rub)\n2 tablespoons kosher salt\n2 tablespoons onion powder\n2 tablespoons smoked paprika\n1 tablespoon dry mustard\n1 tablespoon granulated garlic\n1 tablespoon ground black pepper\n1 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1 teaspoon allspice\nMETHOD\n1 Mix: Place all the spices in an airtight glass jar and shake gently to combine.\n2 Store: Store in an airtight container for up to a year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nSlow and Low Country Ribs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n4 country ribs, about 3 pounds\nKosher salt\nVegetable oil\nThe barbecue sauce of your choice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cut and salt the ribs: Country ribs are usually more than a foot long. We recommend slicing them in half before cooking, as they'll be easier to handle. Coat the ribs in oil and then salt them well.\nMuch of the fat will render away in cooking, leaving a crispy-salty-fatty bit you will be fighting over with your friends.\n2 Slow cook the ribs for 90 min to start: To cook the ribs, you have several choices. You can bake them in a 250\xc2\xb0F oven (line a baking pan with foil and cover the pan).\nYou can slow-roast them in a gas grill (covered) with half the burners turned off (put them on the side that is not over direct flame).\nYou can set up a large charcoal grill like a smoker and cook the country ribs on the cool side (again covered). But best of all would be to build a wood fire on one side of the grill and slowly barbecue these ribs over woodsmoke.\nNo matter what you do, let the ribs cook untouched for 90 minutes. At the 90-minute mark, turn them and paint them with your barbecue sauce \xe2\x80\x93 we like the sweet-spicy Dr. Pepper BBQ sauce for this, but you could also use a South Carolina mustard-based barbecue sauce, a Bourbon BBQ sauce, or a traditional Kansas City-style sauce.\n3 Then, every 30 minutes or so, turn your ribs and paint them again with the sauce. How long to cook? Depends on how hot your fire is. At least 3 hours. Maybe as many as 5 hours. You really, really want to slow-cook these ribs because they are pretty fatty. The slower you cook them, the more fat renders out and the smoother your ribs will be. Take your time.\n4 Move to hot side of grill or broil: When the meat begins to fall apart \xe2\x80\x93 you\xe2\x80\x99ll notice this when you turn the rib \xe2\x80\x93 you\xe2\x80\x99re ready for the final step. Paint the ribs one more time and then move them to the hot side of the grill. If you are using the oven method, move the ribs to the broiler.\nLet the ribs cook a minute or two so the sauce can caramelize. Pay attention, and do not let the ribs get too blackened. A little char is good, but you don\xe2\x80\x99t want a briquette.\nServe with coleslaw, potato salad, deviled eggs or whatever you\xe2\x80\x99d like. Oh, and napkins. Lots of napkins.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nSanta Maria Style Tri Tip Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 5 to 8\nTri-tip roasts range from 2 1/2 pounds to 4 pounds. Figure on 1/2 pound of meat (before cooking) per person.\nA Santa Maria rub has salt, pepper, and either garlic salt or garlic powder. That's the base of the rub, anything beyond that is optional.\nIf you don't have access to the tri-tip cut where you are, try using a thick london broil or sirloin steak.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tri-tip roast, also known as triangle steak, a bottom sirloin cut (anywhere from 2 1/2 pounds to 4 pounds), look for one well-marbled with fat\nSanta Maria Rub (enough for a 4 pound roast)\n1 Tbsp Kosher salt\n1 Tbsp finely ground black pepper\n1 Tbsp garlic powder\n1 Tbsp onion powder\n1 teaspoon cayenne\n1 Tbsp dried oregano\n1 teaspoon dry rosemary (or fresh, finely minced)\n1/2 teaspoon dry sage\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Mix rub and massage into roast: Mix the rub ingredients together in a bowl.\nPlace the roast in a roasting pan or a baking pan with edges (this will help keep the rub from getting all over the floor).\nSprinkle the rub on the meat on all sides, and massage the rub into the meat.\n2 Cover and let sit at room temp for an hour. Cover the roast with foil or plastic wrap and let it sit at room temp for an hour to take the chill off and allow the rub to work its magic on the roast.\n3 Prepare grill: Prepare your grill for hot direct heat on one side, and indirect heat on the other. (By the way, if you are working with a wood-fired grill, Santa Maria BBQ traditionally uses red oak wood.)\n4 Sear the roast on all sides, 3-4 minutes per side. Carefully watch the roast during this process as one side of the roast is typically quite fatty and as the fat heats up it can drip down and cause flare-ups. Keep moving the tri-tip away from the flame if flare-ups occur.\n5 Move roast to cool side of grill, fat side up: Once the tri-tip is seared on all sides, move it away from direct heat and place it fat-side up on the grill rack.\nIf you are using a gas grill with a top rack, I recommend placing the roast on that rack, with an aluminum tray on the bottom rack underneath to catch the fat drippings.\nIf you are grilling on charcoal or wood, you may want to turn the roast over every few minutes, for more even heating.\nTry to maintain a grill temperature of 250\xc2\xb0F to 300\xc2\xb0F.\n6 Cover to finish cooking: Cover the grill and cook until the temperature of the interior of the tri-tip reaches 120\xc2\xb0F for a rare roast, 130\xc2\xb0F for medium-rare and 140\xc2\xb0F for medium.\nAt this point the meat will take anywhere from 20 to 40 minutes to cook, depending on how hot your grill is, how well done you want it, and the size of the cut.\nNote that the interior temperature will continue to rise at least 5\xc2\xb0F after you take the roast off the heat.\n7 Tent roast with foil to let it rest: Once the roast reaches temperature, remove it from the grill and let it rest, loosely tented with foil, for 10-15 minutes.\nSlice across the grain to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEasy BBQ Chicken in the Oven Recipe\nCook time: 35 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutes or overnightYield: 4 servings\nLiquid smoke adds a hint of smokiness to the chicken. Look for it with the condiments in the grocery store.\nYou can easily double or triple this recipe for a larger crowd; just make sure there is a little space between each chicken leg on the pan and work in batches if necessary.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds (skin-on, bone-in) chicken legs\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup barbecue sauce (any tomato- or mustard-based sauce), divided\n1 teaspoon liquid smoke (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nSpecial equipment:\nPastry brush\nBaking sheet\nMetal cooling rack\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Set the chicken legs in a shallow dish and sprinkle both sides with salt. If you're using liquid smoke, mix it into the barbecue sauce.
