b"Print\nCaprese Corn Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nMany recipes I've found online for corn and tomato salad just use raw corn, freshly shucked and the kernels scraped off. I prefer it with grilled corn, but if you have particularly fresh corn that tastes great raw, feel free to use it here.\nNeither tomatoes nor basil do well refrigerated, so this salad is best made fresh and eaten immediately.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 to 6 ears of sweet corn (still in husks, do not shuck)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n3 Tbsp sherry vinegar or white wine vinegar\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon sugar (optional)\n3 cups roughly chopped, seeded tomatoes, or halved cherry or sun gold tomatoes\n1/2 cup sliced scallions, including light green parts\n8 ounces fresh mozzarella, cut into 1/4-inch cubes\n1/2 cup to 1 cup of fresh basil leaves, thinly sliced\nMETHOD\n1 Grill the corn: Prepare your grill for high, direct heat. Place the corn cobs still in their husks directly on the grill. Cook for 15 minutes or so, turning every few minutes, so that the husks get completely charred. The corn will steam in the husks. There is no need to soak the corn in water first if the corn is fresh.\nIf you want some char on the corn itself, remove a few of the outer corn husks first, so there is less of a protective layer around the corn.\nOnce the husks are completely charred, remove from the grill and let cool for a few minutes. Then remove the husks and silk.\nTo remove the corn from the cob, stand the shucked cob upright in shallow baking pan or rimmed dish. Hold the cob steady in one hand, and with the other hand use a sharp knife to make downward strokes on the cob, separating the kernels from the cob.\nAlternatively, if you have frozen corn kernels, you can use them for this salad (4 cups). Just heat a large cast iron pan on medium high to high heat. Put a layer of frozen corn directly on the pan, do not defrost first. Once the corn has browned on one side, stir and let the corn brown some more. Then remove to cool.\n2 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, vinegar, salt, and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Adding sugar will depend on how sweet your corn or tomatoes are, so you may want to withhold sugar until the end and add to taste.\n3 Toss together the corn, tomatoes, scallions, cheese, and dressing: In a large bowl, toss together the corn, tomatoes, scallions, Mozzarella, and the dressing. Adjust seasonings to taste. Let sit for 10 minutes.\n4 Add basil: Right before serving, stir in the freshly sliced basil.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nStrawberry-Basil Moscow Mule Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 1 drink\nThe proportions for this drink are designed for a Moscow Mule mug, which is typically 16 ounces. If you don't have a copper mug, you can make it in a regular glass\xe2\x80\x94just make sure it's around 16 ounces for the best results!\nThis drink is also very good with tequila, should you feel so inclined.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 ounces vodka\n4 or 5 strawberries (5 for medium-to-large strawberries, 4 for truly enormous ones)\n5 basil leaves\n3/4 ounce fresh-squeezed lime juice\nCrushed ice\n2 to 3 ounces ginger beer, or to top\nSpecial equipment:\nCocktail shaker or mixing glass with Hawthorne strainer\nMuddler or spoon\n16 ounce copper mug (strongly recommended)\nTea strainer (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Muddle the strawberries and basil: Add strawberries and basil to the bottom of a shaker. Pour the lime juice on top, then muddle them with a muddler or the back of a spoon. Do this enough to gently smoosh the strawberries, but not completely pulverize them.\n2 Add the vodka and shake: Add the vodka to the shaker, then the ice. (I find that 4 or 5 large cubes per drink works well.) Cover and shake for about 30 seconds.\n3 Strain: Strain directly into a copper mug full of crushed ice or double strain by pouring the drink through a tea strainer, which will catch the finer particles. A single strain is also fine.\n4 Add ginger beer: Fill the cup with ginger beer. Drink on a patio in the sunshine!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nRotini with Kale and Walnut Pesto Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4-6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 bunch kale, stems removed\n1 cup loosely packed basil\n2 cloves garlic\n1/2 cup toasted walnuts\n1/3 cup water\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n12 ounces rotini pasta\nParmesan cheese, for serving\nFor the Lemon Pepper Chicken (Dad Add)\n2 chicken cutlets\n2 teaspoons lemon pepper\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the kale and basil: Set a pair of tongs or a slotted spoon next to the stove. Bring a large pot of water to a boil seasoned with salt. (I usually add 1 tablespoon kosher salt per 2 quarts of water)\nOnce boiling, add the kale and basil to the pot for only 10 seconds. Use the tongs to lift the kale and basil out of the water and let cool on a baking sheet. If it looks like an excessive amount of water remains on the greens, feel free to press them with a paper towel.\nUse this same pot of water to cook your pasta.\n2 Make the pesto: Add the blanched kale and basil to a blender or food processor with garlic, walnuts, 1/3 cup water, olive oil, and salt. Blend until pureed into a paste. Taste and adjust seasoning to your liking. If the pesto needs more liquid, add water, 1-2 tablespoons at a time, until it reaches your desired consistency.\n2 Boil the pasta: Add rotini pasta to the water you used to blanch the vegetables. Cook until al dente according to package. Reserve 1 cup pasta water and drain the pasta.\nReturn the pasta to the pot and add all the pesto. Stir to combine. If the pesto seems really dry, add reserved pasta water a little at a time. Stir between each addition until it coats the pasta well.\n3 Serve: Serve pesto rotini with grated parmesan cheese on top.\n4 For the Lemon Pepper Chicken: Season the chicken cutlets liberally with lemon pepper and salt.\nIn a medium skillet over medium heat, add olive oil and cook cutlets for 5 to 6 minutes per side until they reach an internal temperature of 165\xcb\x9aF. After they come out of the skillet, let them rest briefly and then slice and serve on top of the rotini.\nLEFTOVERS!\nLeftovers keep in the fridge for 2 to 3 days. Reheat gently in a pot with a splash of water over low heat or in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSweet Corn Gnocchi Skillet Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound gnocchi\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nKernels from 3 ears sweet corn, or about 3 cups corn kernels\n1 small sweet onion, diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1/2 cup heavy cream (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nGround black pepper\n8 ounces small mozzarella balls (also called pearls or ciliegine)\nFresh basil, minced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the gnocchi: Bring a pot of salted water to boil. Add gnocchi and cook until they float, about 4-5 minutes. Remove gnocchi and reserve 1/2 cup of the cooking water for the skillet.\n2 Cook the corn kernels: Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat, then add the olive oil. When the oil is shimmering, add the corn kernels. Let kernels cook in the skillet for 4-5 minutes until they are brown and blistered. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir them too much. Let them sit so they get some color.\n3 Add onions and garlic: Once the corn has blistered, add the sweet onions and garlic. Cook for a few minutes until the onions have softened and are translucent.\n4 Make the skillet sauce: Once the onions are soft, add the cooked gnocchi to the skillet and toss everything together. Turn the heat down to low and add 1/2 cup of the reserved gnocchi water, or 1/2 cup cream. Stir to combine ingredients, then let simmer until the sauce has thickened slightly. Taste and season with salt and pepper.\n5 Finish the dish: Right before serving, add the mozzarella balls to the skillet and garnish with fresh basil.\nLeftovers will keep well in the fridge for a few days. Reheat it in a skillet over low heat with a little water. If you freeze the dish, make sure to thaw and reheat it gently. A microwave will ruin the sauce and the gnocchi texture.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBasque Lamb Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 4 hoursMarinating time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 4 to 6\nFeel free to substitute some or all of the paprika with smoked paprika.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds lamb shoulder, cut into 2 inch pieces\n6 cloves garlic, crushed and peeled\n1 sprig fresh rosemary, about 1 tablespoon chopped\n1/2 cup dry white wine\n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, peeled and chopped\nSalt\n2 teaspoons sweet paprika\n1 10-ounce can roasted red bell peppers, cut into 1/2 inch strips\n1 large ripe tomato, peeled, seeded, and chopped\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\n1 bay leaf\n1 cup dry, full-bodied red wine\n1 cup chicken stock\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate lamb with garlic, rosemary, white wine: Combine the lamb, half of the garlic cloves, rosemary, and white wine in a medium bowl. Let marinate for 2 to 3 hours.\nDrain the meat, discard the marinade, and pat dry with paper towels. Mince the remaining garlic cloves and set aside.\n2 Brown the lamb: Heat olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pan with lid, over medium-high heat. Working in batches, brown the meat on all sides, about 10 minutes per batch. Salt the meat as it browns.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and garlic: Remove the meat from the pan and add the chopped onion to the pan. Cook, scraping browned bits stuck to the bottom of the pot with a wooden spoon, until the onions are soft, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook another minute.\n4 Return meat to pan, add paprika, roasted peppers, tomatoes, parsley, bay leaf, red wine, bring to simmer: Return the meat to the pan with the onions and garlic. Stir in paprika, roasted peppers, tomatoes, parsley, bay leaf, and red wine. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium, and simmer uncovered for 15 minutes, allowing the liquids to reduce a bit.\n5 Add chicken stock, simmer: Add the chicken stock, bring to a boil, reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, stirring occasionally, until meat is very tender, 2 to 2 1/2 hours. Add freshly ground black pepper and more salt to taste.\nServe with rustic bread. If you want, try garnishing with fresh mint leaves (though I have no idea how "Basque" that is, it just tastes good.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBasque-Style Chicken with Peppers and Olives Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n3 mild chili peppers (Anaheim, poblanos, Fresno, or another variety)\nOlive oil, for sprinkling\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n8 skin-on, bone-in chicken thighs (about 3 pounds)\n1 medium red onion, thinly sliced\n1/4 pound (one thick piece) baked ham, cut into matchsticks\n1 clove garlic, thinly sliced\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o or other small hot chili pepper, seeded and chopped\n1 (15-ounce) can chopped tomatoes\n1 cup chicken stock\n1/2 cup pitted green olives, coarsely chopped\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the chiles: Turn on the broiler and set a rack about 5 inches from the broiler element. Brush the chiles with enough oil to lightly coat. Broil for 5 minutes, turning several times, or until they are charred. (Alternatively, roast the chiles on the open flame of a gas stovetop.)\nTransfer to a bowl, cover with a plate to help steam and soften the skins, and set aside for 5 minutes.\n2 Peel the chiles: Carefully pull the charred skin of the chili by hand. Cut the chile open, remove and discard the seeds, and chop coarsely.\n3 Brown the chicken: Trim away the excess fat from the thighs. Sprinkle all over with salt and pepper.\nIn a large deep skillet or Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Working in batches, add half of thighs, skin side down. Cook for 4 minutes, or until golden on the undersides. Turn and brown the other sides for 3 minutes.\nTransfer the chicken to a bowl. Brown the remaining thighs in the same way. Transfer the thighs to the bowl.\n4 Make the sauce: Discard all but 2 tablespoons fat from the pan. Add the onion, ham, and garlic. Cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes until the onions have started to soften. Add the roasted chiles and jalape\xc3\xb1o. Continue cooking, stirring often, for 2 minutes.\nAdd the tomatoes and stock. Use a wooden spatula to scrape up the dark glaze from the bottom of the pan. Bring to a boil, lower the heat, and partially cover. Simmer 5 minutes.\n5 Cook the chicken: Return all the chicken to the pan, skin side up, along with any juices in the bowl. It\xe2\x80\x99s ok if the thighs are a tight fit. Spoon some of the sauce over the chicken. Return to a boil, lower the heat, and partially cover.\nSimmer for 20 to 25 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through, opaque, and registers 165\xc2\xb0F with a digital thermometer.\n6 Finish and serve: Taste the sauce for seasoning and add more salt and black pepper, if you like. Sprinkle the dish with the chopped olives and parsley. Serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBarbecued Chicken on the Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 45 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nChicken thighs and legs will hold up better to long, slow cooking than will breasts which can more easily dry out. If you barbecue breasts, keep them on the coolest part of the grill (or follow this method).\nThis recipe assumes fairly large chicken pieces (like the main pieces from a 4 to 5 pound whole chicken). If you are working with smaller chicken pieces, they may require a shorter cooking time. If you are cooking wings, they too may be done before the other larger pieces.\nA note about the skin. Even if you do not plan on eating the chicken skin, it\'s still best to barbecue it with it on. The skin will protect the chicken pieces from drying out.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 pounds of your favorite chicken parts (legs, thighs, wings, breasts), skin-on\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil or vegetable oil\n1 cup barbecue sauce, store-bought or homemade\nMETHOD\n1 Oil and salt chicken pieces: Coat the chicken pieces with olive oil and sprinkle salt over them on all sides.\n2 Prepare grill: Prepare one side of your grill for high, direct heat. If you are using charcoal or wood, make sure there is a cool side to the grill where there are few to no coals.\n3 Sear chicken on hot side of grill, move to cool side: Lay the chicken pieces skin side down on the hottest side of the grill in order to sear the skin side well. Grill uncovered for 5-10 minutes, depending on how hot the grill is (you do not want the chicken to burn).\nOnce you have a good sear on one side, turn the chicken pieces over and move them to the cooler side of the grill.\nIf you are using a gas grill, maintain the flame on only one side of the grill, and move the chicken pieces to the cooler side, not directly over the flame. Reduce the temp to low or medium low (between 250\xc2\xb0F and 275\xc2\xb0F, no more than 300\xc2\xb0F).\nCover the grill and cook undisturbed for 20-30 minutes.\n4 Turn over and baste with barbecue sauce: Turn the chicken pieces over and baste them with with your favorite barbecue sauce. Cover the grill again and allow to cook for another 15-20 minutes.\nRepeat, turning the chicken pieces over, basting them with sauce, covering, and cooking for another 10-30 minutes.\nNOTE that timing will depend on your grill set-up, the size of your chicken pieces, and how cold your chicken pieces are to start with! If you are grilling smaller pieces of chicken on a charcoal grill, they may be done much earlier. The goal is to maintain a low enough grill temp so that the chicken cooks "low and slow".\n5 Finish with a sear or remove from heat when done: The chicken is done when the internal temperature of the chicken pieces are 160\xc2\xb0F for breasts and 170\xc2\xb0F for thighs, when tested with a meat thermometer.\nOr if you insert the tip of a knife into the middle of the thickest piece and the juices should run clear, the chicken is done.\nIf the chicken isn\'t done, turn the pieces over and continue to cook at a low temperature.\nIf you want, you can finish with a sear on the hot side of the grill. To do this, put the pieces, skin side down, on the hot side of the grill. Allow them to sear and blacken slightly for a minute or two.\n6 Paint with more barbecue sauce to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nThe Best Dry Rub for Ribs Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 1 1/2 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar (or 1/2 cup if you prefer a more savory rub)\n2 tablespoons kosher salt\n2 tablespoons onion powder\n2 tablespoons smoked paprika\n1 tablespoon dry mustard\n1 tablespoon granulated garlic\n1 tablespoon ground black pepper\n1 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1 teaspoon allspice\nMETHOD\n1 Mix: Place all the spices in an airtight glass jar and shake gently to combine.\n2 Store: Store in an airtight container for up to a year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBarbecued Pork Shoulder on a Gas Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nNote that this cooking time is for a 4-pound Boston butt pork shoulder. A general rule on barbecued pork is to cook it at about 215\xc2\xb0F to 225\xc2\xb0F for 90 minutes per pound.\nIf using a rub, you\'ll need to get the rub on the night before and refrigerate.\nCooking a 4 pound roast, allowing time for the barbecue to heat up and for the meat to rest once done, can easily take 9 hours, so start early in the morning if you want to have the roast done in time for dinner.\nYou need to keep smoke on the meat for at least 4 hours for a 4 pound roast. If the roast isn\'t done after 6 hours, finish it in the oven, wrapped tightly in foil to hold in the moisture.\nTwo rub recipes are provided here. Pick one for a 4 pound roast, or if barbecuing two roasts, try one each.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 4 pound pork shoulder roast, preferably Boston butt, boneless or bone-in (you can easily make two 4 pound roasts in about the same amount of time if your grill is big enough to accommodate them both)\n5 to 6 cups of wood chips, hickory, oak, apple, or other fruit wood\nBBQ Rub (enough for a 4 pound roast)\n2 Tbsp brown sugar, packed\n2 Tbsp white sugar\n2 Tbsp paprika\n1 Tbsp kosher salt\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1 1/2 teaspoons garlic powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons chipotle chile powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons black pepper\nSanta Maria Rub (enough for a 4 pound roast)\n1 Tbsp salt\n1 Tbsp finely ground black pepper\n1 Tbsp garlic powder\n1 Tbsp onion powder\n1 teaspoon cayenne\n1 Tbsp dried oregano\n1 teaspoon dry rosemary (or fresh, finely minced)\n1/2 teaspoon dry sage\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nThe day before:\n1. Prepare the rub. Mix all the ingredients for the rub together, breaking up any clumps. Taste the rub as you make it and see if you like the taste, adjust accordingly.\n2. Rub the roast with the rub. Unwrap the pork roast and place it on its butcher paper or in a roasting pan, something that can catch the rub. With your (clean) hands work the rub mixture into the pork shoulder all over, including inside any crevasses you may find in a boneless roast where the bone had been. Be generous with the amount of rub.\nRewrap it in the butcher paper or wrap it in plastic and place it in a pan (to catch any liquid that may drip out), and refrigerate it overnight.\nThe night before:\n3. Soak the wood chips. Take 3 or 4 large handfuls of wood chips (hickory, oak, apple or other fruit wood) and place them in a bowl and cover them with water to soak them overnight (can also do for an hour before using).\nI think it helps to have a mix of sizes, from small chips to larger (1-inch x 2-inch) chunks. The smaller chips will get smoking more quickly, but will burn out more quickly too. The larger chunks will take longer to catch, but last well past when the smaller chips have burned themselves out.\nThe Day Of:\n4. Bring the chilled roast to room temp. 1 to 2 hours before you start the barbecue, take the pork out of the refrigerator to come to room temperature.\nNow, if you forget to do this, which I have done, you can still go ahead and BBQ it. You\'ll likely be finishing it in the oven anyway. It will just take a bit longer to cook.\n5. Prepare your grill. Remove one of the grill grates. This will be your "hot" side, where the wood chips will go. The other side of the grill will be the "cool" side, and where the meat will be, away from direct heat.\nDepending on the structure of your grill, you may want to remove the "flavor bar", the thin metal piece with lots of holes in it that sits over the burner. The wood chips will smoke more easily if they lay in a (fireproof metal or foil) container directly on the burner.\n6. Place a tray of water on the grill: If there is room on your grill, place a small aluminum tray of water on the grill to help moderate the heat and help keep the roast from getting too dry. A good place to place this is on an upper rack if you grill has one.\n7. Get the grill smoking. Create a double layered aluminum foil boat with a handful or two of damp wood chips in it.\nPlace the boat directly on the burner on the "hot" side of the grill if you can (otherwise place on the flavor bar). Turn the grill on to medium flame, cover the grill and let it heat up until the the wood chips start smoking.\nYou\'ll either see smoke coming out of the grill, or if you raise the lid, you\'ll see smoke coming out of the wood chip boat. You should see and smell the smoke.\nYou\'ll be replenishing the wood chips periodically for the next several hours so put more dry chips into water to soak if needed.\n8. Cook roast on cool side of grill, fat side up: Once the grill is smoking, place the roast on the grill grates on the cool side of the grill, away from direct heat. If your grill has a hot spot, position the roast away from it. If there is a fatty side to the meat, put that side facing up; the fat will render over time and baste the pork.\nCover the grill, lower the flame, and let the cooking begin. The temperature you want to maintain ideally is 225\xc2\xb0F. Try to keep it close to that temperature, within a range of 210\xc2\xb0F to 240\xc2\xb0F. If the temperature goes too high, the roast may dry out. If it\'s too low, it will take forever to cook.\n9. Maintain the smoke and the 225\xc2\xb0F temperature. This is the tricky part. You will want to maintain smoke in the grill for at least 4 hours (6 hours for a bigger roast). You will also want to maintain a cooking temperature of around 225\xc2\xb0. So, you have to check the grill!\nCheck if the temperature is being maintained between 210\xc2\xb0F and 240\xc2\xb0F, and check to make sure the chips are still producing smoke, every half hour. About once an hour you will likely need to replenish the chip boat with more wood chips.\nResist the temptation to open the grill more than once an hour. Every time you open the grill the inside temperature drops and you increase your overall cooking time.\nI found the best way to check the temperature, since I don\'t have a gauge in the grill itself, is to put an instant read meat thermometer into an opening in the hood on the meat side (cool side) of the grill, and just keep checking it. Make sure sensor tip of the probe is not touching the meat itself.\nYou want to avoid opening up the hood too often, because every time you do that, you lose heat. Of course, if your gas grill gets too hot, opening the hood can cool it down quickly.\nExpect a minimum cooking time, if you have been diligent at maintaining a 225\xc2\xb0F, of 90 minutes per pound. So if you are cooking a 4 pound roast, total cooking time will be at least 6 hours (and easily more). An 8 pound roast will take at least 12 hours of cooking time.\nIf you want to cook 8 pounds of pork shoulder more quickly, I recommend starting with two 4 pound roasts, spaced on the grill a few inches apart, which will cook in just a little more time than an 8 pound roast.\n10 Reposition the roast: After 2 or 3 hours, during one of your hourly opening of the grill to refresh the wood chips, reposition the roast so that the side that was closest to the heat is now furthest from the heat.\n11. Test internal temperature of meat. After about 5 hours, start taking the pork\'s internal temperature: You can eat it at 165\xc2\xb0F, but if you are making pulled pork the meat needs to be ideally 195\xc2\xb0F.\n12 Remove from heat, let rest: When the meat reaches 195\xc2\xb0F, remove it from the heat, tent it loosely with foil over a cutting board (to catch the juices) and let it rest for at least 30 minutes, and preferably 1 hour.\nIf after 6 hours of cooking, if the meat hasn\'t reached 195\xc2\xb0 internal temp (usually after 6 hours, the internal temp on my roasts is about 155\xc2\xb0F), my recommendation is to remove it from the grill and finish in the oven.\nTo finish in the oven, wrap the roast in aluminum foil to help prevent it from drying out in the oven, and place it in a roasting pan, in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven.\nCook until the internal temperature of the roast reaches 195\xc2\xb0F. If your starting internal meat temperature is 150\xc2\xb0F or so, this can take anywhere from an hour to two hours.\nWhen it reaches temperature, remove the roast from the oven and let rest for at least 30 minutes, up to an hour.\n13. Pull the pork. Pull the pork with 2 forks. Only now do you add any barbecue sauce (and any accumulated juices) to the meat. Taste it first! It might not need sauce at all, and if it does, add only a little at a time. One of the biggest sins of barbecue is to over-sauce perfectly good meat.\nServe on a bun with or without sauce, and with or without coleslaw. Also great with grilled or raw pineapple.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nThree Bean Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 8\nPrep the onion first. Soak the chopped onion in a small bowl of water to take the edge off the onion while you prep the other ingredients.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the salad:\n1 (15-ounce) can cannellini beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (15-ounce) can garbanzo beans, rinsed and drained\n1/2 red onion, finely chopped (about 3/4 cup), soaked in water to take the edge off the onion\n2 celery stalks, finely chopped (about 1 cup)\n1 cup loosely packed, fresh, finely chopped flat-leaf parsley\n1 teaspoon fresh finely chopped rosemary\nFor the dressing:\n1/3 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/4 cup granulated sugar (more or less to taste)\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the salad: In a large bowl, mix the 3 different types of beans, the celery, onion (drained of soaking water), parsley, and rosemary.\n2 Make the dressing: In a separate small bowl, whisk together the vinegar, sugar, olive oil, salt, and pepper. Add the dressing to the beans. Toss to coat.\n3 Chill and Serve: Transfer the salad to the refrigerator for several hours, to allow the beans to soak up the flavor of the dressing. Let come to close to room temperature to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nWhite Bean and Ham Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nUse ham shanks rather than hocks if you would like a meaty soup.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb or 2 1/2 cups dry white beans\xe2\x80\x94Cannellini or Great Northern\n2 quarts of water\n2-3 lbs of smoked ham shanks or ham hocks\n2 teaspoons Herbes de Provence, or Italian seasoning\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 cup of diced onions (about 1 small onion)\n1 cup chopped celery (about 2-3 ribs)\n2/3 cup chopped carrots (about 1 medium carrot)\n2-3 cloves garlic, minced\nTabasco sauce\nSalt and pepper\nFresh parsley\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the dry beans in hot water: Fill a pot large enough to hold the beans with water and bring to a boil. Turn off the heat, add the beans and soak the beans for about 2 hours. Drain the water.\n2 Make the ham broth: While the beans are soaking in step 1, put the ham shanks or ham hocks in a separate large pot and cover them with 2 quarts of water. Add the herbes de Provence or Italian seasoning. Heat on high heat until the water comes to a simmer, then lower the heat, partially cover and maintain the simmer for about an hour.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Heat olive oil in a small saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until translucent, about 5 to 6 minutes. Add the minced garlic and cook a minute more.\n4 Add vegetables and beans to the ham broth: Once the ham hocks or shanks have been simmering for an hour, add the drained soaked beans from step 1, the onions, garlic, and the chopped celery and carrots. Cook for another 40 minutes or so, uncovered, until the vegetables are soft and the ham meat easily pulls away from the bone. Remove the ham bones from the soup and pull off any meat and return it to the soup. Discard the bones.\n5 Season to taste: Add several drops of Tabasco to taste. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nServe with a pinch of chopped fresh parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Taco Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesSlow cooking time: 6 to 7 hoursYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 pound (450g) lean ground beef\n1 1/2 cups (180g) diced yellow or red onions\n2 to 3 cups (475ml to 710ml) chicken or beef broth (use more if you want a thinner soup)\n1 15-oz. (425g) can diced tomatoes\n1 15-oz. (425g) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1 15-oz. (425g) can kidney beans, drained and rinsed\n1 4-oz. (115g) can chopped green chiles\n1 1/4 cups (135g) corn kernels, fresh or frozen\n2 1/2 teaspoons chili powder\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon paprika\n1 teaspoon salt\nTo serve:\nTortilla chips, lightly crushed\nSour cream\nChopped cilantro\nFinely diced red onion\nLime juice\nChopped red onions\nSpecial equipment:\n4-quart or larger slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef with the onions (can be done a day or two ahead): Heat the olive oil in a large skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add beef and onions and cook 2 to 3 minutes, until the ground beef is browned but not completely cooked and the onions are starting to look soft around the edges. Use your spatula to break up the ground beef into smaller pieces as it cooks. Remove from heat and use immediately, or refrigerate for a day or two until needed.\n2 Combine and cook: Combine the browned beef, onions and the remaining soup ingredients in a slow cooker and stir. Cover and cook on low for 6 to 7 hours. It\'s fine if the soup cooks a little longer or the slow cooker switches to the "warm" setting.\n3 Serve the soup: Serve soup in bowls and top with crushed tortilla chips, sour cream, cilantro, red onion and lime juice.\nThis soup will keep refrigerated for 1 week or frozen for up to 3 months.\nHello! b'Print\nTurkey Chili (with Leftover Turkey) Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 20 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups chopped onion\n1 cup chopped green bell pepper\n4 garlic cloves, chopped fine\n2 tablespoons chili powder (or up to 4 Tbsp if you like it spicier)\n1 tablespoon ground cumin\n3 15-ounce cans crushed tomatoes (fire roasted if you can get it)\n1 tablespoon tomato paste\n1 cup of turkey stock or chicken stock\nTwo 15 oz cans kidney beans, drained\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1 tablespoon sea salt, plus more if desired to taste\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n3 to 4 cups of shredded, cooked turkey meat\n1 to 3 teaspoons sugar (optional)\nShredded cheddar cheese, chopped green or red onion, sour cream for optional garnish.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions, peppers, garlic, and spices: In a large, 8-quart, thick-bottom pot, heat the olive oil on medium high heat. Add the onions and green peppers and cook, stirring, until golden, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the garlic, chili powder, and cumin, and cook, stirring, for a minute or two more. Add a bit more olive oil if needed.\n2 Add tomatoes, beans, stock, cooked turkey: Add tomatoes, tomato paste, stock, kidney beans, oregano, salt, pepper, and cooked turkey meat. Bring mixture to a simmer and reduce heat to low. Simmer, partially covered, for an hour.\n3 Add salt: Salt to taste. Add sugar to taste if needed to balance the acidity of the tomatoes.\nThe chili may be made in advance and chilled for 2 days, or frozen for 2 months.\n4 Serve with toppings: Serve with shredded cheddar cheese, chopped red onion, and or sour cream. Serve alone, over rice, or with cornbread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nHow To Make Fast, No-Soak Beans in the Instant Pot\nCook time: 30 minutesYield: about 5 cups cooked beans\nDon\'t skip the olive oil. This helps reduce foam during cooking, which could clog the pressure valve on the pressure cooker.\nIf cooking red kidney beans, I recommend boiling the beans for about 10 minutes first to break down the lectins.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried beans (see below for cooking times for specific beans)\n8 cups water\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 to 2 teaspoons salt\n2 o 3 cloves peeled garlic, optional\n1 bay leaf, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n6- to 8-quart pressure cooker (I use a 6-quart Instant Pot)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine all ingredients in the pressure cooker. Do not fill the pressure cooker more than half full.\n2 Secure the lid. Make sure the pressure regulator valve is closed. (On an Instant Pot, this means it will be set to the the "sealing" position.)\n3 Cook the beans: Here are the cooking times for unsoaked beans in the Instant Pot. Cooking times will be similar for other electric pressure cookers; cooking time will be slightly less for stovetop pressure cookers. Double-check the manual that came with your pressure cooker for more exact cooking times:\nBlack beans: 20 to 25 minutes\nBlack-eyed peas : 20 to 25 minutes\nGreat Northern beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nNavy beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nPinto beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nCannellini beans: 35 to 40 minutes\nChickpeas (garbanzo beans): 35 to 40 minutes\nRed kidney beans: 25-30 minutes (boil for 10 minutes before pressure cooking)\nCook beans at high pressure for the time recommended above. The pressure cooker will take 15 to 20 minutes to come to full pressure before cooking begins.\n4 Let the pressure release: Once cooking is complete, you can let the pressure release naturally on its own, which takes about 20 to 30 minutes, or you can do a "quick release" by opening the pressure valve on the top of the pressure cooker. If doing a rapid release, be careful because the bean liquid sometimes foams into the valve.\nI recommend letting the pressure release naturally for as long as you\'re able before the beans are needed. This helps the beans retain their shape and avoids the bean liquid foaming.\nWhat to do if your beans aren\'t quite done: Put the lid back on the pressure cooker and make sure the release valve is set back to "sealing." Cook at high pressure for another 5 to 10 minutes (depending on if you think your beans need just a little more time or a little more time to finish). The pot will quickly come back up to pressure because the contents are already hot. Check your beans after the extra cooking time and continue cooking for longer if needed.\n5 Using and storing your beans: The beans can be strained and used right away, or cooled and stored in their cooking liquid. They will keep for up to a week refrigerated or up to 3 months in the freezer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Homemade Hummus Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Makes about 3 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup of tahini (roasted, not raw)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil (plus more for garnishing)\n2 garlic cloves, mashed and roughly chopped\n2 15-oz cans of chickpeas (garbanzo beans), drained\n1/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice\n1/2 cup water\n1/2 teaspoon of salt\nGarnishes: A sprinkling of paprika, a swirl of olive oil, toasted pine nuts, and/or chopped parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Process tahini and olive oil: In a food processor, combine the tahini and olive oil and pulse until smooth.\n2 Add remaining ingredients, process until smooth: Then add the garlic, garbanzo beans, lemon juice, 1/2 cup water and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Process until smooth. The longer you process in the food processor, the smoother the hummus will be. Add more salt or lemon juice to taste.\n3 Serve: Spoon into serving dish, swirl a little olive oil over the top and sprinkle with garnishes\xe2\x80\x94a little paprika, toasted pine nuts, or chopped fresh parsley.\nServe with crackers, raw dip vegetables such as carrots or celery, or with toasted pita bread.\nTo toast pita bread, cut the pita bread into triangles, brush with olive oil and toast for 10 minutes in a 375\xc2\xb0F oven, turning them over half-way through the cooking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nQuinoa Bowls with Sweet Potatoes, Black Beans, and Spinach Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the sauce:\n1/4 cup sour cream\n1 teaspoon Frank\xe2\x80\x99s Red Hot Sauce or more to taste\n1 teaspoon fresh lime juice\n1 1/2 teaspoon water\nFor the quinoa:\n2 cups water\n1 cup dry quinoa\n1 teaspoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the pepitas:\n1/2 teaspoon olive oil\n1/4 cup pepitas\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the sweet potatoes:\n1 pound sweet potatoes, peeled, and cut into \xc2\xbd inch cubes.\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1/4 cup water\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\n1/4 teaspoon smoked paprika\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the black beans:\n1 teaspoon olive oil\n1/2 medium yellow onion, diced small\n2 cloves minced garlic\n2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1 teaspoon cumin\n1 bay leaf\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n1/4 cup water\n1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar or lime juice\nFor the spinach:\n8 ounces baby spinach, two large handfuls per person\n3 tablespoons water\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the garnish:\n2 ounces cotija cheese, crumbled\nLime wedges\nChopped fresh cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the sauce: In a small bowl, combine sour cream, Frank\xe2\x80\x99s Red Hot, lime juice, and water. Cover and place in the refrigerator.\n2 Cook the quinoa: Put the quinoa in a fine mesh strainer and rinse it under cold water for about a minute. In a medium-sized pot, combine water, quinoa, 1 teaspoon oil, and 1/2 teaspoon salt.\nCover and cook over medium heat until the water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Remove from the heat, fluff with fork, and keep it covered.\n3 Toast the pepitas: Set a large skillet over medium heat. Add 1/2 teaspoon of olive oil. When the oil shimmers, add the pepitas and the salt. Stir frequently and toast for about 5 minutes until the seeds start popping and some parts turn a toasty brown.\nTransfer to a large plate. Scoot pepitas to one side. You\xe2\x80\x99ll put the sweet potatoes on the other side.\n4 Cook the sweet potatoes in sugar and spices: Using the same skillet you used to toast the pepitas, keep the heat at medium and add 2 teaspoons oil. Once the oil starts to shimmer, add the cubed potatoes. Stir to coat. Cook for about 1 minute. Stir again. Add the water. Cover and leave untouched for 5 minutes.\nCombine sugar, paprika, cayenne, and salt in a small bowl. Add the spice mixture to the potatoes. Stir to coat.\nCook uncovered for 7 additional minutes. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir. The sugar should be caramelized, one side of the potatoes should be brown, and the potatoes should be tender but still hold together.\nRemove the potatoes from the skillet and place them on the plate alongside the pepitas. Tent with foil to keep them warm.\n5 Make the beans: Return the skillet to the burner over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, after about a minute, add the diced onion, garlic, oregano, cumin and bay leaf. Cook until the onions are softened, about 2 minutes.\nAdd the beans, 1/4 cup of water, and 1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar. Turn to medium-high, stirring occasionally until the liquid is reduced, about 5 minutes.\nDivide the beans evenly among four bowls. Wipe out the pan with a paper towel and set it over medium heat.\n6 Wilt the spinach: Add 3 tablespoons of water to the pan followed by all of the spinach. Drizzle with 2 teaspoons of olive oil and 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt. Toss gently until the spinach is wilted\xe2\x80\x94this should take about 2 minutes.\n7 Serve the bowls: To the bowls with the black beans, add a 1/2 cup of sweet potatoes, 1/2 cup quinoa, and the spinach. Top with toasted pepitas, crumbled cotija, a squeeze of lime, and a drizzle of creamy lime hot sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Beef Chili Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you have leftover tomato paste after making this recipe, you can freeze it in tablespoon portions for another recipe.\nStovetop Instructions: In a medium saucepan or soup pot, cook the bell pepper, onion, celery and garlic in olive oil over medium heat until the onions are softened and translucent. Add the ground beef and cook until no longer pink. Add the spices, tomato paste, tomatoes, and beans, along with a cup of water or broth. Bring to a simmer. then turn the heat down to low, cover the pot, and let simmer for one hour.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon olive or vegetable oil\n1 medium green bell pepper, chopped\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n2 ribs celery, chopped\n1 clove garlic, finely chopped\n1 pound ground beef (85% lean)\n2 tablespoons chili powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/2 teaspoon oregano\n3 tablespoons tomato paste\n1 (14-ounce) can diced tomatoes\nWater or broth, as needed to make 1 cup liquid with the tomato juices\n1 (15.5-ounce) can kidney beans, drained and rinsed\n1 cup shredded cheese, any favorite mix, to serve\n2 green onions, sliced thinly, to serve\nRice, cornbread, or garlic knots, to serve\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot, or other pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the vegetables: Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d program on your pressure cooker and add the oil to the pot. (If you are using a stovetop pressure cooker, heat the oil over medium heat.) Add the bell pepper, onion, celery, and garlic. Saut\xc3\xa9 until the onions are softened and translucent, about five minutes.\n2 Cook the ground beef: Add the ground beef to the pot, breaking it up in small pieces. Cook until no longer pink, about five minutes.\n3 Stir in the spices and tomato paste. Add the chili powder, salt, oregano, and tomato paste to the pot. Stir until the tomato paste is evenly mixed into the other ingredients and no clumps remain.\n4 Add the tomatoes and beans: Strain the tomatoes, then add enough water or broth to make 1 cup total liquid. Add the liquid, the strained tomatoes, and the beans to the pressure cooker.\n5 Cook the chili: Place the lid on the pressure cooker. Make sure the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. If you are using an Instant Pot, select the \xe2\x80\x9cChili\xe2\x80\x9d program, then adjust the time to 20 minutes. If your pressure cooker does not have a \xe2\x80\x9cChili\xe2\x80\x9d program, set it manually to \xe2\x80\x9cHigh Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d for 20 minutes. For stovetop pressure cookers, cook for 17 minutes at high pressure.\nIt will take about 10 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the actual cooking will begin. Total time from the time you seal the pressure cooker to the finished dish is about 30 minutes.\n6 Release the pressure after cooking: When the timer goes off, you may either perform a quick pressure release by moving the pressure release knob from \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cVenting,\xe2\x80\x9d or let the pot depressurize naturally on its own (this takes about 20 minutes; open the vent to "Venting" when you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to serve the chili.) For stovetop pressure cookers, perform a quick pressure release.\n7 To serve: Top bowls of chili with shredded cheese and green onions, if desired. Serve alone, over rice, or with cornbread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nSlow Cooked Boston Baked Beans Recipe\nCook time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 5-6 as a main dish or 10-12 as a side\nWhy pre-soak the beans? You don't have to (see this great Russ Parsons article in the LA Times about why you don't need to soak beans), but not doing so in this recipe will increase the cooking time. With the beans pre-soaked, they'll still take 8 hours to cook and soften in a slow-cooker. Once beans come in contact with the molasses, the sugar in the molasses will keep the beans firm. That's why they take so long to cook.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (2 to 2 1/4 cups) dry white beans such as Navy beans or Great Northern beans (can also use kidney beans)\n1/3 cup molasses\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n3-4 Tbsp Dijon mustard\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n3 cups hot water\n1/2 pound salt pork (can sub bacon), cut into 1/2-inch to 1-inch pieces\n1 medium onion, (1 1/2 cups) chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak beans in water: Place beans in a large pot and cover with 2 inches of water. Soak overnight and drain. Alternatively, bring a pot with the beans covered with 2 inches of water to a boil, remove from heat and let soak for a hour, then drain.\n2 Mix molasses, brown sugar, mustard, ground cloves with water: Whisk together the molasses, brown sugar, mustard, and ground cloves with 3 cups of hot water.\n3 Add ingredients to slow-cooker, layering them, starting with the salt pork: Line the bottom of a slow-cooker (or a Dutch oven if you are cooking in the oven) with half of the salt pork (pick the fattiest pieces). Layer over with half of the drained beans. Add all of the chopped onion in a layer.\nTop with another layer of beans and the remaining salt pork. Pour the molasses water mixture over the beans to just cover the beans.\n4 Slow cook until beans are tender: Cover and cook in a slow-cooker on the low setting for 8 hours (or in a 250\xc2\xb0F oven), until the beans are tender. Check the water level a few hours in, and if the beans need more water, add some. Add additional salt to taste if needed.\nNote that fresher beans will cook faster than older beans. Your beans may be ready in less than 8 hours, or they may take longer. Best the next day.\nServe with Boston brown bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBean and Bacon Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesBean soaking time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 6 to 8\nIn this recipe we are making the bean soup starting with dry beans that we soak overnight. If you don't have time to soak beans overnight, you can put the beans into a pot of water, bring the water to a boil, remove from heat, and let sit for hour, and then drain. Pre-soaking the beans will help them cook faster.\nIf you would rather work with canned beans, use 3 to 4 15-ounce cans of drained white beans and cook them in step 3 for only 15 minutes, not an hour.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dry Great Northern white beans, covered with a couple inches of water and soaked overnight\n5 ounces of bacon, cut into 1/2-inch wide pieces\n2 cups chopped onion (1 large onion)\n3/4 cup chopped celery (about 2 ribs of celery)\n3/4 cup chopped carrots (1 large carrot)\n3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 tablespoon)\n6 cups chicken stock\n2 bay leaves\n1 Tbsp fresh thyme\n2 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n3 Tbsp tomato paste\n1/2 teaspoon paprika\n1 ounce bacon (1 to 2 slices), cooked and crumbled for garnish (optional)\n2 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley for garnish (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Drain the beans: Drain the beans that have been soaking in water. (If you haven't already soaked the beans, and you don't have time to do so overnight, you can put them in a large pot of water, bring to a boil, remove from heat and let sit for an hour, then drain.)\n2 Cook the bacon and vegetables: Put the bacon into a large (5 to 6 quart) thick-bottomed Dutch oven on medium high heat. Let the bacon cook for a minute or two to start rendering out some of its fat, then add the chopped onion, celery, and carrots.\nLower the heat to low, cover and cook for 12 to 15 minutes, until vegetables are completely cooked through and softened. Add the garlic and cook a minute more.\n3 Add beans, stock, seasonings, simmer: Add the drained beans to the pot. Add the stock, the bay leaves, thyme, salt and pepper.\nIncrease heat to high to bring to a simmer, then lower the heat to maintain a simmer, partially covered, for 1 hour or until the beans are very soft.\n4 Add tomato paste and paprika: Stir in the tomato paste and the paprika. Cook for 5 more minutes.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e half the soup: Remove the bay leaves. Using an immersion blender, pur\xc3\xa9e most of the soup. You don't want the soup to be perfectly smooth, but you want to pur\xc3\xa9e enough of it so that the beans create a creamy base.\nAdd more salt and pepper to taste.\nGarnish with crumbled cooked bacon and chopped parsley to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nRefried Black Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hour, 10 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6\nThis recipe gives instructions for making refried beans from scratch, starting with dry beans which must first be cooked. You can also start with three 15-ounce cans of whole black beans, in which case, skip to step 5, rinse and drain the beans and add to the pan with a little water in step 6.\nINGREDIENTS\nIngredients for cooking the dry beans:\n1 pound dry black beans\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 large white onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1 garlic clove, minced\n2 teaspoons salt\n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro (leaves and tender stems)\nAdditional ingredients for frying the beans after they've been cooked:\n1 teaspoon chipotle chili powder\n1 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 large white onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1 garlic clove, minced\nGreen onion\nCilantro\nCrumbled cotija or queso fresco cheese (omit for vegan version)\nTortilla chips or corn tortillas\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak dry beans: Place dry black beans in a bowl and add enough water to cover the beans by two inches. Let sit overnight.\nAlternatively, if you don't have time to soak the beans overnight, place the dry beans in a large bowl and pour boiling water over the beans, covering the beans with at least an inch of water, and let sit for one hour.\nNote, if your dry beans are a little old, or if you have reason to believe that they will be tough to cook (beans stored in hot or humid climates can get tough), you can add some salt to the water (1 1/2 teaspoons of salt 2 quarts of water) which at this stage will help the beans soften when they cook later.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 cumin, onion, garlic:  Heat a tablespoon of olive oil in a large thick-bottomed pot (the pot you will use to cook the beans) on medium high heat.\nAdd the cumin. Once the cumin is sizzling, add the chopped onion. Cook for 5 minutes or so, until translucent. Add the minced garlic and cook for a minute more.\n3 Add drained beans and water, simmer 2 hours: Once the beans have soaked, they should have expanded noticeably. Drain the soaking liquid.\nAdd the drained beans and 2 quarts of water to the onions. Bring to a simmer. Partially cover the pot and lower the heat to maintain a simmer. Simmer for 2 hours.\n4 Add Salt and Cilantro, cook 30 min more: After the beans have simmered for 2 hours, add 2 teaspoons of salt (if you salted the soaking water in step 1, then taste first, and only add a teaspoon or so more of salt if you think it needs it).\nAdd 1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro. Let cook uncovered for another half hour, or until the beans are tender.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 the spices, then add onions and cook: Heat 2 Tbsp of olive oil in a large frying pan on medium high heat. Add the chipotle powder, chili powder, and cumin.\nOnce the spices are sizzling, add the chopped white onion and cook until translucent.\nAdd the garlic and cook a minute more.\n6 Add beans, then mash: Add the cooked black beans (and liquid from the pot) to the frying pan. Use a potato masher to mash the beans in the pan.  Let them cook 3 to 4 minutes longer.\nIf the beans are a little soupy for your taste, just let them cook longer. If too thick or dry, add more water. Adjust seasonings to taste.\n7 Serve: Garnish with chopped green onions, fresh cilantro, and crumbled cotija or queso fresco cheese.\nServe with tortilla chips or corn or flour tortillas (corn if you are gluten-free). Great in tacos or burritos, or for a dip, or a side with steak.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nCoconut Rice and Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nThe chile is cooked whole with the rice and is there just for a bit of flavor. It doesn't make the rice hot at all, as it stays whole and you discard it at the end.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp vegetable oil\n1/2 yellow onion, chopped\n4 garlic cloves, chopped\n2 cups long-grain rice\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger\n1 cup water\n1 cup chicken stock (or vegetable stock for vegetarian option)\n2 cups coconut milk\n1 15-ounce can kidney beans, rinsed and drained, or 1 1/2 cups cooked kidney beans\n2 teaspoons dried thyme\n1 whole Scotch bonnet chile (can substitute a whole habanero)\nLime (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions: Heat the oil in a medium pot over medium-high heat. Add the onions and saut\xc3\xa9 for 4-5 minutes, until they begin to brown on the edges.\n2 Add garlic and rice: Add the garlic and rice, stir well and cook for another 2-3 minutes, stirring often.\n3 Add remaining ingredients: Add the grated ginger, salt, water, stock and coconut milk and stir well. Add the kidney beans and sprinkle the thyme over everything. Add the whole Scotch bonnet chile (or habanero); it will season the rice much like a bay leaf would.\n4 Cook: Bring to a simmer, then turn the heat to low and cover. The rice should be done in about 15-20 minutes, depending on the type of rice you are using (some long grained rice takes longer to cook). Check after 15 minutes.\n5 Remove from heat, cover: Once done, remove from heat and cover for 10 minutes.\n6 Serve: Fluff with a fork. Sprinkle with a little lime juice if you want. Discard the habanero (or eat it, if you dare!)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nQuick and Easy White Bean Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4\nYou can easily double or quadruple the recipe to serve a larger group.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 14.5-ounce can white beans, drained but not rinsed\n2 tablespoons chopped red onion\nA squeeze of lemon juice\n2 teaspoons wine vinegar (red or white)\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon dry Herbs de Provence (crumbled) OR 1 teaspoon of some combination of finely chopped rosemary, tarragon, thyme, and lavender\nSalt and freshly ground pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Let the onion marinate in lemon juice: After you chop up the onion, squeeze a little lemon juice over it and let it sit while prepping the other ingredients. According to my mother, this will take the edge off the onion.\n2 Combine all ingredients into a serving dish. You can serve right away if you want, but if you chill for a few hours, the flavors will come together better.\nLasts a couple of days in the refrigerator.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nSpicy, Citrusy Black Beans Recipe\nCook time: 2 hoursBean soaking time: OvernightYield: Serves 8\nAdapted from a recipe in the Fields of Greens cookbook.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups dried black beans\n2 1/2 quarts (10 cups) water\n2-3 fresh sprigs oregano, or 1 tablespoon dried\n3 bay leaves\n6 small or 3 large sage leaves\n2 teaspoons salt\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 yellow onions, chopped\n2 chopped peppers \xe2\x80\x93 bell pepper, Anaheim, or jalape\xc3\xb1o (your choice, depending on taste for heat), seeds, stems and ribs discarded\n6 cloves crushed garlic\n2 tablespoons Ancho red chili sauce, or chili powder or Tabasco to taste*\n1-2 teaspoons of pur\xc3\xa9ed chipotle in adobo, chipotle Tabasco, or chipotle powder (to taste)\n1 tablespoon cumin, (crushed whole toasted cumin seed is best, if possible)\n3 tablespoons frozen orange juice concentrate or 1/2 cup fresh orange juice\nJuice of 1 lime\n2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar\nChopped fresh cilantro for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the beans (optional): Rinse and sort the beans, discarding any stones or shriveled beans. You can soak the beans overnight in cold water (cover with several inches of water) OR pour enough boiling water over them to cover by a few inches and soak them for an hour OR skip the pre-soaking step.\nSoaking will speed up the cooking process. If you soak, discard the soaking liquid after soaking.\n2 Cook the beans: Add beans to a large pot with 2 1/2 quarts (10 cups) of water. Add oregano, bay leaves, and sage. Bring the beans to a boil and reduce heat to a simmer.\nCook until the beans are soft, but not quite done. The time will vary depending on how large, dry, or old your beans are, and if you have pre-soaked them, from anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour and a half.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and peppers, add spices: While the beans are cooking, saut\xc3\xa9 onions and peppers in olive oil until soft. Add chili sauce, chili powder, and/or chili pur\xc3\xa9e, cumin, and garlic. Saut\xc3\xa9 until spices are fragrant.\n4 Fish out and discard the bay leaves, stems of oregano, and sage leaves from the pot of beans. Remove, but reserve, extra cooking liquid until there is about 1/2-inch of liquid above beans.\n5 Add the onion mixture and salt to the pot of beans. Cook another hour or so until thickened. Add reserved liquid if needed.\n6 Add half of the orange juice, and simmer. Adjust chili heat at this point \xe2\x80\x93 you may or may not want to add more of your chili paste.\nJust before serving, add remaining orange juice, lime juice, and vinegar. Salt to taste. Garnish with chopped fresh cilantro.\nServe with corn tortillas, and/or rice, sour cream, and salsa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nMexican Quinoa Salad with Black Beans, Corn, and Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nIf you are working with frozen corn, you can add more flavor by taking the frozen corn kernels and searing them directly on a hot pan, without defrosting first. Save time by prepping most of the ingredients while the quinoa is cooking.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked quinoa, well rinsed\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 cups water\n1/3 cup diced red onion\n2 Tbsp lime juice\n1 15-ounce can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1 cup frozen corn, defrosted, OR 1 cup of fresh corn, parboiled, drained and cooled (approximately the amount of kernels from one ear of corn)\n3 medium tomatoes, seeded and cut into chunks\n5 ounces Queso fresco, Queso Panela, fresh Mozzarella or other mild farmer's cheese, cut into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch cubes\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o, seeded and finely chopped\n1/4 cup chopped cilantro, including tender stems, packed\n3 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the quinoa: Put the rinsed quinoa, salt and water into a pot and bring it to a boil. Cover and simmer gently until the quinoa absorbs all the water, about 10-15 minutes.\nRemove from heat and let sit for 5 minutes. Place into a large bowl and fluff up with a fork to help it cool more quickly.\n2 Soak onions in lime juice: While the quinoa is cooking, prepare the rest of the salad. Soak the red onions in the lime juice and set aside. Soaking the onions in lime juice (or lemon juice or water) helps take the edge off of them.\n3 Mix the prepped black beans, corn kernels, tomatoes, cheese, jalape\xc3\xb1os, cilantro, and oil into a large bowl.\n4 Add quinoa and onions to bean mixture: When the quinoa has cooled, mix it into the bean mixture. Add the red onion and the lime juice and add salt, more oil or lime juice to taste.\nServe at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nPressure Cooker Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCooking (including pressure release) time: 2 hoursYield: 8 to 10 servings\nThis recipe uses an electric pressure cooker. Pressure cooking times will be slightly less if you\'re using a stovetop pressure cooker.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried Great Northern beans\n1/3 cup molasses\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n3 tablespoons Dijon mustard\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n8 ounces bacon, cut into 1/2-inch pieces\n1 medium onion, diced\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Par-cook the beans: Combine the dried beans and 8 cups of the water in an electric pressure cooker. Secure the lid on the pressure cooker. Make sure that the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nIf you are using an Instant Pot, select the \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, then adjust the time to 15 minutes. If your pressure does not have a \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, set it manually to \xe2\x80\x9cHigh Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d for 15 minutes.\nIt will take about 20 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the 15 minutes of actual cooking will begin. \n2 Naturally release the pressure and drain the beans: When the timer goes off, wait for the pressure to release naturally for 15 minutes, then release the rest of the pressure by moving the pressure release knob from \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cVenting.\xe2\x80\x9d It will take a minute or two for the pressure to release completely.\nAt this point, the beans should be mostly cooked through, but still firm. It\'s fine if there\'s still a little bit of white at the center. If you\'d like to use some of the bean cooking liquid to make your baked beans, scoop out 1 1/2 cups of liquid and set it aside.\nWearing a pair of heat-proof mitts, lift the inner pot out of the pressure cooker and drain the beans into a colander in the sink. Wash out the pot and return it to the pressure cooker.\n3 Prepare the cooking liquid: In a small bowl, whisk together the molasses, sugar, mustard, ground cloves, and 1 1/2 cups water or reserved bean cooking liquid. Set aside.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the bacon and onions: Reset the electric pressure cooker, then select its \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d program. Add the bacon to the pot and saut\xc3\xa9 it until it begins to render some fat, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the onions and saut\xc3\xa9 until they are translucent, about 5 more minutes. When done, hit "Cancel" to stop saut\xc3\xa9ing.\n5 Finish cooking the beans: Gently stir the beans and the cooking liquid into the pot with the bacon and onions. Secure the lid on the pressure cooker, again making sure that the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nIf you are using an Instant Pot, select the \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, then adjust the time to 15 minutes. If your pressure does not have a \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, set it manually to \xe2\x80\x9cHigh Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d for 15 minutes.\nIt will take about 15 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the 15 minutes of actual cooking will begin.\n6 Let the pressure release naturally: When the cooking program finishes, let the pressure cooker completely release its pressure naturally. This will take about 30 minutes.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t perform a quick release, as the thick cooking liquid will sputter out of the pressure release valve.\n7 Serve the beans warm: They are very good straight out of the pot, and taste even better the next day. Reheat beans over low temperature on the stovetop, in a low oven, or in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nGreen Beans with Tomatoes and Bacon Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nRee's original recipe does not include the garlic or thyme. We added them because, why not? Tastes good. Also we halved the recipe, because for everyday meals we don't need to serve 10 to 12. Feel free to double to Ree's original Thanksgiving-worthy proportions.\nThis recipe also works well in the slow cooker, so I've added instructions for that as well.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 slices thick cut bacon (about 4 ounces), cut into 1-inch segments\n1/2 large onion, diced (about 3/4 cup)\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 pounds of fresh, firm green beans (they should break when you bend them, not bend like a rubber band), stem ends trimmed\n1 14.5-ounce can whole tomatoes\n1 large sprig fresh thyme\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/8 to 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon until fat begins to render: Place the bacon pieces on the bottom of a large, thick-bottomed pot. Heat on medium heat for several minutes until the bacon fat begins to render.\n2 Add onions, then garlic: Add the chopped onions to the bacon. Cook a few minutes until the onions are translucent. Add the garlic (if using) and cook a minute more. Drain off any excess fat.\n3 Add green beans, tomatoes, spices: Add the green beans to the pot. Add the whole, peeled, canned tomatoes and their juices. Add a sprig of thyme to the pot (if using). Sprinkle with salt, pepper, and cayenne.\n4 Cover and simmer: Cover the pot and lower the heat to low. Simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the beans are cooked through and tender, stirring occasionally.\nSlow Cooker Instructions If you want to use a slow cooker for step 4, you can easily do so. Just put the cooked bacon and onions from steps 1 and 2, and the beans, tomatoes and spices into a slow cooker and cook on high for 2 to 3 hours, depending on your slow cooker, until the beans are completely tender and the tomatoes have broken down.\nServe!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nMediterranean Chickpea Bowls with Tahini Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: 4 servings\nAll components to this recipe can be made ahead and kept refrigerated until serving.\nDouble the recipe as needed to make more servings.\nIf you don't already have brown rice prepared, start a pot before you begin prepping this recipe so that it's ready when you're finished.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the tahini dressing:\n1/4 cup tahini (at room temperature)\n1/4 cup warm water\nJuice 1/2 to 1 lemon (1 to 2 tablespoons)\n1 teaspoon honey, agave, or maple syrup\n1 clove garlic, finely minced\n1/4 cup finely minced parsley\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\nFor the chickpeas:\n1 16-ounce can chickpeas (or 2 cups homemade chickpeas)\n1/2 tablespoon paprika (either sweet or hot)\n1/2 tablespoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon ground coriander\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\n1 tablespoon olive oil, divided\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 teaspoon finely minced fresh chili (optional)\n1/2 cup finely chopped fresh herbs (I like the combination of parsley, mint, and cilantro)\nFor the bowls:\n6 cups baby spinach\n2 cups cooked brown rice\n1 pint cherry or grape tomatoes, halved\n1 English cucumber, diced\n1/4 red onion, finely diced (about 2 tablespoons)\nFresh mint leaves\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the tahini dressing: In a small bowl, whisk tahini with 2 tablespoons of the warm water, 1 tablespoon of the lemon juice, honey, minced garlic, parsley, salt, and pepper.\nGive the dressing a taste. Add salt if needed. If it needs more acid or tastes slightly bitter, add more lemon juice one teaspoon at a time. If the dressing is too thick, add more water a tablespoon at a time.\nDressing can be made several days ahead and kept refrigerated. You may need to allow it to warm slightly at room temperature (or very briefly in the microwave) to loosen it up before using.\n2 Warm the chickpeas: Drain chickpeas and rinse well in a colander. Rub the chickpeas gently with a clean, lint-free towel to dry, or let them air dry for about 10 minutes. When dry, toss the chickpeas in a mixing bowl with the paprika, cumin, coriander, salt, pepper. Add 1/2 tablespoon of the olive oil and mix until well-coated.\nWarm a large skillet over medium-high heat until hot enough that a drop of water sizzles on contact. Add the remaining 1/2 tablespoon of olive oil and tilt the pan to evenly coat.\nImmediately add the chickpeas. Stir constantly until they are warmed through, 3 to 5 minute). Turn off heat, then add garlic and chili (if using), and mix well.\nToss with fresh herbs just before serving. (The chickpeas are best if served while still warm, but are also good if you make them ahead and serve cold.)\n3 Assemble the bowls: Divide the spinach evenly between four bowls. Top each bowl with 1/2 cup of the brown rice, 1/2 cup warm chickpeas, a quarter of the tomatoes, a quarter of the cucumber, and a quarter of the red onion. Drizzle with tahini dressing, and top with fresh mint leaves.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nThree Bean Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 7 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 pound sliced bacon\n2 cups chopped onion\n1 Tbsp dry mustard\n1 teaspoon minced fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoons dry thyme)\n3/4 cup ketchup\n3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1/4 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup water\n1 bay leaf\n1 15-ounce can red kidney beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can black beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can cannellini (white kidney beans), rinsed, drained\n1 teaspoon Tabasco\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook and crumble the bacon: Cook the bacon in a large Dutch oven over medium heat until browned and crisp. Remove bacon and place on paper towels to soak up excess fat. Crumble up the bacon and set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Remove all but a tablespoon of the bacon drippings from the pot. Add the chopped onions and cook on medium high heat until translucent, about 5 minutes.\n4 Add the rest of the ingredients: Sprinkle the onions with dry mustard and thyme. Stir in the ketchup, vinegar, molasses, bay leaf, beans, Tabasco, and water. Add salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Cover and bake: Cover the pot and put into a 350\xc2\xb0F oven. Bake for 1 hour, checking every 15 minutes to stir and add more water if needed. Stir in the bacon the last 15 minutes of cooking.\nAlternatively, cook in a slow cooker 4 hours on high, or 8 on low.\nDiscard bay leaf before serving.\nHello!
