b'Save It Print\nPasta and Bean Picnic Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 8 to 12 servings as a side dish\nThis recipe can be prepared up to a day ahead.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 teaspoons salt\n1 pound small-shaped pasta (curly, twisted, corkscrew, shells, or bow-ties)\n7 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n2 cans (15-to 16-ounces each) white beans, like Great Northern, navy, or cannellini, drained and rinsed\nZest of 1 lemon\n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1 heaping teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 pint mixed cherry or grape tomatoes, sliced or cut into quarters\n2 stalks celery, halved lengthwise and very thinly sliced\n1/2 red onion, very thinly sliced\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of water with 2 teaspoons of the salt to a boil. Add the pasta and cook, stirring occasionally, for 8 minutes or until the pasta is tender.\nDrain but do not rinse; shake the colander to remove excess water.\n2 Combine the pasta and beans: Transfer the pasta to a large bowl and sprinkle with 3 tablespoons of the olive oil. Shake the bowl to distribute the oil.\nAdd the rinsed beans and lemon zest to the hot pasta. Stir the salad gently. Leave to cool.\n3 Make the dressing: In a bowl, whisk the vinegar, mustard, remaining 1 teaspoon salt, and pepper. Slowly whisk in the remaining 4 tablespoons oil until it is all added.\nTaste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like.\n4 Finish mixing the salad: Pour the dressing over the pasta and beans and stir. Add the tomatoes, celery, onion, and parsley to the pasta mixture and stir gently but thoroughly.\nTaste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like. You can also squeeze some lemon juice over the top if it needs a touch more brightness.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nChinese Chicken Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups loosely packed, shredded, cooked white chicken meat (about 3/4 pound), (see How to Poach Chicken)\n1/4 cup soy sauce (use gluten-free soy sauce for gluten-free version)\n1 Tbsp sherry\n1 Tbsp sugar\nAbout 1 cup canola oil or peanut oil\n2 ounces (1 bunch) bean threads\n4 green onions, shredded lengthwise\n1 large head of romaine lettuce (or 2 small heads), cut into 1/2 to 3/4 inch slices\n2 Tbsp chopped toasted almonds\n2 Tbsp toasted sesame seeds\nDressing:\n2 Tbsp sugar\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground pepper\n3 Tbsp vegetable oil\n1 Tbsp dark sesame oil\n3 Tbsp rice vinegar (can sub cider vinegar)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Shred, season, and marinate the cooked chicken: Using two forks, shred the cooked chicken. (If starting with raw chicken, see How to Poach Chicken).\nMix soy sauce, sherry and sugar in a bowl and add the chicken. Let soak for 10 minutes. Remove chicken and pat dry with paper towels.\n2 Fry the bean threads in hot oil: Put 3/4 inch of high smoke point cooking oil (such as canola oil or peanut oil) into a small saucepan. Heat on high heat until shimmering.\nTake one bunch of the dried bean threads and gently break them up a bit. Test the oil by putting one bean thread into the oil.\nIf the oil is hot enough, the bean thread will almost immediately sizzle and puff up. That's when you know the oil is hot enough.\nWhen the oil is ready, working with a few bean threads at a time, put them in the hot oil.\nAs soon as they puff up, remove them carefully with tongs and place them on a paper towel to cool. The paper towel helps remove any excess oil. Set aside.\n3 Fry the shredded chicken: In a large skillet over medium high heat, heat 2 tablespoons of oil from the bean threads until hot.\nAdd the chicken and cook for 2 to 3 minutes to bake in the seasoning. Set aside.\n4 Slice green onions lengthwise: Cut the green onions in 3 to 4 inch long pieces, and shred them lengthwise.\n5 Toast the chopped almonds and sesame seeds: Toast the chopped almonds, or chop your toasted almonds; toast your sesame seeds. (Heat a thin skillet to medium high heat, add the seeds - or nuts, don't do them both together - stir frequently until they begin to brown, remove from heat, they will continue to cook. Let cool to room temp.)\n6 Make the dressing: Put all of the dressing ingredients together in a jar\xe2\x80\x94sugar, salt, pepper, vegetable oil, dark sesame oil, rice vinegar\xe2\x80\x94cover with a lid and shake until emulsified.\n7 Serve: Just before serving the salad, mix all of the salad ingredients together - lettuce, chicken, bean threads, almonds, sesame seeds, and dressing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nHow to Grill the Best Burgers\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: 6 burgers\nThis recipe will make six burgers that are 1/3 pound each. The patties should be 4-inches across and 1-inch thick at the edges before cooking.\nI like hamburgers with a bit of a garlic kick, so if you prefer a subtler garlic flavor, feel free to reduce the amount to your liking or eliminate altogether.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds 80/20 ground beef, cold\n4 cloves minced garlic\n2 tablespoons minced onion\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n1 3/4 teaspoons freshly ground pepper\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n6 hamburger buns\nButter for buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the burger mix: Put the cold ground beef in mixing bowl. Sprinkle the other ingredients evenly over top. Fold the meat over a few times to get everything incorporated. This entire process should only take about 30 to 45 seconds. Don\xe2\x80\x99t over handle the meat.\n  2 Shape the burger patties: Rather than forming the patties in your hand, form them on a tray. This makes it easier to shape the patties without over-handling or warming the meat. I like to use a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper, but any tray or platter will do.\nOn the tray, divide the meat into 6 equal parts (about 5 1/4 ounces each). Gently form each portion into a patty that is 4-inches across with 1-inch sides and a shallow depression in the middle (see photos below). You want the outer 1/2 inch of the patty to be slightly taller than the inside. This keeps the patty from shrinking too much and from puffing up in the center during grilling\nCover the patties with plastic wrap and transfer to the fridge while you heat up your grill and butter your buns.\n  3 Heat the grill: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to 450 to 500\xc2\xb0F, or hot enough that you can only hold your hand above the grill grates for about 1 second.\nButter the insides of all the buns and set them near the grill.\n4 Grill the burgers: Place patties on the grill over direct heat. Cook to your desired doneness:\nFor rare burgers, cook for 4 minutes total (125\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium-rare burgers, cook for 5 minutes total (135\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium burgers, cook for 6 to 7 minutes total (145\xc2\xb0F)\nFor well-done burgers, cook for 8 to 9 minutes total (160\xc2\xb0F)\nFlip the burgers at least once during cooking, or as often as you wish. Do not press down on the patties at any time.\n  5 Add the cheese and toast the buns: When you have about 1 minute left on the cooking time, add the cheese to the burgers and the buttered buns to the grill over indirect heat.\n6 Rest the burgers: Remove burgers and buns from grill and transfer to a clean platter. Let the burgers rest for 1 minute before serving.\n7 Serve: Serve with tomato jam, mayonnaise, bacon jam, garlic aioli, blue cheese sauce, saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms, Thousand Island, or the classic and always wonderful lettuce, tomato, pickles and red onion.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nGrilled Marinated Flank Steak Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesMarinating time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade Ingredients\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n1/3 cup soy sauce\n1/4 cup honey\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nOther ingredients\n2 pounds flank steak\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the steak: Combine the marinade ingredients in a large non-reactive bowl.\nPlace steak in the bowl and turn so that it is completely coated with the marinade. (You can also place the steak and marinade in a freezer bag and place it in a bowl.)\nChill and marinate for at least 2 hours and up to overnight.\n2 Prepare your grill for high, direct heat with one part of the grill for lower, indirect heat. The grill is hot enough when you hold your hand about an inch over the hot side and you can only hold it there for about a second.\n3 Grill the steak: Remove the steak from the marinade and gently shake off the excess marinade from the steak (but make sure there is still a coating of it, you'll want the oil on it to help keep the steak from sticking to the grill).\nIf you want, sprinkle generously on all sides with coarse salt and freshly ground pepper. The salt and pepper will help form a savory crust on the steak.\nPlace steak on the hot side of the grill. Grill for a minute or two on each side to get a good sear, then move the steak to the cooler side of the grill, cover and cook a few minutes more until done to your liking.\nHow do you know when the steak is done? One way to tell is to poke it with your fingertips. While the steak is still raw, test it with your fingers; it will be quite squishy. That's what a very rare steak feels like. Touch the tip of your nose and that's what a very well done steak feels like. Here's a visual guide, the finger test to check the doneness of steak.\nOtherwise use a good meat thermometer (I recommend a thermapen.)  Pull the steak off the grill at 120 to 125\xc2\xb0F for rare, 130-140\xc2\xb0F for medium rare, and 145\xc2\xb0F for medium.\n4 Rest the steak: When the steak has cooked to your preferred level of doneness, remove from the grill and place on a cutting board. Cover with aluminum foil to hold in the heat while the steak rests for 10 to 15 minutes.\n5 Slice across the grain: Notice the direction of the muscle fibers of the steak; this is called the grain of the meat. Flank steak is a very lean cut that will be tough and chewy unless you cut it in a way that breaks up the muscle fibers.\nSo, cut the steak across the grain of the meat, at a steep diagonal, so that the slices are wide. I find it easiest to use a long serrated bread knife for this, but any long sharp knife will do.\nIf you want, you can take the excess marinade and bring it to a boil, simmer for several minutes, and serve with the flank steak. Great also with salsa or horseradish sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nAsian Beef Lettuce Wraps Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 10 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutes - 24 hoursYield: 4-6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade/dipping sauce:\n1/2 cup low sodium soy sauce\n3 tablespoons lime juice\n2 teaspoons fish sauce\n2 teaspoons Sriracha or other hot sauce (or to taste)\n1 teaspoon sesame oil\n3 tablespoons dark brown sugar\n2 tablespoons finely chopped peeled ginger root\n1 teaspoon finely chopped garlic\n2 scallions, finely sliced\n1 1/2 pounds flank steak\nFor the wraps:\n6 ounces rice noodles (any kind)\nLeaves from 1 head Boston or red leaf lettuce\n4 scallions, thinly sliced\n4 radishes, thinly sliced\n2 Persian cucumbers, thinly sliced\n1/2 cup roasted peanuts\nHandful of fresh cilantro leaves\nHandful of fresh mint leaves\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the marinade/dipping sauce: In a small bowl, combine the soy sauce, lime juice, fish sauce, sriracha, sesame oil, brown sugar, ginger, garlic, and scallions. You will use some of it for the marinade and some for the dipping sauce.\n2 Marinate the steak: Place the steak in a shallow dish. Pour 1/3 cup of the marinade over the steak and set the remaining marinade aside to use later as the dipping sauce.\nTurn the steak to coat it in the marinade. Let the steak marinate at room temperature for 30 minutes, turning the steak once or twice, or cover it and let the steak marinate for up to 24 hours in the refrigerator.\nIf you refrigerate the meat, let it come to room temperature before grilling.\n3 Cook the rice noodles: Follow the cooking directions on the package of noodles. (Individual manufacturers\xe2\x80\x99 instructions vary.) Drain the noodles in a colander and rinse under cold running water, tossing with your hands, to remove the excess starch and prevent the noodles from sticking together.\n4 Grill the steak: Light a charcoal grill or turn a gas grill to high (about 450\xc2\xbaF). Grill the steak for 3 to 5 minutes per side for medium-rare (135\xc2\xbaF). The exact timing will depend upon the heat of the individual grill and the thickness of your steak.\nFor best results, use an instant read thermometer inserted into the center of the steak: 125\xc2\xbaF for rare, 135\xc2\xbaF for medium rare, 145\xc2\xbaF for medium.\n5 Rest and slice the steak: Transfer the steak to a cutting board, cover with foil, and let rest for 10 minutes. Thinly slice it across the grain.\n6 Arrange the ingredients on a platter: Tear the lettuce leaves into large pieces, removing the stiff stem ends.\nArrange the lettuce leaves, scallions, radish, cucumbers, peanuts, mint, and cilantro on a large platter around the sliced steak, rice noodles, and dipping sauce. This allows each person to build his or her own wrap.\n7 To make one wrap: Set a lettuce leaf on a plate. Place some rice noodles and steak slices over the leaf, and top with scallions, cilantro, mint, radishes, cucumbers, and peanuts. Roll or fold and serve with dipping sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nRosemary Olive Steak Kabobs Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutesYield: 8 skewers; 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound sirloin steak, cut into thin 2-inch strips (or use beef labeled "stir-fry beef")\n1 1/2 cups mixed black and green pitted olives\n1/3 large red onion, cut into pieces\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\n2 tablespoons minced fresh rosemary\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\nFlat-leaf parsley, for serving\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate the meat: Combine the steak strips, olives, onion pieces, olive oil, lemon juice, rosemary, salt, and pepper into a bowl. Stir to combine everything. Place in the refrigerator to marinate for 30 minutes. If using wood skewers, place in water at this time.\n2 Assemble the skewers: When ready to grill, thread pieces of beef, onion, and olives onto the skewers. For longer pieces of beef, make an "S" shape as you thread onto the skewers.\n3 Heat the grill: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to high heat, about 500\xc2\xb0F or until you can hold your hand above the grate for 1 to 2 seconds.\n4 Grill the steak skewers: When your gas or charcoal grill is hot, use tongs to oil the grill grates with a small folded piece of paper towel dipped in oil.\nPlace the skewers on the hot grill and cook, turning once or twice, until charred and the steak is cooked to your preferred level of doneness, about 6 minutes total for medium-rare or up to 10 minutes for well-done.\n5 Serve: Remove from the grill and place on a clean serving platter. Sprinkle with fresh parsley and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Grill the Best Burgers\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: 6 burgers\nThis recipe will make six burgers that are 1/3 pound each. The patties should be 4-inches across and 1-inch thick at the edges before cooking.\nI like hamburgers with a bit of a garlic kick, so if you prefer a subtler garlic flavor, feel free to reduce the amount to your liking or eliminate altogether.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds 80/20 ground beef, cold\n4 cloves minced garlic\n2 tablespoons minced onion\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n1 3/4 teaspoons freshly ground pepper\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n6 hamburger buns\nButter for buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the burger mix: Put the cold ground beef in mixing bowl. Sprinkle the other ingredients evenly over top. Fold the meat over a few times to get everything incorporated. This entire process should only take about 30 to 45 seconds. Don\xe2\x80\x99t over handle the meat.\n  2 Shape the burger patties: Rather than forming the patties in your hand, form them on a tray. This makes it easier to shape the patties without over-handling or warming the meat. I like to use a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper, but any tray or platter will do.\nOn the tray, divide the meat into 6 equal parts (about 5 1/4 ounces each). Gently form each portion into a patty that is 4-inches across with 1-inch sides and a shallow depression in the middle (see photos below). You want the outer 1/2 inch of the patty to be slightly taller than the inside. This keeps the patty from shrinking too much and from puffing up in the center during grilling\nCover the patties with plastic wrap and transfer to the fridge while you heat up your grill and butter your buns.\n  3 Heat the grill: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to 450 to 500\xc2\xb0F, or hot enough that you can only hold your hand above the grill grates for about 1 second.\nButter the insides of all the buns and set them near the grill.\n4 Grill the burgers: Place patties on the grill over direct heat. Cook to your desired doneness:\nFor rare burgers, cook for 4 minutes total (125\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium-rare burgers, cook for 5 minutes total (135\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium burgers, cook for 6 to 7 minutes total (145\xc2\xb0F)\nFor well-done burgers, cook for 8 to 9 minutes total (160\xc2\xb0F)\nFlip the burgers at least once during cooking, or as often as you wish. Do not press down on the patties at any time.\n  5 Add the cheese and toast the buns: When you have about 1 minute left on the cooking time, add the cheese to the burgers and the buttered buns to the grill over indirect heat.\n6 Rest the burgers: Remove burgers and buns from grill and transfer to a clean platter. Let the burgers rest for 1 minute before serving.\n7 Serve: Serve with tomato jam, mayonnaise, bacon jam, garlic aioli, blue cheese sauce, saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms, Thousand Island, or the classic and always wonderful lettuce, tomato, pickles and red onion.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCorned Beef and Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nCorned beef is cured in a salt mixture, so it can be very salty, depending on the source. We recommend first bringing the corned beef to a boil in plain water, and discarding the water, (repeat for less salt), before proceeding with the baked version.\nINGREDIENTS\nCorned Beef (baked)\n3 pounds corned beef (in package)\n10 whole cloves\n1/4 cup hot sweet honey mustard\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\nCorned Beef (boiled)\n3 pounds corned beef (in package, including spice packet)\nCabbage (saut\xc3\xa9ed)\nExtra virgin olive oil and butter\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n1 cloves garlic, minced\n1 large head of cabbage, sliced into 3/8-inch to 1/2-inch wide slices\nSalt\nCabbage (boiled)\n1 large head of cabbage, sliced into 3/8-inch to 1/2-inch wide slices\nAdditional vegetables such as a couple carrots (cut to 1 inch pieces) or several new potatoes (quartered)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nCorned Beef (Baked)\n1 Lightly boil to remove excess salt: Take the corned beef from the package and discard the spice packet. Note that one side of the roast should have a layer of fat, the other side should have distinct lines indicating the grain of the beef.\nCorned beef can be very salty, especially when baked. To remove some of the salt before cooking, place it in a pot fat side up. Cover with water, bring to a boil, and discard the water. Repeat to remove even more salt.\n2 Top with cloves, honey mustard, brown sugar: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Lay the corned beef, fat side up, on a large piece of heavy duty, wide, aluminum foil (you may have to get creative with the way you wrap the beef if your foil isn't wide enough).\nInsert the cloves into the top of the slab of corned beef, evenly spaced. Spread the top with the hot sweet honey mustard. Sprinkle brown sugar over the top.\n3 Wrap in foil and bake: Wrap the corned beef with foil in a way that allows for a little space on top between the corned beef and the foil, and creates a container to catch the juices. Place foil-wrapped corned beef in a shallow roasting pan and bake for 2 hours at 350\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Add more honey mustard, broil: Open the foil wrapping, spread a little more honey mustard over the top of the corned beef, and broil it for 2-3 minutes, until the top is bubbly and lightly browned.\n5 Slice: Let rest for 5 to 10 minutes, then place on cutting board. Pull out and discard the cloves.\nLift the corned beef up to see which direction the grain of the meat is.  Then cut the meat at a diagonal, across the grain of the meat, into 1/2-inch thick slices.\nServe immediately.\nCorned Beef (Boiled)\n1 Place corned beef in a large (6 to 8 quart) pot. Cover the beef with an inch water. Add the contents of the spice packet to the water. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer.\nSimmer for 2-3 hours, until the corned beef is fork tender. Remove from pot to a cutting board. (Reserve cooking liquid for boiling cabbage, if you plan to boil and not saut\xc3\xa9 the cabbage.)\nCut slices across the grain, into 1/2-inch thick slices. Serve.\nCabbage (Saut\xc3\xa9ed)\n1 Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil (enough to well coat the pan) on medium high to high heat in a large, wide pot (8-quart if available) or large, high-sided saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Add chopped onions, cook for a couple of minutes, then add garlic.\n2 Add a third of the sliced cabbage to the pan. Sprinkle with a little salt and stir to coat with oil and mix with onions.\nSpread out the cabbage evenly over the bottom of the pan and do not stir until it starts to brown. If the heat is high enough, this should happen quickly. The trick is to have the burner hot enough to easily brown the cabbage, but not so hot that it easily burns.\nWhen the bottom of the cabbage is nicely browned, use a metal spatula to lift it up and flip it, scraping the browned bits as you go.\n3 Once the cabbage in the pan has browned on a couple of flips, add another third of the cabbage to the pan. Mix well, then spread out the cabbage and repeat. Add a bit of butter to the pan for flavor, and to keep the cabbage from sticking too much to the pan. Once this batch has cooked down a bit and browned, add the remaining third of the cabbage and repeat.\nServe with the corned beef. Serve with boiled new potatoes. Can be made ahead and reheated.\nCabbage (Boiled)\n1 Once you have removed the corned beef from the pot, add the cabbage and any other vegetables (carrots, new potatoes) to the pot. Taste the liquid. If it is too salty, add more water to the pot. Raise the heat until the liquid is simmering well. Simmer until the cabbage and any other vegetables are cooked through, 15-30 minutes.\nPlace vegetables in a serving bowl, add a little of the cooking liquid to the bowl.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEasy Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds potatoes (about 3 large potatoes), peeled and quartered\n8 Tablespoons (1 stick) butter\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1-2 cups vegetables\xe2\x80\x94diced carrots, corn, peas\n1 1/2 lbs ground round beef\n1/2 cup beef broth\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\nSalt, pepper, other seasonings of choice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the potatoes: Place the peeled and quartered potatoes in medium sized pot. Cover with at least an inch of cold water. Add a teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until tender (about 20 minutes).\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 vegetables: While the potatoes are cooking, melt 4 tablespoons of the butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until tender, about 6 to 10 minutes.\nIf you are including vegetables, add them according to their cooking time. Carrots should be cooked with the onions, because they take as long to cook as the onions do.\nIf you are including peas or corn, add them toward the end of the cooking of the onions, or after the meat starts to cook, as they take very little cooking time.\n3 Add the ground beef, then Worcestershire sauce and broth: Add ground beef to the pan with the onions and vegetables. Cook until no longer pink. Season with salt and pepper.\nAdd the Worcestershire sauce and beef broth. Bring the broth to a simmer and reduce heat to low. Cook uncovered for 10 minutes, adding more beef broth if necessary to keep the meat from drying out.\n4 Mash the cooked potatoes: When the potatoes are done cooking (a fork can easily pierce), remove them from the pot and place them in a bowl with the remaining 4 Tbsp of butter. Mash with a fork or potato masher, and season with salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Layer the meat mixture and mashed potatoes in a casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Spread the beef, onions, and vegetables (if using) in an even layer in a large baking dish (9x13 casserole).\nSpread the mashed potatoes over the top of the ground beef. Rough up the surface of the mashed potatoes with a fork so there are peaks that will get well browned. You can even use a fork to make creative designs in the mashed potatoes.\n6 Bake in oven: Place in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven and cook until browned and bubbling, about 30 minutes. If necessary, broil for the last few minutes to help the surface of the mashed potatoes brown.\n(Be careful when broiling using Pyrex or glass dishes, they have been known to shatter under the high heat of the broiler. It's not a worry if you are using a ceramic or metal casserole dish.)\nSuggested variations:\nPut a layer of creamed corn between the ground beef and the mashed potatoes.\nSprinkle grated cheddar cheese over the top of the mashed potatoes before baking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nHow to Grill the Best Burgers\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: 6 burgers\nThis recipe will make six burgers that are 1/3 pound each. The patties should be 4-inches across and 1-inch thick at the edges before cooking.\nI like hamburgers with a bit of a garlic kick, so if you prefer a subtler garlic flavor, feel free to reduce the amount to your liking or eliminate altogether.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds 80/20 ground beef, cold\n4 cloves minced garlic\n2 tablespoons minced onion\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n1 3/4 teaspoons freshly ground pepper\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n6 hamburger buns\nButter for buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the burger mix: Put the cold ground beef in mixing bowl. Sprinkle the other ingredients evenly over top. Fold the meat over a few times to get everything incorporated. This entire process should only take about 30 to 45 seconds. Don\xe2\x80\x99t over handle the meat.\n  2 Shape the burger patties: Rather than forming the patties in your hand, form them on a tray. This makes it easier to shape the patties without over-handling or warming the meat. I like to use a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper, but any tray or platter will do.\nOn the tray, divide the meat into 6 equal parts (about 5 1/4 ounces each). Gently form each portion into a patty that is 4-inches across with 1-inch sides and a shallow depression in the middle (see photos below). You want the outer 1/2 inch of the patty to be slightly taller than the inside. This keeps the patty from shrinking too much and from puffing up in the center during grilling\nCover the patties with plastic wrap and transfer to the fridge while you heat up your grill and butter your buns.\n  3 Heat the grill: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to 450 to 500\xc2\xb0F, or hot enough that you can only hold your hand above the grill grates for about 1 second.\nButter the insides of all the buns and set them near the grill.\n4 Grill the burgers: Place patties on the grill over direct heat. Cook to your desired doneness:\nFor rare burgers, cook for 4 minutes total (125\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium-rare burgers, cook for 5 minutes total (135\xc2\xb0F)\nFor medium burgers, cook for 6 to 7 minutes total (145\xc2\xb0F)\nFor well-done burgers, cook for 8 to 9 minutes total (160\xc2\xb0F)\nFlip the burgers at least once during cooking, or as often as you wish. Do not press down on the patties at any time.\n  5 Add the cheese and toast the buns: When you have about 1 minute left on the cooking time, add the cheese to the burgers and the buttered buns to the grill over indirect heat.\n6 Rest the burgers: Remove burgers and buns from grill and transfer to a clean platter. Let the burgers rest for 1 minute before serving.\n7 Serve: Serve with tomato jam, mayonnaise, bacon jam, garlic aioli, blue cheese sauce, saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms, Thousand Island, or the classic and always wonderful lettuce, tomato, pickles and red onion.\nHello! b"Save It Print\nRoast Beef Tenderloin with Saut\xc3\xa9ed Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4\nBeef tenderloin is a beautiful, tender cut of beef and is what is used to make filet mignon. To make a roast from the tenderloin you can ask your butcher to cut a big center piece from a whole tenderloin, or purchase a whole tenderloin and cut it yourself for this purpose, saving the rest for filet mignon. You can find whole beef tenderloin at Costco or Sam's Club for a reasonable price.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 3/4 to 2 pound piece of beef tenderloin (preferably a piece cut from the center of the tenderloin), trimmed of excess fat and silverskin\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon coarse black pepper\n1 1/2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n  1 pound cremini mushrooms, sliced into 1/8 to 1/4-inch thick slices\n3 Tbsp butter\n1 teaspoon salt (use 1/2 teaspoon if using salted butter)\n2 Tbsp minced shallots\n2 Tbsp minced garlic\n1 1/2 teaspoons of Herbs de Provence or a teaspoon of dried tarragon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt and pepper roast, let sit at room temp: Remove roast from refrigerator 1 to 2 hours before cooking so that it has time to come close to room temperature. Sprinkle all sides with salt and pepper and set aside.\n2 Sear roast on stovetop: When ready to cook the tenderloin roast, preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Heat olive oil in a cast iron or thick-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan that can take the heat, on high heat. When the oil is hot, place the roast in the pan and brown it on all sides, including the ends, about 10 minutes.\n3 Finish cooking in oven: When sufficiently browned, remove the roast from the pan (do not clean out the pan) and place on a roasting pan.\nPlace in the oven and roast at 425F until the internal temperature is 130\xc2\xb0F for rare (140\xc2\xb0F for medium), about 20 minutes (or longer if your roast wasn't at room temp to begin with. Use a meat thermometer!\n4 Let roast rest before slicing: Remove from oven and loosely tent with foil to rest for 15 to 20 minutes before slicing.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots, garlic, mushrooms: While the roast is resting, prepare the mushrooms. Add 3 Tbsp of butter to the same pan you used to sear the beef roast. Heat on medium heat to melt the butter. Add the minced shallots and garlic, and cook for half a minute.\nStir the mushrooms into the pan and cook until they start to give off steam. Then add salt, pepper, and herbs de provence. Continue to cook until just cooked through.\nAdd a few tablespoons of warm water to the pan to scrape up any remnants from the bottom of the pan (can also use white wine or marsala). Remove from heat.\n6 Slice the roast: Use a sharp knife to slice the roast across the grain into 1/4 to 1/2-inch thick slices. Serve with the saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCorned Beef Hash Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nIf you have leftover cabbage from corned beef and cabbage, feel free to chop that up as well and add that to the hash.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 to 3 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 medium onion, finely chopped (about 1 cup)\n2 to 3 cups finely chopped, cooked corned beef\n2 to 3 cups chopped cooked potatoes, preferably Yukon gold\nSalt and pepper\nChopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions in butter: Heat butter in a large skillet (preferably cast iron) on medium heat. Add the onion and cook a few minutes, until translucent.\n2 Add potatoes and corned beef: Mix in the chopped corned beef and potatoes. Spread out evenly over the pan. Increase the heat to high or medium high and press down on the mixture with a metal spatula.\n3 Cook until browned, then flip: Do not stir the potatoes and corned beef, but let them brown. If you hear them sizzling, this is good.\nUse a metal spatula to peek underneath and see if they are browning. If nicely browned, use the spatula to flip sections over in the pan so that they brown on the other side. Press down again with the spatula.\nIf there is too much sticking, you can add a little more butter to the pan. Continue to cook in this manner until the potatoes and the corned beef are nicely browned.\n4 Stir in parsley, black pepper to serve: Remove from heat, stir in chopped parsley. Add plenty of freshly ground black pepper, and add salt to taste.\nServe with fried or poached eggs for breakfast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nGrilled Marinated Flank Steak Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesMarinating time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade Ingredients\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n1/3 cup soy sauce\n1/4 cup honey\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nOther ingredients\n2 pounds flank steak\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the steak: Combine the marinade ingredients in a large non-reactive bowl.\nPlace steak in the bowl and turn so that it is completely coated with the marinade. (You can also place the steak and marinade in a freezer bag and place it in a bowl.)\nChill and marinate for at least 2 hours and up to overnight.\n2 Prepare your grill for high, direct heat with one part of the grill for lower, indirect heat. The grill is hot enough when you hold your hand about an inch over the hot side and you can only hold it there for about a second.\n3 Grill the steak: Remove the steak from the marinade and gently shake off the excess marinade from the steak (but make sure there is still a coating of it, you'll want the oil on it to help keep the steak from sticking to the grill).\nIf you want, sprinkle generously on all sides with coarse salt and freshly ground pepper. The salt and pepper will help form a savory crust on the steak.\nPlace steak on the hot side of the grill. Grill for a minute or two on each side to get a good sear, then move the steak to the cooler side of the grill, cover and cook a few minutes more until done to your liking.\nHow do you know when the steak is done? One way to tell is to poke it with your fingertips. While the steak is still raw, test it with your fingers; it will be quite squishy. That's what a very rare steak feels like. Touch the tip of your nose and that's what a very well done steak feels like. Here's a visual guide, the finger test to check the doneness of steak.\nOtherwise use a good meat thermometer (I recommend a thermapen.)  Pull the steak off the grill at 120 to 125\xc2\xb0F for rare, 130-140\xc2\xb0F for medium rare, and 145\xc2\xb0F for medium.\n4 Rest the steak: When the steak has cooked to your preferred level of doneness, remove from the grill and place on a cutting board. Cover with aluminum foil to hold in the heat while the steak rests for 10 to 15 minutes.\n5 Slice across the grain: Notice the direction of the muscle fibers of the steak; this is called the grain of the meat. Flank steak is a very lean cut that will be tough and chewy unless you cut it in a way that breaks up the muscle fibers.\nSo, cut the steak across the grain of the meat, at a steep diagonal, so that the slices are wide. I find it easiest to use a long serrated bread knife for this, but any long sharp knife will do.\nIf you want, you can take the excess marinade and bring it to a boil, simmer for several minutes, and serve with the flank steak. Great also with salsa or horseradish sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nHome Cured Corned Beef\nPrep time: 5 daysCook time: 3 hours\nThe spice mix with the gallon of brine makes easily enough curing brine for a 5 pound brisket, cured in a somewhat large-ish container. If you were to use a 2-gallon freezer bag or marinating bag, you would likely need just half (or less) of the amount of brine and brine spices.\nPink curing salt, or sodium nitrite, goes by many names, such as Prague Powder #1 or DQ Curing Salt #1, and is available online and may be available at your local specialty market or butcher shop. If you don\'t have it, you can still make corned beef, but it is necessary for that vibrant pink color we associate with corned beef. And it adds flavor too. Without it the corned beef will be a dull grey color.\nNote that pink curing salt is NOT Himalayan pink salt. Pink curing salt is toxic and can be deadly if ingested directly, which is why it is colored pink, so consumers do not mistake it for table salt.\nINGREDIENTS\nPickling spices:\n1 tablespoon whole allspice berries\n1 tablespoon whole mustard seeds (brown or yellow)\n1 tablespoon coriander seeds\n1 tablespoon red pepper flakes\n1 tablespoon whole black peppercorns\n2 teaspoons whole cloves\n9 whole cardamom pods\n6 large bay leaves, crumbled\n2 teaspoons ground ginger\n1/2 stick cinnamon\nBrine:\n1 gallon (3.8 liters) water\n300 g Kosher salt (2 cups of Diamond Crystal brand Kosher Salt OR 1 cup 3 1/2 tablespoons of Morton\'s Kosher Salt)\n5 teaspoons pink curing salt (optional, see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons pickling spices\n1/2 cup (90 g) brown sugar\nBrisket:\n1 5-pound beef brisket\n1 tablespoon pickling spices\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast and crush spices: You can either used store-bought pickling spices or you can make your own. To make your own, toast the allspice berries, mustard seeds, coriander seeds, red pepper flakes, peppercorns, cloves, and cardamom pods in a small frying pan on medium heat until fragrant. Note that it is pretty easy to burn spices; you want enough heat to release their flavors, not so much that they get burned.\nRemove from heat and place in a small bowl. Use a mortar and pestle to crush the spices a little (or the back of a spoon or the side of a knife on a flat surface). Add to a small bowl and stir in the crumbled bay leaves and ground ginger.\n2 Make curing brine: Add about 3 Tbsp of the spice mix (reserve the rest for cooking the corned beef after it has cured), plus the half stick of cinnamon, to a gallon of water in a large pot, along with the Kosher salt, pink salt (if using), and brown sugar. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. Then refrigerate until well chilled.\n3 Brine the brisket for 5-7 days: Place the brisket in a large, flat container or pan, and cover with the brine. The brine should cover the meat. The meat may float in which case you may want to weigh it down with a plate.\nAlternatively you can use a 2-gallon freezer bag (placed in a container so if it leaks it doesn\'t leak all over your refrigerator), place the brisket in the freezer bag and about 2 quarts of brine, squeezing out the air from the bag before sealing.\nPlace in the refrigerator and chill from 5-7 days. Every day flip the brisket over, so that all sides get brined equally.\n4 Cook the corned beef: At the end of the cure, remove the brisket from the brine and rinse off the brine with cold water. Place the brisket in a large pot that just fits around the brisket and cover with at least one inch of water. If you want your brisket less salty, add another inch of water to the pot.\nAdd a tablespoon of the pickling spices to the pot. Bring to a boil, reduce to a very low simmer (barely bubbling), and cook 3-4 hours, until the corned beef is fork tender. (At this point you can store in the fridge for up to a week.)\n5 Cut across the grain: Remove the meat to a cutting board. (You can use the spiced cooking liquid to cook vegetables for boiled dinner or corned beef and cabbage.) Notice the visible lines on the meat; this is the "grain" of the meat, or the direction of the muscle fibers.\nTo make the meat easier to cut, cut it first in half, along the grain of the meat. Then make thin crosswise cuts, across the grain to cut the meat to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHow to Make Gravy\nCook time: 15 minutes\nWhen you cook a roast, whether it\'s turkey, chicken, beef, or lamb, you should end up with plenty of browned drippings and fat from the roast when it\'s finished.\nThe "drippings" are browned juices and fat. All of the flavor a gravy you make from the drippings comes from those browned bits. You need fat as a base for the gravy.\nIf you have pan juices, but they haven\'t browned at the bottom of the pan after the roast is done, you can put the empty pan back in the oven. Set the temp to 450 or 500\xc2\xb0F and cook until the juices evaporate and begin to bubble and brown at the bottom of the pan.\nIn this approach to making gravy, we break up the drippings as well as we can with a whisk, but don\'t worry about any browned bits in the gravy itself. If you want, you can pulse the gravy in a blender to make it smoother, but we never bother. The browned bits are the best part!\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMaking Gravy with Flour\n1 Remove all but 1/4 cup of fat from pan: Remove the roast from the pan. Remove excess fat leaving 4 Tbsp of fat plus juices and browned drippings in the pan.\n2 Scrape up drippings and place pan on stovetop on medium heat: Use a metal spatula to scrape up any drippings that are sticking to the pan. Place the pan on the stovetop on medium high heat.\n3 Sprinkle 4 Tbsp flour onto the drippings. Quickly stir with a wire whisk so that the flour gets incorporated into the drippings. Let the flour brown a bit if you want, before adding liquid in the next step. (You can also start with a slurry of flour and water if you want.)\n4 Whisk while slowly adding liquid: Slowly add stock, water, milk, cream, or a combination to the pan, whisking vigorously to dissolve the flour into liquid.\nAllow the gravy to simmer and thicken, and continue to slowly add liquid until you have about 2 cups of gravy. (You\'ll probably need to add 3 to 4 cups of liquid.)\n5 Season to taste with salt and pepper. (Always taste first before adding more salt! It may not need it.)\n  Making Gravy with Cornstarch\n1 Remove all but 1/4 cup of fat from pan: Remove the roast from the roasting pan. Pour off all but 4 Tbsp of the fat in the pan. If you don\'t have enough fat in the pan, add butter so that you have at least 4 Tbsp of fat in the pan.\n2 Scrape up browned drippings: While the pan is still warm, scrape the bottom of the pan with a metal spatula to loosen any browned drippings that might be stuck to the bottom of the pan.\n3 Place the pan on the stovetop on medium heat. If you are using a roasting pan that won\'t work well on the stovetop, scrape up all of the drippings and fat and put into a large shallow saut\xc3\xa9 pan.\n4 Make cornstarch slurry: Dissolve 4 Tbsp of cornstarch in the minimum amount of water needed to make a thin paste - about 1/2 cup.\n5 Pour the cornstarch slurry into the pan with drippings and use a wire whisk to blend into the drippings.\n6 Whisk while slowly adding liquid: Stir with a wire whisk until the gravy begins to thicken. As the gravy thickens, slowly add stock, water, milk, or cream, or some combination to the pan (I like to use stock, my mother usually uses water).\nAlternate stirring and adding liquid, maintaining the consistency you want, for several minutes (about 5 minutes).\nYou will probably add about 3 to 4 cups of liquid all together. Taking into consideration the evaporation that is occurring while the gravy is simmering, you will end up with about 2 cups of gravy.\nIf the gravy isn\'t thick enough, make more cornstarch slurry and whisk it into the pan.\n7 Season to taste with salt and pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nQuick and Easy Pan-Fried Flank Steak Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesSteak resting time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pound flank steak\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nDry mustard\nSoftened butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Tenderize the steak with shallow cuts: Remove the steak from the refrigerator a half hour before cooking.\nCut away any tough connective tissue on the surface of the steak.\nUsing the tip of a sharp knife, poke small cuts into the meat, almost all the way through. The cuts should be at an angle, in the direction of the grain of the meat as the knife tip is going in. The cuts should be about an inch apart from each other.\nTurn the steak over and repeat the cuts on the other side. Make sure that the cuts you are making on this side are parallel with the cuts you made on the other side, otherwise you may cut across an existing cut, and end up poking a hole through the meat.\n2 Rub with salt, pepper, dry mustard, and butter: Sprinkle one side of the steak with salt and freshly ground pepper. Sprinkle the steak with dry mustard. (You can use regular mustard if you don't have any dry mustard.)\nRub a tablespoon of butter all over the side of the steak. Turn the steak over and repeat with the dry mustard, pepper, and butter.\n3 Sear steak in hot frying pan: Heat a large cast iron frying pan on high heat. Place steak in hot pan. Let sear for 2 to 3 minutes until well browned.\nUse tongs to lift up to see if nicely browned. If so, flip to the other side and let sear for 2 to 3 minutes.\n4 Remove from heat: Remove the pan from the heat and let the steak continue to cook for 5 to 10 minutes in the residual heat of the pan (assuming you are using cast iron, if not, lower the heat to low).\n5 Check for doneness: Use your fingertips to check for doneness or insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the steak - 120\xc2\xb0F for very rare, 125\xc2\xb0F for rare, or 130\xc2\xb0F for medium rare. Flank steak should be served rare or medium rare, otherwise it may be too dry.\nIf the steak isn't done enough to your liking, return the steak and pan to medium high heat for a few minutes.\n6 Let the steak rest: Remove the steak from the pan to a cutting board and let rest for 10 minutes, covered with aluminum foil.\n7 Thinly slice: Cut the meat in very thin slices, at an angle, across the grain of the meat. (This way you break through the tough long muscle fibers.)\n8 Boil juices, deglaze pan, add butter to make sauce: Any juices that come out of the meat while cutting or resting, return to the pan. Return the pan to a burner on high heat and deglaze the pan with a little water, scraping up any browned bits. Once the water has mostly boiled down, add a little butter to the pan for a nice sauce.\nArrange the cut meat on a serving plate and pour the deglazed pan juices over the meat.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nNew England Boiled Dinner Recipe\nCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nCorned beef can be pretty salty, so if you are making boiled dinner with corned beef you may want to put it in a pot, cover with cold water, bring to a boil, and then discard the water before starting the recipe. If the broth ends up being too salty, you can serve just the meat and vegetables, without the broth, or add water to the broth to dilute it.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds corned beef brisket or plain beef brisket\n15 peppercorns\n8 whole cloves\n1 bay leaf\nSalt, if using plain brisket\n2 medium sized turnips, peeled and quartered\n4 red new potatoes, peeled and quartered\n3 large carrots, cut into thirds and the thickest pieces quartered lengthwise\n1 small head cabbage, cut into fourths\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put corned beef in a pot, cover with water, add seasonings, simmer: Put the brisket in a 5 or 6 quart Dutch oven and cover with an inch of water.\nIf you are using corned beef brisket and it does not come already packed in seasoning, add peppercorns, cloves, and a bay leaf to the pot.\nIf using plain brisket, add a teaspoon of salt for every quart of water.\nBring to a simmer and then cover, lower the heat until it is barely simmering. Keep at a low simmer for four hours or until the meat is tender (a fork goes through easily).\n2 Remove meat, add vegetables, simmer: Remove the meat and set aside, keeping the meat warm. Add the vegetables to the pot. Check the broth for taste. If it is too salty, add a little more water to taste.\nRaise the temperature and bring the soup to a high simmer. Cook at a high simmer until done, about 15-30 minutes longer, depending on the size of the cut of your vegetables.\n\n3 Slice meat across the grain: Slice the meat in thin slices across the grain. You may find it easier to slice if you first cut the roast in half along the same direction as the grain of the meat. Then slice smaller lengths across the grain.\n\nServe in bowls, a few pieces of meat in each, add some of the vegetables and some broth. Serve with horseradish or mustard or both.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nSlow Cooker Guinness Beef Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nIf you would prefer to make the stew in the oven, cook everything in a large Dutch oven. After you add the liquid, bring it to a simmer on the stovetop then put it, tightly covered, in a 225\xc2\xb0F oven for 6 hours (or a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 4 hours).\nNote that different people have different sensitivities to bitter flavors. If Guinness Stout tastes bitter to you, then the stew will taste bitter as well. If it doesn\'t taste bitter to you, the stew should not taste bitter.\nYou can either use celery root, young turnips, or potatoes in addition to parsnips and carrots. If you use turnips, make sure you only use young turnips, which are smaller and sweeter than regular turnips. Regular turnips can be quite bitter.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp butter\n2 pounds (900 g) well marbled chuck beef roast, cut into 2-inch pieces\nSalt\n2 cups chopped onion (about 1 large onion)\n2 celery stalks, chopped\n2 Tbsp tomato paste\n1 pint (16 ounces, 475 ml) Guinness extra stout (make sure you use extra stout and not draught)\n3 cups (700 ml) beef broth\n2 large carrots, peeled and cut into chunks\n3 to 4 parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks\n1/2 pound (280 g) celery root, potatoes, or very young turnips, peeled and cut into chunks\n2 teaspoons dried thyme\n4 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart or larger slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef, transfer to slow cooker: Heat the butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Brown the beef in the butter, starting with the fattiest pieces of meat, fat side down in the pan. This will allow some beef fat to render out. Work in batches as to not crowd the pan.\nSprinkle salt over the beef as it browns. Once browned on all sides, transfer the beef pieces into a 6-quart or larger slow cooker.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and celery, transfer to slow cooker: Add the onions and celery to the pan in which you just browned the beef. Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and celery until they begin to brown at the edges, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the tomato paste and mix well. Cook for a minute or two, then add a little of the Guinness, enough to make it easier for you to scrape up any browned bits at the bottom of the pan.\nTransfer the celery and onions into the slow cooker.\n3 Add Guinness, broth, root vegetables, thyme, salt: Add the rest of the Guinness, the beef broth, carrots, parsnips, celery root, and thyme to the slow cooker. Add two teaspoons of salt.\n4 Cook in slow cooker: Cover and cook on "high" for 4 hours, or "low" for 8 hours. When done, add more salt to taste. If you want, sprinkle with fresh parsley to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Guinness Beef Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 20 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings\nIf using a stovetop pressure cooker:\nDo steps 1 to 3 on the stovetop.\nSecure the lid on the pressure cooker, bring up to high pressure, then turn down the heat and let the stew cook for 25 minutes at high pressure. Let the pressure release naturally completely, or allow the pressure to release naturally for at least 10 minutes before performing a quick pressure release.\nAdd the root vegetables, then cook the stew under pressure for two more minutes.\nPerform a quick pressure release and open the pot. Stir in the cornstarch slurry right away while stew is still bubbling. Serve.\nLooking for a slow cooker version? Here you go!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds beef stew meat\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons butter or neutral flavored oil\n1 large (8 ounce) onion, chopped\n2 celery stalks, chopped\n2 tablespoons tomato paste\n1 cup Guinness extra stout, or other stout\n1 1/2 cups beef broth\n1 teaspoon dried thyme or 2 teaspoons fresh thyme leaves\n2 large carrots, peeled and cut into chunks\n3 to 4 parsnips (about 1 pound), peeled and cut into chunks\n1/2 pound potatoes, rutabaga, or celery root, peeled and cut into chunks\n2 teaspoons cornstarch\n2 teaspoons water\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot, or other electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the meat: Pat the pieces of beef dry with a paper towel, then season them on all sides with the salt and pepper.\nSelect the high \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d setting on the electric pressure cooker and heat the butter or oil. Brown the beef in the butter in two batches, searing the pieces for 4 minutes per batch and flipping them halfway through cooking.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t worry about trying to sear every side of the beef\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re just trying to get some browning on the beef and some flavor developing in the pot. Use a pair of tongs to transfer the meat to a dish.\n2 Cook the onions and celery: Add the onions and celery to the now-empty pressure cooker. Cook until the onions begin to soften and turn translucent, about 4 minutes. Stir in the tomato paste and cook for another minute.\n3 Add the liquids to the pot: Pour in the Guinness. Use a stiff spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot. Let it simmer for five minutes to reduce the beer a bit, then stir in the reserved beef, beef broth, and thyme.\n4 Pressure cook the meat: Secure the lid on the pressure cooker and make sure it\xe2\x80\x99s set to its \xe2\x80\x9csealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Cancel the cooking program, then select the Meat/Stew,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting, and set the cooking time to 30 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the actual cooking time begins.)\nWhen the cooking program finishes, let the pressure release naturally for 10 minutes, then release the remaining pressure by moving the pressure vent to its \xe2\x80\x9cventing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nAt this point, you may also leave the stew on the \xe2\x80\x9cKeep Warm\xe2\x80\x9d setting for up to 10 hours, before continuing with the rest of the recipe. The beef will become more tender the longer it sits.\n5 Add the root vegetables and pressure cook: When the pressure has released, open the pot. (Optional: for a leaner stew, you can use a ladle or spoon to skim off some of the fat.) Stir in the carrots, parsnips, and root vegetables.\nPut the lid back on the pressure cooker and make sure it\xe2\x80\x99s set to its \xe2\x80\x9csealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Cancel the cooking program, then select the \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting and set the cooking time to 3 minutes at high pressure.  (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the actual cooking time begins.)\n6 While the stew is finishing, mix the cornstarch and water together in a small bowl to make a slurry.\n7 Finish the stew: When the cooking program ends, perform a quick pressure release by moving the pressure vent to its \xe2\x80\x9cventing\xe2\x80\x9d position. (It\'s also ok if you need to leave the stew on the "Warm" setting for a little while before venting the pressure and serving, though the vegetables will eventually start to get mushy if left too long.)\nStir in the cornstarch slurry right away while stew is still bubbling. The residual heat will thicken the stew within a couple minutes.\n8 Serve: Ladle the stew into bowls and serve it hot, with fresh parsley sprinkled on top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Taco Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesSlow cooking time: 6 to 7 hoursYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 pound (450g) lean ground beef\n1 1/2 cups (180g) diced yellow or red onions\n2 to 3 cups (475ml to 710ml) chicken or beef broth (use more if you want a thinner soup)\n1 15-oz. (425g) can diced tomatoes\n1 15-oz. (425g) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1 15-oz. (425g) can kidney beans, drained and rinsed\n1 4-oz. (115g) can chopped green chiles\n1 1/4 cups (135g) corn kernels, fresh or frozen\n2 1/2 teaspoons chili powder\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon paprika\n1 teaspoon salt\nTo serve:\nTortilla chips, lightly crushed\nSour cream\nChopped cilantro\nFinely diced red onion\nLime juice\nChopped red onions\nSpecial equipment:\n4-quart or larger slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef with the onions (can be done a day or two ahead): Heat the olive oil in a large skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add beef and onions and cook 2 to 3 minutes, until the ground beef is browned but not completely cooked and the onions are starting to look soft around the edges. Use your spatula to break up the ground beef into smaller pieces as it cooks. Remove from heat and use immediately, or refrigerate for a day or two until needed.\n2 Combine and cook: Combine the browned beef, onions and the remaining soup ingredients in a slow cooker and stir. Cover and cook on low for 6 to 7 hours. It\'s fine if the soup cooks a little longer or the slow cooker switches to the "warm" setting.\n3 Serve the soup: Serve soup in bowls and top with crushed tortilla chips, sour cream, cilantro, red onion and lime juice.\nThis soup will keep refrigerated for 1 week or frozen for up to 3 months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nAlbondigas Soup (Mexican Meatball Soup) Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nIf fresh mint is not available, you can use a couple teaspoons of dried mint from herbal mint tea.\nYou can vary the vegetables depending on what you have on hand. Spring peas in their pods instead of shucked peas, for example. Or you could add some chopped fresh zucchini or corn.\nMy mother often puts a couple extra tablespoons of chopped fresh mint directly into the soup.\nFeel free to substitute ground turkey for the ground beef, we do it often.\nUse spearmint or Mexican yerba buena for the mint in this soup (not peppermint).\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, chopped\n1 large garlic clove, minced\n2 quarts of chicken stock or beef stock\n1 quart of water\n1/2 cup of tomato sauce\n1/2 pound of green beans, strings and ends removed, cut into 1 inch pieces\n2 large carrots, peeled and sliced\n1/3 cup of raw white rice\n1 pound ground beef\n1/4 cup (loosely packed) chopped fresh spearmint leaves\n1/4 cup (loosely packed) chopped parsley\n1 egg\n1 1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nA dash of cayenne (optional)\n1 1/2 cup of frozen or fresh peas\n1 teaspoon of dried oregano, crumbled, or 1 tablespoon fresh chopped oregano\nSalt and pepper\n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the soup base with onion, garlic, broth, tomato sauce, carrots and green beans: Heat oil in large heavy-bottomed pot (5-qt) over medium heat. Add onion and cook until tender, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook a minute more. Add stock, water, and tomato sauce. Bring to boil and reduce heat to simmer. Add carrots and string beans.\n2 Prepare the meatballs: Mix rice into meat, adding mint leaves and parsley, salt and pepper. Mix in raw egg. Form mixture into 1-inch meatballs.\n3 Add meatballs to soup, let simmer, add peas: Gently add the meatballs to the simmering soup, one at a time. Cover and let simmer for 1/2 hour.\nAdd the peas towards the end of the 1/2 hour. Add a few pinches of oregano and sprinkle with salt and pepper, and a dash of cayenne, to taste.\nGarnish with chopped fresh cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBeef Noodle Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 medium white onion, peeled and chopped, about 1 1/2 cups\n1 bell pepper, seeded, ribs removed, finely chopped, about 1 cup\n3 cloves garlic, minced, about 1 tablespoon\n1 28-ounce can whole peeled or crushed tomatoes\n1 1/2 pounds ground beef\nSalt\n4 ounces mushrooms, sliced\n12 ounces egg noodles\n1 1/2 cups frozen corn, defrosted\n1 15-ounce can of black olives, strained and chopped\n8 ounces cheddar cheese, grated\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven and start heating water: Pre-heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F and start to heat a large pot of salted water (1 Tbsp salt, 2 quarts water) for cooking the egg noodles.\n2 Make tomato sauce base: Heat 1 Tbsp of oil on medium high heat in a large, heavy bottomed pot or skillet. Add the onions and bell pepper and saut\xc3\xa9 until softened, about 4 minutes. Add garlic and cook for a minute more.\nAdd the tomatoes, breaking them up with your fingers or a knife if you are using whole canned tomatoes. Bring to a simmer and let cook for 10 minutes. Lower the heat to warm.\n3 Brown the ground beef: In a separate skillet, add 1 Tbsp of oil and heat to medium-high. Working in batches, so you do not crowd the pan, add the ground beef, breaking it up with your fingers as you add it to the pan.\nDo not stir the ground beef, but let it sit and cook for a minute or two until it browns on one side.\nSprinkle a little salt over the meat while cooking.\nOnce browned on one side, turn the pieces over to get the other side browned. Once the meat is mostly browned (can still be rare in the center), remove the beef from the pan and add to the tomato onion mixture.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the mushrooms: Add the mushrooms to the same pan that you had used for browning the beef, and saut\xc3\xa9 the mushrooms in the remaining oil and beef drippings. Once browned, add the mushrooms to the beef and tomato mixture.\n5 Cook the egg noodles: While the mushrooms are cooking, add the egg noodle pasta to the boiling water. Cook as directed, about 4-5 minutes. Strain when cooked, but still a little firm (al dente).\n6 Add everything to casserole dish: Add the cooked egg noodles to a large  (3 quart) casserole dish. (If your casserole dish isn't big enough, you may need to use 2 casserole dishes.)\nStir in the tomato beef mixture. Stir in the corn, chopped olives, and about two thirds of the cheese.\n7 Bake: Sprinkle remaining cheese on top of casserole. Place in the oven. Bake uncovered at 350\xc2\xb0F for 30 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nSwedish Meatballs Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4 to 6 as a main, 8 to 12 as an appetizer\nLingonberry jelly is traditionally used with Swedish meatballs; you can substitute cranberry, red currant or raspberry jelly if you can't find lingonberry jelly.\nThis recipe serves 4 to 6 people and can easily be doubled for serving a party.\nINGREDIENTS\nMeatballs:\n1 Tbsp butter\n1/2 large yellow or white onion, peeled, grated (use the large holes of a box cheese grater)\n1/4 cup milk\n3 slices of bread, crusts removed, bread cut into cubes (2 cups of cubed bread)\n1 large egg\n3/4 pound ground beef\n1/2 pound ground pork\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg\n1/2 teaspoon ground cardamom\nSauce:\n3 Tbsp butter\n3 Tbsp flour\n2 cups beef stock\n1/4 cup sour cream (use full-fat sour cream or the sauce may curdle)\nSalt and pepper\n2 Tbsp of Lingonberry, red currant, raspberry or cranberry jelly, less or more to taste (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak bread in milk, shred: Place the cubed bread in a large bowl and mix with the milk. Let sit for 5 to 10 minutes for the bread to absorb all of the milk. Once the bread has soaked up the milk, shred with the tines of a fork or by hand.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 grated onion: Melt the butter in a saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium-high heat. Stir in the grated onion and cook until translucent and softened, 3-4 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool for a minute.\n3 Make meatball mixture with bread, onions, eggs, meat, spices: Stir the cooled onions into the milk bread mixture. Add the eggs, ground pork and beef, salt, pepper, nutmeg, and cardamom. Use your (clean) hands to mix everything together until well combined.\n(If you have extra time, chilling the mixture for 20 minutes or so will make it easier to roll out the meatballs.)\n4 Form meatballs: Use your hands to form the mixture into meatballs about 1 1/4-inch to 1 1/2-inch wide and place them on a plate or sheet pan. This recipe should make about 40 meatballs. Note that the meatballs will be a bit on the wet side.\n5 Brown meatballs on all sides: Heat 3 Tbsp of butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. When the butter is melted and foamy, start adding some meatballs to the pan.\nWorking in batches as to not crowd the pan, slowly brown the meatballs on all sides. Use a spoon or tongs to turn them. Handle the meatballs gently so they do not break apart as you turn them.\n   Once the meatballs have browned on all sides and are just cooked through, remove them from the pan to a bowl. You'll warm the meatballs in the sauce later.\nOnce you have removed the meatballs from the pan, wipe out the butter and browned and blackened bits with a paper towel and rinse out the pan.\nWe'll want to start with fresh butter because that way we won't pick up any burnt bits from the pan, and we will be able to more accurately gauge the amount of fat in the pan for making the meatball sauce in the next step.\n6 Make a roux: To make the sauce, first make the roux. Add 3 Tbsp of fresh butter to the pan. Heat the butter in the pan on medium heat until it melts and starts to bubble up.\nSlowly whisk in 3 Tbsp of flour. Stir until smooth. Continue to stir, allowing the flour mixture to cook, several minutes, until the roux is the color of coffee-with-cream.\n   7 Add stock to roux to make sauce: When the roux has cooked to a lovely shade of light brown, slowly add the stock to the roux, stirring as you add the stock.\nThe stock will sputter at first and the roux may seize up, but keep adding the stock slowly and keep stirring. Eventually the sauce will loosen and become silky.\n8 Stir in sour cream and jelly if using: Remove the pan from heat and stir in the sour cream. If you are including jelly, either stir it in now or serve it on the side. Taste for seasonings and add more salt and pepper to taste (I use about 1/2 teaspoon of kosher salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of pepper.)\n9 Add meatballs to sauce: Return the meatballs to the pan with the sauce and cook on low heat to warm the meatballs through for a few minutes.\n10 Serve: Serve over mashed potatoes or egg noodles. Or serve individual Swedish meatballs dipped in gravy as an appetizer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBeef and Broccoli Ramen Stir Fry Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the stir fry sauce:\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger\n1/3 cup soy sauce\n1/4 cup honey\n1/4 cup hoisin sauce\n3/4 cup beef broth\n2 tablespoons rice vinegar\n2 tablespoons sesame oil\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\nFor the stir fry:\n2 (3-ounce) packages dried ramen noodles, seasoning packets discarded\n2 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 pound sirloin steak, trimmed of fat and sliced into 1/4-inch thick strips\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n3 cups fresh broccoli florets\nSesame seeds, garnish\nSriracha, garnish (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n12-inch anodized wok\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the stir fry sauce: Add garlic and ginger to a bowl and whisk in soy sauce through sesame oil. Whisk in cornstarch last, and try to whisk out as many lumps as possible. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay if there are a few lumps, as they will cook out when you add the sauce to the skillet.\nThis makes a lot, because I like this dish to be very saucy. You could halve the recipe if you like a drier stir fry. If you have leftover sauce, it stores well in the fridge for a week in an airtight container or jar.\n2 Prepare the noodles: Cook dry ramen noodles in boiling water until they are tender, 2 to 3 minutes. Drain the noodles and rinse with cold water to stop them from cooking.\n3 Cook the stir fry: In a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat, add 1 tablespoon olive oil. Season the steak with 1/2 teaspoon salt and pepper.\nOnce the skillet is glistening hot, add the steak strips. Cook for about 3 minutes, undisturbed, to allow them to sear well on one side. Then stir and continue to cook for 2 to 3 more minutes, until the steak is cooked through.\nRemove the steak from skillet, and add another tablespoon of olive oil and the broccoli florets. Add 1/2 cup of water to the skillet and cover. Steam broccoli for 2 minutes. Broccoli should be bright green and tender, and not mushy at all.\nAdd the steak back to the skillet, along with cooked and rinsed noodles. Pour in all of the sauce. (If you prefer a drier stir fry, you can start with half the sauce.) Use tongs or a large rubber spatula to stir together ingredients as sauce cooks. Cook for another 2 to 3 minutes until sauce thickens.\n5 Serve: Serve stir fry immediately, garnished with sesame seeds and, optionally, sriracha.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nPressure Cooker Shepherd's Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nChanges I Made to This Cookbook Recipe:\nI used beef instead of lamb\nI used chicken stock instead of vegetable stock (it's what I had!)\nTaste the mashed potatoes and the filling for seasoning and add salt if needed (I used roughly double the amount of salt as indicated in the recipe)\nReprinted with permission from The Ultimate Instant Pot Cookbook, copyright 2018 by Coco Morante. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon avocado oil or other neutral oil with high smoke point\n1 pound ground lamb or beef\n1 yellow onion, diced\n1 celery stalk, diced\n1 large carrot, diced\n1 garlic clove, minced\n1 1/4 teaspoons kosher salt\n1 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n1 tablespoon tomato paste\n1 cup vegetable broth\n1 cup frozen peas\n4 medium russet potatoes, peeled (about 2 1/2 pounds)\n1/2 cup whole milk\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric pressure cooker, such as the Instant Pot\nSteam rack for pressure cookers\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the meat: Select the Saut\xc3\xa9 setting on the Instant Pot and heat the avocado oil. Add the lamb and saut\xc3\xa9, breaking it up with a wooden spoon or spatula, for about 7 minutes, until cooked through and no traces of pink remain.\nSet a colander in a bowl. Wearing heat-resistant mitts, lift out the inner pot and pour the lamb into the colander, letting it drain. Return the inner pot to the Instant Pot housing. (Note from Emma: I just scooped out the meat with a slotted spoon and then poured off all but a tablespoon of fat, which I used for sauteing the vegetables.)\n2 Cook the vegetables and stir in the meat: Add the onion, celery, carrot, garlic, and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt to the pot and saut\xc3\xa9 for about 4 minutes, until the onion is translucent. (Note from Emma: As the onions release moisture, use that to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. More flavor!)\nStir in the thyme, pepper, Worcestershire, and tomato paste. Return the lamb to the pot, then add the vegetable broth and peas.\n3  Add the potatoes: Place a tall steam rack in the pot, making sure all of its legs are resting firmly on the bot\xc2\xadtom. Place the potatoes in a single layer on the rack.\n4 Pressure cook the filling and the potatoes together: Secure the lid and set the Pressure Release to Sealing. Press the Cancel button to reset the cooking program, then select the Pressure Cook or Manual program and set the cooking time for 15 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 15 minutes to come up to pres\xc2\xadsure before the cooking program begins.)\n5 Vent the pressure: When the cooking program ends, perform a quick pressure release by moving the Pressure Release to Venting.\n6 Mash the potatoes: Using tongs, transfer the potatoes to a bowl. Add the milk and remaining 3/4 teaspoon salt, then use a potato masher to mash the potatoes until smooth. (Note from Emma: If the filling seems a little liquidy at this point, put the Instant Pot on the Saut\xc3\xa9 function and let it simmer while you mash the potatoes.)\nWearing heat-resistant mitts, remove the steam rack from the pot. Stir 1/2 cup of the mashed potatoes into the lamb mixture in the pot. (Note from Emma: Taste both the mashed potatoes and the filling at this point, and add more salt if needed.)\n7 Assemble the casserole: Transfer the lamb mixture to a broiler-safe 8-inch square baking dish, dollop the mashed potatoes on top, and spread them out with a fork, creating a surface texture.\nNote: If you like, instead of assembling and broiling the pie, you can simply serve the lamb mixture with the mashed potatoes on the side.\n8 Broil the casserole: Broil the shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s pie in a toaster oven (or a conventional oven) for about 5 minutes, checking often, until the potatoes are lightly browned.\n9 Serve: Spoon the shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s pie onto plates and serve immediately.\nNote from Emma: Leftovers will keep for about a week in the fridge and can be warmed in a low oven or in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nBest Ever Sloppy Joes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nSave time on prep by pulsing roughly chopped veggies in a food processor.\nBrown the meat well. Don't crowd the pan, work in batches, and don't stir the meat until it is well browned on one side.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup minced carrots (can sub chopped bell pepper)\n1 cup finely chopped onion (about 1 medium onion)\n1/2 cup finely chopped celery\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 1/4 pound ground beef\n1/2 cup ketchup\n2 cups tomato sauce (or 1 15-ounce can whole tomatoes, pur\xc3\xa9ed)\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n1 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n1 1/2 tablespoons brown sugar\nPinch ground cloves\n1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\nPinch cayenne pepper\n2 turns of freshly ground black pepper\n4 hamburger buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the carrots, onions, celery, and garlic: Heat olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the minced carrots and saut\xc3\xa9 for 5 minutes. (If you are using bell pepper instead of carrots, add those at the same time as the onions.)\nAdd the chopped onion and celery. Cook, stirring occasionally until onions are translucent, about 5 more minutes.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook for 30 more seconds. Remove from heat. Remove vegetables from the pan to a medium sized bowl, set aside.\n2 Brown the ground beef: Using the same pan (or you can cook the meat at the same time as the vegetables in a separate pan to save time), crumble the ground beef into the pan. If you are using extra lean beef, you may need to add a tablespoon of olive oil to the pan. Sprinkle the meat with salt.\nDo not stir the ground beef, just let it cook until it is well browned on one side. Then flip the pieces over and brown the second side.\nIf you're cooking in batches, use a slotted spoon to remove the ground beef from the pan (can add to the set-aside vegetables) and repeat with the rest of the ground beef.\nWhen the meat is done cooking, strain off all but 1 tablespoon of any fat left in the pan.\n3 Make the sloppy joe mix: Return the cooked ground beef and vegetables to the pan. Use a wooden spoon to break up any chunks of ground beef into smaller bits.\nAdd the ketchup, tomato sauce, Worcestershire sauce, vinegar, and brown sugar to the pan. Stir to mix well. Add ground cloves, thyme, and cayenne pepper.\nLower the heat to medium low and let simmer for 10 minutes.
