Adjust seasonings to taste.\n4 Serve the sloppy joes: Serve immediately, or refrigerate to make ahead and reheat to serve. Serve with toasted hamburger buns.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Bourbon Short Ribs with Cheesy Grits Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 8 hoursYield: 6 servings\nFor a gluten free version of this dish, toss the short ribs in a light dusting of gluten-free flour or cornstarch before browning.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the short ribs:\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n3 to 4 pounds bone-in beef short ribs\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 large shallot, sliced\n2 stalks celery, chopped\n2 large carrots, chopped\n2 cups beef broth\n1/4 cup bourbon\n1/4 cup brown sugar\n2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce\n2 cloves garlic\n1 bay leaf\nOrange zest, for garnish\nFor the cheesy grits:\n1 cup coarse ground corn grits\n4 cups chicken or vegetable stock\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n2 tablespoons butter\n1 cup grated cheddar cheese\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Quickly brown the short ribs: Toss flour with salt and pepper and coat ribs well in the mixture.\nHeat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the short ribs and brown well on all sides, working in batches so as to not crowd the pan.\nWhen the short ribs are browned well, transfer them to a slow cooker.\n2 Scrape up the pan drippings: Add the shallot, carrots, and celery to the skillet along with 1/2 cup of water. Use the liquid to scrape up any bits stuck to the pan.\nTransfer the vegetables (they don\xe2\x80\x99t need to be fully cooked) to the slow cooker along with any liquid from the skillet.\n3 Slow cook the short ribs and veggies: Add beef broth, bourbon, brown sugar, Worcestershire, garlic, and bay leaf to the slow cooker. Cover and cook on low for 8 hours (or high for 5 to 6 hours).\n4 Cook the grits: When there\xe2\x80\x99s about thirty minutes left on the short ribs, heat the stock in a medium pot over medium heat until it\xe2\x80\x99s simmering.\nWhisk in corn grits in a steady stream. Turn the heat down to low, and cover the pot and simmer for about 20 minutes until grits are thick and tender. Stir regularly to prevent sticking.\nThe only way to truly know when grits are done is to taste them. If they are crunchy, keep going and if you need to add more liquid, then do so.\nWhen the grits are soft, add salt, pepper, butter, and cheese and stir to combine. Keep warm until ready to serve. If the grits get too thick (they hold their shape if stirred and don\xe2\x80\x99t flow back into a single layer), add water by the 1/4 cup to loosen the grits.\n5 Serve: Divide the grits onto between plates and top each plate with a short rib. Add the veggies and a few spoonfuls of juice from the slow cooker as well and garnish with fresh orange zest.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nEasy Beef Brisket Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 pounds of a brisket cut of beef\n3/4 cup barbecue sauce\n1/4 cup soy sauce\n1 cup of water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 300\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Make the sauce: In a bowl, mix together the barbecue sauce, soy sauce, and water.\n3 Roast the brisket in the oven (2 methods):\nFoil method: Place a large piece of aluminum foil in a roasting pan. Add the brisket and spread the BBQ sauce mixture generously over meat. Wrap the brisket in the aluminum foil so it's well sealed, like a package.\nBake for 3 hours for a 3 pound roast and 1 more hour for every additional pound of meat.\nOR, instead of foil, you can use an oven roasting bag:\nOven roasting bag method: Place the barbecue sauce and the brisket in an oven roasting bag. Sprinkle a teaspoon of flour into the bag. Poke a couple small holes in the bag. Place the bag in a roasting pan. You may find that the cooking time is faster with this method, or you can reduce the oven temperature to 275\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Let the brisket rest: Remove from oven and let rest in the foil for 30 minutes before serving.\n5 Slice across the grain of the meat: The easiest way to serve the roast is to first cut it in half along the grain of the meat (poke the meat with the tip of a knife or tines of a fork to see which way the grain or lines of the muscles are going if you can't see it from the surface).\nThen make 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch thick cuts across the grain to serve. (Cutting the meat across the grain will make it much easier to eat, as the cuts break up the muscle tissue.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBeef Brisket Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 8-12\nINGREDIENTS\n4 to 5 pound (about 2 kg) beef brisket, flat cut or point cut\nSalt\n1 to 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 large onions, sliced\n5 to 6 garlic cloves, minced\n1 sprig thyme\n1 sprig rosemary\n3 to 4 bay leaves\n2 cups beef stock\n2 to 3 large carrots, peeled and cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces\n1 tablespoon mustard (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the brisket: On one side of the brisket there should be a layer of fat, which you want. If there are any large chunks of fat, cut them off and discard them. Large pieces of fat will not be able to render out completely.\nUsing a sharp knife, score the fat in parallel lines, about 3/4-inch apart. Slice through the fat, not the beef. Repeat in the opposite direction to make a cross-hatch pattern.\nSalt the brisket well and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n2 Sear the brisket: You\'ll need an ovenproof, thick-bottomed pot with a cover, or Dutch oven, that is just wide enough to hold the brisket roast with a little room for the onions.\nPat the brisket dry and place it, fatty side down, into the pot and place it on medium high heat. Cook for 5 to 8 minutes, lightly sizzling, until the fat side is nicely browned. (If the roast seems to be cooking too fast, turn the heat down to medium. You want a steady sizzle, not a raging sear.)\nTurn the brisket over and cook for a few minutes more to brown the other side.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and garlic: When the brisket has browned, remove it from the pot and set aside. There should be a couple tablespoons of fat rendered in the pot. If not, add some olive oil.\nAdd the chopped onions and increase the heat to high. Sprinkle a little salt on the onions. Saut\xc3\xa9, stirring often, until the onions are lightly browned, 5 to 8 minutes. Stir in the garlic and cook 1 to 2 more minutes.\n4 Simmer the brisket and roast it: Preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C). Use kitchen twine to tie together the bay leaves, rosemary and thyme.\nMove the onions and garlic to the sides of the pot and nestle the brisket inside. Add the beef stock and the tied-up herbs. Bring the stock to a boil on the stovetop. Cover the pot, then place in the 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C) oven. Cook for 3 hours. Carefully flip the brisket every hour so it cooks evenly.\n5 Add carrots, continue to cook: After 3 hours, add the carrots. Cover the pot and cook for 1 hour more, or until the carrots are cooked through and the brisket is falling-apart tender.\n6 Remove brisket: When the brisket is falling-apart tender, take the pot out of the oven and remove the brisket to a cutting board. Cover it with foil. Pull out and discard the herbs.\n7 Make sauce (optional): At this point you have two options. You can serve as is, or you can make a sauce with the drippings and some of the onions. If you serve as is, skip this step.\nTo make a sauce, remove the carrots and half of the onions, set aside and cover them with foil. Pour the ingredients that are remaining into a blender, and pur\xc3\xa9e until smooth. If you want, add 1 tablespoon of mustard to the mix. Put into a small pot and keep warm.\n8 Slice and serve: Notice the lines of the muscle fibers of the roast. This is the "grain" of the meat. Slice the meat perpendicular to these lines, or across the grain (cutting this way further tenderizes the meat), in 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch slices. (A sturdy bread knife works great for slicing roasts.)\nServe with the onions, carrots and gravy. Serve with mashed, roasted or boiled potatoes, egg noodles, or polenta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nHow to Make Beef Stock\nYield: Makes about 4 quarts\nINGREDIENTS\n4-5 pounds meaty beef stock bones (with lots of marrow), including some knuckle bones if possible, cut to expose the center marrow, and include at least a couple veal bones if you can, for their gelatin\n1 pound of stew meat (chuck or flank steak) and/or beef scraps, cut into 2-inch chunks\nOlive oil\n1-2 medium onions, peeled and quartered\n1-2 large carrots, cut into 1-2 inch segments\nHandful of celery tops, or 1 large celery rib, cut into 1 inch segments\n2-3 cloves of garlic, unpeeled\nHandful of parsley, stems and leaves\n1-2 bay leaves\n10 peppercorns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the meat, bones, and vegetables:  Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Rub a little olive oil over the stew meat pieces, carrots, and onions. Place stock bones, stew meat or beef scraps, carrots and onions in a large, shallow roasting pan.\nRoast in oven for about 45 minutes, turning the bones and meat pieces half-way through the cooking, until nicely browned. If bones begin to char at all during this cooking process, lower the heat. They should brown, not burn.\nWhen the bones and meat are nicely browned, remove them and the vegetables and place them in a large (12 to 16 quart) stock pot.\n2 Add hot water and scrape up the browned bits: Place the roasting pan on the stove-top on low heat (will cover 2 burners), pour 1/2 cup to a cup of hot water over the pan and use a metal spatula to scrape up all of the browned bits stuck to the bottom of the pan.\nPour the browned bits and water into the stock pot.\n3 Add vegetables, water, bring to a low simmer: Add celery tops, garlic, parsley, bay leaves, and peppercorns to the stock pot.\nFill the stock pot with cold water, to 1 to 2 inches over the top of the bones. Put the heat on high and bring the pot to a low simmer and then reduce the heat to low.\nIf you have a candy or meat thermometer, the temperature of the water should be between 180\xc2\xb0 and 200\xc2\xb0F (boiling is 212\xc2\xb0F). The stock should be at a bare simmer, just a bubble or two coming up here and there. (You may need to put the pot on your smallest burner on the lowest temp, or if you are using an oven-safe pot, place it in the oven at 190\xc2\xb0F.)\nCover the pot loosely and let simmer low and slow for 3-6 hours.\nDo not stir the stock while cooking. Stirring will mix the fats in with the stock, clouding up the stock.\n4 Skim scum and fat: As the stock cooks, fat will be released from the bone marrow and stew meat and rise to the top. From time to time check in on the stock and use a large metal spoon to scoop away the fat and any scum that rises to the surface.\n(Do not put this fat down your kitchen drain. It will solidify and block your pipes. Put it in a bowl or jar to save for cooking or to discard.)\n5 Remove solids and strain: At the end of cooking time (when you want to end the cooking is up to you, 3 hours minimum, 6 to 8 hours if you can do it) use a slotted spoon or spider ladle to gently remove the bones and vegetables from the pot (discard them, though if you see a chunk of marrow, taste it, it's delicious).\nLine another large pot (8-quart) with a fine mesh sieve, covered with a couple layers of cheesecloth if you have it.\nPour the stock through the sieve to strain it of remaining solids.\n6 Chill: Let cool to room temperature then chill in the refrigerator.\nOne the stock has chilled, any fat remaining will have risen to the top and solidified. The fat forms a protective layer against bacteria while the stock is in the refrigerator. If you plan to freeze the stock however, remove and discard the fat, pour the stock into a jar or plastic container. (You can also remove the fat, and boil the stock down, concentrating it so that it doesn't take as much storage space.) Leave an inch head room from the top of the stock to the top of the jar, so that as the stock freezes and expands, it will not break the container.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nChicken Fried Steak Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 quarter-pound cube steaks (pre-tenderized) or round steaks\nA sprinkling of salt for pre-salting the meat\n2 cups flour, for breading\n2 teaspoons Kosher salt, for breading\n1 1/2 teaspoons garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon cayenne\n2 large eggs, beaten\n1/2 cup milk\nCanola oil, peanut oil, extra virgin olive oil, or other fat for frying\nGravy:\n3 tablespoons pan drippings\n3 tablespoons flour\n1/4 cup whipping cream\n1 3/4 cups milk\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n  METHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pound steaks to an even thinness: If you are using round steak instead of the pre-tenderized cube steak, you will need to pound the steaks thin or they will be way too chewy. (Already tenderized cube steaks can also use some meat mallet attention to get more thin.)\nPlace each steak between two pieces of plastic wrap. Using a meat mallet, rubber mallet, rolling pin, or empty wine bottle, beat the steak until it is very thin, less than 1/4-inch.\nAs you beat the steak, you will want to turn over often, and spread out the plastic wrap which tends to wrinkle as you work.\n2 Salt meat, warm the oven: Sprinkle a little salt over the meat. Preheat the oven to 200\xc2\xb0F.  In the oven put a wire rack over a baking sheet. This will keep the finished steaks warm and dry while you cook the gravy.\n3 Dredge steaks in flour, egg, and flour again: Prepare two wide, shallow dishes such as a pyrex casserole dish. In the first  whisk together the eggs and milk. In the second, whisk together the flour, salt, cayenne, and garlic powder.\nWorking one at a time, dredge a steak into the flour. Using the heel of your hand, press the flour into both sides of the steak.\nLift up the steak, shake off the excess flour and dip the steak into the egg wash, coating it on both sides.\nLift the steak out of the egg wash, shake off the excess egg wash, and then dredge the steak again in the flour. Again, press the flour into the steak on both sides.\nSet aside on a plate. Repeat with remaining steaks.\n4 Fry the steaks: Pour enough oil in a large frying pan to cover the bottom by 1/4-inch. Heat the oil to 350\xc2\xb0F or when you drop a little flour into the oil it sizzles. If the oil doesn't sizzle it isn't ready, if it burns, the oil is too hot, reduce the heat.\nWorking one at a time, lay a flour-egg-coated steak into the hot oil. Gently shake the pan a little to wash a little hot oil on the top of the steak. Or you can use a metal spoon to spoon some of the oil over the steak. This sets the coating.\nFry until you see the edges of the steak turn golden brown, about two minutes. Carefully turn the steak over in the pan, and fry for two more minutes.\nOnce both sides of the steak are golden brown, tip the steak up with a metal spatula to drain the excess oil. Remove it from the pan and place if on the wire rack in the oven to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining steaks.\n5 Make a roux with fat and flour: Turn off the heat of the pan. Pour out all but about 3 tablespoons of fat from the pan. Whisk in 3 tablespoons of flour and turn the heat on to medium.\nLet the flour mixture cook until it's the color of milk chocolate, about 4 to 5 minutes, stirring constantly.\n6 Stir in milk and cream to make gravy: When the flour fat mixture is smooth and a lovely milk chocolate color, slowly add the milk and cream, whisking constantly. Note that the mixture will seize up initially, and will loosen as you whisk in more liquid.\nAdd milk to your desired thickness for gravy. If the gravy is too thick for you, add more milk. If it's too thin, let it cook longer.\nSeason with salt to taste. Season with lots of black pepper, to taste.\n7 Serve: Serve chicken fried steak with the gravy and a side of mashed potatoes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nPenne Pasta with Meat Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound penne pasta (use rice pasta for gluten-free version)\nSalt\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups chopped onion (from about 1 large onion)\n2 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 teaspoon Italian seasoning (blend of dried basil, oregano, rosemary, thyme, marjoram, and savory)\nDash red pepper flakes\n1/2 teaspoon fresh thyme (or a pinch of dried)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\n1 pound (16% fat) ground beef\n3 fresh basil leaves, chopped (or a 1/2 teaspoon of dried)\n2 1/2 cups canned chunky tomato sauce (almost 1 28-ounce can, Muir Glen brand if you can get it)\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the penne pasta: Heat to boiling a large pot with 4 quarts of water in it. Once the water is boiling, salt it with 2 Tbsp of salt. Once the water returns to a boil add the pasta to the pot.\nLeave uncovered, let cook on high heat with a vigorous boil. Put the timer on for 8-10 minutes, or whatever your pasta package says is appropriate for al dente (cooked but still a little firm). Drain.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, with seasonings: Once you've started to heat the water, start working on the sauce. Heat olive oil in a very large skillet on medium heat. Add the chopped onion, Italian seasoning and red pepper flakes.\nCook for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are softened. Add the garlic, fresh thyme, season with salt and pepper. Cook for an additional minute, until the garlic is fragrant. Remove from heat and set aside.\n3 Brown the ground beef: Heat a large cast iron pan on high heat. Salt the bottom of the pan generously. Once the pan is hot, break up small chunks of ground beef and add them to the pan, without stirring. (You may need to work in batches; do not crowd the pan.) You want the meat to get well browned.\nIf the pan is too hot and the meat is burning, not browning, take the pan off the heat for a little, and reduce the heat to medium high. On our coil electric stove, it takes the high heat setting for the meat to brown sufficiently, but your stove may be different.\nOnce the meat is browned on one side (a couple of minutes), use a metal spatula to flip the meat over to brown on the other side. At this point, assuming you are using a cast iron pan, you can remove the pan from the heat. The residual heat in the pan will finish cooking the meat.\n4 Add beef and tomato sauce to onions: Use a slotted spoon to lift the meat from the cast iron pan and add it to the pan with the seasoned onions.\nAdd tomato sauce. Use the edge of your metal spatula to break up the bigger chunks of meat into smaller pieces.\nAdd basil. Add a teaspoon of sugar. Bring to a simmer on low heat, let cook, uncovered, for 15 minutes.\n5 Adjust seasonings and add the pasta: Once the sauce has simmered for 15 minutes, adjust seasonings. Add salt and pepper to taste. Add a little more sugar if the sauce is too acidic. Add more tomato sauce if the sauce is a little dry. Stir in the cooked penne pasta. Sprinkle with chopped parsley. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSous Vide Beef Tenderloin with Port Wine and Garlic Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nOne and half pounds of beef will comfortably feed four people; two pounds will feed six. You can stretch it to feed a few more people if you are serving the tenderloin with several other dishes on the table.\nWhen buying your tenderloin roast, make sure the butcher removes the silver skin. Also ask them to truss the roast with twine. You can do both of these steps yourself, but it\'s one less thing for you to worry about back home!\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds center-cut beef tenderloin (See Recipe Note)\n1 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided\n2 tablespoons butter\n1/2 cup tawny port wine\n4 to 5 medium cloves garlic\n5 to 6 sprigs fresh thyme, plus extra to serve\nSpecial equipment:\n10-inch stainless steel or cast iron skillet\nJoule, or other sous vide immersion circulator\n1-gallon zip-top freezer bag\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the beef tenderloin: Sprinkle the tenderloin with salt and a generous amount of pepper. Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat. When the pan is hot enough, a drop of water should sizzle and quickly evaporate on contact.\nSear the tenderloin in the pan until it\'s dark brown all over, 1 to 2 minutes on each side and both ends. Transfer to a plate or cutting board and allow to cool slightly.\n2 Make the port-garlic sauce: While the pan is still hot, add the butter and garlic. Cook until the garlic is golden and fragrant, 30 to 60 seconds.\nAdd the port wine and use a stiff spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Let the wine come to a simmer, then remove from heat.\n3 Seal the tenderloin in a zip-top freezer bag: Make sure the tenderloin and sauce are no longer steaming. It\'s fine if they are still quite warm, but they can melt through the bag if they\'re still steaming hot.\nPlace a gallon-sized zip-top freezer bag on your counter and flip the zip-top edge outward, forming a cuff around the bag. This helps the bag stay open and upright as you fill it.\nTransfer the tenderloin to the bag and pour the sauce over top. Lay 5 or 6 sprigs of thyme over the top of the tenderloin.\nFill a stock pot with 5 or 6 inches of water. Slowly submerge the tenderloin in the water, using your hands to help push out all the air from the bag as you go. When you reach the top of the bag, zip it closed.\nLift the tenderloin out of the water and place it on a towel while you heat the water for the sous vide.\nRead more about this method here.\n4 Heat the water for sous vide cooking: Place your Joule or other sous vide immersion circulator in the stockpot of water. Set the sous vide immersion circulator to heat the water to 133\xc2\xb0F for rare beef, 140F for medium-rare (my preference), 149\xc2\xb0F for medium-well, or 167\xc2\xb0F for well-done.\n5 Cook the tenderloin sous vide for 2 1/2 to 3 hours: When the water has heated to its required temperature, lower the tenderloin into the water so that it is entirely submerged. It\'s ok if the top of the bag pokes out of the water as long as the tenderloin itself is submerged.\nCook for 2 1/2 to 3 hours, but avoid cooking for much longer or the beef will start to get a little soft and mushy.\n6 Sear the tenderloin a second time: When the tenderloin is done, lift it from the water and place the bag on a kitchen towel. Heat the remaining tablespoon of oil in the skillet over medium-high heat until a drop of water sizzles and evaporates on contact.\nUse tongs to lift the roast from the bag and transfer it to the skillet. Be careful\xe2\x80\x94it will sputter! Sear for 30 to 60 seconds on all sides, until the outside is even more deeply browned and a crust has formed.\nTransfer the tenderloin to a cutting board and rest for 5 to 10 minutes.\n7 Deglaze the pan: With the pan still over medium-high heat, pour in the sauce directly from the bag into the pan (discard the sprigs of thyme). Simmer for about a minute and scrape up any browned bits stuck to the bottom of the pan. Carefully transfer the sauce to a serving cup.\n8 Slice and serve the tenderloin: Cut through the twine and discard. Slice the tenderloin either into thick "filet mignon" steaks (one steak per person), or into thinner "roast beef" slices (3 or 4 slices per person). Serve immediately with the sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHamburger and Macaroni Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups uncooked macaroni (use rice pasta or gluten-free pasta for gluten-free version)\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 pound ground beef\n1 yellow onion, chopped (or mixed chopped green onion greens and yellow onion)\n1/2 teaspoon seasoned salt\nPinch chili pepper flakes\n1/2 teaspoon celery seed\n1 large can (28 oz) of diced tomatoes\n2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nSalt  and freshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Start cooking the pasta: Get a large pot of salted hot water (1 tablespoon of salt for 2 quarts of water) heating and begin cooking the macaroni as per the directions on the macaroni package.\n2 Brown the beef and onions: While the water is heating and macaroni cooking, prepare the sauce. In a skillet, brown the ground beef in a tablespoon of olive oil on high heat. Stir only infrequently so that the ground beef has an opportunity to brown.\nWhen the beef has mostly browned, add the onions to the pan and toss to combine. Cook until the onions are soft, about 4-6 minutes.\n3 Add seasonings, tomatoes: Add the celery seed, a dash of crushed red pepper and seasoned salt. Pour in canned tomatoes, add the Worcestershire sauce and stir to combine. Simmer for 5 minutes.\n4 Add cooked pasta: Reserve a half cup of the pasta cooking water. Mix in the drained and cooked macaroni and the parsley. Cook for another 5 minutes. Add in some of the pasta water if the dish is too dry.\nAdd freshly ground black pepper and salt to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nItalian Meatballs Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes about 16 meatballs. Serves 8\nWe've used equal amounts of ground beef and ground pork. You could also use a third each of ground beef, pork and veal.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the meatballs:\n1 pound ground beef (at least 16 percent fat)\n1 pound ground pork\n2/3 cup milk (whole or 2 percent)\n3 slices of white bread, crusts removed (about 3 ounces)\n1/4 cup ricotta cheese\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan or Romano cheese\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon salt (or 2 teaspoons of kosher salt)\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley\n2 teaspoons black pepper\n1 teaspoon dried oregano or marjoram\n2-3 garlic cloves, minced\nAbout 1 cup flour, for dusting\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 1/2 cups (24 ounces) tomato sauce (recipe follows, or use already prepared)\nTomato Sauce:\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3/4 cup finely chopped onions\n3/4 cup finely chopped carrots\n3/4 cup finely chopped celery\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 28-oz can crushed or whole tomatoes, including the juice, or 1 3/4 pound of fresh tomatoes, peeled, seeded, and chopped\n1/2 teaspoon dried basil or 2 Tbsp chopped fresh basil\n1 teaspoon tomato paste\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the tomato sauce: Heat olive oil in a large skillet on medium heat. Add the onions, carrots, celery, and parsley. Stir to coat with the oil, reduce the heat to low and cover the pan. Cook for 15 to 20 minutes until the vegetables are soft and cooked through.\nRemove the cover, add the garlic, and increase the heat to medium high. Cook the garlic for half a minute, then add the tomatoes (if using whole canned tomatoes, break up with your fingers as you add them to the pan). Add the tomato paste and basil. Season with salt and pepper.\nBring to a low simmer, reduce the heat to low and let cook uncovered until thickened while you prepare the meatballs, 15 to 30 minutes.\nPur\xc3\xa9e in a blender, or push through a food mill for a smooth consistency. Return to pan. Adjust seasonings.\n2 Soak torn bread in hot milk: Heat the milk in a small pot until steamy. Turn off the heat, tear the bread into little pieces and soak it in the milk until it partially dissolves. Mash it until you get something that resembles a paste. Turn it out onto a plate to let it cool.\n3 Make meatball mixture: In a large bowl, combine the beef, pork, ricotta cheese, grated Parmesan, eggs, salt, parsley, oregano, black pepper, garlic cloves and the bread-milk mixture. Mix it well with your hands until it barely combines.\nDon't overwork the mixture or it will become tough. It is OK to have some discernible bits of bread or meat in the mix; better that than overworked meatballs.\n4 Form meatballs: Wet your hands and form the meatballs. A traditional size for this sort of meatball is 2-3 inches across, but you can make them any size you want.\nOnce you roll the meatball in your hands, roll it in the flour to give it a good coating. Set each one on a baking sheet as you work. You might need to rinse your hands a few times as you make the meatballs.\n5 Brown meatballs: When all the meatballs are formed, heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Brown the meatballs on at least two sides. Don't worry about the center getting cooked through, as you will finish these in the sauce.\n6 Finish cooking meatballs in tomato sauce: Once all the meatballs are browned, arrange them in the sauce, turning each one over in the sauce to coat.\nCover the pot and simmer gently for 15-20 minutes. Serve with the sauce and pasta or crusty bread. Sprinkle with a little chopped parsley for garnish if you want.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nRoast Beef Tenderloin with Saut\xc3\xa9ed Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4\nBeef tenderloin is a beautiful, tender cut of beef and is what is used to make filet mignon. To make a roast from the tenderloin you can ask your butcher to cut a big center piece from a whole tenderloin, or purchase a whole tenderloin and cut it yourself for this purpose, saving the rest for filet mignon. You can find whole beef tenderloin at Costco or Sam's Club for a reasonable price.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 3/4 to 2 pound piece of beef tenderloin (preferably a piece cut from the center of the tenderloin), trimmed of excess fat and silverskin\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon coarse black pepper\n1 1/2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n  1 pound cremini mushrooms, sliced into 1/8 to 1/4-inch thick slices\n3 Tbsp butter\n1 teaspoon salt (use 1/2 teaspoon if using salted butter)\n2 Tbsp minced shallots\n2 Tbsp minced garlic\n1 1/2 teaspoons of Herbs de Provence or a teaspoon of dried tarragon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt and pepper roast, let sit at room temp: Remove roast from refrigerator 1 to 2 hours before cooking so that it has time to come close to room temperature. Sprinkle all sides with salt and pepper and set aside.\n2 Sear roast on stovetop: When ready to cook the tenderloin roast, preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Heat olive oil in a cast iron or thick-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan that can take the heat, on high heat. When the oil is hot, place the roast in the pan and brown it on all sides, including the ends, about 10 minutes.\n3 Finish cooking in oven: When sufficiently browned, remove the roast from the pan (do not clean out the pan) and place on a roasting pan.\nPlace in the oven and roast at 425F until the internal temperature is 130\xc2\xb0F for rare (140\xc2\xb0F for medium), about 20 minutes (or longer if your roast wasn't at room temp to begin with. Use a meat thermometer!\n4 Let roast rest before slicing: Remove from oven and loosely tent with foil to rest for 15 to 20 minutes before slicing.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots, garlic, mushrooms: While the roast is resting, prepare the mushrooms. Add 3 Tbsp of butter to the same pan you used to sear the beef roast. Heat on medium heat to melt the butter. Add the minced shallots and garlic, and cook for half a minute.\nStir the mushrooms into the pan and cook until they start to give off steam. Then add salt, pepper, and herbs de provence. Continue to cook until just cooked through.\nAdd a few tablespoons of warm water to the pan to scrape up any remnants from the bottom of the pan (can also use white wine or marsala). Remove from heat.\n6 Slice the roast: Use a sharp knife to slice the roast across the grain into 1/4 to 1/2-inch thick slices. Serve with the saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBeef Brisket Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 8-12\nINGREDIENTS\n4 to 5 pound (about 2 kg) beef brisket, flat cut or point cut\nSalt\n1 to 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 large onions, sliced\n5 to 6 garlic cloves, minced\n1 sprig thyme\n1 sprig rosemary\n3 to 4 bay leaves\n2 cups beef stock\n2 to 3 large carrots, peeled and cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces\n1 tablespoon mustard (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the brisket: On one side of the brisket there should be a layer of fat, which you want. If there are any large chunks of fat, cut them off and discard them. Large pieces of fat will not be able to render out completely.\nUsing a sharp knife, score the fat in parallel lines, about 3/4-inch apart. Slice through the fat, not the beef. Repeat in the opposite direction to make a cross-hatch pattern.\nSalt the brisket well and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n2 Sear the brisket: You\'ll need an ovenproof, thick-bottomed pot with a cover, or Dutch oven, that is just wide enough to hold the brisket roast with a little room for the onions.\nPat the brisket dry and place it, fatty side down, into the pot and place it on medium high heat. Cook for 5 to 8 minutes, lightly sizzling, until the fat side is nicely browned. (If the roast seems to be cooking too fast, turn the heat down to medium. You want a steady sizzle, not a raging sear.)\nTurn the brisket over and cook for a few minutes more to brown the other side.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and garlic: When the brisket has browned, remove it from the pot and set aside. There should be a couple tablespoons of fat rendered in the pot. If not, add some olive oil.\nAdd the chopped onions and increase the heat to high. Sprinkle a little salt on the onions. Saut\xc3\xa9, stirring often, until the onions are lightly browned, 5 to 8 minutes. Stir in the garlic and cook 1 to 2 more minutes.\n4 Simmer the brisket and roast it: Preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C). Use kitchen twine to tie together the bay leaves, rosemary and thyme.\nMove the onions and garlic to the sides of the pot and nestle the brisket inside. Add the beef stock and the tied-up herbs. Bring the stock to a boil on the stovetop. Cover the pot, then place in the 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C) oven. Cook for 3 hours. Carefully flip the brisket every hour so it cooks evenly.\n5 Add carrots, continue to cook: After 3 hours, add the carrots. Cover the pot and cook for 1 hour more, or until the carrots are cooked through and the brisket is falling-apart tender.\n6 Remove brisket: When the brisket is falling-apart tender, take the pot out of the oven and remove the brisket to a cutting board. Cover it with foil. Pull out and discard the herbs.\n7 Make sauce (optional): At this point you have two options. You can serve as is, or you can make a sauce with the drippings and some of the onions. If you serve as is, skip this step.\nTo make a sauce, remove the carrots and half of the onions, set aside and cover them with foil. Pour the ingredients that are remaining into a blender, and pur\xc3\xa9e until smooth. If you want, add 1 tablespoon of mustard to the mix. Put into a small pot and keep warm.\n8 Slice and serve: Notice the lines of the muscle fibers of the roast. This is the "grain" of the meat. Slice the meat perpendicular to these lines, or across the grain (cutting this way further tenderizes the meat), in 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch slices. (A sturdy bread knife works great for slicing roasts.)\nServe with the onions, carrots and gravy. Serve with mashed, roasted or boiled potatoes, egg noodles, or polenta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nItalian Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 4 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 to 4 pound rump or chuck beef roast\n1 teaspoon salt plus more to taste\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 large carrot, diced (about 1 cup)\n1 large celery stalk, diced (about 1 cup)\n1 medium red onion, diced (1 to 1 1/2 cups)\n2 garlic cloves, finely minced\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley\n1 bay leaf\n1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh sage\n3 cups medium-bodied Italian red wine (we used a Barbera)\n1 28-ounce can Italian plum tomatoes, put through a food mill to remove the seeds\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the roast: Trim some of the fat from the meat. Pat dry with paper towels. Season generously with the salt and pepper. Heat the oil in a large, heavy pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat.\nWhen the oil is hot, shimmering but not smoking, add the roast and cook, turning it a few times, until it is nicely browned on all sides, 10-12 minutes.\nTransfer the meat to a platter.\n2 Add vegetables: Reduce the heat to medium. Add the carrot, celery, and onion. Cook, stirring occasionally until the vegetables are golden brown and begin to stick to the bottom of the pan, 10-12 minutes.\nAdd the garlic, parsley, and sage, and stir until the herbs are lightly colored and fragrant, about 1 minute.\n3 Deglaze the pan with wine, return meat to the pan: Add 1 cup of the wine and stir quickly, lifting up the richly browned caramelized vegetables that stick to the bottom of the pan.\nWhen the wine is almost all evaporated and thickly coats the vegetables, return the meat to the pan and turn it over a few times to coat it with the savory base.\n4 Add remaining ingredients, simmer until tender: Raise the heat to high, adding the remaining wine, the bay leaf, and the tomatoes, and bring to a boil. Cover the pot, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, turning and basting the meat every half hour or so, until the meat is very tender and flakes away when pierced with a fork, 3-4 hours.\n5 Turn off the heat and let the roast sit in its juices for an hour. (You can also put the pot into a 300\xc2\xb0F oven and turn the roast every hour.)\n6 Remove meat, reduce sauce: Remove the meat from the pot and place it on a cutting board, covered loosely with aluminum foil. If the sauce is too thin, bring it to a fast boil and reduce it until it has a medium-thick consistency. Taste and adjust seasoning.\n7 Cut the meat into thick slices (it will probably fall apart), and place on warm serving dishes. Spoon the sauce over the meat and serve hot. Serve with rice, mashed potatoes, or polenta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSous Vide French Dip Sandwiches Recipe\nPrep time: 45 minutesCook time: 18 to 24 hoursYield: 6 to 8 sandwiches\nLook for top or bottom round roast for this recipe since these cuts are less fatty and easier to cut into thin slices. Use chuck roast if round roast can\'t be found and cut thicker slices.\nThe roast from this recipe is also fantastic for lunch sandwiches, tacos, salads, and any other recipe calling for tender slices of steak or beef.\nInstead of doing the second sear on the stovetop, try grilling it! This gives the meat a nice smoky flavor.\nMake-ahead instructions: Cook the roast as per the recipe through the end of the sous vide cook time. Lift the roast from the water and transfer it to a bowl of cold water to cool it down. Once cooled, refrigerate until ready to serve. Re-warm in a 140F sous vide bath for an hour or so, then continue with searing the roast and assembling the sandwiches.\nIf you don\'t have a sous vide immersion circulator: Cook the roast either in a Dutch oven (or heavy, covered pot) in the oven at 325\xc2\xb0 F for 3 to 4 hours, or in a slow cooker for 6 to 8 hours.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 pounds boneless beef top or bottom round roast\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper, plus more to taste\n1 to 3 tablespoons cooking oil, like canola or grapeseed\n1/2 cup red wine\n2 cups low-sodium beef broth or stock\n1 bay leaf\nTo serve:\n1 large yellow onion, or 2 small yellow onions, thinly sliced (1 to 1 1/4 pounds)\n6 to 8 French rolls or hoagie buns\nSliced provolone cheese, optional\nSpecial equipment:\nJoule immersion circulator, or other immersion circulator\nLarge (8-quart or more) stock pot\nName-brand 1-gallon resealable plastic freezer bag, such as Ziploc\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Calculate your cooking time: This roast cooks sous vide for 18 to 24 hours, so it\'s important to begin cooking with your serving time in mind. Calculate backward from your dinner time to figure out when you should start cooking the roast.\nFor make-ahead instructions if you don\'t plan on serving your sandwiches right away, see the instructions in the headnotes.\n2 Trim and season the roast: Trim any large pieces of fat from the exterior of the roast, but don\'t worry about getting every last speck. Season it on all sides with the salt and pepper.\n3 Sear the roast: Warm a large skillet over medium-high heat and add 1 tablespoon of oil. When the oil shimmers and glides smoothly, and a flick of water evaporates on contact with the pan, add the roast.\nSear the roast very well on all sides, 4 to 5 minutes per side. The seared surfaces should look dark reddish-brown. If the oil starts to get smoky, lower the heat slightly; otherwise, maintain a medium-high heat for the best sear.\n4 Transfer the seared beef to a plate to cool slightly. If the roast is still scorching hot from the pan when you put it in the plastic bag, it can melt a hole in the plastic.\n5 Deglaze the pan with the wine: With the pan still over medium-high heat, add the wine all at once. It will bubble and steam as it hits the pan. As it bubbles, use a stiff spatula to scrape up any dark bits that were stuck.\nOnce you\'ve scraped up all the bits and the wine is simmering, pour it carefully into a measuring cup. Let it cool slightly.\n6 Pack up the roast for sous vide cooking: Place a 1-gallon plastic freezer bag on your counter and fold the top outwards to form a cuff; this will help it stand up and make it easier to fill. (Alternatively, place the bag in a bowl while filling).\nPlace the slightly cooled roast into the bag. Pour the wine and broth over top, and tuck the bay leaf inside. Zip the bag almost entirely shut, leaving about an inch open at one edge.\n7 Seal the bag: Fill a large stock pot three-quarters full with water. Submerge the bag with the roast until just the zipper part of the bag is above the water.\nAs you submerge the bag, the pressure of the water will press the sides of the plastic bag up against the roast and the liquid, "hugging" the ingredients. You may need to use your hands or a spatula to poke the roast below the surface of the water and force out any bubbles.\nOnce all the air bubble are out, submerge the bag up to the zipper, then zip it all the way closed so the bag is sealed. Lift the roast from the water and place it on a dishtowel while you heat the water.\nAs you lift the bag, the plastic should look like it\'s hugging the ingredients inside the bag. A few small air pockets are fine; vacuum-sealing isn\'t necessary. Check carefully to make sure the bag isn\'t leaking; if it is, transfer it to a new bag and repeat this sealing step.\nRead more about this method here.\n8 Heat the water with the immersion circulator: Place the pot of water on a trivet or other heatproof surface. Place the immersion circulator in the water and set it to heat the water based on your preferred doneness for the roast beef: 135\xc2\xb0F (medium-rare), 140\xc2\xb0F (medium), 145\xc2\xb0F (medium-well) or 150\xc2\xb0F (well-done).\nIt will take approximately 5 to 10 minutes for the water to heat, depending on the volume of water in your pot. (You can also use warm water out of the tap to cut down on heating time.) Once the water is up to temp, your immersion circulator will indicate that you\'re ready to start cooking.\nWith Joule, this is controlled through the Joule app: Open the app on your phone and press the orange circular button in the bottom right corner. Input the temperature and press the orange button again to start the device and begin heating the water.\n9 Cook the roast: Once the water has finished heating, lower the roast into the water. It\'s fine if the zipper is above the surface of the water, but the roast itself should be completely submerged by at least an inch or so. Add more water if needed.\nCook the roast for 18 to 24 hours (yes, hours!). It will become more tender the longer you let it cook. Set a timer so you know when it\'s ready.\n10 Check the roast and monitor the water during cooking: Every so often during cooking, take a peek at your roast and make sure that it\'s still submerged in the water and the bag isn\'t leaking. (If it\'s leaking, the liquid will start to look diluted and you\'ll notice air bubbles in the bag. Just transfer the roast and liquid to another bag and carry on with cooking. This doesn\'t happen very often, but is something to watch out for.)\nKeep an eye on the water level and add additional water if it looks like it\'s getting low. The immersion circulator will heat the water right back up to temperature. To help prevent evaporation, you can also cover your pot with plastic wrap, a silicon bowl cover (as I have), or any other cover.\n11 Cook the onions at any point while the roast is cooking: At any point during this cooking time when you have a spare 10 minutes, cook the onions. Warm a teaspoon or two of oil in a skillet and cook the onions with 1/4 teaspoon salt until they are very soft and browned.\nIf you\'re not serving them right away, cool and refrigerate until needed. To reheat, add them to a hot skillet and stir until warmed through.\n12 Sear the roast (again!): When you\'re done cooking the roast, lift the bag from the water and set it on a kitchen towel on the counter. Warm a tablespoon of oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.\nOpen the bag with the roast; be careful not to spill any of the cooking liquid. Use tongs to lift the roast from the bag and transfer it to a cutting board. Pat it dry on all sides.\nTransfer the roast to the hot skillet and sear on all sides, 2 to 3 minutes per side, until the outside is very crusty. Add more oil as needed to the pan. Once seared, set the roast on a cutting board until ready to slice.\n13 Strain the "jus": While the roast sears, strain the cooking liquid ("jus") into a measuring cup. Taste and add salt or pepper if needed. If the jus seems overly concentrated to you, add a little water to thin it out again.\nUse a little of the jus to deglaze the pan after searing the roast, if you like.\nTransfer the jus to individual cups for serving.\n14 Toast the French rolls: Warm the oven to 400F. Open up all the French rolls and arrange them in a single layer on a baking sheet with the cut sides facing up. Toast in the hot oven until they are warm and feel crispy when you press the surface of the bread, about 5 minutes. Remove from the oven, but leave the oven on.\nIf you like, spoon a little of the beef jus over the bottom buns for flavor.\n15 Slice the beef: Use a sharp chef\'s knife and slice the beef against the grain as thinly as possible.\n16 Assemble the sandwiches: Pile slices of beef on the bottom half of the rolls. The meat should divide equally between all the rolls, but you may have some leftover.\nTop each pile of beef with some onions and a slice or two of cheese, if desired.\n17 Broil the sandwiches: Set aside the tops of the buns so they don\'t burn. Switch the oven to "broil" and slide the pan of sandwiches under the broiler. Broil until the cheese starts to melt, about 1 minute.\n18 Serve the sandwiches: Top each sandwich with the top bun. Serve with the jus alongside for dipping. (Refrigerate leftovers and consume within 3 to 4 days, or freeze for up to 3 months.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBeef Roast Braised in Red Wine Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (3 1/2 pound) chuck roast, boneless\nSalt and ground black pepper\n4 oz pancetta, cut into 1/4-inch cubes\n2 medium onions, chopped medium (about 2 cups)\n2 medium carrots, chopped medium (about 1 cup)\n2 ribs celery, chopped medium (1 cup)\n1 Tbsp tomato paste\n3 medium cloves garlic, minced or pressed through garlic press (about 1 tablespoon)\n1 (750 ml) bottle Zinfandel wine (can substitute Cabernet Sauvignon, or other full bodied red wine)\n1 can (14 1/2 ounces) diced tomatoes, drained\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh oregano\n1 teaspoon minced fresh rosemary\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt the roast and let sit at room temp while you prep the vegetables: If your roast is very fatty, trim some of the fat. But it is important to keep some fat, as this will keep the roast moist while braising. In many supermarkets chuck roasts will already be properly trimmed.\nSalt the roast well and set aside at room temperature while you prepare all the other vegetables.\n2 Render fat and crisp the pancetta: Pour a little water into a Dutch oven or other heavy, lidded pot. Set the pot over medium heat and add the diced pancetta. As soon as the water begins to simmer, lower the heat to medium-low and slowly crisp up the pancetta; the water allows some of the fat in the pork to render out without charring the pancetta.\nWhen the pancetta is crispy and brown, remove it with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n3 Brown the roast on all sides: Preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F. Pat the beef roast dry with a paper towel, increase the heat to medium and brown all sides in the pot.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the chopped vegetables: Once the meat has browned remove it to a bowl and add the onions, carrot and celery. Sprinkle salt over the vegetables while they cook. Increase the heat to medium-high and saut\xc3\xa9 for 2-3 minutes.\nAdd the tomato paste and stir well, saut\xc3\xa9 for another 1-2 minutes. Add the garlic and cook a minute more.\n5 Add tomatoes, pancetta, herbs, wine, and the roast. Cover and cook: Increase the heat to high and add the tomatoes, the pancetta, herbs and red wine. Nestle the beef roast into the pot, cover, place in the 300\xc2\xb0F oven and cook for 3 hours. At the halfway point, use tongs to turn the beef roast over.\n6 Strain and reduce the sauce: Remove the pot from oven and transfer beef to a large bowl; tent with foil to keep warm. Allow the liquid to settle in the pot for a few minutes, if you'd like, skim off some of the fat with a wide shallow spoon. If you have an immersion blender, use it to blend the contents of the pot. If you don't, use a whisk to help break down the vegetables.\nBoil the sauce until it is reduced to about 3 1/2 cups. Strain liquid through large fine-mesh strainer, pressing on solids with spatula to extract as much liquid as possible; you should have a couple cups strained sauce.\nAdd any accumulated juices from the bowl you have the beef in. Boil the sauce again until it has reduced to 1 1/2 cups. Season sauce to taste with salt and pepper.\n7 Slice the meat and serve with the sauce: Cut the meat into roughly 1/2-inch-thick slices and pour the sauce over them. Serve with a bold red wine and crusty bread or mashed potatoes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nTraditional Roast Beef Hash Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutes\nTo make the hash you want approximately equal amounts of cooked beef, raw potato, and onion. The amounts listed here in the ingredient list are approximations. Scale up or down as needed.\nA grinder makes a big difference here because of the way it grinds the beef into the onions and potatoes.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups roughly chopped cooked roast beef or pot roast beef\n1 large Russett or 2 smaller Yukon gold potatoes, peeled and quartered\n1 large onion, peeled and quartered\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt and pepper\nKetchup\nMETHOD\n1 Grind the beef, potatoes, and onions together: Take approximately equal proportions of beef, potatoes, and onions and put them through a meat grinder using a medium grinder attachment so that they are well mixed and ground.\nIf you don't have a meat grinder, you can pulse a few times in a food processor, or finely chop by hand.\n2 Brown the hash: Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan, preferably a cast iron pan, on medium high to high heat.\nAdd the hash to the frying pan so that a half an inch of hash covers the bottom of the pan. If you have more hash to cook, do so in separate batches.\nBrown the hash, stirring only infrequently at first to make sure that the hash has an opportunity to brown well.\nAs you cook the hash, add pinches of salt and fresh ground pepper. Do this a couple of times with each batch of hash.\nCook for at least 10 minutes and until the hash is well browned.\nServe immediately with ketchup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nMarinated Tri-Tip Roast with Mushrooms and Garlic Recipe\nYield: Serves 4-8, depending on the size of the roast and your appetites.\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade:\n20 cloves of garlic, peeled\n1 fresh jalape\xc3\xb1o chili pepper, stem removed, the rest left whole\nJuice of one lime\n2 cups warm water\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nTri tip and sauce:\nOne tri tip roast, about 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 pounds, with a layer of fat on one side left on\nExtra virgin olive oil\n8 ounces fresh shiitake mushrooms, sliced, or 2 oz dried shiitake that have been soaking in water\n6-8 large cloves garlic, peeled and sliced\n1 red onion, chopped\n1 to 2 cups fine dry red wine, such as a Cabernet\nSalt and pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate the tri-tip overnight: Prepare the marinade by putting the marinade ingredients into a blender, and blend for 10 to 15 seconds until well blended. Place meat and marinade in a airtight plastic bag or plastic container. Place in refrigerator and let marinate overnight.\n2 Let come to room temp: Remove meat from refrigerator and still wrapped, let come to room temperature.\n3 Roast in oven: Pre-heat oven to 500\xc2\xb0F. Line a roasting pan with aluminum foil. Rub olive oil all over the roast surface. Place on a roasting pan, fat side up. Bake in oven for 20-40 minutes (depending on the size of the roast) until the internal temperature is 130-135\xc2\xb0F for rare, 140-145\xc2\xb0F for medium. If you have a smaller roast (1 1/2 lb), take it out on the low side of the range of temps. Cover with aluminum foil and let rest for 2-5 minutes (but no more than 5 minutes) before carving.\n4 Prepare the mushrooms: While the roast is cooking, you can prepare the mushrooms. Coat the bottom of a large skillet with about 4 tablespoons of olive oil and bring to high heat.\nAdd the mushrooms, onions, garlic and saut\xc3\xa9 for several minutes, stirring constantly, until the mushrooms get browned and the onions translucent. Add a cup of wine.\nReduce the wine, adding more wine as needed if the mushrooms absorb too much.\n5 Slice: Slice the roast across the grain and serve slices with the mushrooms.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nGrilled Tri-Tip Steak with Bell Pepper Salsa Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf you don't have a grill, you can prepare the tri-tip by browning it in a hot cast iron pan on the stove top, then placing it a 325\xc2\xb0F oven until the internal temperature of the steak/roast reaches 130\xc2\xb0F.\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade\n2 tablespoons soy sauce\n2 tablespoons sherry vinegar or apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n4 garlic cloves, minced\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nSteak\nOne 2-pound tri-tip steak or roast\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nSalsa\n1 large bell pepper (any color), stem and seeds removed, finely chopped\n4 green onions, thinly sliced, white and green parts\n1 garlic cloves, finely chopped (1 teaspoon)\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley, basil, or arugula\n1/4 teaspoon red chile flakes\n2 tablespoons apple cider or red wine vinegar\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the steak: Prepare the marinade in a large bowl, stirring together all of the marinade ingredients. Place steak in the bowl and coat on all sides with the marinade. Marinate for 20 minutes while you are preheating the grill.\n2 Prepare the grill: Prepare the grill for direct high heat. If you are using charcoal, use approximately 5 pounds of coals. Bank the coals so that more of them are on one side than the other, so that you have a high heat zone and a lower heat zone.\n3 Pat dry steak, sprinkle with salt and pepper: When the grill is ready and hot, remove the meat from the marinade and pat it dry with paper towels. Sprinkle generously all over with salt and freshly ground black pepper.\n4 Sear tri-tip on hot side of grill: Place the tri-tip on the hot side of the grill. Leave the cover off and watch carefully for flare-ups.\nAs the meat browns, any fat will melt and drip on to the coals causing flare-ups. These are okay, as long as they don't get out of control.\nKeep moving the tri-tip around the grill away from the flames if they get too high. Brown well on both sides.\n5 Move steak to lower heat side of grill: When the tri-tip steak is browned all over, move it to the lower heat side of the grill.\nCover the grill and close the vents enough so that you maintain about 300-325\xc2\xb0F temperature in the grill. (If you are using a charcoal grill, you can place a meat thermometer through the vents to measure the heat.)\nIf you are using a gas grill, turn off one of the burners and move the meat over that burner for indirect heating.\n6 Check temperature: Cook the tri-tip until a meat thermometer reads 130\xc2\xb0F when inserted into the thickest part of the meat (15-30 minutes, depending on the thickness of the meat).\n7 Let rest: Remove from grill, cover with foil and let rest for 15 minutes.\n8 Make salsa: Make the bell pepper salsa by stirring together all of the salsa ingredients in a small bowl.\n9 Slice: Cut the tri-tip in 1/4-inch slices across the grain of the meat. Serve with the bell pepper salsa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 8 hoursYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\n2 teaspoons fresh cracked pepper\n2 teaspoons garlic powder\n3 pounds beef chuck arm or rump roast\n1 tablespoon canola oil\n5 sprigs fresh thyme\n1 large onion, quartered, peeled\n1 bay leaf\n3/4 cup red wine\n3 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce\n2 cups beef stock\n3 large cloves garlic, smashed\n8 ounces cremini mushrooms, halved\n6 carrots, peeled and halved\n1 1/2 pounds baby potatoes, halved\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\nSpecial equipment:\n6- to 8-quart slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Season and sear the roast: Combine salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Rub onto all sides of the roast.\nSet a medium skillet over medium-high heat. Add the oil to the skillet. Once the oil shimmers, add the roast and sear the roast on all sides. This should take about 5 minutes. Transfer the roast to the slow cooker, and nestle thyme, quartered onion and bay leaf around the roast.\n2 Deglaze the skillet: Reduce the heat for the skillet to medium. Add the wine, Worcestershire sauce, and garlic cloves to the skillet to deglaze the pan. Cook for about 1 to 2 minutes, just until some of the alcohol cooks off the wine, and you scrape the brown bits off the bottom of the pan. Turn off the burner.\n3 Add the vegetables and liquid to the slow cooker: Nestle the mushrooms, carrots, and potatoes around the roast. Pour the wine from the skillet and the beef stock over everything.\n4 Cover and cook: Secure the lid, cover and cook on high for 4 to 5 hours or low for 8 to 10 hours.\n5 Make the gravy and serve: Ladle 2 cups of the slow cooker liquid into a medium saucepan. Set it over medium-high heat and bring to a boil.\nMake a slurry by combining 2 tablespoons of cornstarch with 3 tablespoons of water. Whisk the slurry into the boiling liquid. You should see it thicken to the consistency of honey within a minute or so.\nOnce thickened, remove it from heat. Serve up some pot roast and veggies, then top with gravy. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nNew England Boiled Dinner Recipe\nCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nCorned beef can be pretty salty, so if you are making boiled dinner with corned beef you may want to put it in a pot, cover with cold water, bring to a boil, and then discard the water before starting the recipe. If the broth ends up being too salty, you can serve just the meat and vegetables, without the broth, or add water to the broth to dilute it.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds corned beef brisket or plain beef brisket\n15 peppercorns\n8 whole cloves\n1 bay leaf\nSalt, if using plain brisket\n2 medium sized turnips, peeled and quartered\n4 red new potatoes, peeled and quartered\n3 large carrots, cut into thirds and the thickest pieces quartered lengthwise\n1 small head cabbage, cut into fourths\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put corned beef in a pot, cover with water, add seasonings, simmer: Put the brisket in a 5 or 6 quart Dutch oven and cover with an inch of water.\nIf you are using corned beef brisket and it does not come already packed in seasoning, add peppercorns, cloves, and a bay leaf to the pot.\nIf using plain brisket, add a teaspoon of salt for every quart of water.\nBring to a simmer and then cover, lower the heat until it is barely simmering. Keep at a low simmer for four hours or until the meat is tender (a fork goes through easily).\n2 Remove meat, add vegetables, simmer: Remove the meat and set aside, keeping the meat warm. Add the vegetables to the pot. Check the broth for taste. If it is too salty, add a little more water to taste.\nRaise the temperature and bring the soup to a high simmer. Cook at a high simmer until done, about 15-30 minutes longer, depending on the size of the cut of your vegetables.\n\n3 Slice meat across the grain: Slice the meat in thin slices across the grain. You may find it easier to slice if you first cut the roast in half along the same direction as the grain of the meat. Then slice smaller lengths across the grain.\n\nServe in bowls, a few pieces of meat in each, add some of the vegetables and some broth. Serve with horseradish or mustard or both.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Guinness Beef Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nIf you would prefer to make the stew in the oven, cook everything in a large Dutch oven. After you add the liquid, bring it to a simmer on the stovetop then put it, tightly covered, in a 225\xc2\xb0F oven for 6 hours (or a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 4 hours).\nNote that different people have different sensitivities to bitter flavors. If Guinness Stout tastes bitter to you, then the stew will taste bitter as well. If it doesn\'t taste bitter to you, the stew should not taste bitter.\nYou can either use celery root, young turnips, or potatoes in addition to parsnips and carrots. If you use turnips, make sure you only use young turnips, which are smaller and sweeter than regular turnips. Regular turnips can be quite bitter.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp butter\n2 pounds (900 g) well marbled chuck beef roast, cut into 2-inch pieces\nSalt\n2 cups chopped onion (about 1 large onion)\n2 celery stalks, chopped\n2 Tbsp tomato paste\n1 pint (16 ounces, 475 ml) Guinness extra stout (make sure you use extra stout and not draught)\n3 cups (700 ml) beef broth\n2 large carrots, peeled and cut into chunks\n3 to 4 parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks\n1/2 pound (280 g) celery root, potatoes, or very young turnips, peeled and cut into chunks\n2 teaspoons dried thyme\n4 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart or larger slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef, transfer to slow cooker: Heat the butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Brown the beef in the butter, starting with the fattiest pieces of meat, fat side down in the pan. This will allow some beef fat to render out. Work in batches as to not crowd the pan.\nSprinkle salt over the beef as it browns. Once browned on all sides, transfer the beef pieces into a 6-quart or larger slow cooker.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and celery, transfer to slow cooker: Add the onions and celery to the pan in which you just browned the beef. Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and celery until they begin to brown at the edges, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the tomato paste and mix well. Cook for a minute or two, then add a little of the Guinness, enough to make it easier for you to scrape up any browned bits at the bottom of the pan.\nTransfer the celery and onions into the slow cooker.\n3 Add Guinness, broth, root vegetables, thyme, salt: Add the rest of the Guinness, the beef broth, carrots, parsnips, celery root, and thyme to the slow cooker. Add two teaspoons of salt.\n4 Cook in slow cooker: Cover and cook on "high" for 4 hours, or "low" for 8 hours. When done, add more salt to taste. If you want, sprinkle with fresh parsley to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Guinness Beef Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 20 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings\nIf using a stovetop pressure cooker:\nDo steps 1 to 3 on the stovetop.\nSecure the lid on the pressure cooker, bring up to high pressure, then turn down the heat and let the stew cook for 25 minutes at high pressure. Let the pressure release naturally completely, or allow the pressure to release naturally for at least 10 minutes before performing a quick pressure release.\nAdd the root vegetables, then cook the stew under pressure for two more minutes.\nPerform a quick pressure release and open the pot. Stir in the cornstarch slurry right away while stew is still bubbling. Serve.\nLooking for a slow cooker version? Here you go!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds beef stew meat\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons butter or neutral flavored oil\n1 large (8 ounce) onion, chopped\n2 celery stalks, chopped\n2 tablespoons tomato paste\n1 cup Guinness extra stout, or other stout\n1 1/2 cups beef broth\n1 teaspoon dried thyme or 2 teaspoons fresh thyme leaves\n2 large carrots, peeled and cut into chunks\n3 to 4 parsnips (about 1 pound), peeled and cut into chunks\n1/2 pound potatoes, rutabaga, or celery root, peeled and cut into chunks\n2 teaspoons cornstarch\n2 teaspoons water\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot, or other electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the meat: Pat the pieces of beef dry with a paper towel, then season them on all sides with the salt and pepper.\nSelect the high \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d setting on the electric pressure cooker and heat the butter or oil. Brown the beef in the butter in two batches, searing the pieces for 4 minutes per batch and flipping them halfway through cooking.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t worry about trying to sear every side of the beef\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re just trying to get some browning on the beef and some flavor developing in the pot. Use a pair of tongs to transfer the meat to a dish.\n2 Cook the onions and celery: Add the onions and celery to the now-empty pressure cooker. Cook until the onions begin to soften and turn translucent, about 4 minutes. Stir in the tomato paste and cook for another minute.\n3 Add the liquids to the pot: Pour in the Guinness. Use a stiff spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot. Let it simmer for five minutes to reduce the beer a bit, then stir in the reserved beef, beef broth, and thyme.\n4 Pressure cook the meat: Secure the lid on the pressure cooker and make sure it\xe2\x80\x99s set to its \xe2\x80\x9csealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Cancel the cooking program, then select the Meat/Stew,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting, and set the cooking time to 30 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the actual cooking time begins.)\nWhen the cooking program finishes, let the pressure release naturally for 10 minutes, then release the remaining pressure by moving the pressure vent to its \xe2\x80\x9cventing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nAt this point, you may also leave the stew on the \xe2\x80\x9cKeep Warm\xe2\x80\x9d setting for up to 10 hours, before continuing with the rest of the recipe. The beef will become more tender the longer it sits.\n5 Add the root vegetables and pressure cook: When the pressure has released, open the pot. (Optional: for a leaner stew, you can use a ladle or spoon to skim off some of the fat.) Stir in the carrots, parsnips, and root vegetables.\nPut the lid back on the pressure cooker and make sure it\xe2\x80\x99s set to its \xe2\x80\x9csealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Cancel the cooking program, then select the \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting and set the cooking time to 3 minutes at high pressure.  (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the actual cooking time begins.)\n6 While the stew is finishing, mix the cornstarch and water together in a small bowl to make a slurry.\n7 Finish the stew: When the cooking program ends, perform a quick pressure release by moving the pressure vent to its \xe2\x80\x9cventing\xe2\x80\x9d position. (It\'s also ok if you need to leave the stew on the "Warm" setting for a little while before venting the pressure and serving, though the vegetables will eventually start to get mushy if left too long.)\nStir in the cornstarch slurry right away while stew is still bubbling. The residual heat will thicken the stew within a couple minutes.\n8 Serve: Ladle the stew into bowls and serve it hot, with fresh parsley sprinkled on top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCarbonnade Beef and Beer Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nYou are trying to achieve a sweet and sour flavor with this stew. You can swap out the sugar for tomato paste and you can use cider vinegar instead of mustard if you want.\nYou can brown the meat in vegetable oil instead of butter, though it will be more flavorful with the butter. You can also use a couple slices of bread, instead of adding flour, to thicken the stew.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 lbs chuck roast, cut into 1-inch pieces\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\n4 Tbsp butter, divided 2 Tbsp and 2 Tbsp\n3 medium yellow onions sliced about 1/4 inch thick (about 8 cups)\n3 Tbsp all-purpose flour\n1 1/2 cups chicken or beef broth\n1 1/2 cups (12 oz bottle) Belgian beer\n4 sprigs fresh thyme\n2 bay leaves\n1 Tbsp whole grain mustard\n1 Tbsp brown sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef: Pat beef dry with paper towels, then season well with salt and pepper. On the stove top, heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a large heavy bottomed dutch oven over medium-high heat until hot, almost smoking.\nWorking in batches, brown the meat, without stirring, about 3 minutes on each side (do not stir, give the meat an opportunity to brown well).\nTransfer browned beef to a separate bowl.\n2 Cook the onions: Add 2 tablespoons butter to dutch oven; reduce heat to medium. Add the onions and 1/2 teaspoon of salt; cook until onions are browned, about 15 minutes.\n3 Add flour and stir until onions are evenly coated and flour is lightly browned, about 2 minutes.\n4 Stir in broth, scraping pan bottom to loosen browned bits; stir in beer, thyme, bay, browned beef with any of the accumulated juices, and salt and pepper to taste. Increase heat to medium-high and bring to a full simmer. Reduce heat to low, partially cover, let cook for 2-3 hours until beef is fork tender. (Alternatively can cook in the oven at 300\xc2\xb0F.)\nStir occasionally, scraping up anything that is sticking to the bottom of the pan.\nAbout half an hour before it finishes cooking, add the mustard and brown sugar. Adjust seasonings to taste.\n5 Serve: Discard thyme and bay leaf. Adjust seasonings with salt and pepper to taste and serve. Can serve plain, with potatoes, over noodles, or over French fries.\nWhatever ale you have used in the cooking makes for a great drink accompaniment to the stew.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBeef Goulash with Dumplings Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nMake sure you are using fresh, flavorful paprika! Old paprika can lose its flavor.\nINGREDIENTS\nGoulash\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 large onions, thinly sliced (about 4 cups sliced onions)\n1 tablespoon sugar\n3 garlic cloves, minced (about 1 Tbsp)\n1 tablespoon caraway seeds, toasted and ground\n6 tablespoons sweet Hungarian paprika\n1 teaspoon spicy Hungarian paprika\n2 tablespoons minced fresh marjoram or oregano (or 1 Tbsp of dried)\n1 teaspoon minced fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)\n1 bay leaf\n3 tablespoons tomato paste\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n4 cups chicken stock\n2 1/2 pounds chuck roast, cut into 2-inch cubes (trimmed of excess fat)\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nDumplings\n2 cups cake flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon salt\n3/4 cup milk\n2 tablespoons melted butter\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the onions, add garlic and caraway: Heat olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the onions, sprinkle with sugar, and cook, stirring often, until the onions are browned and caramelized, about 20 minutes.\nIf the onions at any point look like they are drying out in the pan, lower the heat.\nAdd the minced garlic and ground toasted caraway seeds and cook a minute more.\n2 Add spices: Sprinkle with the sweet and spicy paprikas and toss to coat. Stir in the marjoram, thyme, and bay leaf. Cook for another minute, until fragrant.\n3 Stir in the tomato paste. Add the vinegar and stock and deglaze the pan, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.\n4 Add the cubed beef and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Bring the whole mixture to a boil on high heat, then lower the heat to low to maintain a simmer.\nCover and cook until the beef is falling apart tender, about 1 1/2 hours, stirring occasionally. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Make the dumplings: To prepare the dumplings, whisk together the cake flour, baking powder and salt. Combine with the milk and melted butter, mixing lightly.\n6 Drop dumplings into stew: After the stew has cooked until tender in step 4, drop the dumpling batter by (heaping) teaspoonfuls into the simmering stew. Cover and cook for 15 minutes.\nOnce you have covered the pan, do not uncover while the dumplings are cooking! In order for them to be light and fluffy, they must steam. If you uncover the pan, the steam will escape and the dumplings will boil instead.\nAfter 15 minutes, test the dumplings with a toothpick. If the toothpick comes out clean, the dumplings are done.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBeef and Barley Stew with Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nIf you can't find celery root, you can substitute turnips, rutabagas or potatoes. Just be sure to adjust your cooking times\xe2\x80\x94potatoes cook faster than celery root. Save time in the prep work by prepping the onions and mushrooms while the beef is browning.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp unsalted butter\n2-3 pounds beef chuck, cut into chunks\nSalt\n3 cups chopped onions\n1 pound button or cremini mushrooms, quartered if small or 1/4-inch sliced\n1 quart beef or chicken broth\n3 cups water\n2 teaspoons dried marjoram\n1 cup pearl barley\n1 cup roughly chopped carrot\n3 cups celery root, peeled and chopped into 3/4-inch to 1-inch chunks\nBlack pepper\nAbout 1/2 cup sour cream (around 1 Tbsp sour cream per serving)\nDill for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the beef: In a large, thick-bottomed pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add enough pieces of the beef to sear in the pot without crowding.\nYou will need to brown the meat in several batches. Salt the beef as it cooks, and set aside browned pieces in a bowl.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: When all the beef has browned, add the onions. As the onions release some of their water, use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot.\nSprinkle a little salt over the onions as they cook. Lower the heat to medium and cook the onions until they begin to brown, 5-6 minutes.\n3 Add the mushrooms: When the onions have lightly browned, mix in the mushrooms and increase the heat to high. Cook the mushrooms until they release their water, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Add back beef, add marjoram, stock, water, then simmer: Add the beef back to the pot and sprinkle with marjoram.\nAdd 1 cup of the stock and use the wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot. Add the rest of the stock and water and bring to a simmer.\nCover the pot, lower the heat to low and simmer very gently for 1 hour.\n4 Add barley, celery root, carrots, continue to simmer: Add the barley, celery root and carrots, stir well and recover the pot.
