Simmer gently until the barley and celery root are tender, between 40 minutes and an hour.\n5 Serve with sour cream and dill: Ladle servings into bowls, then top with a dollop of sour cream and a few sprigs of dill. Grind a little black pepper over right before you serve. To eat, stir in the sour cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nBeef Bourguignon Recipe\nYield: Serves 6-8\nWe are using shiitake mushrooms for the fresh mushrooms in this recipe, even though they are not traditionally used for this dish, because they are just so meaty and good. Feel free to use any fresh mushroom you'd like.\nIf you don't have access to salt pork, you can use bacon, but simmer it first for 8 minutes in water, then drain and rinse, to remove its smokiness. A word on salt. Salt pork is salty. Be sparing with salt as you make this dish until the end, when you can adjust. Commercial beef stock is also salty, so you very well may have enough salt for the dish just from these two sources.\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 ounces salt pork, cut into 1/2 inch chunks\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, divided\n4 pounds trimmed beef chuck, cut into 2-inch cubes, patted dry with paper towels\nSalt\n10-12 shallots, chopped, about 2 cups\n2 large, peeled carrots, 1 chopped, 1 cut into 2-inch chunks\n4-5 garlic cloves, chopped\n1 ounce of dried porcini mushrooms (optional)\n2 tablespoons tomato paste\n1/2 cup brandy, plus 2 tablespoons\n1 bottle Pinot Noir, or other red wine\nBeef Stock (low sodium), at least 1 cup, quite easily more\n1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley\n2 bay leaves\n2 teaspoons dried thyme\n4 whole cloves\n24 pearl onions, fresh or frozen\n1 pound fresh shiitake, cremini or button mushrooms\nBeurre manie: 3 tablespoons flour blended with 2 tablespoons butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Rehydrate dried porcini mushrooms: If you are using the dried porcini mushrooms, pour 1 cup of boiling water over the them and allow them to rehydrate for 30 minutes. Remove the mushrooms and chop coarsely. Pour the soaking water through a paper towel (to remove any dirt or debris) into a bowl and set aside.\n2 Cook the salt pork: In a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan, pour enough water to cover the bottom by about 1/8 inch. Over medium heat, cook the salt pork in the pan until the water evaporates, stirring occasionally.\nOnce the water is gone, reduce the heat to medium-low, and continue to cook the salt pork until much of the fat has rendered out of it. Add a tablespoon of butter and continue to cook the salt pork until the pieces are browned and crispy.\nUse a slotted spoon to remove the salt pork pieces to a large Dutch oven or other large, thick-bottomed, lidded pot.\n3 Brown the beef: Increase the heat to medium-high. Working in batches so that you do not crowd the pan, brown the beef.\nLeaving space around each piece of sizzling meat ensures that it browns and does not steam. Don't move the pieces of beef in the pan until they get a good sear, then turn them so they can get browned on another side.\nTake your time. This will take 15-25 minutes, depending on how large a saut\xc3\xa9 pan you have.\nOnce browned, remove the beef from the saut\xc3\xa9 pan and place in the Dutch oven with the salt pork.\n4 Cook the shallots, carrot, chopped porcini, then add garlic and tomato paste: When all the beef has browned and removed from the pan, add the shallots, the one chopped carrot, and the chopped porcini mushrooms if using.\nStir in the pot to remove any browned, stuck-on bits in the pan. Cook for 2-3 minutes, then add the garlic and the tomato paste. Cook another 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently.\n5 Add brandy, mushroom soaking water: Add the brandy and stir to combine. Boil down by half, then add the strained mushroom soaking water (if using).\nScrape any remaining browned bits off the bottom of the saut\xc3\xa9 pan and pour the contents of the pan into the Dutch oven.\n6 Simmer beef with wine, stock, herbs: To the Dutch oven add the bottle of wine and enough beef stock to almost cover the beef; the beef pieces should be barely poking up out of the liquid. Add the parsley, bay leaves, thyme and cloves. Cover and bring to a bare simmer for 1 hour.\n7 Add carrot: After 1 hour, add the second carrot, peeled and cut into chunks of 1-2 inches. Continue cooking for another hour, or until the beef is tender.\n8 Prep the mushrooms and onions: While the stew is cooking, trim the tough stems off the shiitake, cremini, or button mushrooms and slice into 2-3 large pieces; small mushrooms leave whole.\nPrepare the pearl onions. Boil them in their skins for 4-5 minutes. Drain and submerge in a bowl of ice water. Slice the tips and root ends off the onions and slip off the outer skins.\n9 Start on the sauce: When the beef is tender, use tongs to remove all the beef and the chunks of carrots; set aside in a bowl. Strain the contents of the Dutch oven through a fine-meshed sieve set over a medium pot. This will be the sauce.\nBoil the sauce down, tasting frequently. If it begins to taste too salty, turn off the heat. Otherwise, boil down until you have about 3 cups. Turn off the heat.\n10 Cook mushrooms and onions: Heat a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over high heat and add the mushrooms. Dry saut\xc3\xa9 the mushrooms over high heat, shaking the pan and stirring often, until they release their water, about 4-5 minutes.\nAdd the pearl onions and 3 tablespoons butter and toss to combine. Sprinkle salt over the onions and mushrooms. Saut\xc3\xa9 until the onions begin to brown. Remove from heat.\n11 Finish the sauce: Returning to the sauce, reduce the heat to medium and whisk in the beurre manie. Whisk in a third of the paste, wait for it to incorporate into the sauce, then add another third of the beurre manie, and so on. Do not let this boil, but allow it to simmer very gently for 2-3 minutes.\nStir in the remaining 2 tablespoons of brandy. Taste for salt and add some if needed.\n12 Serve: To serve, coat the beef, carrots, mushrooms and pearl onions with the sauce and serve with potatoes, egg noodles or lots of crusty bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nShort-Rib Beef Stew with Ale Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup flour\n2 Tbsp hot paprika\n2 teaspoons smoked paprika\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n4 pounds bone-in beef short ribs, trimmed of excess fat\n4 strips thick-cut bacon\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n4 cloves garlic, finely chopped\n1 bottle (12 oz.) a malty brown ale (we used Newcastle Brown ale)\n1 can (14.5 oz.) whole peeled tomatoes, chopped and juices reserved\n2 pounds Yukon Gold or russet potatoes\n2 large carrots\n1 pound turnips (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Place bacon strips in a large (5 to 6 quart), thick-bottomed Dutch oven. Set the heat to medium and cook the bacon until much of the fat has been rendered. Remove bacon to a paper-towel lined plate.\nPour off all but 1 Tbsp of the bacon fat from pot. (Do not pour down the drain or you will clog your drain when the fat hardens as it cools.)\n2 Dredge the short ribs: Preheat oven to 300\xc2\xb0F. While the bacon is cooking, in a large bowl, whisk together the flour, hot paprika, smoked paprika, 1 teaspoon of salt and 1 teaspoon of black pepper. Dredge the short ribs in the flour mixture.\n3 Brown the short ribs in the bacon fat: Add the short ribs to the pot with the bacon fat, taking care to not crowd the pot (work in batches if necessary). Brown on all sides, about 3 to 5 minutes per side.\nIf you want to get good browning, do not stir the short ribs unless to turn.\nWhile the short ribs are browning, chop the bacon and set aside.\n4 Cook the onions and garlic: Use tongs or a slotted spoon to remove the short ribs from the pot to a bowl. Add the chopped onions to the pot. Sprinkle with 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Cook until translucent, about 4 minutes.\nAdd the garlic and cook for an additional minute.\n5 Add ale and tomatoes: Add the ale and, using a wooden spoon or spatula, scrape up any browned bits on the bottom of the pan.\nAdd tomatoes and their juices and reserved bacon. Increase heat to high and bring mixture to a boil.\n6 Cover and cook in oven: Return the short ribs to the pot, cover, put in the 300\xc2\xb0F oven, and cook for two hours. (Alternatively, you can do the cooking on the stovetop, just lower the heat to the lowest setting and cover.)\n7 Add the root vegetables: Peel potatoes, turnips (optional), and carrots, and cut into 1-in. pieces. Add to short ribs, cover, and cook until the vegetables are tender and meat pulls away easily from the bone, about 30-45 minutes. Add salt and pepper to taste.\n8 Remove bones, excess fat: Spoon off excess fat (it helps if you have a fat separator). If you want, remove the bones before serving and cut any big pieces of meat into smaller chunks.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nQuick Beef Stew with Mushrooms and White Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n4-5 ounces of cremini or button mushrooms, quartered\n4-5 ounces some other fresh mushroom, shiitake, oyster, chanterelle, etc.\n1 1/2 pounds boneless beef top sirloin steak, cut into 1-inch cubes\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\n2 medium carrots, cut into 1/4 inch thick slices\n1 medium onion, cut lengthwise into thin wedges\n2 garlic cloves, sliced thin\n1/2 cup dry white or red wine (can sub beef or chicken broth)\n16-ounce can small white beans (such as Great Northern, navy, or cannellini), rinsed, drained\n14 1/2-ounce can diced tomatoes with garlic and onion, undrained\nChopped parsley for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Dry saut\xc3\xa9 the mushrooms: Put a large skillet over high heat and add all the mushrooms. Shaking the pan from time to time to prevent the mushrooms from sticking, dry saut\xc3\xa9 them until they being to release their water. Keep cooking until the mushrooms begin to brown. Remove to a bowl and set aside.\n2 Brown the beef: Add 2 tablespoons olive oil to the skillet and lower the heat to medium-high. Brown the beef cubes in batches, turning to brown at least two sides of the meat. Remove from skillet, add to the bowl with the mushrooms and sprinkle salt over them.\n\n3 Cook the carrots, onions, and garlic: Add the carrots and saut\xc3\xa9 3-4 minutes. Add the onions and cook another 5 minutes, then add the garlic and cook another minute.\n4 Add wine, bring to a boil and return the cooked beef and mushrooms to the pan. Continue cooking 3 more minutes.\n5 Stir in the beans and tomatoes. Cook 5 minutes more. Add salt to taste. Serve, garnished with chopped parsley.\n\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nVeal Goulash with Sauerkraut Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter or rendered beef fat\n2 pounds of veal, cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes\n1 1/2 cups sliced onions, sliced root to tip, 1/4-inch thick slices\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 cup canned crushed tomatoes, or chopped fresh ripe tomatoes\n1 cup full-fat sour cream\n2 teaspoons paprika\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds, chopped or crushed in a mortar with pestle\n2 28-30 ounce jars sauerkraut (we recommend Bubbies, in the refrigerated section of the grocery store)\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Lightly brown the veal: Heat butter or beef fat in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Pat dry the cubed veal. Sprinkle with salt and add to pan. Working in batches, saut\xc3\xa9 the meat until the meat is just beginning to brown.\n2 Add onions, then garlic: Add the onions to the pan with the veal, cook for another 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for another minute.\n3 Add a teaspoon of salt, a half teaspoon of black pepper, and the tomatoes. Add enough water to just barely cover the meat, about 2 cups or so, depending on the size and shape of your pan.\n4 Simmer about 30 minutes: Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a simmer, then lower the heat to maintain a low simmer, uncovered. Cook until the meat is almost cooked through, about 30 minutes.\n5 Remove veal, reduce the sauce: Use a slotted spoon to remove the veal from the pan to a bowl to temporarily set aside. Increase the heat to high and let the liquid boil until it is reduced by half. Lower the heat to medium.\nAdd the meat back to the pan.\n6 Add the sour cream, paprika, and crushed caraway seeds, and simmer uncovered for another 20 minutes.\n7 Heat the sauerkraut in a medium pot on medium heat until hot.\nTo serve, strain the sauerkraut. Place the sauerkraut in a serving dish and top with the goulash.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSous Vide Beef Tenderloin with Port Wine and Garlic Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nOne and half pounds of beef will comfortably feed four people; two pounds will feed six. You can stretch it to feed a few more people if you are serving the tenderloin with several other dishes on the table.\nWhen buying your tenderloin roast, make sure the butcher removes the silver skin. Also ask them to truss the roast with twine. You can do both of these steps yourself, but it\'s one less thing for you to worry about back home!\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds center-cut beef tenderloin (See Recipe Note)\n1 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided\n2 tablespoons butter\n1/2 cup tawny port wine\n4 to 5 medium cloves garlic\n5 to 6 sprigs fresh thyme, plus extra to serve\nSpecial equipment:\n10-inch stainless steel or cast iron skillet\nJoule, or other sous vide immersion circulator\n1-gallon zip-top freezer bag\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the beef tenderloin: Sprinkle the tenderloin with salt and a generous amount of pepper. Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat. When the pan is hot enough, a drop of water should sizzle and quickly evaporate on contact.\nSear the tenderloin in the pan until it\'s dark brown all over, 1 to 2 minutes on each side and both ends. Transfer to a plate or cutting board and allow to cool slightly.\n2 Make the port-garlic sauce: While the pan is still hot, add the butter and garlic. Cook until the garlic is golden and fragrant, 30 to 60 seconds.\nAdd the port wine and use a stiff spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Let the wine come to a simmer, then remove from heat.\n3 Seal the tenderloin in a zip-top freezer bag: Make sure the tenderloin and sauce are no longer steaming. It\'s fine if they are still quite warm, but they can melt through the bag if they\'re still steaming hot.\nPlace a gallon-sized zip-top freezer bag on your counter and flip the zip-top edge outward, forming a cuff around the bag. This helps the bag stay open and upright as you fill it.\nTransfer the tenderloin to the bag and pour the sauce over top. Lay 5 or 6 sprigs of thyme over the top of the tenderloin.\nFill a stock pot with 5 or 6 inches of water. Slowly submerge the tenderloin in the water, using your hands to help push out all the air from the bag as you go. When you reach the top of the bag, zip it closed.\nLift the tenderloin out of the water and place it on a towel while you heat the water for the sous vide.\nRead more about this method here.\n4 Heat the water for sous vide cooking: Place your Joule or other sous vide immersion circulator in the stockpot of water. Set the sous vide immersion circulator to heat the water to 133\xc2\xb0F for rare beef, 140F for medium-rare (my preference), 149\xc2\xb0F for medium-well, or 167\xc2\xb0F for well-done.\n5 Cook the tenderloin sous vide for 2 1/2 to 3 hours: When the water has heated to its required temperature, lower the tenderloin into the water so that it is entirely submerged. It\'s ok if the top of the bag pokes out of the water as long as the tenderloin itself is submerged.\nCook for 2 1/2 to 3 hours, but avoid cooking for much longer or the beef will start to get a little soft and mushy.\n6 Sear the tenderloin a second time: When the tenderloin is done, lift it from the water and place the bag on a kitchen towel. Heat the remaining tablespoon of oil in the skillet over medium-high heat until a drop of water sizzles and evaporates on contact.\nUse tongs to lift the roast from the bag and transfer it to the skillet. Be careful\xe2\x80\x94it will sputter! Sear for 30 to 60 seconds on all sides, until the outside is even more deeply browned and a crust has formed.\nTransfer the tenderloin to a cutting board and rest for 5 to 10 minutes.\n7 Deglaze the pan: With the pan still over medium-high heat, pour in the sauce directly from the bag into the pan (discard the sprigs of thyme). Simmer for about a minute and scrape up any browned bits stuck to the bottom of the pan. Carefully transfer the sauce to a serving cup.\n8 Slice and serve the tenderloin: Cut through the twine and discard. Slice the tenderloin either into thick "filet mignon" steaks (one steak per person), or into thinner "roast beef" slices (3 or 4 slices per person). Serve immediately with the sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nChocolate Guinness Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes one 8 or 9-inch cake\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup Guinness extra stout\n10 tablespoons unsalted butter\n3/4 cup unsweetened natural cocoa\n1 1/2 cups superfine sugar\n1/2 cups dark brown sugar\n3/4 cup sour cream\n2 eggs\n1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract\n2 cups all-purpose flour\n2 1/2 teaspoons baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cream cheese frosting recipe\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prepare pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease a 8 or 9-inch springform pan with butter and line the bottom with a round of parchment paper.\n2 Heat Guinness, butter, add cocoa and sugar: In a large saucepan place the stout and butter. Cook over medium-high heat until the butter has melted. Add the cocoa powder and sugars and whisk together. Take off heat and allow to come to room temperature.\n3 Beat sour cream, eggs, vanilla, then add to stout butter mixture: In another bowl beat together the sour cream, eggs, and vanilla extract until very, very well combined. Add to the butter-stout mixture and whisk together.\n4 Whisk flour, baking soda, salt, add to stout-butter mixture: In another bowl whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Add to the stout-butter mixture and whisk together until it just comes together.\n5 Bake: Pour into the prepared pan and give the pan a few short drops onto the countertop to shake the air pockets in the batter to the surface and out of the cake. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 50-60 minutes.\n6 Cool: Allow to cool on a wire rack. Run a knife around the edge to separate the cake from the pan and pop the ring off the springform.\n7 Frost: Spread frosting on the cooled cake and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nGrilled Polish Sausage and Sauerkraut Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-6\nWe recommend jarred fresh sauerkraut (like Bubbies), which you can find in the refrigerated section of the grocery store. If you don't have a grill, or this isn't grilling season, you can also put all ingredients into a casserole dish and bake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 1/2 hours.\nINGREDIENTS\n2-3 pounds kielbasa, Polish sausage or bratwurst\n1 to 2 light-colored (not dark) beers\n1 to 1 1/2 pints of sauerkraut\n2 medium yellow onions, thickly sliced\n2 Tbsp vegetable oil\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon celery seed\n1 Tbsp. caraway seed\nMustard\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Grill the sausages slowly over medium heat, allowing them to get well browned. Be patient; do not be tempted to grill the links over high heat, or they will break open and the juices and fat will drain into the grill (they may break open anyway, but they'll break less if you cook them slowly).\n2 Heat the beer with celery seed and caraway seeds: While the sausages are cooking, put an aluminum grilling pan on a cooler part of the grill and pour in the beer. Stir in the celery and caraway seeds and salt. Bring to a simmer. (This may require covering the grill.)\n3 Add sausages and sauerkraut: Once the sausages are browned add the sausages, the sauerkraut and sauerkraut juices to the pan.\n4 Grill the onions: Paint the sliced onion with the vegetable oil and grill on high direct heat. If your grates are too wide and you think you will lose too much onion through the grates, you can either skip the grilling part and put the onions directly into the beer bath, or you can cut the onions in halves or quarters and grill them that way.\nThen slice them and add them to the beer.\n5 Cover the grill and simmer (a low simmer, not a boil) for 30 minutes to 2 hours before serving. Cut the sausages into serving sized pieces before serving.\nServe as is in a bowl or on a plate, or in a sandwich roll. Serve with mustard on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nRabbit Braised in Belgian Ale Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nMany markets carry whole frozen rabbits. Call ahead to have your butcher defrost and cut rabbit into parts. Otherwise, defrost by by placing into a large bowl of cool water. Once thawed, cut into parts (see these instructions). Try to remove any stray little bones at the edges of some of the cuts of rabbit.\nThe dish works best with a Belgian ale. If not available, try Newcastle brown ale or Anchor Steam ale, or O-Doule amber ale if you need to avoid alcohol. Do not attempt this recipe with a hoppy beer.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 2 1/2 to 3 pound rabbit, cut into 6 to 7 serving pieces (2 front legs, 2 back legs, the loin cut into 2 to 3 pieces), plus ribs and flap meat\nSalt\n1/2 cup all purpose flour for dredging\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons butter\n2 medium onions, sliced stem to root (about 2 1/2 cups sliced)\n4-6 whole cloves of garlic, peeled\n6 sprigs of fresh thyme, tied together with kitchen string (or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme)\n1 1/2 cups of Belgian ale, such as Chimay or Ommengang\n1/2 cup of chicken stock\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 celery root, peeled and diced\n2 teaspoons whole grained mustard\n2 teaspoons brown sugar\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sprinkle rabbit pieces with salt: Place rabbit pieces on a platter, sprinkle both sides with kosher salt. Let sit for 30 minutes to an hour.\n2 Dredge rabbit with flour, brown in butter: Place flour on plate. Dredge rabbit pieces in flour.\nHeat oil and butter in a large  Dutch oven on medium heat (large enough to fit rabbit pieces in a single layer). Once the butter is melted and foamy, add the rabbit pieces in a single layer to the pot.\nBrown on one side without stirring for 5 to 6 minutes. Then turn the pieces over and brown on the other side. Remove to a plate.\n3 Brown the onions, add garlic and thyme: Add the sliced onions to the pot, and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly brown, scraping up and browned rabbit bits from the bottom of the pot. Add garlic cloves and thyme, cook until onions are soft and the garlic quite fragrant.\n4 Add ale, then stock, salt, pepper: Increase the heat to high and add the Belgian ale. Let it simmer for a minute or two, then add the stock. Add a half teaspoon of salt and the freshly ground black pepper.\n5 Add celery root, rabbit, then simmer: Place the diced celery root over the onions in a single layer. Place the browned rabbit pieces over the  celery root. Bring to a simmer. Cover and reduce heat to maintain a very low simmer. Cook for 45 minutes, or until the rabbit is just cooked through and tender.\n6 Reduce sauce: Remove rabbit pieces from the pot and keep warm on a platter. Increase the heat to high and reduce the liquid by one third. Then, reduce the heat to low, stir in the mustard and sugar. Taste and add more salt and pepper in needed.\n7 Return meat to sauce in pot: Slice the flap meat pieces of the rabbit into strips and return to the pot. Strip away any available meat from the back and chest parts and return meat to the pot. Add the serving pieces to the pot. Cover and let rewarm for a minute.\n8 Serve: Sprinkle with chopped parsley to serve. Serve with crusty bread, egg noodles, or rice pilaf, along with some Belgian ale.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBeer Braised Chicken and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nWhat beer you use matters. Dark beers tend to be more full bodied and malty and sweet. They will work well in this stew. Hoppy beers like IPA or pale ale are too bitter for this stew and should be avoided.\nFor this recipe we've used Moylan's Kilt Lifter, a Scottish ale, and also Ommegang Abbey Ale. A soft Belgian beer like Flanders Red or one of the Chimay beers would also be ideal.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp unsalted butter\n6 chicken thighs, about 2 to 2 1/2 pounds\nSalt\n3 pounds yellow onions, sliced 1/4-inch thick, root to stem, about 6-8 cups sliced\n1 Tbsp brown sugar, packed\n2 bay leaves\n2 teaspoons dried thyme\n2 Tbsp smooth Dijon mustard\n1 1/2 cups dark beer\n1 cup chicken stock\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the chicken thighs on all sides: Melt the butter in a large, heavy pot with a lid, such as a Dutch oven, over medium-high heat. Pat the chicken thighs dry with paper towels and set them skin side down in the butter. Salt the meat side lightly.\nBrown the chicken on both sides well. Remove the browned thighs from the pan and set aside in a bowl.\n2 Drain off some of the fat: The chicken skin has likely rendered quite a bit of fat. Drain off all but 2 tablespoons of fat from the pan, taking care to not discard any of the tasty browned bits. (Note, do not discard the fat down the drain, you may clog your plumbing. Pour off into a jar.)\n3 Cook the onions: Lower the heat to medium and add the sliced onions to the pan. If you want, sprinkle brown sugar over the onions. This is optional. The added sugar will intensify the natural sweetness of the onions.\nCook the onions slowly, stirring occasionally, until they begin to brown, about 15 minutes.\n4 Add herbs mustard, salt, beer, stock, chicken, bring to simmer: Add the bay leaves, thyme, mustard, 2 teaspoons of salt, and beer to the onions. Scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot with a wooden spoon. Add the chicken thighs and the chicken stock and bring to a simmer.\n5 Cook until chicken is falling off the bone tender: Cook covered for 45 minutes, then uncover the pot and simmer well until the liquid is greatly reduced and the meat wants to fall off the bone, between 45 minutes and 1 hour.\nIf you are using unsalted or low sodium stock, you will likely need to add more salt. Add freshly ground black pepper and more salt to taste.\nServe over egg noodles or with rice or potatoes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Beets with Balsamic Glaze Recipe\nCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds red beets, medium sized, scrubbed clean, green tops removed (see beet greens recipe for what to do with beet greens)\n2 teaspoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\n1/2 cup balsamic vinegar\n2 teaspoons sugar\n1 teaspoon grated orange zest\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F and line pan with aluminum foil.\n2 Prepare the beets: Place the beets in the pan. Rub olive oil over the beets, and sprinkle with salt. Cover the beets with another sheet of aluminum foil.\n3 Roast the beets: Roast for 1 to 2 hours, depending on the size of the beets and how old they are. After 1 hour, test every fifteen minutes by poking a beet with the tines of a fork. Once the fork tines go in easily, the beets are tender and cooked. Remove from the oven.\n4 Prepare balsamic glaze: While the beets are cooling, prepare the balsamic glaze. In a small, shallow saut\xc3\xa9 pan, add the balsamic vinegar and sugar. Heat on high until the vinegar has reduced to a syrup consistency. Remove from heat.\n5 Peel and cut cooked beets: After the beets have cooled for several minutes, but are still warm to the touch, peel off the outer skins and discard. Cut the beets into quarters or more bite-sized pieces.\n6 Pour glaze over beets: Place beets in a serving bowl. Pour balsamic glaze over the beets. Stir in grated orange zest, and add salt and pepper to taste.\nGarnish with a little orange zest to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nCider Vinaigrette Roasted Root Vegetables Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nIf your root vegetables are competing with a roast for the oven for a holiday meal, just make them ahead, and put them in the oven to warm them up again while the roast rests before serving.\nWe are using parsnips, golden beets, carrots, and yams for this recipe, but you could use any of your favorite root vegetables.\nThis recipe makes enough for 6 to 8 people and requires two roasting pans. You can easily cut the recipe in half.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup cider vinegar\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n3 tablespoons dark brown sugar\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFreshly grated black pepper to taste\n4 medium golden beets, peeled, thickly sliced\n4 medium carrots, peeled, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces\n3 medium garnet yams, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces\n4 medium parsnips, peeled, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces, any tough woody core removed\n1 large red onion, thickly sliced\n3/4 teaspoon thyme, dry or fresh\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss vegetables with vinegar, oil, sugar, salt, pepper: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. In a large bowl (enough room for all the vegetables) mix together the cider vinegar, olive oil, brown sugar, salt and pepper. Add the vegetables\xe2\x80\x94the beets, carrots, yams, parsnips, onion\xe2\x80\x94to the bowl and toss to combine.\n2 Spread vegetables out into two lined sheet pans: Line two large roasting pans or sturdy rimmed baking sheets with aluminum foil. Spread the root vegetables out over the pans in a single layer, with some space in between so that the vegetables don't crowd each other too much and the hot oven air can circulate around the vegetables. (You'll get better browning that way.) Pour the remaining vinaigrette over the root vegetables in the pans.\n3 Roast the vegetables: Place vegetables in the oven and roast at 450\xc2\xb0F for 35 to 40 minutes, turning the pans (and swapping bottom and top rack positions), half-way through the cooking. Cook until the vegetables are well browned and caramelized around the edges.\n4 Sprinkle with thyme: Remove from oven and gently loosen the root vegetables from the foil with a wooden spoon. Sprinkle with thyme. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nArugula Salad with Beets and Goat Cheese Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCooking the Beets time: 1 hourYield: Makes enough for 2 salads\nThe amount of ingredients shown is just a guideline for two servings. The actual amounts depend on how much salad per serving you want.\nINGREDIENTS\nSalad Ingredients:\n2 medium beets, cooked (roasted* or boiled**) until a fork easily goes in one (about an hour), peeled, diced into bite-sized pieces\n2 handfuls (about 2.5 ounces) fresh baby arugula\n4 Tbsp goat cheese (about 1.5 ounces)\n1/4 cup roughly chopped toasted walnuts\nDressing ingredients:\n3 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon dry powdered mustard\n1/2 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\n* To roast beets, scrub raw beets clean, coat with a little olive oil, wrap in aluminum foil, and roast in 400\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 to 2 hours, until fork tender\n** To boil beets, scrub raw beets clean, put in small pot, cover with water, bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook for 45 min to an hour, until fork tender\nMETHOD\n1 Make the vinaigrette: Place dressing ingredients in a jar and shake to emulsify. Adjust ingredients to taste.\n2 Assemble the salad according to how much you want. Compose each dish with a handful of arugula leaves, a few cooked chopped beets, some crumbled goat cheese, and some chopped toasted walnuts.\n3 Drizzle the salad with vinaigrette. (You may have a little extra vinaigrette.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nRoasted Root Vegetables with Tomatoes and Kale Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 pounds of root vegetables such as parsnips, rutabagas, carrots, potatoes, golden beets, turnips, and celery root, peeled and cut into chunks\n1 head of garlic, the cloves separated and peeled\n6 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, divided 3 Tbsp and 3 Tbsp\n1 teaspoon Kosher salt\n1/2 cup chopped onion\n1 heaping tablespoon tomato paste\n1 28-ounce can of whole peeled tomatoes\n2 cups (packed) of chopped leafy greens such as kale or chard\n1 teaspoon Italian seasoning or dried oregano\nBlack pepper to taste\nTabasco sauce (optional, to taste)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the root vegetables: Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Into a large roasting pan, mix together the vegetables, garlic, 3 Tbsp olive oil. Sprinkle with salt.  Roast for 45 minutes, turning the vegetables over in the pan halfway through cooking.\n2 Make the tomato base: While the root vegetables are roasting, in a 4 to 5 quart Dutch oven, heat 3 Tbsp of olive oil over medium high heat. When the oil is hot, add the onions and saut\xc3\xa9 until the edges of the onions just begin to brown. Stir in the tomato paste, and cook a minute longer.\nUsing your hands, tear the canned tomatoes into large pieces as you add them to the pot. Add the remaining liquid from the can into the pot. Stir well. Add the Italian seasoning. Bring to a simmer, then lower the heat to the lowest possible setting. Cover the pot and let cook gently while the root vegetables are roasting.\n3 Combine and simmer the roasted root vegetables, tomatoes, and greens: When the root vegetables are ready (they should be browned on the edges and easily pierced with a fork), remove from the oven. Add chopped leafy greens to the pot of tomatoes. Simmer until the greens are wilted, about 5 minutes. Stir in the root vegetables. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Season with Tabasco to taste if using.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nAutumn Tabbouleh with Cauliflower, Carrots, and Golden Beets Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesResting time time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nThis salad is best if you can give it a full 30 minutes to rest before serving. It can also be made up to 3 days ahead and kept refrigerated.\nTo make this dish gluten-free, substitute quinoa for the bulgur. (Follow package directions to cook the quinoa.)\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup bulgur wheat\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 head medium cauliflower\n2 medium carrots, peeled and trimmed\n2 small golden beets, peeled and trimmed\n1/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 cup olive oil\n2 cups minced parsley\n1 bunch scallions, trimmed and minced\n1 tablespoon sherry vinegar\nGround black pepper or to taste\nSpecial Equipment:\nMandolin\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the bulgur: Bring 3 cups of water to a boil in a small saucepan. When the water boils, stir in the bulgur and salt. Cover the pan and remove from heat. Let the bulgur sit for 20 to 30 minutes or until tender. Strain bulgur with a mesh strainer, shaking to remove as much water as possible.\n2 Prep the vegetables: Break the cauliflower into large florets and carefully slice them 1/16-inch thick on a mandolin. Next, switch to a julienne blade and julienne 1/8-inch thick to julienne carrots and beets. (The vegetables can be shredded on a box grater or in a food processor, instead.)\n3 Marinate the vegetables: Combine the vegetables in a large serving bowl and toss with salt and lemon juice. Set aside 20 minutes to marinate, until crisp-tender.\n4 Finish the salad: To the bowl with the vegetables, add the olive oil, cooked bulgur, parsley, scallions, and sherry vinegar. Stir to combine. Taste and add salt, lemon juice, or olive oil as needed.\n5 Let stand 30 minutes before serving: Cover and let mixture marinate at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before serving to give the flavors time to combine. (If marinating longer, set in the fridge.)\nSalad will keep well covered in the fridge for 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nRed Flannel Hash Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 Tbsp butter\n1 cup chopped onion\n2 cups chopped cooked corned beef\n1 1/2 cups chopped cooked beets*\n1 1/2 cups chopped cooked potatoes\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce (optional, and use gluten-free Worcestershire sauce if cooking gluten-free)\n1/4 cup (packed) chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\n*For easy cooked beets, place a few beets in a saucepan and cover with water. Simmer for 35 to 45 minutes, depending on the size of the beets, until they are easily pierced with a fork. Let them cool, slip the peels off, then chop the beets.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the onions: Heat butter in a frying pan (cast iron preferred) on medium high heat. Add the onions and cook a couple minutes, until translucent.\n2 Add the corned beef, potatoes, and beets. Stir in the pan to combine, and spread out evenly in the pan. Reduce the heat to medium. Press down with a metal spatula to help brown the mixture.\nDon't stir, but just let cook until nicely browned on one side, then use a metal spatula to lift up sections of the mixture and turn over to brown the other side.\nIf the mixture sticks to the pan too much, just add a little more butter to the pan where it's sticking.\n3 When nicely browned, remove from heat. Sprinkle in some Worcestershire sauce, if using. Stir in fresh chopped parsley, if using, and sprinkle on freshly ground black pepper to taste.\nThere should be enough salt from the corned beef, but if not, add salt to taste.\nServe plain or with fried or poached eggs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nMoroccan Grated Carrot and Beet Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWe always have fresh mint growing in yard somewhere, which is why I like tossing it into salads. If you don't have easy access to fresh mint for this recipe, just skip it.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups of grated carrots (from about 3 carrots)\n1 cup of grated fresh beets (from about 1 medium sized peeled beet)\n1/2 cup golden raisins\n1/2 teaspoon paprika (sweet, not hot)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\nSmall pinch of salt\nSmall pinch of cayenne\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n2 teaspoons honey\n2 Tbsp sliced fresh mint leaves\nMETHOD\n1 Rinse the grated beets, combine with carrots and raisins: Place the grated carrots in a medium sized serving bowl.\nPlace the grated beets into a sieve and briefly rinse with cold water. This will rinse away a little of the excess beet juice that may otherwise color the whole salad beet red.  Pat dry with a paper towel.\nThen add to the bowl with the carrots.  Add the raisins.  Stir to gently combine.\n2 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the paprika, cumin, cinnamon, salt, and cayenne. Then add the lemon juice and honey and whisk until smooth.\n3 Dress the carrots and beets, let sit for an hour: Drizzle over the the carrots and beets, then gently fold until the carrots and beets are lightly coated.  Let sit for an hour before serving, either chilled or at room temperature, for the dressing to seep into the carrots and beets.\n4 Stir in sliced mint before serving: Right before serving, stir in a couple tablespoons of sliced fresh mint leaves. Garnish with fresh mint.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nOrange and Beet Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 bunch of beets, leaves removed (save them for beet greens!) - about 4 or 5 medium sized, scrubbed clean\n2 large navel oranges, peels cut off with a small small knife and sliced\n1 bunch of arugula leaves, cleaned, and any thick stems removed\nSeveral thin slices of red onion\noptional 1/4 cup chopped walnuts\nVinaigrette Dressing:\n3 Tbsp white wine vinegar\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 teaspoon dried mustard\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the beets: You can either boil or roast the beets. To boil the beets, cover the unpeeled beets with water, bring to a boil, and simmer for 30 minutes or until beets can easily be pierced through with a fork.\nIf you prefer to roast the beets instead of boiling them, wrap the unpeeled beets in aluminum foil and bake them in the oven at 400\xc2\xb0F for an hour or until done. (See our Roasted Beets recipe.)\nAfter cooking, allow the beets to come to room temperature and remove their peels. Slice or quarter them.\nIf you have time, place them in a small bowl and marinate them in half of the oil and vinegar dressing.\n2 Make the dressing: While the beets are cooking, make the dressing by putting all of the dressing ingredients into a jar. Seal and shake until the dressing is well blended.\n3 Compose the salad: Compose individual salad plates with arugula, a few slices of orange, a few beets, a few slices of red onion and a few chopped walnuts.\nIf you want some added color, gently add a few slices of the orange to the beet juice from your bowl of beets. Let the oranges absorb the beet color and use in your salad.\nSprinkle dressing over the individual salads.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGolden Beets and Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nThis recipe can easily be scaled up to serve more people.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 medium sized golden beets\n10 Brussels sprouts, trimmed of rough outer leaves and cut in half\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 shallot, peeled and sliced\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 teaspoons fresh thyme, chopped\n2 tablespoons almond slivers, toasted\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Boil or roast the beets: The beets take the longest to cook so start them first. Either boil them in water in a small saucepan for 45 minutes (or how ever long it takes to get them tender), or wrap them in foil and roast them in the oven at 350\xc2\xb0F for an hour fifteen minutes or until done.\nRoasting will give you better flavor, but takes longer and uses a lot more energy (unless you are already cooking something in the oven).\nWhen done, set the beets aside to cool for 10 minutes, then peel and chop them into 1 x 1/2 inch chunks.\n2 Toast the slivered almonds: While beets are cooking toast your almond slivers if you are starting with raw almonds. Just heat a skillet to medium high heat and put in the almonds. Stir frequently with a spatula. When the almonds begin to brown, remove from pan into a small bowl. Let cool, set aside.\n3 Blanch the Brussels sprouts: Also while the beets are cooking, prepare the Brussels sprouts. Bring 1 1/2 quarts of salted water (2 teaspoons salt) in a medium saucepan to a boil. Add the Brussels sprouts to the water and blanch them for 2-3 minutes. They should be almost all the way cooked through.\nDrain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking. Set aside.\n4 Cook the shallots, add beets and Brussels sprouts: In a medium sized skillet heat 1 Tbsp olive oil on medium heat. Add the shallot slices and cook until translucent, a few minutes.\nAdd another tablespoon of olive oil and raise the heat to medium high. Add the sprouts and beets to the pan, along with the thyme and mix well. Salt and pepper to taste.\nCook for 1 minute more, stirring. Remove from heat and serve. Can serve warm or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nAvocado Beet Salad with Citrus Vinaigrette Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium-sized beets (any color), green tops removed, beets scrubbed clean\n1 just ripe avocado\n4 ounces mixed green lettuces\n2 tablespoons pistachios, chopped\nCitrus Vinaigrette:\n1 tablespoon minced shallot\n2 tablespoons rice vinegar (unseasoned)\n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice\n1 tablespoon fresh orange juice\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1 teaspoon orange zest\nA Pinch of salt\n1/3 cup good quality extra virgin olive oil\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the beets: Place beets in a medium saucepan and cover with an inch of water. Bring to a boil and reduce heat to maintain a low simmer for 30 to 40 minutes, depending on the size of the beets, until easily pierced with the tines of a fork.\n2 Make the vinaigrette: Whisk together the citrus vinaigrette ingredients in a small bowl.\n3 Toss the beets in vinaigrette: When the beets are done, drain them, and peel off the outer skin. Cut the beets in half, and the halves into wedges.(Tip: use a plastic cutting board when cutting red beets. Red beets will stain wooden cutting boards.)\nPlace the beet wedges in a bowl and toss with a tablespoon of the vinaigrette.\n4 Cut and peel the avocado, cut the avocado into wedges (see how to peel and cut an avocado).\n5 Arrange the salad: Toss the salad greens with a half of the citrus vinaigrette. Arrange the dressed greens on serving plates.\nArrange the beet wedges and avocado wedges on top of the salad greens. Sprinkle with chopped pistachios. Drizzle remaining vinaigrette over the salads.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGolden Beet and Pomegranate Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf you want to boil the beets instead of roasting them, put the beets in a small saucepan. Cover with water. Bring to a boil and simmer for 45 minutes or until tender.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 golden beets (about 1 pound)\n1 cup diced red onion\n1/4 cup red wine vinegar\n1/4 cup water\n1/4 cup orange juice ( can sub with 3 Tbsp Triple Sec)\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1 teaspoon orange zest\n1 cup pomegranate seeds\n1 teaspoon extra virgin olive oil for the salad, plus 1/2 teaspoon more for roasting the beets\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black or white pepper\n2 cups arugula and/or butter lettuce leaves\n1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese\nMETHOD\n1 Roast the beets: Rub the beets with a little olive oil, wrap them together in foil, place them in a roasting pan, and roast them at 400\xc2\xb0F for an hour or until tender when poked with the tines of a fork.\nRemove from oven. Remove the peels from the beets. Dice the beets into bite-sized pieces.\n2 Make the glaze: Put the diced cooked beets, onions, vinegar, water, orange juice, orange zest, sugar, salt, and pepper, in a skillet on high heat.\nHeat the mixture to a boil, and continue to boil, stirring often, until the liquid is reduced to a glaze, about 2 tablespoons (5 minutes or so). Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature.\n3 Assemble the salad: Stir pomegranate seeds and olive oil into the beet mixture and add more salt and pepper to taste.\nServe on top of salad greens and sprinkle with feta cheese.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nFestive Beet Citrus Salad with Kale and Pistachios Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8 to 10\nSave time by prepping the ingredients while the beets are cooking.\nBecause the kale resists wilting, this salad holds up remarkably well, several days in the fridge.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 - 10 large beets (about 4 to 5 pounds), a mix of red, pink, and golden\n2 - 3 blood oranges (or cara cara or navel oranges or a mixture)\n1 bunch of kale (lacinato or dinosaur kale if available), center ribs removed, leaves thinly sliced\n1 cup roasted pistachios, roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chopped fresh mint leaves\n3 Tbsp chopped Italian parsley\nDressing:\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/2 cup good quality extra virgin olive oil\n6 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar (or unseasoned rice vinegar plus 2 teaspoons of sugar)\nZest of one orange\nZest of one lemon\n2 Tbsp capers, coarsely chopped\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the beets: Scrub the beets clean, leaving the skin on. You can boil or roast the beets to cook them.\nIf boiling, boil the beets separately by color (otherwise the red beets will run into the the orange, turning the orange beets red). Place each batch of beets in a pot and cover with water by about an inch. Add a couple teaspoons of salt. Bring to a boil and reduce to a simmer. Simmer until you can just pierce easily with a fork, 30 to 60 minutes, depending on the size of the beets. Drain. Let cool. Rub the skins off.\nTo roast the beets, wrap them in foil and roast them in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, until fork tender. Then cool and peel. See our roasted beets recipe.\n2  While the beets are cooking, prepare the dressing and prep the rest of the ingredients. Place all of the dressing ingredients into a jar, cover and shake until well blended.\n3 Marinate beets in dressing: Cut the beets into 1/2-inch to 1-inch pieces. Separate by color and place in separate bowls and toss with a little of the dressing (use about a third of the dressing). Chill for an hour or up to two days.\n4 Sprinkle sliced kale with some dressing: 15 minutes to an hour or two before serving, place the thinly sliced kale in a serving bowl. Sprinkle half of the remaining dressing over the sliced kale and toss to lightly coat the leaves.\n5 Serve: Either create a composed salad by placing the beets, citrus, mint, parsley, over the kale, sprinkling with the chopped roasted pistachios, and drizzling with the remaining dressing, OR toss everything together, sprinkling with with pistachios at the end.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nArugula Salad with Beets and Goat Cheese Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCooking the Beets time: 1 hourYield: Makes enough for 2 salads\nThe amount of ingredients shown is just a guideline for two servings. The actual amounts depend on how much salad per serving you want.\nINGREDIENTS\nSalad Ingredients:\n2 medium beets, cooked (roasted* or boiled**) until a fork easily goes in one (about an hour), peeled, diced into bite-sized pieces\n2 handfuls (about 2.5 ounces) fresh baby arugula\n4 Tbsp goat cheese (about 1.5 ounces)\n1/4 cup roughly chopped toasted walnuts\nDressing ingredients:\n3 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon dry powdered mustard\n1/2 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\n* To roast beets, scrub raw beets clean, coat with a little olive oil, wrap in aluminum foil, and roast in 400\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 to 2 hours, until fork tender\n** To boil beets, scrub raw beets clean, put in small pot, cover with water, bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook for 45 min to an hour, until fork tender\nMETHOD\n1 Make the vinaigrette: Place dressing ingredients in a jar and shake to emulsify. Adjust ingredients to taste.\n2 Assemble the salad according to how much you want. Compose each dish with a handful of arugula leaves, a few cooked chopped beets, some crumbled goat cheese, and some chopped toasted walnuts.\n3 Drizzle the salad with vinaigrette. (You may have a little extra vinaigrette.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'

If you don't have easy access to fresh mint for this recipe, just skip it.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups of grated carrots (from about 3 carrots)\n1 cup of grated fresh beets (from about 1 medium sized peeled beet)\n1/2 cup golden raisins\n1/2 teaspoon paprika (sweet, not hot)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\nSmall pinch of salt\nSmall pinch of cayenne\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n2 teaspoons honey\n2 Tbsp sliced fresh mint leaves\nMETHOD\n1 Rinse the grated beets, combine with carrots and raisins: Place the grated carrots in a medium sized serving bowl.\nPlace the grated beets into a sieve and briefly rinse with cold water. Then add the lemon juice and honey and whisk until smooth.\n3 Dress the carrots and beets, let sit for an hour: Drizzle over the the carrots and beets, then gently fold until the carrots and beets are lightly coated.  Let sit for an hour before serving, either chilled or at room temperature, for the dressing to seep into the carrots and beets.\n4 Stir in sliced mint before serving: Right before serving, stir in a couple tablespoons of sliced fresh mint leaves. b'Save It Print\nGolden Beet and Pomegranate Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf you want to boil the beets instead of roasting them, put the beets in a small saucepan. Cover with water. Bring to a boil and simmer for 45 minutes or until tender.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 golden beets (about 1 pound)\n1 cup diced red onion\n1/4 cup red wine vinegar\n1/4 cup water\n1/4 cup orange juice ( can sub with 3 Tbsp Triple Sec)\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1 teaspoon orange zest\n1 cup pomegranate seeds\n1 teaspoon extra virgin olive oil for the salad, plus 1/2 teaspoon more for roasting the beets\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black or white pepper\n2 cups arugula and/or butter lettuce leaves\n1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese\nMETHOD\n1 Roast the beets: Rub the beets with a little olive oil, wrap them together in foil, place them in a roasting pan, and roast them at 400\xc2\xb0F for an hour or until tender when poked with the tines of a fork.\nRemove from oven. b'Save It Print\nFestive Beet Citrus Salad with Kale and Pistachios Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8 to 10\nSave time by prepping the ingredients while the beets are cooking.\nBecause the kale resists wilting, this salad holds up remarkably well, several days in the fridge.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 - 10 large beets (about 4 to 5 pounds), a mix of red, pink, and golden\n2 - 3 blood oranges (or cara cara or navel oranges or a mixture)\n1 bunch of kale (lacinato or dinosaur kale if available), center ribs removed, leaves thinly sliced\n1 cup roasted pistachios, roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chopped fresh mint leaves\n3 Tbsp chopped Italian parsley\nDressing:\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/2 cup good quality extra virgin olive oil\n6 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar (or unseasoned rice vinegar plus 2 teaspoons of sugar)\nZest of one orange\nZest of one lemon\n2 Tbsp capers, coarsely chopped\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the beets: Scrub the beets clean, leaving the skin on. You can boil or roast the beets to cook them.\nIf boiling, boil the beets separately by color (otherwise the red beets will run into the the orange, turning the orange beets red). Place each batch of beets in a pot and cover with water by about an inch. Add a couple teaspoons of salt. Bring to a boil and reduce to a simmer. Simmer until you can just pierce easily with a fork, 30 to 60 minutes, depending on the size of the beets. Drain. Let cool. Rub the skins off.\nTo roast the beets, wrap them in foil and roast them in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, until fork tender. Then cool and peel. See our roasted beets recipe.\n2  While the beets are cooking, prepare the dressing and prep the rest of the ingredients. Place all of the dressing ingredients into a jar, cover and shake until well blended.\n3 Marinate beets in dressing: Cut the beets into 1/2-inch to 1-inch pieces. Chill for an hour or up to two days.\n4 Sprinkle sliced kale with some dressing: 15 minutes to an hour or two before serving, place the thinly sliced kale in a serving bowl.
