b'Save It Print\nBlackberry Slump Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nThis recipe uses blackberries, but you could easily use any berry you would like, such as blueberries, raspberries, or strawberries.\nINGREDIENTS\nDumplings:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp butter\n1/3 cup whole milk\nBerries:\n4 cups fresh or frozen (defrosted and drained) blackberries\n1/2 to 3/4 cup sugar (depending on how sweet your berries and how sweet you would like your slump to be)\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/3 cup water\nWhipping cream or vanilla ice cream for topping\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dumplings: In a medium sized bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar.\nCut the butter into small cubes and add to the flour. Using a pastry cutter, two knives, or your clean hands, cut the butter into the flour until the flour resembles a coarse meal.\nAdd the milk all at once and stir until the flour is just moistened. Handling the dough as little as possible, form into a ball. Set aside.\n2 Heat berries with sugar, cinnamon, lemon, water until boiling: In a 2-qt saucepan, add the berries, sugar, cinnamon, lemon juice, lemon zest, and water. Heat until boiling, stirring a few times so that the berries are well coated with the sauce.\n3 Add chunks of dumpling dough: Once the berry mixture is boiling, tear off spoonful chunks from the dough ball and drop onto the fruit around the edges of the pot. You should have enough dough for 6 dumplings.\n4 Cover and simmer: Cover the pot and reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook for 25 minutes, without peeking at the dumplings.\nPlace dumplings in serving bowls and top with berries. Serve with cream or ice cream. Serve hot or chilled.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nLemon Blueberry Scones Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 18 minutesChilling time: 2 hoursYield: 16 scones\nTo make the scones without a food processor: Whisk the dry ingredients in a medium mixing bowl. Use a pastry cutter to work the butter into the flour mixture until the mixture looks sandy with only small gravel-sized bits of butter remaining. Pour the whisked yogurt and egg mixture over top, and use a wooden spoon or dough whisk to mix the wet and dry ingredients. Fold in the blueberries.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the scones:\n2 1/3 cup (300g) unbleached all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup (56g) granulated sugar\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n8 tablespoons (1 stick, 4 ounces) unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n3/4 cup (170g) whole milk Greek yogurt\n1 large egg\n1 (6 ounce) container fresh blueberries, picked over for stems, rinsed, and dried\nFor the glaze:\n1 tablespoon lemon zest, from 1 medium lemon\n2 tablespoons lemon juice, from 1 medium lemon\n1 cup (120g) powdered sugar\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough in a food processor: Measure the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a food processor. Process the ingredients to combine them evenly.\nSprinkle the cubed butter over the flour mixture, and process the mixture in 1-second pulses until the butter is no longer visible and the mixture looks somewhat sandy.\nIn another mixing bowl, whisk together the yogurt and egg until no streaks of egg yolk remain. Pour this mixture into the food processor with the flour and the butter.\nRun the food processor for about three seconds, just until all of the flour is absorbed and the dough begins to come away from the sides of the bowl.\n2 Fold in the blueberries: Turn out the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Scatter the blueberries over top and fold the dough a few times with a spatula to incorporate. (You can also do this in a separate mixing bowl instead of on the counter, if you prefer.)\n3 Shape the dough into disks and chill: With a bench scraper or knife, divide the dough in half and pat into two disks, about 1/2-inch thick and six inches across (you can use the length of your hand as a guide).\nWrap the disks of dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least two hours, or up to 24 hours.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350F: Line a baking sheet with a silicon baking mat or parchment paper.\n5 Cut and bake the scones: Unwrap the disks of chilled dough and cut each one into eight wedges (16 wedges total).\nPlace the wedges an inch apart on the lined baking sheet. Try not to touch the sides or handle the scones too much as you transfer them since this can inhibit how much they rise in the oven.\nBake the scones for 15 to 18 minutes, until they are lightly browned.\n6 Make the glaze: While the scones are baking, whisk together the lemon zest, lemon juice, and powdered sugar in a small bowl. The glaze should be a pourable consistency; add additional lemon juice (or milk, or water) 1 teaspoon at a time if needed.\n7 Glaze and cool the scones: Transfer the scones to a cooling rack with something underneath to catch any dripping glaze (I use wax paper). While the scones are still warm, drizzle each one with a teaspoon of the glaze. Let the scones cool until the glaze has fully set, about 30 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBlueberry Sorbet Recipe\nYield: Makes a little less than a quart\nIf you want your sorbet to last a while in the freezer, and not get too rock hard, you might want to add a tablespoon or two of corn syrup to the mix. Or you can add 2 tablespoons of kirsch or a berry or orange liqueur.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, rinsed, stems removed and discarded\n1/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup honey\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nPinch salt\nFresh blueberries and sprigs of mint for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Place the blueberries, sugar, honey, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt in a large bowl. Stir to coat blueberries with the sugar. Mash with a potato masher.\n2 Put the mashed blueberries into a blender and blend for a couple of minutes until smooth.\n3 Place a sieve over a large bowl and working in batches, press the mixture through the sieve, using a rubber spatula. This will catch the tougher and larger pieces of lemon and blueberry peel.\n4 Chill the mixture for at least an hour in the fridge. Then process following the directions of your ice cream maker.\nEat immediately (the sorbet will still be a little soft) or freeze at least a few hours to help firm up before eating. Eat soon after making though, as the sorbet will get progressively harder the longer it stays in the freezer.\nServe with a few fresh blueberries and a sprig of mint.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nStrawberry Mousse with White Chocolate Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesChilling time: Several hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 \xc2\xbd pounds of strawberries\n2 Tbsp fresh lemon juice, divided\n8 ounces white chocolate, finely chopped\n1 \xc2\xbc teaspoon unflavored gelatin (about half a small envelope)\n2 cups heavy cream\n2 Tbsp powdered (confectioner's) sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make strawberry pur\xc3\xa9e: Clean and hull the strawberries. Starting with about half of the strawberries (3/4 pound), quarter them and pur\xc3\xa9e them in either a blender or food processor.\nPress the pur\xc3\xa9e mixture through a mesh sieve with the back of a spoon into a bowl. You want to end up with 1 cup of pur\xc3\xa9e.\nStir in 1 Tbsp of the lemon juice and set aside.\n2 Slice remaining berries: With the remaining 3/4 pound or so of berries, slice as many as to fill up 2 cups, and set aside.\n3 Melt the white chocolate: Melt white chocolate in a double boiler, or a stainless steel bowl set over simmering water (make sure the simmering water doesn't actually touch the bottom of the bowl.)\nStir until smooth, set aside.\n\n4 Soften the gelatin: Put 1/4 cup of cold water into a small bowl. Sprinkle the gelatin powder over the water and let sit for 5 minutes.\n\n5 Dissolve gelatin mixture into heated cream and powdered sugar: Put 1/4 cup of the cream into a small saucepan on medium heat. Whisk in 2 tablespoons of the powdered sugar and bring to a simmer. Stir in the water gelatin mixture until dissolved.\n6 Combine with melted chocolate: Pour this mixture into the bowl with the melted white chocolate and whisk until smooth.\n7 Stir in 3/4 cup of the pur\xc3\xa9ed strawberries, reserving the remaining 1/4 cup.\n8 Make whipped cream: Using an electric mixer with the whisk attachment, beat the remaining 1 3/4 cup of cream on medium-high speed until medium peaks form. (It helps if your cream is very cold.)\n9 Incorporate whipped cream into mousse base, chill: Stir a  third of the whipped cream into the chocolate mixture.\nUsing a large rubber spatula, gently fold the remaining whipped cream into the mixture.\nRefrigerate for 1 hour.\n10 Incorporate sliced strawberries into mousse: Stir the remaining 1 Tbsp of lemon juice into the reserved sliced berries. Fold the sliced berries into the mousse.\n11 Spoon mousse into serving cups and refrigerate for at least another hour, preferably several hours, or even over night (cover with plastic wrap).\n12 Top with reserved strawberry pur\xc3\xa9e: When you are read to serve the mousse, pour a dollop of the reserved strawberry pur\xc3\xa9e onto each serving. Add a few slices of strawberries as garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Slump Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nDumplings:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp butter\n1/3 cup milk\nBlueberries:\n4 cups of fresh or frozen blueberries\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1 1/2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/3 cup water\nVanilla ice cream or whipping cream for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dumplings: In a medium bowl whisk together the flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt.\nCut the butter into small cubes and use your clean hands to work the pieces of butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nMake a well in the center and add the milk. Mix together with a fork or wooden spoon just until the dough comes together. Form it into a ball. It should be rather shaggy. Do not knead or over work it or the dumplings will be tough.\n2 Heat the blueberries: Place the blueberries, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon juice, lemon zest, and water into a medium (2 quart) saucepan. Stir so that the berries are well coated with everything. Heat on high heat until the berries start to boil.\n3 Add the dumplings: When the blueberry mixture is boiling, pull off clumps of dumpling dough from the ball of dough and place on top of the berries. You should have enough dough for 6 dumplings, so portion accordingly.\n4 Cover and cook: Cover the pan, and lower the heat to maintain a low simmer. Cook for 25 minutes.\nDo not uncover to peek at the dumplings while cooking! The dumplings need the steady steam and pressure from being covered to cook properly so they are light and fluffy.\n5 Serve: Portion into individual serving bowls and top with vanilla ice cream or whipping cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBlueberry Shortcake Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\nBerries\n5 cups blueberries, fresh or frozen\n3/4 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\n1 pinch cinnamon\nBiscuits\n2 cups all purpose flour\nPinch cinnamon\nPinch ground nutmeg\n2 Tbsp white granulated sugar\n1 Tbsp baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n8 Tbsp (1 stick) cold, unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n7/8 cup (1 cup minus 2 Tbsp) heavy whipping cream\n1 large egg*\n1 tsp vanilla extract\nHeavy cream for whipping\n*The egg is optional. Including the egg will result in a less crumbly shortcake biscuit, but either way, with or without egg, is good.\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer blueberries, sugar, lemon, cinnamon: Place blueberries, sugar, lemon zest, lemon juice, and cinnamon into a medium saucepan. Heat until the sugar has melted and the mixture is just barely coming to a simmer.\nUse a potato masher to mash some of the berries to help release their juices. Remove from heat and let come to room temp.\n2 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F.\n3 Stir flour with dry ingredients, work in butter: In a large bowl stir together the flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Add the small cubes of butter, and use your fingers to rub the butter into the dry ingredients until the mixture resembles a coarse meal, with pea-sized pieces of butter still intact.\n4 Mix in wet ingredients: In a small bowl mix the egg, whipping cream, and vanilla extract. Form a well in the center of the dry ingredients and pour the wet mixture into it. Stir with a fork just until the dough barely comes together. Do not over mix or your biscuits will be tough.\n5 Form dough into rounds: Turn the dough out onto a clean, lightly floured surface. Form the dough into a large pancake shape, about 3/4 to 1-inch thick.\nUsing a pastry round (or the lightly floured ridges of drinking glasses) cut into biscuit forms and place 1 1/2-inches apart on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or silpat.\nYou can also cut the biscuits into squares if that's easier. The the dough is too soft to work with, put it in the refrigerator to chill for about 15 minutes first.\n5 Bake the biscuits: Put the biscuits in the 425\xc2\xb0F oven for 12-15 minutes, or until they have risen and are lightly browned. Remove from the oven and let cool on a baking rack.\n6 Serve the berries spooned over biscuits that have been broken open, and top with whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nBlackberry Shortcake Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nBlackberries:\n2 to 2 1/2 pounds of blackberries (6 to 8 cups), gently rinsed if fresh, defrosted if frozen (save any juices that come from defrosting!)\n1/4 cup to 1/2 cup of sugar (to taste, depending on the tartness of the berries)\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\nBiscuits:\n3 cups flour\n3 Tbsp sugar\n4 teaspoons baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n8 Tbsp cold butter, cut into small cubes\n1 1/2 cups heavy cream\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nWhipped Cream:\n1 cup heavy whipping cream\n2 teaspoons powdered sugar\nA few drops of vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Macerate the berries with sugar: Put the blackberries into a large bowl, sprinkle with sugar, and toss to coat all the berries with sugar. Use a potato masher to gently mash about half of the berries, releasing their juices.\nStir in lemon juice and zest.\nLet sit for 20 minutes to an hour to macerate, allowing the sugar to help release more of the juices from the blackberries.\n2 Whisk flour, sugar, baking powder salt. Cut in butter: In a large bowl vigorously whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. Add the chilled butter cubes and use your fingers (or a fork, pastry cutter, or food processor) to break up the butter and mix with the flour until the largest pieces of butter are the size of peas.\n3 Add cream and vanilla: Make a well in the center of the flour mixture and pour in the cream and vanilla. Use a fork to mix the flour and the cream until the dough just comes together.\nIt should have a rather shaggy appearance. Empty on to a clean surface and knead a few times to form a loose ball. Do not over mix or over-knead!\n4 Form into square shape and chill: Place ball on a small tray or baking sheet and form into an 8-inch by 8-inch square. Cover with plastic wrap and place in the refrigerator to chill for 15 to 20 minutes.\n5 Cut into squares, arrange on baking sheet: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Once the dough has chilled sufficiently, remove it from the refrigerator and cut it into 9 even squares. Arrange them on a baking sheet with an inch or two between each square.\n6 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F until the biscuits are nicely browned, about 18 minutes.\n7 Make whipped cream: While the biscuits are baking place the heavy whipping cream into a large chilled bowl (I usually put a metal mixing bowl into the freezer for a few minutes if I know I'm going to be making whipped cream.)\nSprinkle with powdered sugar and a few drops of vanilla extract. Use a hand mixer to beat until you have peaks that somewhat hold their shape. Chill until ready to serve.\n8 Assemble shortcakes: When the biscuits are ready, remove them from the oven and let them cool for a few minutes. To serve, place one in a bowl or dessert plate, pull it apart in half.\nPlace a large scoop of berries and the juices from the berries over the bottom half. Top with the other half of the biscuit and a generous dollop of whipped cream.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nMixed Berry Chia Seed Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: 1 to 2 cups jam\nThe blueberries and raspberries break down quite easily. If you want chunks of fruit in the jam, don\xe2\x80\x99t chop the strawberries too finely. Consider halving small strawberries and cutting large strawberries into quarters.\nLook for chia seeds at natural food stores in the baking aisle or with the other nuts and seeds. You can also order them online.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup blueberries\n3/4 cup chopped strawberries (stems removed)\n3/4 cup raspberries\n2 tablespoons sugar, plus more to taste\n2 tablespoons lemon juice (from about 1/2 a lemon), plus more to taste\n1 1/2 tablespoons chia seeds\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, sugar, and lemon juice in a medium saucepan. Give everything a quick stir to distribute the sugar.\n2 Cook the fruits over medium heat for about 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the fruit breaks down. The fruit should look like a syrupy, runny sauce. (If you want a smooth jam without chunks, use the back of a wooden spoon or a fork to mash large chunks of fruit.\n3 Remove the saucepan from heat. Mix in the chia seeds and let the jam sit for 10 minutes to thicken. Taste and add additional sugar or lemon juice to taste.\n4 Cool to room temperature, then transfer to a jar and refrigerate. The jam will continue to thicken in the refrigerator. Store for up to 3 to 4 weeks.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBlackberry Frozen Yogurt Recipe\nYield: Makes a little more than a quart\nThe berries release a lot of water when cooked, which is why I add cream to the mix. The additional fat helps keep the frozen yogurt from getting too icy. The brandy will help the frozen yogurt from getting too icy too, but you can leave it out if you want.\nINGREDIENTS\n3-4 cups blackberries or boysenberries (fresh or frozen)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 cup sugar\n2 cardamom pods, crushed\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 cups whole milk yogurt\n2 Tbsp heavy whipping cream\n2 Tbsp brandy (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer blackberries, sugar, zest, spices: Place blackberries, lemon zest, cardamom, cinnamon, and sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, stirring to help break up the berries and release their juice. Simmer for 10 minutes, then remove from heat to cool for 15 minutes.\n2 Push berry mixture through sieve: Place a sieve over a bowl. Push the berries through the sieve to capture the concentrated syrup below. Use the back of a spoon or a rubber spatula to help press the berries against the side of the sieve. Discard the berries in the sieve, save the syrup.\n3 Stir in yogurt and cream, then chill: Stir the yogurt and cream into the berry syrup. Cover with plastic wrap and chill for several hours.\n4 Add brandy, process in ice cream maker: Right before processing in your ice cream maker, add the brandy if using. Process in your ice cream maker according to the maker's instructions. Then either eat while still rather soft, or scoop into a container and freeze for several hours until firm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBlueberry Frozen Yogurt Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling and Churning time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Make about 1 quart\nFrozen blueberries work great for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries (about 1 lb)\n3 Tbsp lemon juice\n3/4 cup to 1 cup of sugar (depending on how sweet your blueberries are, and how sweet you want the result to be)\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 1/2 cups full fat plain yogurt (full fat yogurt is preferred, if you use low-fat or non-fat yogurt, substitute 1/4 cup of it with heavy whipping cream)\n1/2 cup whole milk\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook blueberries with lemon juice, sugar, salt, cinnamon: Place the blueberries, lemon juice, sugar, salt, and cinnamon in a medium saucepan. Heat on medium heat, stirring, until all of the sugar has dissolved.\nWhile the mixture is heating, use a potato masher to mash up the blueberries.\nWhen all of the sugar has dissolved, remove from heat. Strain out the blueberry skins and let the juicy blueberry syrup cool for 10 minutes.\n2 Stir in yogurt, milk, then chill: Stir in the yogurt and milk until completely incorporated.\nCover and chill the mixture in the refrigerator for several hours (or overnight) until completely cold.\n3 Process in ice cream maker: Process the blueberry yogurt mixture in your ice cream maker according to manufacturer's instructions (usually about 25 minutes).\nServe immediately (it will be soft) or let it firm up a bit by freezing it for several hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nAmerican Flag Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesDough chilling time: 1 hourYield: Serves 12\nIf you haven't worked with a sour cream pie dough before, it's wetter and more pliable than a standard butter crust dough. Don't worry, it will firm up when it chills.\nWhile this recipe calls for blueberries and strawberries, you can easily change it up a bit. Add raspberries, cherries, or rhubarb to the strawberries or use blackberries instead of or in addition to blueberries.\nAs you are rolling out the dough for the crust and stars and stripes, if it becomes too too soft to handle, just put it in the refrigerator for a few minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nCrust:\n3 1/2 cups flour\n3 1/2 teaspoons sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n14 ounces butter (3 1/2 sticks), cut into cubes\n7/8 cup sour cream (that's 3/4 cup plus 2 Tbsp)\nStrawberry filling:\n3 1/2 pounds strawberries, hulled, quartered\n1/2 cup sugar\n2 teaspoons orange zest\n4 Tbsp cornstarch, flour, or minute tapioca\nBlueberry filling:\n1 pint blueberries (about 0.6 lbs, 280 g)\n3 Tbsp sugar\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n2 Tbsp cornstarch, flour, or minute tapioca\nEgg wash:\n1 egg white\n1 teaspoon of milk or cream\nSpecial equipment:\nOne 13 x 18-inch rimmed sheet pan\nStar-shaped cookie cutter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the pie dough: Cut the butter into cubes and let sit out for a 10 minutes to take the chill off. Whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt in a large mixing bowl.\nAdd the butter and toss to coat with the flour. Using your (clean) hands, work the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nAdd the sour cream and mix with a fork until well incorporated.\nKnead with your hands until the mixture comes together as a ball. Divide into 3 equal sized balls of dough (it helps to use a kitchen scale).\nForm the balls into rectangular discs. Sprinkle with a little flour and wrap individually with plastic wrap.\nChill for 1 to 2 hours or overnight (can freeze this point if making several days ahead).\n2 Make berry fillings: Put the quartered strawberries in a large bowl and toss with sugar, cornstarch (or flour, or minute tapioca), and orange zest.\nIn a separate smaller bowl, put the blueberries, sugar, cinnamon, lemon zest, lemon juice, and cornstarch (or flour or minute tapioca), and toss to combine.\n3 Roll out the dough for the bottom crust: Line the bottom of a 13 x 18-inch rimmed sheet pan with parchment paper.\nRemove two dough discs from the refrigerator and let sit for 10 minutes to soften a bit. On a clean, lightly floured surface, roll out one disk to 11 x 17-inches and arrange on half of the sheet pan, with an inch of edge over the sides of the sheet pan.\nRoll out the second disc and cover the other half of the sheet pan.\nFold the dough over along the edges and crimp.\nRemove any excess dough from center. Form into a ball, then use your hands to roll into a long rope. Crimp that rope of dough and form a rectangle in one corner of the sheet pan. This is where your berries and stars will go. The dough will help keep the blueberries from running into the strawberries. (If you don't have excess dough at this point, no worries, you will later when you cut away the stars and stripes.)\nPut in the refrigerator to chill.\n4 Make egg wash: In a small bowl, whisk together the egg white and milk or cream.\n5 Roll out dough for stars and stripes: Remove third rectangular disc of dough from the fridge and let sit for 10 minutes to soften a bit. Roll out so that the longest point is 18-inches.\nUse a dinner knife (blunt) or a pizza wheel to cut out stripes. You'll need 2 stripes that are about 18 inches long and 1 1/2 inches wide, and 2 stripes that are about 10 inches long and 1 1/2 inches wide.\nUse a star shaped cookie cutter to cut out stars.\nPlace stars and stripes on a cookie sheet, sheet pan, or large plate. Brush with egg wash. Chill.\n6 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F.\n7 Fill the pie and top with stars and stripes: Spread the strawberries over the part of the sheet pan where the red and white stripes should be. Scoop the blueberries into the corner where the stars should be.\nArrange the stars and strips of dough on top of the berries to form the flag. Chill for 10-15 minutes before baking.\n8 Bake: Bake at 450\xc2\xb0F for 15 minutes. Then tent with foil and lower the heat to 375\xc2\xb0F and bake for another 45 to 55 minutes or longer, until the filling is bubbling.\nRemove from oven and let cool at least an hour before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nRed, White, and Blue Layer Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: 8 to 12 slices\nNote that the prep and cook times for the layer cake and the Swiss meringue are not included in this recipe; both recipes should be prepared in advance before beginning this recipe.\nThe cake layers can be baked and cooled, wrapped tightly in plastic, and stored on the counter for several days. Make the Swiss meringue and frost the cake the same day that you're planning to serve it.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds mixed berries (strawberries, raspberries, and blueberries)\n3 baked and cooled layers of Vanilla Buttermilk Cake\n1 recipe for Swiss meringue frosting (about 4 cups)\nSpecial equipment:\nOffset spatula\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the berries: Wash and dry all the berries. Hull the strawberries to remove the stems. Cut the majority into slices for layering into the cake; cut a few in half or in quarters for decorating the top.\n2 Layer and frost the cake: Place one of the layers of vanilla buttermilk cake onto a cake plate and spread a third of the Swiss meringue over the top using an offset spatula. Distribute about 1 cup of berries and sliced strawberries over the Swiss meringue.\nTop with the second layer of cake. Spread another third of the frosting over top and another cup of berries and strawberries.\nRepeat with the remaining layer of cake, ending with a layer of Swiss meringue topped by the remaining berries and the halves or quartered strawberries.  \n3 Serve the cake: Serve the cake with any remaining berries alongside. The cake is best eaten the day it is assembled.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nPanna Cotta with Summer Berries Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 4 hours or overnightYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the panna cotta:\nVegetable oil, or vegetable oil spray (for the molds)\n1/2 cup cold milk\n3 teaspoons unflavored gelatin powder\n3 cups heavy cream\n1/3 cup (67g) sugar\nPinch of salt\n1/2 cup sour cream\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the sauce and berries:\n1 12-ounce package (about 3 cups) frozen raspberries, defrosted\n3 tablespoons sugar\n3 tablespoons orange juice\n2 cups fresh blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, sliced strawberries, or a mix\nSpecial equipment:\n6 (6-ounce) ramekins, or other similarly sized molds or serving dishes\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the molds: Lightly brush or spray six 6-ounce ramekins with oil. (Skip this step if you are planning to serve straight from the dishes.)\nPlace the ramekins on a baking sheet for easy transfer of the panna cotta from the counter to the fridge.\n2 Soften the gelatin: Pour the milk into a medium mixing bowl and sprinkle the gelatin over top. Stir with a fork to combine. Set aside for 5 minutes without stirring to allow the gelatin to soften. (It will look like curdled milk or milky applesauce.)\n3 Warm the cream and sugar: In a medium saucepan over medium heat, bring the cream, sugar, and salt to a simmer. Stir frequently until the sugar is dissolved and the milk is just starting to steam. Do not let it come to a boil (if it does, let it cool slightly before continuing to the next step).\n4 Whisk the cream into the gelatin: Slowly pour the hot cream over the gelatin, whisking as you go in order to dissolve the gelatin. Rub a little of the cream mixture between your fingers to make sure the gelatin has dissolved; it should feel smooth, not grainy.\n5 Whisk in the sour cream and vanilla until smooth.\n6 Fill and chill the molds: Divide the panna cotta mixture between the ramekins. Transfer to the ramekins to the fridge and chill for at least 4 hours until set, or overnight.\n7 Make the raspberry sauce: Close to when you're ready to serve, puree the raspberries, sugar and orange juice in a blender until smooth. Pass through a fine meshed strainer to remove the seeds. Set aside or refrigerate until needed. (This sauce can also be made several days in advance and kept refrigerated.)\n8 Unmold the panna cotta: Slide a paring knife around the edge of each ramekin. Place a dessert plate upside-down over the top of the ramekin. Holding the plate in position, flip it over so the ramekin is now upside down on top of the plate. Slowly lift the ramekin at a slight angle to release the panna cotta.\nSpoon some of the sauce around the panna cotta and sprinkle with berries. (If you're serving straight from the dish, spoon some of the sauce over top and sprinkle with berries.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nRicotta and Summer Berry Parfaits Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n4 ounces cream cheese, cut into chunks and softened to room temperature\n2 tablespoons honey\n2 teaspoons finely grated lemon zest\n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 cups (12 ounces) whole milk ricotta cheese\n3 tablespoons strawberry jam\n4 cups mixed fresh berries, such as blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced strawberries\n2 tablespoons chopped pistachios (for garnish)\nMint leaves (for garnish)\nMETHOD\n1 Make the ricotta cream: Combine the cream cheese, honey, lemon zest, 1 tablespoon of the lemon juice and vanilla in a mixing bowl, and beat with an electric mixer for 1 to 2 minutes on medium speed, until light and fluffy. Beat in the ricotta until smooth.\n2 Glaze the berries: Use a spatula to push the jam through a fine mesh strainer into a small mixing bowl; this will remove any tiny seeds in the jam. Add the remaining1 tablespoon of the lemon juice to the strained jam and mix until smooth. Add the berries and stir to coat them.\n3 Assemble the parfaits: Into four dessert glasses or bowls, layer 1 to 2 tablespoon of the berries and 2 to 3 tablespoons ricotta mixture. Repeat, ending with berries on top. Sprinkle with chopped pistachios, and garnish with mint leaves.\nThe fruit and ricotta can be layered into dishes and refrigerated for up to a day. Sprinkle with pistachios and mint until just before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBerry Almond Crumble Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6\nRecipe by Melissa Clark of The New York Times.\nInstant tapioca is needed as a thickener. You can make this without it, but it will be quite runny. If you don't have instant tapioca, you can try substituting corn starch.\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling:\n8 cups mixed fresh berries: blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, strawberries\n1 Tbsp quick-cooking tapioca\n2 to 3 tablespoons granulated sugar, depending upon sweetness of berries\n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest\nCrumble Topping:\n1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour\n1/3 cup dark brown sugar\n1/3 cup granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\nA pinch of salt\n1/2 cup melted butter\n1/2 cup finely chopped almonds.\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Mix berries with tapioca, sugar, zest: In a large bowl put berries and mix with tapioca, sugar and lemon zest. (Without tapioca, crumble will be very runny.) Set aside.\n3 Make the topping: Whisk together the flour, sugars, spices and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the melted butter and almonds until coarse crumbs form.\n4 Assemble: Pour the filling into a 9-inch square or round pan (do not grease first). Using your fingers, form topping mixture into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch crumbs and spread over cake.\n5 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until filling bubbles and topping is light golden, about 45-55 minutes.\nLet cool at least half an hour. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nApricot Berry Cobbler Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nINGREDIENTS\nCobbler Filling:\n5 cups pitted, quartered apricots (Blenheims if you can get a hold of some)\n3 cups blackberries (or boysenberries or blueberries)\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n2 Tbsp flour (for thickening)\nCobbler Topping:\n2 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick or 4 ounces) butter softened plus 1/4 cup melted butter\n1 cup buttermilk\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n2 Tbsp brown sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss the apricots with sugar and flour, place in baking dish: In medium bowl toss the apricots, berries, 1 cup white sugar, and 2 Tbsp flour together.\nPlace filling into baking dish (one 9x13x2 baking dish, or two smaller baking dishes).\n2 Whisk flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, sugar, then work in butter: Whisk together the 2 cups of flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, 1 Tbsp white sugar in a medium bowl.\nCut the butter into small cubes and toss into the flour mixture. Work the butter with your fingers to smear it and crumble it into the flour, until the mixture resembles a coarse cornmeal.\nTip: at this point, if you briefly heat the apricot berry mixture in the microwave or oven, until it is warm, it will help the biscuit topping to rise.\n3 Add almond extract and buttermilk: Add almond extract to the buttermilk, then form a well in the middle of the flour mixture and pour in the buttermilk.\nGently mix (with wooden spoon or your hands) until the dough just comes together. Do not over-mix.\n4 Form "cobblestone" shapes of the dough and arrange on the top of the apricot berry mixture. (You can also just crumble the dough over the top.) Sprinkle brown sugar over the top of the dough. Drizzle melted butter over the top (aim for the fruit more than the biscuits).\n5 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Let the cobbler sit and rise for 10-20 minutes before baking.\n6 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 10-15 minutes or until the top is just beginning to brown, then reduce the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cook for an additional 30 to 40 more minutes, until the center fruit is thickened and bubbly.\nCheck during cooking, if the topping is getting too brown, cover it with foil and turn the heat down to 325\xc2\xb0F.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nShrimp with Orange Beurre Blanc Recipe\nINGREDIENTS\nShrimp Ingredients\nFresh Gulf of Mexico shrimp - 6 per person, or about 1/4 pound per person\nExtra virgin olive oil\nSalt and pepper\nSauce ingredients (Sauce also posted here. Makes 1 cup, enough for 4-6 servings. Divide or multiply to needs.)\n2 oranges\n1/2 cup (120 ml) white wine\n2 teaspoons minced shallots\n1/2 pound (2 sticks, 225 g) cold, unsalted butter\nSalt and white pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Peel and de-vein the shrimp. Work with the shrimp one at a time, leaving the rest in a bowl of ice water. Holding on to the body of the shrimp, use your fingers to pull off head if it is still attached, and then the legs.\nStarting with the head end, gently peel back the shell. Use your fingernails or a knife to cut into the base shell segment.\nRemove the shrimp from its shell entirely. Place shrimp down flat on a cutting board and use a small sharp knife to make a shallow cut down the back of the shrimp.\nYou may see a dark, vein-like intestinal tract running through the meat. Use your fingers, or the sharp tip of a knife to remove. As you complete each shrimp, put into a bowl of ice water to keep cool. Set aside while you prepare the sauce.\n2 Make orange syrup: Zest half of one orange (about 2 teaspoons) and juice the two oranges (about 3/4 cup). Put the juice, zest, wine and shallots in a sauce pan on medium high heat. Cook until it is syrupy and almost gone.\n3 Whisk in the butter: On low heat, whisk in the butter continuously and vigorously, 1 tablespoon at a time. Butter is the only emulsifier for this sauce, and if you slowly add it, continuously stirring, the sauce will achieve a silky smooth texture. Do not let the sauce boil. Salt and pepper to taste. Keep warm while you continue with the shrimp.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the shrimp: Heat a skillet on medium high heat. Drain the shrimp and coat with olive oil. When the pan is hot, add the shrimp and sprinkle on some salt and pepper.\nCook the shrimp about 45 seconds on each side. Add some more olive oil if necessary to keep the shrimp from sticking to the pan. Do not overcook or the shrimp will be tough and rubbery.\n5 Drizzle with sauce: Drizzle Beurre Blanc sauce over shrimp, or serve in a separate small container for dipping.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nRed, White, and Blue Layer Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: 8 to 12 slices\nNote that the prep and cook times for the layer cake and the Swiss meringue are not included in this recipe; both recipes should be prepared in advance before beginning this recipe.\nThe cake layers can be baked and cooled, wrapped tightly in plastic, and stored on the counter for several days. Make the Swiss meringue and frost the cake the same day that you're planning to serve it.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds mixed berries (strawberries, raspberries, and blueberries)\n3 baked and cooled layers of Vanilla Buttermilk Cake\n1 recipe for Swiss meringue frosting (about 4 cups)\nSpecial equipment:\nOffset spatula\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the berries: Wash and dry all the berries. Hull the strawberries to remove the stems. Cut the majority into slices for layering into the cake; cut a few in half or in quarters for decorating the top.\n2 Layer and frost the cake: Place one of the layers of vanilla buttermilk cake onto a cake plate and spread a third of the Swiss meringue over the top using an offset spatula. Distribute about 1 cup of berries and sliced strawberries over the Swiss meringue.\nTop with the second layer of cake. Spread another third of the frosting over top and another cup of berries and strawberries.\nRepeat with the remaining layer of cake, ending with a layer of Swiss meringue topped by the remaining berries and the halves or quartered strawberries.  \n3 Serve the cake: Serve the cake with any remaining berries alongside. The cake is best eaten the day it is assembled.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nPumpkin Biscotti Recipe\nYield: Makes about 40 cookies\nMeasure flour by fluffing up the flour in its container, then do a scoop with a measuring cup, and level the top with the edge of a dull dinner knife (the "scoop and level" method).\nIf you don\'t have molasses, sub out the white sugar and the molasses with one cup (packed) of brown sugar.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups of flour (330 g), plus more for shaping the dough\n1 teaspoon of baking powder\n1 teaspoon of cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon of ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon of ground cloves\n1/4 teaspoon of salt\n7/8 cup (175 g) of sugar (that\'s 1 cup minus 2 tablespoons)\n1 Tbsp molassses\n2 large eggs, room temperature\n1/2 cup (100 g) of pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e\n2 Tbsp melted butter\n1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1/2 cup dried sweetened cranberries (optional0\n1/2 cup toasted chopped pecans or walnuts (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whisk flour, baking powder, salt, spices: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, ground cloves, and salt into a bowl.\n2 Whisk wet ingredients and sugar: In a separate large bowl, whisk together the sugar, molasses, eggs, pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e, melted butter, and vanilla extract.\n3 Combine dry with wet ingredients: Add the dry mixture to the wet mixture a third at a time, stirring after each addition. The dough should be rather wet and sticky.\nIf adding dried cranberries or toasted chopped nuts, stir them in now.\n4 Form the dough: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat.\nSprinkle a clean surface with about 1/4 cup of flour. Scoop the dough onto the floured surface. Flour your hands and lightly knead the dough a few times.\nDivide the dough in half.\nForm the dough into 2 long logs, each about 10-11 inches long.\nTransfer the logs onto the lined baking sheet and use your fingers to flatten them into long rectangles.\nThe loaves should be relatively flat, about 10 to 11 inches long, about 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 inches wide, and about 1/2-inch high.\n5 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes, until lightly browned all over and the center is firm to the touch.\n6 Slice biscotti and bake again: Let biscotti cool for 10 minutes and then use a serrated knife cut into 1/2 inch to 3/4-inch wide pieces.\nLay the cookies cut side down on baking sheets. Bake for 15-20 minutes more, turning the cookies over halfway through the cooking.\nCool completely.\nStore in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCranberry Pistachio Chocolate Biscotti Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: About 5 dozen small biscotti\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (280 grams) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (200 grams) sugar\n1/2 cup (47.5 grams) unsweetened Dutch process cocoa powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/8 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon finely grated orange zest\n3/4 cup dried sweetened cranberries\n3/4 cup shelled pistachios\n3 large eggs\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xbaF. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n2 Combine dry ingredients: In a large bowl, sift the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Stir in the orange zest, cranberries and pistachios until combined.\n3 Whisk together the eggs and vanilla, in a separate bowl.\n4 Make the dough: Add the eggs to the bowl of dry ingredients and stir until blended. Use your hands as necessary to bring the dough together, mixing until no more dry flour remains.\n5 Shape the dough: On a lightly floured surface, turn out the dough and divide it in half. Shape each half into a log roughly 12 inches long and 2 inches wide. Place the logs about 4 inches apart on one of the baking sheets.\n6 Bake the biscotti logs: Bake the logs for 30 minutes, rotating the pans halfway through. When done, the logs should be risen and slightly firm. (They will still be a little soft in the center and that's ok.)\n7 Cool the logs for 10 minutes: Slide the logs, still on the parchment, onto a wire rack to cool for 10 minutes. The logs should still be warm and a little soft. Do not let the logs cool for longer or they become to crisp and brittle to slice neatly.\n8 Slice the logs into biscotti: Transfer the logs to a cutting board. Use a serrated knife to cut the logs into slices roughly 1/2-inch thick \xe2\x80\x93 cut at a right angle for small biscotti or at a sharp angle for larger biscotti.\nTransfer the biscotti to the baking sheets. Arrange the cookies close together, but without touching.\n9 Bake the cookies: Bake for 8 minutes. Turn the slices over and continue baking for 5 to 6 minutes longer, or until the biscotti are firm and dry. Cool on a wire rack.\nThe finished biscotti will keep for 2 weeks in an airtight container, but I doubt you will have them around that long. The baked cookies will also freeze well for up to 3 months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nGinger Almond Biscotti Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 50 minutesChilling the dough time: 1 hourYield: Makes about 36 biscotti\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup blanched slivered almonds\n3/4 cup (170 g) sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick) butter\n1/2 cup molasses (NOT blackstrap molasses, it's too bitter)\n3 large eggs\n1/4 cup minced fresh ginger\n3 cups (400 g) all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1 teaspoon cinnamon and nutmeg\n1/2 teaspoon each ground cloves and allspice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bake the almonds: Spread the almonds out on a sheet pan and bake them at 350\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes. Let cool, then roughly chop.\n2 Make the biscotti dough base: Beat together the sugar and butter until light and fluffy (about 3 to 4 minutes). Add the molasses and beat a minute more.\nAdd eggs one at a time, beating for 1 minute after each addition. Mix in the minced ginger.\n3 Mix in the dry ingredients and the almonds: Whisk together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, ground cloves and allspice.\nAdd the flour mixture into the butter and eggs mixture, one third at a time. Stir in the almonds.\n4 Refrigerate the dough for 1 hour.\n5 Shape into long rectangles: Turn the dough out onto a well-floured board, and divide in half. With floured hands, shape into long rectangles about 10-12 inches long, 2 1/2 inches wide and 1/2 inch high. Transfer to a parchment or silicone lined baking sheet.\n6 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until golden brown and firm to the touch in the center, 25 to 30 minutes. Remove from oven, and let stand until cool enough to handle.\n7 Cut diagonally: Transfer the rectangles to a cutting board. Using a serrated bread knife, cut the rectangles on the diagonal into 1/2-inch-thick slices.\n8 Bake again: Return pieces cut side down to baking sheet. Re-bake 15-18 minutes, turning the biscotti over half way through baking.\nCool on wire rack. Store in airtight container.\nDip in wine after dinner (classic Italian fashion) or coffee, tea, or hot cocoa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nBiscuits and Gravy Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 12 servings\nThe cornstarch in the biscuit dough reduces the gluten content to help keep the biscuits light and fluffy.\nIf you have White Lily Flour, use 2 1/2 cups of White Lily flour instead of all-purpose, and omit the cornstarch.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the biscuits:\n2 1/4 cups (315 g) all-purpose flour (see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons cornstarch\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 cup unsalted butter, cold\n1 cup buttermilk, cold\nFor the gravy:\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 pound sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup chopped yellow onions\n1 pound breakfast pork sausage\n6 tablespoons all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon ground sage\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 1/2 cups milk, preferably whole\nFor topping:\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter, melted\nSpecial equipment:\n2-quart glass or ceramic baking dish, rectangular or square\n2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the biscuit dough: Combine the flour, cornstarch, baking powder, and salt in a large bowl. Cut the butter into 1/2-inch chunks and sprinkle it over the dry ingredients. Using a pastry blender, a butter knife, or a fork, cut the butter into the dry ingredients until most of it is the size of peas. Don\xe2\x80\x99t overwork it; you want to leave some of the butter in chunks.\nAdd the buttermilk and toss the mixture with a spatula until it starts to look shaggy, and most of the buttermilk has been absorbed. It won\xe2\x80\x99t form a dough yet; that\xe2\x80\x99s OK.\n3 Bring the dough together: Turn out the contents of the bowl onto a clean surface dusted with a little flour. Gather the dough together with your hands into a mound, then roll it out until it is about 10-inches wide. Again, don\xe2\x80\x99t worry if the dough is crumbly!\n4 Fold the dough to create flaky layers: Use a spatula (like the kind you use to make fried eggs) or bench scraper and flip 1/3 of the dough over from the left to the center. Then flip the other side over that side. You\xe2\x80\x99re basically folding the dough over like a letter.\nRotate the dough 90-degrees and roll it out again to about a 10-inch square. It will start to feel more like a dough and less crumbly at this point, but there will still be some loose chunks. Just press them back into the dough if they fall out, and resist the urge to add more liquid.\nRepeat the process of rolling out and folding two more times. By the fourth time, the biscuit dough will hold together and feel like actual dough.\n5 Cut the biscuits: Roll out the dough to a 10-inch square that\xe2\x80\x99s roughly 1/2 inch thick. Using a 2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter, cut out 16 circles. When you press down to cut out the dough, don\xe2\x80\x99t twist the biscuit cutter, which will \xe2\x80\x9cseal\xe2\x80\x9d the edges of the dough. Instead, just cut straight down, so the biscuit will rise and be as flaky as possible.\n5 Bake the bottom layer of biscuits: Set aside 12 of the biscuit rounds. Place the remaining 4 biscuit rounds on the bottom of a 2-quart glass or ceramic casserole dish. Cut up the remaining scraps of dough and jigsaw-puzzle the remaining dough into the bottom of the casserole dish, making sure to cover the bottom in a single layer.\nPlace on a rimmed baking sheet (for ease of removal from the oven and to catch any drips). Bake in the oven for 15 minutes or until the top of the biscuits start to look dry but not brown at all. (There might be a slight darkening around the edges, but don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed if the biscuits still look pale white.)\n6 Meanwhile, make the gravy: While the bottom biscuits are baking, make the gravy by placing the oil, mushrooms, and onions in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Cook on high heat, stirring constantly, until the mushrooms start to soften, and the onions start to look translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the sausage, breaking it up with a wooden spoon or spatula, and cook until the sausage starts to brown, about 5 minutes.\nKeep the heat on high, and add the flour, sage, black pepper, nutmeg, and salt to the pan. Stir until the ingredients are absorbed. Pour in the milk, reduce heat to medium, and cook, continuing to stir until the liquid has started to bubble and thicken, about 3 to 7 minutes. You\xe2\x80\x99re now ready to assemble the casserole!\nIf the first layer of biscuits isn\xe2\x80\x99t done baking, lower the heat on the gravy to a simmer until the biscuits are done. If you still need time to finish the gravy, but the biscuits are done\xe2\x80\x94remove the casserole dish from the oven, and let it sit on the counter or stovetop while you finish the gravy.\n7 Assemble and bake the casserole: Once the gravy has thickened and the first layer of biscuits is done baking, pour or spoon the gravy over the biscuit layer in the casserole dish. Place the 12 reserved biscuits over the gravy and brush the top of the biscuits with the melted butter.\nReturn the dish to the oven and bake until the biscuits are golden brown and the gravy is bubbling and thick, about 18 to 23 minutes.\n8 Cool and serve: Let cool 10 minutes before serving warm from the casserole dish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBisquick Shortcake Biscuits Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Makes 6 biscuits\nA delicious vegan and dairy-free variation of the basic Bisquick biscuit recipe is to swap out the milk with almond milk and the melted butter with melted coconut oil.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/3 cups Bisquick baking mix\n3 tablespoons butter, melted (can sub coconut oil)\n1/2 cup milk (can sub unsweetened almond milk)\n3 tablespoons sugar\nMETHOD\n1 Heat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the dough: Whisk together the baking mix and sugar in a mixing bowl. Stir in the milk and melted butter just until a soft dough comes together. Don't over-mix!\n3 Portion out dough and place on cookie sheet: Grease a cookie sheet with butter. Divide the dough into roughly 6 equal portions and drop them on the cookie sheet.\n4 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 10 to 12 minutes or until golden brown. Cool for 5 minutes on a rack.\n5 Serve: Either break up into big chunks or slice horizontally with a bread knife to serve with berries for shortcake.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nStrawberry Shortcake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 9\nI updated the biscuit recipe to use less cream. If you liked the original, use 1 1/2 cups of heavy whipping cream in place of the 1 cup of milk and 1/4 cup of cream.\nINGREDIENTS\nStrawberries:\n3 baskets of fresh strawberries (about 6 cups)\n1/2 cup (100 g) white granulated sugar for the strawberries\nWhipped Cream:\n1 cup (236 ml) of heavy whipping cream\n2 teaspoons powdered sugar\n2 drops of vanilla extract\nBiscuits:\n3 1/4 cups (455g) all purpose flour, divided ( 3 cups and 1/4 cup)\n3 tablespoons sugar\n1 1/2 tablespoons baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n12 tablespoons (168g) unsalted butter, cut into small cubes\n1 cup (236 ml) milk\n1/4 (60 ml) cup heavy cream\n1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nSTRAWBERRIES\n1 Prep the strawberries: Cut the stems away from the strawberries and discard. Cut the strawberries in half, and then either quarters or thick slices.\n2 Macerate the strawberries with sugar: Put the cut strawberries into a large bowl and sprinkle with sugar. Start with 1/4 cup of sugar and then add up to another 1/4 cup depending on how sweet your strawberries are. Gently stir the strawberries until they are all coated with some sugar.\nLet sit at room temperature for about 20 minutes, until the berries soften and begin to release their juices.\n3 Mash some of the strawberries: After 20 minutes or so, mash about a quarter of the berries in the bowl with a potato masher and stir to mix.\nYou don't want to mash all the berries, just enough of them for their juices. Let sit while you bake the biscuits.\n4 Bake the biscuits using one of the recipes below.\n5 Make whipped cream: While the biscuits are baking, whip the cream using an electric mixer, adding a drop or two of vanilla and 2 teaspoons of powdered sugar. Cover with plastic and place in the refrigerator to chill until ready to serve.\nTo serve, break up one biscuit per person into big pieces into a bowl. Ladle strawberries over the biscuit. Add a dollop of whipped cream.\nHOMEMADE BISCUITS\n1 Stir flour with dry ingredients: In a large bowl, vigorously whisk together 3 cups of the flour, the sugar, baking powder, and salt.\n2 Work in the butter: Cut the butter into the flour mixture, either using your fingers, a pastry cutter, a fork, or a food processor, until the largest pieces of butter are the size of peas.\n3 Add the wet ingredients: Stir together the milk and cream, add the vanilla extract. Make a well in the center of the flour and pour the milk mixture into it.\nMix with a fork or wooden spoon until the mixture is just combined. It should look rather shaggy. If it is too wet to work with, sprinkle some of the remaining 1/4 cup of flour over it. Gently knead by hand a few times to form a loose ball of dough, adding more flour if needed. It should be slightly tacky but not wet.\n4 Chill: Place the dough on a lightly floured surface and form it into an 8-inch square, about 3/4-inch to an inch thick. Place it on a parchment or silicone-lined baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap and chill for 20 minutes.\n5 Bake: Heat the oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Remove the dough from refrigerator. Cut the dough into 9 even squares and space them about 2 inches apart from each other on the baking sheet.\nBake until the biscuits are medium golden brown, 18 to 20 minutes.\nMakes 9 biscuits.\nBisquick biscuits:\nFor quick and easy shortcake biscuits using Bisquick baking mix, see our Bisquick shortcake biscuit recipe.\nGluten-free biscuits:\nFor flaky, fluffy, tender gluten-free biscuits, see our Gluten-free Biscuits Recipe.\nDairy-free vegan biscuits:\nFor easy, tender vegan shortcake biscuits, see our Dairy-free Vegan Biscuits recipe.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Make Gluten-Free Biscuits Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesChilling time: 30 minutesYield: 10 (2 1/2-inch) biscuits\nYou can also bring this dough together in the food processor (with gentle pulses) and by hand (soak your hands in cold water; the butter should be even colder), but we have found that using the stand mixer works quickly and requires the least amount of manual interference with cold butter. And this is what you want for flaky biscuits!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (about 300 g) gluten-free flour mix, preferably Bob\xe2\x80\x99s Red Mill 1-to-1 Gluten-Free Baking Blend or another flour blend with xanthan gum\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon baking soda\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (8 tablespoons) very cold butter, cut into tablespoons and then cut in half, plus more to grease the pan\n3/4 to 1 cup cup cold buttermilk\n1 tablespoon melted unsalted butter\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch cast iron skillet, or 8x8 baking dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine dry ingredients: Mix flour, baking powder, baking soda, sugar, and salt in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. \n2 Add the butter: On the low speed, let the mixer break up the butter into smaller pieces; this should take about a minute. Stop the mixer and check; you still want visible pieces of butter about the size of marbles or even a little bigger. They will look like they are starting to flatten.\nThis dough is not a situation where we say the flour and butter should look like \xe2\x80\x9cthe consistency of small peas.\xe2\x80\x9d If some of the pieces haven't flattened, just press them between your fingertips to break them up a little bit\xe2\x80\x94dime-sized pieces are fine.\n3 Add the buttermilk: Remove the bowl from the stand mixer and add 2 tablespoons of buttermilk. Using a fork, quickly mix the buttermilk into the flour to hydrate it.\nThen, slowly mix in a scant 3/4 cup of buttermilk and combine with a fork until no streaks of flour remain. If the dough seems dry, add additional buttermilk a tablespoon at a time and incorporate before adding more. You don't want a wet dough.\n4 Gather the dough into a ball: On a floured surface, turn out the dough, which will look like a crumbly mess. It will come together when you begin to shape it into a ball. If for some reason (ambient humidity, variations in buttermilk thickness) the dough feels dry, add a couple of tablespoons of buttermilk to hydrate those dry bits.\n5 Fold the dough like a letter: Lightly press the dough (or roll it with a floured rolling pin) into a thick rectangular shape, about 4 inches by 6 inches. Fold one of the short ends of the dough toward the middle, and then the other, like a letter.\nRotate the dough 1/4 turn and roll it out, and fold it again into thirds. Repeat this process one more time, then wrap the dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 1/2 hour to an hour. (This process creates flaky layers; if you skip it, your biscuits will bake flat, like hockey pucks.) \n6 Prep the oven and pan: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F and prep a 9- or 10-inch cast iron pan or an 8x8 glass baking dish with either spray oil or grease with butter.\n7 Roll and cut out the biscuits: Remove the dough from the fridge and, using a rolling pin, gently roll it out to a rectangle about 6 inches by 9 inches and one inch thick. Using a 2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter that\xe2\x80\x99s been lightly floured (this dough can be sticky), cut out about 6 biscuits by pressing the cutter straight down into the dough; if you twist them when you remove them, you\xe2\x80\x99ll stunt their rise!\nReroll the scraps, reflouring the biscuit cutter if needed, and make more biscuits until all the dough is used up.\nTransfer to the pan. You will have to nestle them close to each other, and that\xe2\x80\x99s okay. You want them touching in order for them to rise better. Brush the tops with the melted butter.\n8 Bake: Bake the biscuits for 20 to 25 minutes until the tops look lightly brown around the edges. Check frequently to avoid burning.\n9 Cool and serve: Remove from the oven and brush the tops with melted butter. Let the biscuits cool in the pan for about 5 to 10 minutes before removing from the pan to a wire rack to cool completely. Try to wait the seemingly impossible 10 minutes before you eat one. They will continue to cook a little, firm up a little while cooling, and not burn your mouth. It\xe2\x80\x99s all worth the wait.\nThese biscuits are best eaten warm out of the oven, but they do okay reheated in a toaster or low oven (300\xc2\xb0F) for up to 2 days. They get dried out pretty fast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBiscuits and Gravy Recipe\nCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes 10 to 12 servings\nI recommend preparing the biscuits first (not baking them), getting the gravy started, and then baking the biscuits while the gravy is thickening up. That way you can stir the gravy frequently which is hard to do when your hands are covered with flour and dough.\nIf you don't have self-rising flour, you can substitute using a ratio of 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 1/4 teaspoon baking powder, plus 1/8 teaspoon of salt, for every cup of self-rising flour.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the Buttermilk Biscuits:\n2 1/2 cups self-rising flour (plus extra for flouring your surface)\n2 tsp sugar (optional)\n1/2 tsp kosher salt\n4 Tbsp vegetable shortening (see Baking Tips below)\n4 Tbsp butter, cut into cubes, chilled\n1 cup chilled buttermilk, plus 1-2 Tbsp more, if needed\n1 Tbsp melted butter (optional, to brush on top of biscuits after baking)\nFor the Sausage Gravy:\n1 lb sage-flavored pork sausage\n1/4 cup finely chopped white or yellow onion\n6 tbsp all purpose flour\n4 cups whole milk\n1/2 tsp poultry seasoning\n1/4 tsp ground nutmeg\n1/4 tsp salt\n1-2 dashes of Worcestershire sauce\n1-2 dashes of Tabasco sauce, cayenne pepper, or other hot sauce\n1-2 Tbsp butter or bacon grease (if needed)\nMETHOD\nTO MAKE THE BUTTERMILK BISCUITS:\nBaking Tips: 1) Spoon the flour into your measuring cup, and level it off with the back side of a knife. If you scoop the flour, it will pack into the measuring cup, yielding too much flour, 2) Instead of 4 Tbsp each of butter and shortening, feel free to use 8 Tbsp of shortening or butter, or any combination up to 8 Tbsp.\n1 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Prepare a floured surface for shaping the dough and have an un-greased baking sheet ready (lined with Silpat sheets if you have them).\n2 Whisk together flour, sugar and salt in a medium-sized bowl.\n3 Using a fork or a pastry blender cut in the shortening and butter. Work quickly, you don\xe2\x80\x99t want the fats to melt \xe2\x80\x93 the key to fluffy biscuits is minimal handling. The mixture should be crumbly.\n4 Make a well in the flour mixture, and pour in the buttermilk. Stir with a spoon and blend just until the liquid is absorbed and the dough comes away from the sides of the bowl \xe2\x80\x93 add 1-2 tbsp more buttermilk if the dough is dry. Do not over mix; the dough will be tacky, neither wet nor dry.\n5 Fold and shape dough: With lightly floured hands, turn out the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and gently fold it over on itself 2 or 3 times. Shape into a 3/4\xe2\x80\x9d thick round. If you use a rolling pin, be sure to flour it first to keep the dough from sticking to the pin.\n6 Cut out biscuits: Using a 2-inch biscuit cutter, cut out the biscuits pressing straight down (avoid the temptation to twist the cutter as twisting keeps the biscuits from rising). Dip the cutter in flour between cuttings to keep the dough from sticking to the cutter.\nPlace biscuits on the baking sheet so that they just touch (for crunchy sides, leave space in between). Reshape scrap dough and continue cutting. Remember to handle the dough as little as possible.\n(At this point you can start on making the sausage gravy below, and put the biscuits in the oven right before adding the milk in the last gravy step.)\n7 Bake: Bake at 450\xc2\xb0F for 15-18 minutes or until lightly golden brown on top. Turn the baking sheet around halfway through baking.\n8 Brush with butter: (Optional) Brush the tops of the biscuits with melted butter.\nTO MAKE THE SAUSAGE GRAVY:\n1 Brown the sausage, stir in onions: Preheat a 4-quart saucepan over medium high heat (put a few drops of water in the pan \xe2\x80\x93 when they evaporate, you know the pan is ready). Crumble the sausage into the pan and let it brown for a minute or two, then turn down to medium heat.\nContinue cooking, breaking up the sausage into smaller pieces, until no pink remains. Stir in the onions and cook until they are transparent.\n2 Adjust fat, add flour, brown the flour: Remove sausage with a slotted spatula or spoon, leaving the drippings in the pan. If less than 3 tbsp of drippings remain, add enough butter (or bacon grease) to equal about 3 tbsp of drippings.\nAdd the cooked sausage back to the pan on medium heat, and sprinkle the flour over the sausage.\nStir in the flour and cook for about 6-8 minutes, until the mixture starts bubbling and turns slightly golden brown.\n3 Add seasonings: Stir in poultry seasoning, nutmeg, Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco sauce and salt \xe2\x80\x93 cook for 1 minute to deepen the flavors.\n4 Add the milk, and cook until thickened: Slowly add the milk and cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened (about 15 minutes). Be patient, it will thicken!\nTO SERVE THE BISCUITS AND GRAVY:\nTo serve, break a biscuit in half and put it in a bowl or on a plate. Spoon a generous portion of sausage gravy over the biscuit half and top with the other biscuit half.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCheddar and Jalape\xc3\xb1o Biscuits Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 10-12 biscuits\nTaste the jalape\xc3\xb1o. If too mild, include the seeds, if hot, use just the flesh, not the seeds. Adjust the amount to taste. Pepper Jack or Monterey Jack cheese can also be substituted for the cheddar.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/3 cups (175g) all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup (45g) polenta or fine milled corn meal\n3 tablespoons (45g) sugar\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nPinch cayenne pepper\n6 ounces (1 1/2 cups packed, 170g) shredded sharp cheddar cheese, divided (1 1/4 cup and 1/4 cup)\n2 tablespoons diced fresh jalape\xc3\xb1os (more or less to taste)\n3/4 cup + 2 tablespoons heavy cream (200ml), plus extra for brushing\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C).\n2 Whisk dry ingredients, add cheese and jalape\xc3\xb1os: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, polenta, salt, sugar, cayenne, and baking powder.\nStir in 1 1/4 cups of the grated cheddar cheese and the diced jalape\xc3\xb1os.\n3 Add the cream: Make a well in the center of the flour mixture. Pour the cream into the center of the well and your (clean) hands to gently bring together the ingredients.\nIf you need to add a bit more cream then do so a tiny trickle at a time. You just want everything to get wet enough so that the dough will be sticky and clumpy.\n4 Knead the dough, just enough: Turn the dough out onto a surface lightly dusted with flour. Knead the dough just a few times - maybe only three or four pushes. You just want it to just come together. (Over-kneading will result in firmer, denser biscuits.)\n5 Cut out biscuit shapes: Form the dough into a disc about 3/4-inch to an inch thick. Use a biscuit cutter (or a small juice glass) to cut round biscuit shapes out of the disk. Combine the leftover dough and keep forming small round biscuit shapes until the dough is used up.\n6 Brush with cream, sprinkle with cheese: Place on a silicone-lined or parchment lined baking sheet, with at least an inch or two between the biscuits. Brush the tops of the biscuits with a little more cream. Top the biscuits with a sprinkle of the remaining cheese.\n7 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C) for 11-12 minutes or until golden and the cheese is nicely melted.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nSoda Bread Biscuits Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Makes 12 biscuits\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups all purpose flour\n1/4 cup to 1/2 cup of sugar (depending on how sweet you want them)\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon Kosher salt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, room temperature\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds*\n1/2 to 1 cup of raisins*\n1 1/4 cups buttermilk**\n*These add-ins are entirely optional. You could just do plain biscuits, or add in a teaspoon of orange zest, lemon zest, or a couple tablespoons of chopped candied ginger, or a teaspoon of minced rosemary. Have fun with it!\n**You can substitute the 1 1/4 cups buttermilk with 1 cup 3 Tbsp of regular whole milk mixed with 1 Tbsp of white vinegar.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare muffin pan: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Butter a standard muffin pan.\n2 Combine dry ingredients: In a large bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt.\n3 Cut butter into flour, add mix-ins: Cut the butter into tablespoon sized pieces into the bowl of flour. Using your (clean) fingers, work the butter into the flour, schmooshing (technical term) the butter between your fingers and mixing with the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nIf you are using raisins, caraway seeds, or any other add-ins, mix them into the mixture now.\n4 Add buttermilk and form dough: Make a well in the center of the flour. Pour the buttermilk into the center of the well. Use a wooden spoon to gently mix the flour into the buttermilk until the flour is moistened with the buttermilk.\nThen use your hands to form the mixture into a loose, shaggy, slightly sticky ball of dough.\nThe dough should be a little sticky, if it's too dry, add a tablespoon more of buttermilk. If it's just too wet to handle, add a sprinkling more of flour. Do not over-mix!\nAnd at this point work quickly. As soon as the acidic buttermilk interacts with the alkaline baking soda, bubbles will form and leavening will start.\n5 Divide dough among wells of muffin tin: Break off 12-equal portions of the dough and place them in the wells of the muffin tin.\n6 Bake: Put in the oven and bake for 12-13 minutes at 425\xc2\xb0F, until the tops are nicely browned. Remove from the oven and let cool for a couple minutes in the pan. Remove the biscuits from the muffin tin to a rack to cool for a few minutes more.\nServe with butter and jam.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSavory Scones with Goat Cheese and Chives Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 scones\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick) chilled butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n1/4 cup to 1/2 cup of freshly chopped chives (can also use chopped green onions)\n1 5-ounce log soft fresh goat cheese, crumbled\n1 cup buttermilk (plus an extra tablespoon for finish)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Line 2 heavy baking sheets with silpat or parchment paper.\n2 Make the dough: Whisk flour, baking powder, sugar, baking soda, salt and pepper in a large bowl. Using fingertips, rub butter into dry ingredients until coarse meal forms.\nStir in the chives. Add cheese and buttermilk; stir with fork just until a sticky dough forms (bits of cheese will be visible in dough).\n3 Knead the dough and form into rounds, cut into wedges: Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead gently 8 times with floured hands. Do not over-knead!\nForm into a round, about 3/4-inch to an inch thick. Cut the round into 8 wedges.\n4 Use a pastry brush to brush on some extra buttermilk over the surface of the wedges.\n5 Bake: Arrange wedges about 1/2 inch apart on an un-greased large baking sheet and bake at 400\xc2\xb0F in the middle of the oven until golden brown, about 20 minutes.\nCool on a rack.\nBest eaten just baked and warm, with a little butter.\nHello! b"Save It Print\nBison Burger Recipe\nYield: Makes 6-8 burgers\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds ground bison (buffalo)\n2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh sage\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n2 teaspoons black pepper\n1/2 onion, finely chopped\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSmoky barbecue sauce\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the onions: Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions in the olive oil over medium-high heat until translucent. Turn off the heat and let it cool.\n2 Mix onions, sage, salt, pepper into ground bison meat: When the onions are cool enough to touch, use your (clean) hands to gently mix them in with the bison burger meat, and add everything else.\nDo not overwork the meat, it will result in a tough burger. Just gently fold it until the onions, sage, salt and pepper are well mixed in.\n3 Form patties: Form patties with the meat, using about 1/4 to 1/3 of a pound of meat per patty.\nHere's a tip on making the patty: if you press a slight indentation in the center of each patty it will help keep the burgers in a nice disk shape when cooking. Otherwise the burger will start to get a little egg-shaped as the edges contract from cooking.\n4 Grill or fry the burgers: Grill or fry the burgers on medium heat, about 6-7 minutes per side, less or more depending on the thickness of the burger and the heat of the pan/grill, or until the internal temperature is 140\xc2\xb0F for medium rare, or 160\xc2\xb0F for well done.\nA note on internal temperature. If you are getting the ground meat from a source you trust (we got ours from Whole Foods) that does their own grinding on site, or you grind your own meat, you can safely cook the burgers rare or medium rare. Otherwise you'll want to cook the burgers until well done.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t press on your burgers while cooking, and keep the flipping to a minimum.\nLet the burgers rest about 5 minutes before serving.\nServe the burger with lettuce and tomato, topped with a smoky barbecue sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
