b'Save It Print\nBlue Cheese Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 6 minutesChill time: 30 minutesYield: 1/2 cup, or 8 (1-tablespoon) servings\nINGREDIENTS\n3 ounces blue cheese, crumbled plus more for garnish\n3 tablespoons buttermilk\n2 tablespoons sour cream\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon ground mustard powder\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nMETHOD\n1 Combine the ingredients in a medium bowl: Stir together blue cheese, buttermilk, sour cream, garlic clove, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, pepper, ground mustard powder, and salt.\nIf a creamier sauce is desired, blend with an immersion blender or in a food processor.\n2 Refrigerate the sauce: Place in refrigerator for 30 minutes for flavors to blend.\n3 Serve: Use immediately and garnish with additional crumbled blue cheese or transfer to an airtight container and store in refrigerator for up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBlue Cheese Burgers Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesPattie chilling time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 4 burgers\nHere's a tip, although you might be tempted to go with extra lean hamburger meat for this burger, given all the cheese, I don't recommend it, unless you want blue cheese flavored dry burgers.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound ground beef (16-20%)\n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard\n2 cloves minced garlic\n2 green onions, chopped\n1/2 cup (about 2 ounces) crumbled blue cheese\n1 egg\n1 tablespoon water\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Gently mix ground beef with the other ingredients: Put ground beef, mustard, garlic, onions, blue cheese, water, egg, and a sprinkling of salt and pepper into a large bowl. Use your hands to gently mix the ingredients together until just incorporated. Do not over-mix.\n2 Shape into patties and chill: Shape into patties, about 1/2 inch thick and larger than your bun. Refrigerate at least 30 minutes or until you are ready to cook.\n3 Prepare charcoal or gas grill for cooking over high direct heat. Using tongs and a folded up paper towel dipped in vegetable oil, oil the grill grates. Make sure grill is hot and well oiled before laying down the patties.\n4 Season and grill the burgers: Season patties with salt and pepper. Place the patties on the clean, well-oiled grill grate. Grill the burgers for about 5 minutes per side. Do not press down on the burgers while cooking.\nIf you don't have a grill, you can use a grill pan or a cast iron frying pan for the burgers.\nServe on hamburger buns with lettuce and mayonnaise.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nBuffalo Blue Cheese Deviled Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: 24 deviled eggs\nFor reliably easy-to-peel eggs, we recommend steaming them or cooking them in the pressure cooker. You can do this a day or so ahead of time, and then peel them when you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to make this recipe.\n  INGREDIENTS\n1 dozen hard boiled eggs\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 tablespoon Buffalo sauce, such as Frank's Red Hot Sauce\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n2 tablespoons crumbled blue cheese\n2 tablespoons finely diced celery\nTiny cuts of celery leaf or extra celery dice for garnish, optional\nMETHOD\n1 Peel the hard-boiled eggs: Carefully peel the hard-boiled eggs and cut them in half lengthwise. Scoop out the yolks and transfer to a bowl. \n2 Make the filling: Mash together the yolks, Dijon mustard, the buffalo sauce, mayonnaise, blue cheese and celery with a fork.\n3 Fill the eggs: Place a generous scoop of the filling into the hollowed-out white, or place the mixture into a piping bag lined with a wide star tip and pipe the filling. Garnish with the celery leaves (if using) and serve.\nDeviled eggs are best served the day they\xe2\x80\x99re made, but can sit in an airtight container in the fridge or covered in plastic wrap for half a day or so.\nYou can mash up any leftovers with a little extra mayo and mustard and use it for egg salad sandwiches the next day. (This assumes there will be leftovers, which there probably won't be.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCelery, Blue Cheese and Hazelnut Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-8\nTo save time, start by roasting the hazelnuts. While they roast, you can prep all the other ingredients. Celery bunches come in different sizes, so the amounts here are a little inexact. Just make sure you have enough blue cheese so that you get a little with every bite of the celery.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 ounces good quality blue cheese\n3/4 cup hazelnuts\n1 tablespoon butter\n3 tablespoons maple Syrup\nPinch of cayenne\nSalt\n2-3 bunches of celery, tops removed\n12-15 pitted dates (can sub with a handful of dried cranberries or cherries)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil (or hazelnut oil if you happen to have it)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n4 teaspoons lemon juice (if using Meyer lemons, use 2 Tbsp)\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Remove cheese from refrigerator to come to room temperature.\n2 Roast hazelnuts: Place hazelnuts on a rimmed baking sheet in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 30 minutes.\n3 Prep celery and dates: While the nuts are roasting, prepare the other ingredients. Use a vegetable peeler to peel away the tough outer strings of the stalks of celery. Slice the celery stalks on the diagonal into 1/4-inch thick slices.\nSlice the dates lengthwise first in half, then slice the halves lengthwise into 3 or four pieces. If the dates are on the large size, you may want to slice them in half widthwise first. You want to end up with pieces that are about an inch long and a 1/4 inch wide.\n4 Rub outer skin off hazelnuts: Once the hazelnuts have roasted for half an hour, remove them from the oven, let cool for a few minutes. Then rub the hazelnuts together inside of a clean dish towel to remove as much of the outer dark skin as you can.\n5 Glaze hazelnuts: Melt butter in a small skillet. Add a pinch of cayenne and salt. Add the roasted hazelnuts to the pan and toast them on medium low heat for a few minutes, continuously stirring.\nWhen the hazelnuts are hot, turn off the heat and add maple syrup to the pan. Stir to coat the hazelnuts in the maple syrup.\nLet glazed nuts sit in the pan to cool. Later you will scrape them loose with a wooden spoon and serve atop the salad.\n6 Prepare the salad dressing: In a small jar, mix together the olive oil, lemon zest, and lemon juice. Add salt and black pepper to taste. Shake to combine.\n7 Assemble salad: Layer a shallow platter or dish first with the sliced celery, then dates, then crumble the blue cheese over it and sprinkle with glazed hazelnuts. Right before serving, pour dressing over top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nCreamy Blue Cheese Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 1 cup\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon finely chopped shallots\n2 tablespoons white wine vinegar\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n1/3 cup buttermilk\n1/2 cup crumbled blue cheese (about 2 1/2 ounces)\n1 teaspoon chopped chives (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate the shallots: In a bowl, stir the shallots, vinegar, lemon juice, salt, and pepper together. Let sit for 10 minutes to soften the flavor of the shallots.\n2 Add remaining ingredients: Whisk the mayonnaise and buttermilk into the vinegar and shallot mixture. Add the cheese, and mash any large chunks against the side of bowl (you still want a few smaller crumbles). Stir in the chives, if using.\nStore in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nGrape and Walnut Side Salad with Blue Cheese Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 4 Servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup walnut halves and pieces\n10 cups mixed greens such as endive, radicchio, baby kale, romaine or lettuces of your choice\n1 cup halved red grapes\n1/2 to 3/4 cup blue cheese dressing or (to taste)\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the walnuts: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xbaF. On a baking sheet, spread the walnuts. Toast for 8 to 10 minutes, or until fragrant and toasty. Remove and let cool while you assemble the salad.\n2 Assemble and toss the salad: Tear the greens into bite-size pieces. Wash and spin them dry (if not already washed), and place them in a salad bowl with the grapes. Drizzle with dressing and toss. Sprinkle the walnuts on top and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBacon and Blue Cheese Guacamole Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nBlue cheese and bacon are salty, so this guacamole might not need as much salt as you are used to adding.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 slices bacon, preferably thick cut\n3 large ripe avocados\n2 to 3 teaspoons red or white wine vinegar\n1/4 cup minced red onion\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\nDash hot pepper sauce, such as Tabasco\n1/2 cup crumbled blue cheese, divided\nSalt to taste\nFor serving:\nTortilla chips\nPretzel chips\nSaltines\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Lay the bacon strips in a large skillet. Turn the heat to medium and cook, turning frequently, until the bacon is crisp, 5 to 10 minutes. Lay on a paper towel-lined plate to drain. When the bacon is cool enough to handle, crumble it and set it aside.\n2 Scoop and mash the avocados: Cut the avocados in half pole-to-pole and twist them open. Remove the pit. (See How to Cut and Peel and Avocado.) With a large spoon, scoop the avocado flesh into a medium bowl. Mash it with a large fork until it\xe2\x80\x99s chunky-smooth.\n3 Add the seasonings: Add 2 teaspoons vinegar, the garlic powder, and the hot pepper sauce; mix well. Reserve 1 tablespoon each bacon and blue cheese for garnish, and gently fold the rest into the guacamole. Taste the guacamole on a chip or cracker, then adjust seasoning with salt. If it tastes flat, add another 1/2 to 1 teaspoon vinegar.\n4 Garnish and serve: Transfer to a serving bowl, then garnish with reserved blue cheese and bacon. This guacamole is best enjoyed within 2 hours, but you can refrigerate leftovers up to a day.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBlueberry Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes one dozen muffins\nIf you are using frozen berries, you can use them frozen, just separate them so they're not sticking together and toss them in flour to coat. Your cooking time may need to increase by a few minutes.\nSome brands of sour cream are much thicker than others. Feel free to dilute the sour cream with a little water if you think it's too thick. You can also substitute the sour cream with plain yogurt; if you do, you likely will not need both tablespoons of added milk.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour, plus 1 tablespoon for dusting the blueberries\n1 tablespoon baking powder (make sure your baking powder is still good! click to see how)\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n8 tablespoons butter (1 stick), melted\n1 cup sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 1/2 cup plain sour cream\n2 tablespoons milk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 1/2 cups blueberries, fresh or frozen (see Recipe Note)\nSpecial equipment:\nStandard 12-cup muffin tin\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the muffin tin: Preheat your oven to 400\xc2\xb0F with a rack in the lower middle. Using a standard 12-well muffin pan, place a muffin liner in each well, or if you don't have muffin liners, grease the inside of the muffin pan wells with vegetable oil or butter.\n2 Toss the berries with flour: Place the blueberries in a bowl. Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of flour over them and gently toss to coat. (The flour will help keep the blueberries from sinking in the muffin as it cooks.)\n3 Mix the dry ingredients: In a mixing bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.\n4 Mix the wet ingredients separately: In a large mixing bowl, place the sour cream, sugar, eggs, milk, melted butter, lemon zest, and vanilla (the wet ingredients). Whisk together until smooth.\n5 Make the batter: Add the dry ingredients to the butter/sugar/egg mixture a third at a time and mix until just incorporated.  Do not over mix!\nGently fold the blueberries into the mixture.\n6  Portion out the muffins: Distribute the dough equally among the cups. You'll need to fill them very high to use all of the batter in 12 muffins, which is fine. They won't spill. If you still have too much dough, start filling another tin.\n7 Bake the muffins: Place the muffins in the oven and bake at 400\xc2\xb0F until the muffins are golden brown, about 20 minutes. (If the muffins are getting too brown, tent with foil.) Test with a bamboo skewer to make sure the centers of the muffins are done.\n8 Cool and serve: Let the muffins cool in the muffin pan for 2 to 3 minutes, then remove them from the pan. Let cool another 10 minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nBaked Blueberry French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesChilling time: 30 minutes up to overnight time: Yield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound loaf rustic bread, cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups of cubes)\n1 1/2 (or 2) cups blueberries, frozen or fresh\n5 large eggs\n2 cups milk (whole or 2%)\n1 cup heavy cream\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n8 tablespoons sugar, divided\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, diced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Assemble the dry ingredients: Butter a 9x13 (or other 3-quart) baking dish. Spread half of the bread cubes in an even layer in the prepared pan. Top with 2/3 of the blueberries, followed by the remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\nIf using frozen blueberries, add them to the casserole while still frozen (do not thaw). This helps prevent the berries from coloring the casserole too much.\n  2 Whisk the liquids: Beat the eggs, milk, cream, vanilla, 6 tablespoons of the sugar, lemon zest, and the salt together. Pour the mixture over the bread cubes, pressing down gently (so you don\xe2\x80\x99t burst the berries) to make sure the egg mixture is absorbed.\n3 Soak at least 30 minutes, or overnight: If soaking overnight, cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F about 15 minutes before you plan to bake the casserole.\n5 Bake the casserole: Just before baking, sprinkle the top of the casserole with the remaining sugar and dot with the diced butter. Bake for 45 minutes, until slightly puffed and golden brown. (Casserole that chilled overnight might take a few minutes longer.)\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before cutting. Serve with a dusting of powdered sugar over top or a drizzle of maple syrup.\nLeftovers will keep, refrigerated, for about a week and can be reheated in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nLemon Blueberry Ricotta Pound Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 5 minutesYield: Serves 10 to 12\nTo quickly bring eggs to room temperature, place them in a bowl of warm water for a few minutes.\nMake sure your baking powder is fresh! Baking powder older than 6 months tends to go flat.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 3/4 cups (250 g) all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature\n1 cup (8 ounces, 230 g) ricotta cheese, left to stand at room temperature for a few minutes to take the chill off\n1 1/2 cups sugar (300 g)\n3 large eggs, room temperature\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1 1/2 cups (140 g) blueberries\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C). Prepare a 9x5-inch loaf pan, smearing the inside with butter.\n2 Whisk the dry ingredients: In a medium bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder and salt.\n2 Toss blueberries with flour: Rinse the blueberries and toss them with a little flour to lightly coat them (this will help keep them from sinking to the bottom of the cake).\n3 Mix wet ingredients and sugar for batter: Use an electric mixer (you can mix by hand but will get better results if you use an electric mixer) to beat together the butter, ricotta, and sugar, on high speed, for 3 minutes, until pale and fluffy.\nAdd the eggs one at a time, mixing on medium speed for one minute after each addition.\nMix in the lemon zest and vanilla extract. Don't worry if the batter looks a little curdled at this point. It isn't curdled; it just looks that way.\n4 Add dry ingredients, then blueberries: Remove the bowl from the mixer and stir in the dry ingredients in 3 or 4 additions, until just incorporated. Do not over mix. Stir in the blueberries.\n5 Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan, smoothing out the top with a rubber spatula. Place on a baking sheet on the middle oven rack of the oven. (This will help moderate the temperature at the bottom of the pan.)\n6 Bake: Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C) for 1 hour 10 minutes to 1 hour 20 minutes, or until a tester inserted into the center comes out mostly clean, or if you press on the center with your fingers and lift up, the cake surface gently bounces back.\nAfter the first 40 minutes of baking you may want to put a sheet of aluminum foil over the top of the pan to keep it from browning further.\n7 Cool: Remove from oven and let cool for 15 minutes in the pan. Then run a dull knife around the edge of the cake to make sure it is separated from the pan.\nGently remove the cake from the pan and let cool completely on a wire rack. Let cook completely before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBerry and Banana Terrine Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 envelopes (1/4 ounce each) unflavored gelatin\n2 cups white grape juice, divided\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar\n6 cups of mixed fresh berries and slices of banana (berries can include blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced or quartered strawberries)\nMETHOD\n1 Soften the gelatin: Put 1/4 cup of the white grape juice into a small bowl. Sprinkle the gelatin over the grape juice and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes while the gelatin softens.\n2 Make grape juice gelatin base: Put another 1/4 cup of the white grape juice and a 1/2 cup of sugar into a saucepan and heat on medium high heat until the sugar has dissolved.\nRemove from heat and stir in the gelatin mixture until it has dissolved. Stir in the remaining 1 1/2 cups of grape juice.\n3 Put fruit in loaf pan, cover with grape juice gelatin mixture: Put the berries and banana slices in a 4x8 loaf pan. Pour the grape juice mixture over the berries, and press down on the berries to submerge them into the juice/gelatin mixture.\n4 Chill: Cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator until firm, 3 hours.\n5 Un-mold: To un-mold, fill a basin half-way with hot water. Carefully lower the bottom of the loaf pan into the hot water and hold for 5 to 8 seconds. This will melt the gelatin at the edge of the pan, helping it to release.\nRun a dull knife around the edge of the pan as well.\nPlace a serving platter topside down on top of the loaf pan and turn the whole thing over. Shake gently to release the mold.\nSlice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBerries and Banana Fruit Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups hulled, roughly chopped strawberries\nA handful of raspberries\n1 cup blueberries\n1 apple, peeled, cored, roughly chopped\n2 bananas, peeled and thickly sliced\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon honey\nMETHOD\nPrep the berries before the bananas and apples, and add them to a large bowl.\nAs soon as you add the bananas and apples, sprinkle lemon juice over them to keep them from getting brown.\nAdd the zest and the honey and gently toss to combine.\nServe immediately. Or cover and chill for up to 2 hours before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Buckle Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nMake sure your baking powder is fresh and still active. To test, put a teaspoon of baking powder in a small bowl. Sprinkle with a little warm water. If the baking powder is still good it will bubble up. (See The Difference Between Baking Soda and Baking Powder for more info.)\nINGREDIENTS\nCake ingredients:\n2 cups (260 g) all purpose flour (plus 1-2 Tbsp of flour for dusting the blueberries)\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick, 57 g) unsalted butter, softened\n3/4 cup (150 g) sugar\n1 large egg\n1/2 cup (120 ml) milk\n1 pint (550 ml) blueberries\nTopping ingredients:\n1/4 cup (57 g) unsalted butter, softened\n1/2 cup (100 g) sugar\n1/3 cup (45 g) all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C). Butter the inside of an 8-inch springform pan. Set aside.\n2 Whisk together the 2 cups of flour, the baking powder and the salt in a medium bowl.\n3 Using a stand mixer (or by hand with a wooden spoon) beat together the butter and sugar until fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the egg.\n4 Add the flour mixture in 3 parts, alternating with the milk. Toss the berries with the remaining 1 to 2 tablespoons of flour (to separate and scatter evenly throughout the batter) and fold in. Pour batter into the prepared pan. Set aside.\n5 Combine ingredients (butter, sugar, flour, cinnamon) for topping with a fork (or by hand) to make crumbly mixture. Sprinkle this over the batter.\n6 Bake for one hour, then test for doneness by gently inserting a fork. If it does not come out clean, give the cake another 5 to 10 minutes to bake.\n7 When the cake has cooled, run a knife around the edges and lift the cake out of the pan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nPeach Blueberry Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 8\nIf you are using a dark baking pan, reduce the oven temperature by 25\xc2\xb0F to 350\xc2\xb0F.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pastry crust:\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1 stick (1/2 cup) cold unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n1 large egg\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the filling:\n1/2 cup sugar (can reduce to 1/4 cup of sugar)\n2 Tbsp all-purpose flour\n1 Tbsp instant tapioca (can sub with a Tbsp of cornstarch)\n2 lb ripe, firm, large peaches (about 4), halved lengthwise, pitted, and each half cut lengthwise into four wedges\n1 cup blueberries (1/2 pint)\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nSpecial equipment:\nA 9 to 9 1/2-inch (24-cm) springform pan\nAn electric spice grinder\nFood processor\nMETHOD\n1 Make the crust dough: Put flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt into a food processor and pulse until combined.\nAdd the butter and pulse just a few times, until the pieces of butter are no bigger than a pea.\nAdd the egg and vanilla extract and pulse several more times, until the dough begins to clump together and form a ball.\n2 Press dough into pan: Generously butter the inside of your springform pan. Place a round of parchment paper at the bottom of the pan and butter the top of the parchment as well.\nPress the dough evenly onto the bottom of the pan (about 1/4 inch thick), and about 2 inches up the sides of the pan.\nPut into the refrigerator to chill for at least 10 minutes.\n3 Prepare oven: Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Make the filling: Grind 2 tablespoons sugar with flour and tapioca in a spice grinder until tapioca is powdery. (If using cornstarch instead of instant tapioca, you do not need to grind.)\nTransfer to a large bowl and stir in remaining sugar. Add peaches, blueberries, and lemon juice and gently toss to coat.\n5 Bake: Fill pastry crust with peach and blueberry filling. Cover loosely with foil. Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F until the filling is bubbly in the center and crust is golden, about 1 3/4 hours.\n6 Cool and remove from pan: Remove cake from oven and set on a rack to cool, uncovered for 20 minutes. Run a blunt knife around the inside edge of the pan to help release the crust from the sides of the pan. Then carefully remove the side of pan.\nCool cake to barely warm or room temperature Cut into thick wedges before serving.\nNote that although the cake will come out of the oven somewhat liquidy. The liquid should gel nicely as the cake cools.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Maple Breakfast Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 9 servings\nCan be prepared the night before, and baked before serving.\nRecipe barely adapted from US Highbush Blueberry Council.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 loaf of rustic white bread, crusts removed, bread cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups)\n4 oz cream cheese, cut into small cubes (about 1 cup)\n2 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, divided (if using frozen berries, defrost and drain them first)\n8 eggs, beaten\n1 1/2 cups milk\n1/4 cup melted butter\n1/4 cup maple syrup plus more for serving\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prep baking dish: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease an 8 or 9-inch square baking dish.\n2 Layer cubed bread, cream cheese, and blueberries in baking dish: Place half of the bread cubes in the dish. Sprinkle cream cheese cubes and half of the blueberries over the bread. Top with remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\n3 Combine eggs, milk, maple syrup, and melted butter in a large bowl and pour over bread mixture.\nTo make ahead, cover and chill overnight, and proceed the next morning to bake.\n3 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, about 1 hour to 1 hr 20 min. Cover with aluminum foil if you notice the edges browning too much during baking.\n4 Serve: Let stand for 10 minutes before serving. Cut into squares to serve. Serve with additional maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'

b"Print\nBlueberry Buttermilk Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nDon't have buttermilk? You can substitute the 1/2 cup of buttermilk called for in the recipe with a 1/2 cup of milk to which has been added 1 1/2 teaspoons of vinegar or lemon juice (let sit for several minutes). Or you can mix in 1/4 cup of plain yogurt with 1/4 cup of milk.\nINGREDIENTS\nDry ingredients:\n2 cups all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n2 Tbsp sugar\nOther ingredients:\n2 large eggs\n1/2 cup buttermilk\n1 cup milk\n3 Tbsp warm melted butter\n1 cup blueberries\nButter or vegetable oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make pancake batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients in a large bowl.\nIn a separate bowl, whisk the eggs, then whisk in the milk, and buttermilk.\nPour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and combine, using a wooden spoon. Mix only until the batter just comes together.\nStir in the melted butter. Do not over-mix! The mixture should be a little lumpy. Lumpy is good. A lumpy batter makes fluffy pancakes.\nAt this point you can either gently fold in the blueberries, or wait until you pour the batter onto the griddle, and then place the blueberries into the surface of the pancake batter. Placing the blueberries into the pancakes while they are cooking will help keep them from bleeding.\n2 Ladle batter in hot pan: Heat a griddle or large pan on medium to medium high heat. (A large cast iron pan works great for cooking pancakes.)\nOil the pan with either a little butter or vegetable oil.\nLadle the pancake batter onto the griddle to the desired size (a quarter-cup measure works well for this), anywhere from 4 to 6 inches wide.\nIf you haven't already added the blueberries to the batter, you can place several in each pancake while it cooks.\n3 When you see air bubbles in the center, flip the pancakes over: When air bubbles start to bubble up to the surface at the center of the pancakes (about 2-3 minutes), use a flat metal spatula to flip them over.\nAfter a minute, peek under one for doneness. When golden or darker golden brown, they are done.\nNote that cooking the second side takes only about half as long as the first side. And the second side doesn't brown as evenly as the first side.\nContinue to make the batches of pancakes, putting a little oil or butter on the pan before each batch so the pancakes don't stick.\nServe immediately. Serve with butter, maple syrup, and extra blueberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nLemon Blueberry Scones Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 18 minutesChilling time: 2 hoursYield: 16 scones\nTo make the scones without a food processor: Whisk the dry ingredients in a medium mixing bowl. Use a pastry cutter to work the butter into the flour mixture until the mixture looks sandy with only small gravel-sized bits of butter remaining. Pour the whisked yogurt and egg mixture over top, and use a wooden spoon or dough whisk to mix the wet and dry ingredients. Fold in the blueberries.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the scones:\n2 1/3 cup (300g) unbleached all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup (56g) granulated sugar\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n8 tablespoons (1 stick, 4 ounces) unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n3/4 cup (170g) whole milk Greek yogurt\n1 large egg\n1 (6 ounce) container fresh blueberries, picked over for stems, rinsed, and dried\nFor the glaze:\n1 tablespoon lemon zest, from 1 medium lemon\n2 tablespoons lemon juice, from 1 medium lemon\n1 cup (120g) powdered sugar\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough in a food processor: Measure the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a food processor. Process the ingredients to combine them evenly.\nSprinkle the cubed butter over the flour mixture, and process the mixture in 1-second pulses until the butter is no longer visible and the mixture looks somewhat sandy.\nIn another mixing bowl, whisk together the yogurt and egg until no streaks of egg yolk remain. Pour this mixture into the food processor with the flour and the butter.\nRun the food processor for about three seconds, just until all of the flour is absorbed and the dough begins to come away from the sides of the bowl.\n2 Fold in the blueberries: Turn out the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Scatter the blueberries over top and fold the dough a few times with a spatula to incorporate. (You can also do this in a separate mixing bowl instead of on the counter, if you prefer.)\n3 Shape the dough into disks and chill: With a bench scraper or knife, divide the dough in half and pat into two disks, about 1/2-inch thick and six inches across (you can use the length of your hand as a guide).\nWrap the disks of dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least two hours, or up to 24 hours.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350F: Line a baking sheet with a silicon baking mat or parchment paper.\n5 Cut and bake the scones: Unwrap the disks of chilled dough and cut each one into eight wedges (16 wedges total).\nPlace the wedges an inch apart on the lined baking sheet. Try not to touch the sides or handle the scones too much as you transfer them since this can inhibit how much they rise in the oven.\nBake the scones for 15 to 18 minutes, until they are lightly browned.\n6 Make the glaze: While the scones are baking, whisk together the lemon zest, lemon juice, and powdered sugar in a small bowl. The glaze should be a pourable consistency; add additional lemon juice (or milk, or water) 1 teaspoon at a time if needed.\n7 Glaze and cool the scones: Transfer the scones to a cooling rack with something underneath to catch any dripping glaze (I use wax paper). While the scones are still warm, drizzle each one with a teaspoon of the glaze. Let the scones cool until the glaze has fully set, about 30 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Sorbet Recipe\nYield: Makes a little less than a quart\nIf you want your sorbet to last a while in the freezer, and not get too rock hard, you might want to add a tablespoon or two of corn syrup to the mix. Or you can add 2 tablespoons of kirsch or a berry or orange liqueur.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, rinsed, stems removed and discarded\n1/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup honey\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nPinch salt\nFresh blueberries and sprigs of mint for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Place the blueberries, sugar, honey, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt in a large bowl. Stir to coat blueberries with the sugar. Mash with a potato masher.\n2 Put the mashed blueberries into a blender and blend for a couple of minutes until smooth.\n3 Place a sieve over a large bowl and working in batches, press the mixture through the sieve, using a rubber spatula. This will catch the tougher and larger pieces of lemon and blueberry peel.\n4 Chill the mixture for at least an hour in the fridge. Then process following the directions of your ice cream maker.\nEat immediately (the sorbet will still be a little soft) or freeze at least a few hours to help firm up before eating. Eat soon after making though, as the sorbet will get progressively harder the longer it stays in the freezer.\nServe with a few fresh blueberries and a sprig of mint.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Crumb Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 16 bars\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n2 1/2 cups (312 grams) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (198 grams) sugar\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (227 grams) cold unsalted butter, cubed\n1 large egg yolk\nFor the blueberry filling\n3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries\n3 tablespoon granulated sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Butter and line an 9x9 inch pan with parchment paper leaving an overhang on two sides.\n2 Make the dough: In a food processor, pulse the flour, sugar, lemon zest, and salt together a few times to combine. Add the butter and pulse until you get a fine, sandy texture\xe2\x80\x94all of the butter should be incorporated.\nAdd the egg yolk and pulse until it\xe2\x80\x99s combined, 10 to 15 times. The crumbs should hold together when squeezed in the palm of your hand. If they do not, sprinkle a tablespoon of water over top and pulse a few more times.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a food processor, you can cut the butter into the flour with a pastry blender or a fork. It will take longer, but work just fine.\n  3 Refrigerate the crumb topping: Scoop out about 1/3 of the crumb mixture and press it into a bowl, which helps to make larger clumps of crumbs for the topping. Cover and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes or until needed for the topping.\n4 Press the bottom crust into the pan: Firmly press the remaining 2/3 of the crumbs into the bottom of the prepared pan to create the base for the bars. I like to use a measuring cup to press the crumbs into the pan and really compact the crust.\n5 Make the blueberry filling and top with crumbs: In a mixing bowl, toss the blueberries with the sugar, cornstarch, lemon juice, and zest together to coat. Spread the berries over the crust.\nRemove the remaining crumb mixture from the fridge and crumble. Crumble it with your fingers and sprinkled over the blueberry filling.\n6 Bake the crumb bars: Bake for 1 hour and 5 minutes, or until the blueberries are bubbling and the crumb topping is golden. Remove the bars from the oven and transfer to a cooling rack. Cool completely in the pan, at least 2 hours, before lifting from the pan using the parchment and cutting into squares.\nOnce cooled and sliced, the bars can be transferred to an airtight container and kept at room temperature for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Slump Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nDumplings:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp butter\n1/3 cup milk\nBlueberries:\n4 cups of fresh or frozen blueberries\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1 1/2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/3 cup water\nVanilla ice cream or whipping cream for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dumplings: In a medium bowl whisk together the flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt.\nCut the butter into small cubes and use your clean hands to work the pieces of butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nMake a well in the center and add the milk. Mix together with a fork or wooden spoon just until the dough comes together. Form it into a ball. It should be rather shaggy. Do not knead or over work it or the dumplings will be tough.\n2 Heat the blueberries: Place the blueberries, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon juice, lemon zest, and water into a medium (2 quart) saucepan. Stir so that the berries are well coated with everything. Heat on high heat until the berries start to boil.\n3 Add the dumplings: When the blueberry mixture is boiling, pull off clumps of dumpling dough from the ball of dough and place on top of the berries. You should have enough dough for 6 dumplings, so portion accordingly.\n4 Cover and cook: Cover the pan, and lower the heat to maintain a low simmer. Cook for 25 minutes.\nDo not uncover to peek at the dumplings while cooking! The dumplings need the steady steam and pressure from being covered to cook properly so they are light and fluffy.\n5 Serve: Portion into individual serving bowls and top with vanilla ice cream or whipping cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! b"Save It Print\nBlueberry Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes one dozen muffins\nIf you are using frozen berries, you can use them frozen, just separate them so they're not sticking together and toss them in flour to coat. Your cooking time may need to increase by a few minutes.\nSome brands of sour cream are much thicker than others. Feel free to dilute the sour cream with a little water if you think it's too thick. You can also substitute the sour cream with plain yogurt; if you do, you likely will not need both tablespoons of added milk.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour, plus 1 tablespoon for dusting the blueberries\n1 tablespoon baking powder (make sure your baking powder is still good! click to see how)\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n8 tablespoons butter (1 stick), melted\n1 cup sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 1/2 cup plain sour cream\n2 tablespoons milk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 1/2 cups blueberries, fresh or frozen (see Recipe Note)\nSpecial equipment:\nStandard 12-cup muffin tin\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the muffin tin: Preheat your oven to 400\xc2\xb0F with a rack in the lower middle. Using a standard 12-well muffin pan, place a muffin liner in each well, or if you don't have muffin liners, grease the inside of the muffin pan wells with vegetable oil or butter.\n2 Toss the berries with flour: Place the blueberries in a bowl. Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of flour over them and gently toss to coat. (The flour will help keep the blueberries from sinking in the muffin as it cooks.)\n3 Mix the dry ingredients: In a mixing bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.\n4 Mix the wet ingredients separately: In a large mixing bowl, place the sour cream, sugar, eggs, milk, melted butter, lemon zest, and vanilla (the wet ingredients). Whisk together until smooth.\n5 Make the batter: Add the dry ingredients to the butter/sugar/egg mixture a third at a time and mix until just incorporated.  Do not over mix!\nGently fold the blueberries into the mixture.\n6  Portion out the muffins: Distribute the dough equally among the cups. You'll need to fill them very high to use all of the batter in 12 muffins, which is fine. They won't spill. If you still have too much dough, start filling another tin.\n7 Bake the muffins: Place the muffins in the oven and bake at 400\xc2\xb0F until the muffins are golden brown, about 20 minutes. (If the muffins are getting too brown, tent with foil.) Test with a bamboo skewer to make sure the centers of the muffins are done.\n8 Cool and serve: Let the muffins cool in the muffin pan for 2 to 3 minutes, then remove them from the pan. Let cool another 10 minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBaked Blueberry French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesChilling time: 30 minutes up to overnight time: Yield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound loaf rustic bread, cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups of cubes)\n1 1/2 (or 2) cups blueberries, frozen or fresh\n5 large eggs\n2 cups milk (whole or 2%)\n1 cup heavy cream\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n8 tablespoons sugar, divided\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, diced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Assemble the dry ingredients: Butter a 9x13 (or other 3-quart) baking dish. Spread half of the bread cubes in an even layer in the prepared pan. Top with 2/3 of the blueberries, followed by the remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\nIf using frozen blueberries, add them to the casserole while still frozen (do not thaw). This helps prevent the berries from coloring the casserole too much.\n  2 Whisk the liquids: Beat the eggs, milk, cream, vanilla, 6 tablespoons of the sugar, lemon zest, and the salt together. Pour the mixture over the bread cubes, pressing down gently (so you don\xe2\x80\x99t burst the berries) to make sure the egg mixture is absorbed.\n3 Soak at least 30 minutes, or overnight: If soaking overnight, cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F about 15 minutes before you plan to bake the casserole.\n5 Bake the casserole: Just before baking, sprinkle the top of the casserole with the remaining sugar and dot with the diced butter. Bake for 45 minutes, until slightly puffed and golden brown. (Casserole that chilled overnight might take a few minutes longer.)\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before cutting. Serve with a dusting of powdered sugar over top or a drizzle of maple syrup.\nLeftovers will keep, refrigerated, for about a week and can be reheated in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nLemon Blueberry Ricotta Pound Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 5 minutesYield: Serves 10 to 12\nTo quickly bring eggs to room temperature, place them in a bowl of warm water for a few minutes.\nMake sure your baking powder is fresh! Baking powder older than 6 months tends to go flat.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 3/4 cups (250 g) all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature\n1 cup (8 ounces, 230 g) ricotta cheese, left to stand at room temperature for a few minutes to take the chill off\n1 1/2 cups sugar (300 g)\n3 large eggs, room temperature\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1 1/2 cups (140 g) blueberries\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C). Prepare a 9x5-inch loaf pan, smearing the inside with butter.\n2 Whisk the dry ingredients: In a medium bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder and salt.\n2 Toss blueberries with flour: Rinse the blueberries and toss them with a little flour to lightly coat them (this will help keep them from sinking to the bottom of the cake).\n3 Mix wet ingredients and sugar for batter: Use an electric mixer (you can mix by hand but will get better results if you use an electric mixer) to beat together the butter, ricotta, and sugar, on high speed, for 3 minutes, until pale and fluffy.\nAdd the eggs one at a time, mixing on medium speed for one minute after each addition.\nMix in the lemon zest and vanilla extract. Don't worry if the batter looks a little curdled at this point. It isn't curdled; it just looks that way.\n4 Add dry ingredients, then blueberries: Remove the bowl from the mixer and stir in the dry ingredients in 3 or 4 additions, until just incorporated. Do not over mix. Stir in the blueberries.\n5 Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan, smoothing out the top with a rubber spatula. Place on a baking sheet on the middle oven rack of the oven. (This will help moderate the temperature at the bottom of the pan.)\n6 Bake: Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C) for 1 hour 10 minutes to 1 hour 20 minutes, or until a tester inserted into the center comes out mostly clean, or if you press on the center with your fingers and lift up, the cake surface gently bounces back.\nAfter the first 40 minutes of baking you may want to put a sheet of aluminum foil over the top of the pan to keep it from browning further.\n7 Cool: Remove from oven and let cool for 15 minutes in the pan. Then run a dull knife around the edge of the cake to make sure it is separated from the pan.\nGently remove the cake from the pan and let cool completely on a wire rack. Let cook completely before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBerry and Banana Terrine Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 envelopes (1/4 ounce each) unflavored gelatin\n2 cups white grape juice, divided\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar\n6 cups of mixed fresh berries and slices of banana (berries can include blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced or quartered strawberries)\nMETHOD\n1 Soften the gelatin: Put 1/4 cup of the white grape juice into a small bowl. Sprinkle the gelatin over the grape juice and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes while the gelatin softens.\n2 Make grape juice gelatin base: Put another 1/4 cup of the white grape juice and a 1/2 cup of sugar into a saucepan and heat on medium high heat until the sugar has dissolved.\nRemove from heat and stir in the gelatin mixture until it has dissolved. Stir in the remaining 1 1/2 cups of grape juice.\n3 Put fruit in loaf pan, cover with grape juice gelatin mixture: Put the berries and banana slices in a 4x8 loaf pan. Pour the grape juice mixture over the berries, and press down on the berries to submerge them into the juice/gelatin mixture.\n4 Chill: Cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator until firm, 3 hours.\n5 Un-mold: To un-mold, fill a basin half-way with hot water. Carefully lower the bottom of the loaf pan into the hot water and hold for 5 to 8 seconds. This will melt the gelatin at the edge of the pan, helping it to release.\nRun a dull knife around the edge of the pan as well.\nPlace a serving platter topside down on top of the loaf pan and turn the whole thing over. Shake gently to release the mold.\nSlice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBerries and Banana Fruit Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups hulled, roughly chopped strawberries\nA handful of raspberries\n1 cup blueberries\n1 apple, peeled, cored, roughly chopped\n2 bananas, peeled and thickly sliced\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon honey\nMETHOD\nPrep the berries before the bananas and apples, and add them to a large bowl.\nAs soon as you add the bananas and apples, sprinkle lemon juice over them to keep them from getting brown.\nAdd the zest and the honey and gently toss to combine.\nServe immediately. Or cover and chill for up to 2 hours before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Buckle Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nMake sure your baking powder is fresh and still active. To test, put a teaspoon of baking powder in a small bowl. Sprinkle with a little warm water. If the baking powder is still good it will bubble up. (See The Difference Between Baking Soda and Baking Powder for more info.)\nINGREDIENTS\nCake ingredients:\n2 cups (260 g) all purpose flour (plus 1-2 Tbsp of flour for dusting the blueberries)\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick, 57 g) unsalted butter, softened\n3/4 cup (150 g) sugar\n1 large egg\n1/2 cup (120 ml) milk\n1 pint (550 ml) blueberries\nTopping ingredients:\n1/4 cup (57 g) unsalted butter, softened\n1/2 cup (100 g) sugar\n1/3 cup (45 g) all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C). Butter the inside of an 8-inch springform pan. Set aside.\n2 Whisk together the 2 cups of flour, the baking powder and the salt in a medium bowl.\n3 Using a stand mixer (or by hand with a wooden spoon) beat together the butter and sugar until fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the egg.\n4 Add the flour mixture in 3 parts, alternating with the milk. Toss the berries with the remaining 1 to 2 tablespoons of flour (to separate and scatter evenly throughout the batter) and fold in. Pour batter into the prepared pan. Set aside.\n5 Combine ingredients (butter, sugar, flour, cinnamon) for topping with a fork (or by hand) to make crumbly mixture. Sprinkle this over the batter.\n6 Bake for one hour, then test for doneness by gently inserting a fork. If it does not come out clean, give the cake another 5 to 10 minutes to bake.\n7 When the cake has cooled, run a knife around the edges and lift the cake out of the pan.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nPeach Blueberry Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 8\nIf you are using a dark baking pan, reduce the oven temperature by 25\xc2\xb0F to 350\xc2\xb0F.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pastry crust:\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1 stick (1/2 cup) cold unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n1 large egg\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the filling:\n1/2 cup sugar (can reduce to 1/4 cup of sugar)\n2 Tbsp all-purpose flour\n1 Tbsp instant tapioca (can sub with a Tbsp of cornstarch)\n2 lb ripe, firm, large peaches (about 4), halved lengthwise, pitted, and each half cut lengthwise into four wedges\n1 cup blueberries (1/2 pint)\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nSpecial equipment:\nA 9 to 9 1/2-inch (24-cm) springform pan\nAn electric spice grinder\nFood processor\nMETHOD\n1 Make the crust dough: Put flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt into a food processor and pulse until combined.\nAdd the butter and pulse just a few times, until the pieces of butter are no bigger than a pea.\nAdd the egg and vanilla extract and pulse several more times, until the dough begins to clump together and form a ball.\n2 Press dough into pan: Generously butter the inside of your springform pan. Place a round of parchment paper at the bottom of the pan and butter the top of the parchment as well.\nPress the dough evenly onto the bottom of the pan (about 1/4 inch thick), and about 2 inches up the sides of the pan.\nPut into the refrigerator to chill for at least 10 minutes.\n3 Prepare oven: Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Make the filling: Grind 2 tablespoons sugar with flour and tapioca in a spice grinder until tapioca is powdery. (If using cornstarch instead of instant tapioca, you do not need to grind.)\nTransfer to a large bowl and stir in remaining sugar. Add peaches, blueberries, and lemon juice and gently toss to coat.\n5 Bake: Fill pastry crust with peach and blueberry filling. Cover loosely with foil. Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F until the filling is bubbly in the center and crust is golden, about 1 3/4 hours.\n6 Cool and remove from pan: Remove cake from oven and set on a rack to cool, uncovered for 20 minutes. Run a blunt knife around the inside edge of the pan to help release the crust from the sides of the pan. Then carefully remove the side of pan.\nCool cake to barely warm or room temperature Cut into thick wedges before serving.\nNote that although the cake will come out of the oven somewhat liquidy. The liquid should gel nicely as the cake cools.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Maple Breakfast Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 9 servings\nCan be prepared the night before, and baked before serving.\nRecipe barely adapted from US Highbush Blueberry Council.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 loaf of rustic white bread, crusts removed, bread cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups)\n4 oz cream cheese, cut into small cubes (about 1 cup)\n2 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, divided (if using frozen berries, defrost and drain them first)\n8 eggs, beaten\n1 1/2 cups milk\n1/4 cup melted butter\n1/4 cup maple syrup plus more for serving\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prep baking dish: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease an 8 or 9-inch square baking dish.\n2 Layer cubed bread, cream cheese, and blueberries in baking dish: Place half of the bread cubes in the dish. Sprinkle cream cheese cubes and half of the blueberries over the bread. Top with remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\n3 Combine eggs, milk, maple syrup, and melted butter in a large bowl and pour over bread mixture.\nTo make ahead, cover and chill overnight, and proceed the next morning to bake.\n3 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, about 1 hour to 1 hr 20 min. Cover with aluminum foil if you notice the edges browning too much during baking.\n4 Serve: Let stand for 10 minutes before serving. Cut into squares to serve. b"Save It Print\nBlueberry Buttermilk Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nDon't have buttermilk? You can substitute the 1/2 cup of buttermilk called for in the recipe with a 1/2 cup of milk to which has been added 1 1/2 teaspoons of vinegar or lemon juice (let sit for several minutes). Or you can mix in 1/4 cup of plain yogurt with 1/4 cup of milk.\nINGREDIENTS\nDry ingredients:\n2 cups all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n2 Tbsp sugar\nOther ingredients:\n2 large eggs\n1/2 cup buttermilk\n1 cup milk\n3 Tbsp warm melted butter\n1 cup blueberries\nButter or vegetable oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make pancake batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients in a large bowl.\nIn a separate bowl, whisk the eggs, then whisk in the milk, and buttermilk.\nPour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and combine, using a wooden spoon. Mix only until the batter just comes together.\nStir in the melted butter. Do not over-mix! The mixture should be a little lumpy. Lumpy is good. A lumpy batter makes fluffy pancakes.\nAt this point you can either gently fold in the blueberries, or wait until you pour the batter onto the griddle, and then place the blueberries into the surface of the pancake batter. Placing the blueberries into the pancakes while they are cooking will help keep them from bleeding.\n2 Ladle batter in hot pan: Heat a griddle or large pan on medium to medium high heat. (A large cast iron pan works great for cooking pancakes.)\nOil the pan with either a little butter or vegetable oil.\nLadle the pancake batter onto the griddle to the desired size (a quarter-cup measure works well for this), anywhere from 4 to 6 inches wide.\nIf you haven't already added the blueberries to the batter, you can place several in each pancake while it cooks.\n3 When you see air bubbles in the center, flip the pancakes over: When air bubbles start to bubble up to the surface at the center of the pancakes (about 2-3 minutes), use a flat metal spatula to flip them over.\nAfter a minute, peek under one for doneness. When golden or darker golden brown, they are done.\nNote that cooking the second side takes only about half as long as the first side. And the second side doesn't brown as evenly as the first side.\nContinue to make the batches of pancakes, putting a little oil or butter on the pan before each batch so the pancakes don't stick.\nServe immediately. Serve with butter, maple syrup, and extra blueberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nLemon Blueberry Scones Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 18 minutesChilling time: 2 hoursYield: 16 scones\nTo make the scones without a food processor: Whisk the dry ingredients in a medium mixing bowl. Use a pastry cutter to work the butter into the flour mixture until the mixture looks sandy with only small gravel-sized bits of butter remaining. Pour the whisked yogurt and egg mixture over top, and use a wooden spoon or dough whisk to mix the wet and dry ingredients. Fold in the blueberries.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the scones:\n2 1/3 cup (300g) unbleached all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup (56g) granulated sugar\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n8 tablespoons (1 stick, 4 ounces) unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n3/4 cup (170g) whole milk Greek yogurt\n1 large egg\n1 (6 ounce) container fresh blueberries, picked over for stems, rinsed, and dried\nFor the glaze:\n1 tablespoon lemon zest, from 1 medium lemon\n2 tablespoons lemon juice, from 1 medium lemon\n1 cup (120g) powdered sugar\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough in a food processor: Measure the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a food processor. Process the ingredients to combine them evenly.\nSprinkle the cubed butter over the flour mixture, and process the mixture in 1-second pulses until the butter is no longer visible and the mixture looks somewhat sandy.\nIn another mixing bowl, whisk together the yogurt and egg until no streaks of egg yolk remain. Pour this mixture into the food processor with the flour and the butter.\nRun the food processor for about three seconds, just until all of the flour is absorbed and the dough begins to come away from the sides of the bowl.\n2 Fold in the blueberries: Turn out the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Scatter the blueberries over top and fold the dough a few times with a spatula to incorporate. (You can also do this in a separate mixing bowl instead of on the counter, if you prefer.)\n3 Shape the dough into disks and chill: With a bench scraper or knife, divide the dough in half and pat into two disks, about 1/2-inch thick and six inches across (you can use the length of your hand as a guide).\nWrap the disks of dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least two hours, or up to 24 hours.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350F: Line a baking sheet with a silicon baking mat or parchment paper.\n5 Cut and bake the scones: Unwrap the disks of chilled dough and cut each one into eight wedges (16 wedges total).\nPlace the wedges an inch apart on the lined baking sheet. Try not to touch the sides or handle the scones too much as you transfer them since this can inhibit how much they rise in the oven.\nBake the scones for 15 to 18 minutes, until they are lightly browned.\n6 Make the glaze: While the scones are baking, whisk together the lemon zest, lemon juice, and powdered sugar in a small bowl. The glaze should be a pourable consistency; add additional lemon juice (or milk, or water) 1 teaspoon at a time if needed.\n7 Glaze and cool the scones: Transfer the scones to a cooling rack with something underneath to catch any dripping glaze (I use wax paper). While the scones are still warm, drizzle each one with a teaspoon of the glaze. Let the scones cool until the glaze has fully set, about 30 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Sorbet Recipe\nYield: Makes a little less than a quart\nIf you want your sorbet to last a while in the freezer, and not get too rock hard, you might want to add a tablespoon or two of corn syrup to the mix. Or you can add 2 tablespoons of kirsch or a berry or orange liqueur.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, rinsed, stems removed and discarded\n1/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup honey\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nPinch salt\nFresh blueberries and sprigs of mint for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Place the blueberries, sugar, honey, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt in a large bowl. Stir to coat blueberries with the sugar. Mash with a potato masher.\n2 Put the mashed blueberries into a blender and blend for a couple of minutes until smooth.\n3 Place a sieve over a large bowl and working in batches, press the mixture through the sieve, using a rubber spatula. This will catch the tougher and larger pieces of lemon and blueberry peel.\n4 Chill the mixture for at least an hour in the fridge. Then process following the directions of your ice cream maker.\nEat immediately (the sorbet will still be a little soft) or freeze at least a few hours to help firm up before eating. Eat soon after making though, as the sorbet will get progressively harder the longer it stays in the freezer.\nServe with a few fresh blueberries and a sprig of mint.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Crumb Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 16 bars\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n2 1/2 cups (312 grams) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (198 grams) sugar\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (227 grams) cold unsalted butter, cubed\n1 large egg yolk\nFor the blueberry filling\n3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries\n3 tablespoon granulated sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Butter and line an 9x9 inch pan with parchment paper leaving an overhang on two sides.\n2 Make the dough: In a food processor, pulse the flour, sugar, lemon zest, and salt together a few times to combine. Add the butter and pulse until you get a fine, sandy texture\xe2\x80\x94all of the butter should be incorporated.\nAdd the egg yolk and pulse until it\xe2\x80\x99s combined, 10 to 15 times. The crumbs should hold together when squeezed in the palm of your hand. If they do not, sprinkle a tablespoon of water over top and pulse a few more times.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a food processor, you can cut the butter into the flour with a pastry blender or a fork. It will take longer, but work just fine.\n  3 Refrigerate the crumb topping: Scoop out about 1/3 of the crumb mixture and press it into a bowl, which helps to make larger clumps of crumbs for the topping. Cover and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes or until needed for the topping.\n4 Press the bottom crust into the pan: Firmly press the remaining 2/3 of the crumbs into the bottom of the prepared pan to create the base for the bars. I like to use a measuring cup to press the crumbs into the pan and really compact the crust.\n5 Make the blueberry filling and top with crumbs: In a mixing bowl, toss the blueberries with the sugar, cornstarch, lemon juice, and zest together to coat. Spread the berries over the crust.\nRemove the remaining crumb mixture from the fridge and crumble. Crumble it with your fingers and sprinkled over the blueberry filling.\n6 Bake the crumb bars: Bake for 1 hour and 5 minutes, or until the blueberries are bubbling and the crumb topping is golden. Remove the bars from the oven and transfer to a cooling rack. Cool completely in the pan, at least 2 hours, before lifting from the pan using the parchment and cutting into squares.\nOnce cooled and sliced, the bars can be transferred to an airtight container and kept at room temperature for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlueberry Slump Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nDumplings:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp butter\n1/3 cup milk\nBlueberries:\n4 cups of fresh or frozen blueberries\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1 1/2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/3 cup water\nVanilla ice cream or whipping cream for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dumplings: In a medium bowl whisk together the flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt.\nCut the butter into small cubes and use your clean hands to work the pieces of butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nMake a well in the center and add the milk. Mix together with a fork or wooden spoon just until the dough comes together. Form it into a ball. It should be rather shaggy. Do not knead or over work it or the dumplings will be tough.\n2 Heat the blueberries: Place the blueberries, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon juice, lemon zest, and water into a medium (2 quart) saucepan. Stir so that the berries are well coated with everything. Heat on high heat until the berries start to boil.\n3 Add the dumplings: When the blueberry mixture is boiling, pull off clumps of dumpling dough from the ball of dough and place on top of the berries. You should have enough dough for 6 dumplings, so portion accordingly.\n4 Cover and cook: Cover the pan, and lower the heat to maintain a low simmer. Cook for 25 minutes.\nDo not uncover to peek at the dumplings while cooking! The dumplings need the steady steam and pressure from being covered to cook properly so they are light and fluffy.\n5 Serve: Portion into individual serving bowls and top with vanilla ice cream or whipping cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBaby Bok Choy with Cashews Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 cup chopped green onions, including green ends\n3 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 pound baby bok choy, rinsed, larger leaves separated from base, base trimmed but still present, holding the smaller leaves together\n1/2 teaspoon dark sesame oil\nSalt\n1/2 cup chopped, roasted, salted cashews\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, bok choy: Heat olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add onions, then garlic, then bok choy. Sprinkle with sesame oil and salt.\n2 Cover, and let the baby bok choy cook down for approximately 3 minutes. (Like spinach, when cooked, the bok choy will wilt a bit.)\n3 Remove cover. Lower heat to low. Stir and let cook for a minute or two longer, until the bok choy is just cooked.\n4 Gently stir in the roasted cashews.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected.
