b"Save It Print\nSkillet Chicken with Baby Bok Choy Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 servings\nThis recipe goes well with a side of steamed rice. Put a pot of rice on the stove before you begin cooking the chicken and bok choy, and the rice should be ready around the same time as the chicken.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup chicken broth\n1 1/2 tablespoons soy sauce (or tamari, if gluten-free)\n1 tablespoon corn starch\n1 pound chicken breast cutlets or fillets\n2 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 pound (6 to 8 small heads) baby bok choy, halved lengthwise\n2 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 teaspoon sesame seeds (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the sauce and the chicken fillets: In a small bowl, whisk together the chicken broth, soy sauce, and corn starch. Season the chicken fillets lightly on both sides with salt and pepper.\n2 Sear the bok choy: Heat one tablespoon of the olive oil in a large skillet over high heat. When the oil begins to shimmer and you see a wisp of smoke rise from the skillet, use a pair of kitchen tongs to add the bok choy to the skillet in a single layer, sliced side down. It's fine to crowd the pan for this recipe. Be careful as you add the bok choy since the oil will sputter a bit; wear oven mitts if needed.\nSear the bok choy until it has some color on the bottom, about 2 minutes, then turn over and sear on the other side for another 2 minutes. Transfer the cooked bok choy to a serving plate.\n3 Sear the chicken: Add the remaining tablespoon of olive oil to the pan. Add the chicken fillets to the pan. Sear the fillets for 4 minutes a side, until just cooked through and well browned. Transfer the cooked fillets to the serving plate on top of the bok choy.\n4 Make the sauce: Add the garlic to the skillet and stir just until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Give the broth/soy sauce mixture a final stir to mix in any cornstarch that has settled to the bottom of the bowl, then pour the mixture into the skillet. Use a wooden spoon to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Simmer the sauce until thickened.\n5 To serve: Pour the sauce over chicken and bok choy. Sprinkle with sesame seeds, if desired. Serve with steamed rice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nSoba Noodle Soup with Chicken and Bok Choy Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 servings\nFor an even speedier meal, substitute 2 cups shredded chicken meat (or any other meat) instead of poaching the chicken.\nLook for fish sauce, red chili sauce, and soba noodles in the Asian foods section at your grocery store, or order online. (Look here for the fish sauce, here for the chili sauce, and here for the soba noodles.)\nINGREDIENTS\n8 cups chicken stock, or low-sodium chicken broth\n1 boneless skinless chicken breast (about 12 ounces)\n2-inch piece of fresh ginger, finely chopped (about 2 tablespoons)\n1/4 cup lime juice\n2 tablespoons Thai fish sauce\n3 tablespoons Thai sweet red chili sauce\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n8 ounces soba (buckwheat) noodles\n4 baby bok choy, cut into 1-inch slices, or halved lengthwise\n6 scallions, thinly sliced\nA few sprigs Thai basil, mint or cilantro, for garnish\nLime wedges, to serve\nRed pepper flakes, for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Poach the chicken: Place a boneless skinless chicken breast in a saucepan and add enough stock to barely cover. Cover the pot and bring it to a simmer over medium-low heat.\nOnce simmering, place the lid slightly ajar and continue to simmer for 5 minutes.\nRemove from the heat, cover completely with the lid again, and let the chicken rest for 10 minutes. Transfer to a plate, and shred into pieces with your fingers when cool enough to handle.\n2 While the chicken cools, season the stock: Add the remaining chicken stock to the pot and bring to a simmer. Add the ginger, lime juice, fish sauce, chili sauce and brown sugar. Stir and taste for seasoning. Add more chili sauce if you wish to make a spicier broth. Simmer for about 10 minutes to allow the flavors to mingle.\n3 Meanwhile, cook the soba noodles: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the noodles and cook for 6 to 8 minutes, until tender or according to package directions. Drain into a colander. (If the soup isn't quite ready yet, run the under cold water, drain, and toss with a little olive oil to keep the noodles from sticking together while you finish the rest of the soup.)\n4 Add the bok choy and scallions to the soup broth. Return to a simmer. Remove from the heat after 1 minute. (If you kept the bok choy in halves, cook for a few minutes longer, or until tender.)\n5 Assemble the bowls of soup: Divide the noodles among 4 large soup bowls and top with the chicken. Ladle the broth and vegetables over top and garnish with the basil, mint or cilantro, if desired. Serve with lime wedges and sprinkle with red pepper flakes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBaby Bok Choy with Yellow Bell Peppers Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4-6 as a side\nFor an added touch you can include some pine nuts in step one.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon peanut oil, canola oil, or rice bran oil\n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil\n2 large yellow bell peppers, stem and seed pod removed and discarded, sliced (about 2 cups sliced)\n4 green onions, chopped, including green parts that are not dried out\n1 lb baby bok choy, bottom root ball cut off and discarded, rinsed thoroughly, torn into smaller pieces\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and sliced bell peppers: Heat a tablespoon each of peanut oil and sesame oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on high heat.\nAdd the sliced yellow peppers and chopped green onion, and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned. (Keep a watch so that the onions don't burn.)\n2 Add the bok choy: Lower the heat and add the bok choy. Stir to coat with the oil in the pan. Cook only until the bok choy has wilted. The thicker, whiter ends of the baby bok choy should still be somewhat crunchy.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBaby Bok Choy with Sherry and Prosciutto Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n4 medium cloves garlic, thinly sliced\n6 heads baby bok choy, cut in half lengthwise\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt, more as needed\n1/4 cup dry sherry\n1/2 cup chicken broth\n1 Tbsp soy sauce (use gluten-free soy sauce for gluten-free version of recipe)\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\n1 teaspoon cornstarch mixed with a tablespoon of cold water\n1/3 to 1/2 cup of thinly sliced prosciutto cut into 1/4-inch strips, or finely chopped\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the garlic: Put the oil and garlic into a large, heavy-based saut\xc3\xa9 pan with a lid. Heat on medium high heat and cook, stirring frequently until the garlic begins to sizzle, about 1 minute.\n2 Add the bok choy, then sherry: Add the baby bok choy halves. Use tongs to turn the pieces in the oil. Season with salt. When the bok choy leaves begin to wilt, add the sherry, turning the pieces again.\n3 Add broth, soy sauce, sugar, cover and simmer: Add the chicken broth, soy sauce, and sugar. Reduce the heat to medium. Cover and simmer until the bok choy tops are wilted and the stalks are crisp-tender, about 5 minutes.\nUsing tongs, transfer the bok choy to a plate, leaving the cooking fluid in the pan.\n4 Add cornstarch slurry: Whisk the cornstarch slurry into the cooking fluid. Simmer until liquid has thickened, about 30 seconds.\nRemove the pan from the heat.\n5 Add the bok choy and prosciutto: Add the bok choy back to the pan. Add the prosciutto and toss quickly to coat the bok choy with the broth and mix with the prosciutto. Season to taste with salt. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nLasagna Bolognese Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\nBolognese Sauce:\n2 ounces diced pancetta, finely chopped\n1 medium Spanish onion or yellow onion, finely chopped\n1 stalk celery, finely chopped\n1 carrot, finely chopped\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n11 ounces ground beef\n4 ounces ground pork\n4 ounces ground Italian sausage\n1 freshly ground clove\nDash of freshly ground cinnamon\n1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 pounds peeled and chopped tomatoes (or one 28-oz can whole peeled tomatoes)\n1 cup whole milk\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\nB\xc3\xa9chamel Sauce:\n2 cups whole milk\n1/4 cup unsalted butter\n1/4 cup all-purpose unbleached flour\nLasagna:\nEnough lasagna noodles to make four layers in a 13x9-inch baking pan with the lasagna pieces overlapping each other a little bit.\nRecommended 16 sheets of De Cecco brand Italian lasagna noodles.\n1 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARE THE BOLOGNESE MEAT SAUCE\n1 Make the soffritto: Combine pancetta, onion, celery, and carrot in saut\xc3\xa9 pan with butter and cook over medium heat until onion turns pale gold.\n2 Add the beef, pork, sausage to the soffritto, and increase the heat to high; cook until browned.\nSprinkle with the ground clove, cinnamon, and pepper.\n3 Stir in tomatoes, bring to a simmer and reduce the heat to medium. Cook over medium heat for 15 minutes. If you are using whole canned tomatoes, break them up as you add them to the sauce.\n4 Add milk and season with sea salt. Then turn down the heat and let simmer for 2 and 1/2 hours. Stir at least every 20 minutes. Whenever the sauce simmers down to the point that it is sticking to the bottom of the pan, just add 1/4 cup of water and scrape up the browned bits from the bottom and continue to cook.\nMAKE THE B\xc3\x89CHAMEL SAUCE\n5 Make the roux: Heat the milk until almost boiling in a heavy bottomed sauce pan.\nIn a separate pan melt the unsalted butter with the flour over low heat. Stir rapidly with a spoon. Cook this for 1 minute and then remove from the heat. (See Wikipedia on B\xc3\xa9chamel Sauce for more information on this sauce.)\n6 Slowly add half the milk to the roux: Slowly add half the hot milk to your butter and flour mixture. During this process stir constantly.\n7 Add remaining milk, thicken the sauce: Return the milk, butter, flour mixture to low heat until the sauce begins to thicken. Add the remaining milk slowly while stirring working it into the thickened sauce. Continue to stir until it comes to a boil.\n8 Season, stir: Season with some sea salt, and continue stirring until the right consistency has developed. If any lumps form, beat them out rapidly with a whisk until they dissolve. Remove from heat.\nPREPARE THE LASAGNA\n9 Cook the lasagna noodles: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Cook the lasagna according to instructions. About 8 minutes in 6 quarts of boiling salted water. Drain, rinse with cold water.\nLay the individual lasagna noodles out on kitchen towels, not touching, so they do not stick together while you layer the casserole.\n10 Layer the lasagna: Spread a little olive oil around the inside of a 13x9-inch baking pan. Make sure your baking pan is non-reactive - pyrex or stainless steel. Do not use an aluminum pan as it will react with the acidity of the sauce and ruin the flavor.\nPut a layer of lasagna noodles down first. Layer on a third of the bolognese sauce, then a third of the bechamel sauce.\nSprinkle with grated Parmesan. Repeat two more times. Top with a final layer of noodles and sprinkle with grated Parmesan.\n11 Bake: Tent the casserole with aluminum foil. Put lasagna into the middle rack of a pre-heated 375\xc2\xb0F oven. Bake for 20-30 minutes, until the top begins to get lightly browned.\nRemove from oven and let cool 5-10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nQuick and Easy Bolognese Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 4 cups sauce\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 large yellow onion, cut into 2-inch chunks\n1 large carrot, peeled and thickly sliced\n1 large stalk celery, thickly sliced\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 pound ground beef\n1/2 teaspoon table salt\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup whole milk\nPinch of nutmeg\n3/4 cup dry white wine\n1 (28-ounce) can whole San Marzano or other good quality tomatoes with thick juice\n12 ounces cooked pasta (for serving)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Chop the vegetables: In a food processor, combine the onion, carrot, and celery. Pulse until finely chopped.\n2 Cook the vegetables: In a deep, wide skillet over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the onions, carrots, and celery. Cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes, or until soft and translucent but not browned.\n3 Cook the beef: Add the ground beef to the skillet with the saut\xc3\xa9ed vegetables. Add the salt and pepper. Break the meat up with a fork or a potato masher and cook over medium heat for 3 to 4 minutes, mashing it until it is crumbly and no longer pink. You are not actually browning the meat, just cooking it until it no longer looks raw.\n4 Simmer the meat and milk: Add the milk to the skillet and simmer, stirring often, for about 4 minutes, or until the milk has almost completely evaporated. Stir in the nutmeg.\n5 Add the wine: Add the wine to the skillet and continue to simmer for about 5 minutes, or until it has almost evaporated.\n6 Crush and add the tomatoes: Pour the tomatoes into a bowl and squish them with your hands to break them up so there are no large pieces.\nAdd them to the skillet and bring the sauce to a simmer. Turn the heat to low and simmer the sauce for 15 to 20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce is thick. If the sauce begins to look dry, stir in 1 to 2 tablespoons hot water. Taste and add more salt and pepper if you feel it's needed.\n7 Serve: Serve the sauce over a bed of cooked pasta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nClassic Bolognese Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Sauce for 6 servings of pasta\nINGREDIENTS\n2 ounces pancetta, finely chopped\n1 medium Spanish onion or yellow onion, finely chopped\n1 celery rib, finely chopped\n1 carrot, finely chopped\n3 tablespoons unsalted butter\n11 ounces ground beef\n4 ounces ground pork\n4 ounces ground Italian sausage\n1 freshly ground clove\nDash of freshly ground cinnamon\n1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 pounds peeled and chopped tomatoes (or one 28-ounce can whole peeled tomatoes, packed in water)\n1 cup whole milk\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the soffritto: Combine pancetta, onion, celery, and carrot in saut\xc3\xa9 pan with butter and cook over medium heat until onion turns pale gold, about 10 minutes.\n2 Add the meats: Add the beef, pork, and sausage to the soffritto, and cook until browned, about 5 minutes.\n3 Add the spices: Sprinkle with the clove, cinnamon, and pepper.\n4 Add the tomatoes and simmer: Stir in tomatoes, increase the heat to bring to a simmer and then reduce the heat back to medium. Cook over medium heat for 15 minutes. If you are using whole canned tomatoes, break them up as you add them to the sauce.\n5 Simmer for 2 hours: Add milk and season with sea salt. Then turn down the heat to low, partially cover, and simmer for 2 and 1/2 hours. Stir at least every 20 minutes.\nWhenever the sauce gets too dry and starts sticking to the pan, just add 1/4 cup of water and scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.\n6 Serve: Bolognese is traditionally served with fresh tagliatelle pasta, but you can also serve it with fettucine, pappardelle, penne, or other pasta. Sauce freezes well for future use.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChewy Tahini Blondies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 16 blondies\nTo make these tahini blondies dairy-free, replace the butter with a 1/2 cup olive oil or vegetable oil, plus more for greasing the pan.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, melted and cooled, plus more for buttering the pan\n1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour\n3/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cardamom (or more to taste if you really like this flavor)\n1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons lightly toasted black sesame seeds\n2 tablespoons lightly toasted white sesame seeds\n1 1/4 cups lightly packed light brown sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract\n1/2 cup pure tahini paste\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\nButter an 8-inch square baking pan, then line the pan with 2 criss-crossing strips of parchment paper, buttering between each layer and leaving a 2-inch overhang on all sides. Butter the top and sides of the parchment.\n2 Make the batter: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, cardamom, salt, pepper, and the black and white sesame seeds.\nIn another medium bowl, whisk together the brown sugar, 1/2 cup melted butter, eggs, and vanilla until smooth. Fold the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until just incorporated, then fold in the tahini until smooth.\n3 Bake blondies: Pour the batter into the prepared pan and bake until golden on the outside and the center doesn\xe2\x80\x99t jiggle but is still soft, 25 to 30 minutes.\n4 Serve: Remove from the oven, cool in the pan, and cut into 16 equal squares.\nHello! b'Print\nBeef Bouillon Soup from Oxtails Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Makes 8 cups, serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3-4 lbs oxtails, patted dry\nSalt and pepper\n2 onions, peeled and quartered\n2 carrots, cut into 1-inch sections\nZest of one orange, removed in strips with a vegetable peeler\n1 cup dry white wine\n4 quarts water\n1/3 cup fresh cranberries (if in season, otherwise use a quarter of a lemon)\n10 oz mushrooms, chopped coarse\n3 ribs celery, cut into 1-inch sections\n4 sprigs of thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\n1 bay leaf\n4 cloves\n1 teaspoon peppercorns\nMETHOD\n1 Roast the oxtails, carrots, onions: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Pat dry the oxtails with paper towels and put them in a roasting pan. Sprinkle on all sides with salt and pepper.\nAdd the carrots, onions, and zest. Roast in the middle rack, turning the oxtails as the are browned.\nOnce browned, remove from oven and place the oxtails and vegetables into a large stockpot.\n2 Deglaze the roasting pan: Place the roasting pan on the stovetop on medium high heat. Add the wine to the pan to deglaze the pan, scraping up any browned bits.\n3 Simmer the oxtails and other ingredients: Add the deglazing liquid to the stockpot with the oxtails. Add the cranberries, mushrooms, celery, thyme, bay leaf, cloves, and peppercorns.\nBring the liquid to a boil, skimming whatever foam rises to the surface. Reduce the heat and simmer gently, uncovered, for 3 hours.\n4 Strain the bouillon from the oxtails: Ladle the mixture through a sieve lined with cheesecloth or paper towels into a large bowl.\nReserve the oxtails for another use, such as oxtail pate. Discard the remaining solids.\nThe bouillon can be made 3 days in advance and kept chilled. Discard excess fat (leave enough to cover soup when chilled).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBourbon Maple Glazed Chicken Wings Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes 15 to 20 pieces\nIf you buy whole chicken wings, cut away and discard the wing tips (or save for stock), and separate the drumettes from the rest of the wing with a cleaver or a sharp knife. Single segment wing pieces are much easier to eat as finger food.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds chicken wings\n1 Tbsp butter\n2 Tbsp grated onion (use small hole grater)\n1/2 cup bourbon whisky\n3/4 cup maple syrup (grade A)\n2 Tbsp tomato paste\n2-inch sprig fresh rosemary (or 1 teaspoon dry)\n1 1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco (more or less to taste)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the bourbon maple glaze: Melt butter in a medium saucepan on medium heat. Add the grated onion and cook for 2 to 3 minutes.\nAdd the bourbon whisky, the maple syrup, tomato paste, rosemary, salt, pepper, and Tabasco. Whisk to combine. Bring to a low simmer. Simmer for 5 minutes.\n  2 (Optional) Marinate the wings in the glaze: If you want you can marinate the wings for an hour, or overnight in the glaze. Just let the glaze cool for a few minutes, then toss half of the glaze mixture in a bowl with the wings, cover with plastic wrap and chill. Reserve the remaining half of the glaze mixture to glaze the wings at the end.\n3 Coat wings with glaze and arrange on roasting pan: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. If you haven't marinated the wings, place them in a bowl and pour half of the bourbon maple sauce over the wings, returning the remaining sauce to the stovetop.\nToss the wings with the sauce to coat.\nArrange the wings on an oiled, foil-lined baking pan, with space between each wing.\n4 Roast the wings: Roast the wings at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20 minutes, then turn the wings over and roast them an additional 15 to 25 minutes, or until nicely browned. Lower the heat or remove from oven if the wings start getting too dark.\n5 Boil remaining glaze until thickened: While the wings are roasting, boil the remaining sauce until it thickens slightly and can coat the back of a spoon, then remove from heat.\nIf it is taking too long for the sauce to reduce, pour it into a wide shallow pan and bring to a boil. The wider pan will make sauce evaporate more easily.\n6 Coat cooked wings in glaze: When wings are done, remove them to a bowl and toss with the remaining sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nChocolate Bourbon Cake Recipe\nYield: Serves 10 to 12\nAlthough this is a bundt pan recipe, you can also use the same amount of batter for 2 loaf pans (8 or 9 inch pans). Baking time will be less if you use loaf pans. Test at 55 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, more for greasing pan\n2 cups all-purpose flour, more for dusting pan\n5 ounces high quality, unsweetened dark chocolate\n1/4 cup instant espresso powder (can use instant coffee)\n2 tablespoons unsweetened natural cocoa powder\n1 cup bourbon whiskey (can use 1/2 cup), more for sprinkling\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 cups white granulated sugar\n3 large eggs\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 cup confectioners\xe2\x80\x99 sugar (powdered sugar), for sprinkling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare bundt pan: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Butter and flour the inside of a large (10 cup) bundt pan.\n2 Melt chocolate: Melt chocolate in a microwave oven or in a double boiler over simmering water. Let cool. Put a cup of water on to boil.\n3 Mix instant espresso powder, cocoa powder, boiling water, bourbon, salt: Put instant espresso powder (or instant coffee) and cocoa powder in a large (at least 2 cup) glass measuring cup. Add enough boiling water to come up to the 1 cup measuring line. Mix until powders dissolve. Stir in the bourbon and salt. Set aside and let cool.\n4 Beat butter, add sugar, eggs, vanilla, baking soda, melted chocolate: Beat butter until fluffy (2-3 minutes on high using an electric mixer). Add sugar and beat a minute longer. Add the eggs one at a time, beating a minute after each addition. Add the vanilla extract, baking soda and melted chocolate.\n5 Alternate adding bourbon espresso mixture with flour: With the mixer on the lowest speed, beat in a third of the bourbon espresso cocoa mixture. When liquid is absorbed, beat in half of the flour (1 cup). Repeat additions, ending with bourbon mixture.\n6 Bake: Scrape batter into prepared bundt pan and smooth the top. Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F until a tester inserted into center of cake comes out clean, about 1 hour 10 minutes.\n7 Cool, sprinkle with whisky and powdered sugar: Move the cake to a rack. Gently un-mold after 15 minutes and sprinkle the cake with a little more bourbon whiskey. Let the cake cool completely before serving. Sprinkle powdered sugar through a mesh sieve over the cake before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBourbon Mashed Sweet Potatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8 as a side dish\nINGREDIENTS\n3 pounds garnet sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1 inch chunks\nSalt\n3 to 4 Tbsp of bourbon whisky\n4 Tbsp butter (more or less to taste)\n4 Tbsp brown sugar (more or less to taste)\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the sweet potatoes until tender: Place the sweet potato chunks in a large (5 quart) pot, cover with water.  Add a tablespoon of salt to the water. Bring to a boil.  Cook until tender, about 15 to 20 minutes.\n2 Mash the sweet potatoes: Drain the cooked sweet potatoes and return them to the pot on the stove. Lower the heat to low.\nAdd the bourbon and the butter to the pot and stir. Add the brown sugar and vanilla extract and stir.\nMash with a potato masher until smooth.  Add more salt, bourbon, butter, and brown sugar to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nFall-Spiced Old Fashioned Cocktail Recipe\nPrep time: 2 minutesInfusion time: 24 hours Yield: Infused bourbon for 8 drinks\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the infused bourbon:\n2 cups bourbon\n1 whole star anise\n2 whole cinnamon sticks\n12 whole cloves\n1 vanilla bean, split lengthwise\nFor the Fall-Spiced Old Fashioned (makes one cocktail):\n2 teaspoons maple syrup\n1 teaspoon water\n4 dashes of Angostura Aromatic Bitters\n2 ounces infused-bourbon\nIce\nOrange peel\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Infuse the bourbon: Place bourbon and spices in a glass jar with a lid. Allow to infuse for 24 hours, shaking occasionally. Strain the bourbon into a clean jar. (This makes enough for 8 cocktails)\n2 Make the cocktail: Add the maple syrup, water, and bitters to the bottom of an old-fashioned glass. Add the ice and the bourbon, and stir for about 30 seconds.\n3 Garnish with orange peel: Rub a piece of orange peel around the rim of the glass and drop it in.\nHello! b"Print\nBourbon Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes enough for 4-6 racks of ribs\nNote that most (not all) of the alcohol from the bourbon will boil away while the sauce reduces, leaving bourbon's distinctive caramel-flavored tang.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup vegetable oil, such as canola or peanut\n1/4 cup butter\n1 chopped chile pepper, such as a serrano\n1 medium yellow or white onion, grated\n1 cup bourbon or Tennessee whiskey\n1/2 cup ketchup or tomato sauce\n1/2 cup lemon juice\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/3 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup Worcestershire sauce\n2-3 tablespoons brown sugar\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter and oil in a sauce pan over medium-high heat.\n2 Grate the onion through the coarse grate of a box grater, or finely mince the onion if you don't have a grater.\n3 Add grated onion and chile to the oil/butter combination and cook over medium heat for 3-4 minutes, or until onions turn translucent. You do not want the onions to turn color.\n4 Add the bourbon: Take the pan off the heat and add the bourbon. Return to the stove, turn up the heat to medium-high again and boil down the bourbon for 5 minutes.\n5 Add the ketchup, lemon juice, vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, molasses, and the sugar. Mix well and return to a simmer.\n6 Cook the sauce for a few minutes to combine the flavors and then taste test it. Is it salty enough? (It should be from the Worcestershire sauce). If not, add salt. Is it spicy hot enough? If not, add a little cayenne powder. Is it sweet enough? If not, add some molasses.\n7 Let the sauce cook down slowly until it thickens, about 20 minutes. Keep it on low heat while your ribs cook. Alternatively, you can make this sauce ahead of time and reheat it when you cook the meat. It will stay good in the fridge at least a week; I've held mine for two weeks with no problem.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCoffee Bourbon Chocolate Chip Ice Cream Recipe\nYield: Makes one quart\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups heavy whipping cream, separated 1 cup and 1 cup\n1 1/4 cups milk\n7/8 cup of sugar\nPinch of salt\n1 cup dark roasted coffee beans (use decaf beans if avoiding caffeine)\n6 egg yolks\n2 to 3 Tbsp bourbon\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n5 ounces semi-sweet chocolate, chopped into chip-sized chunks\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steep the coffee beans in milk, cream, with sugar and salt, then strain: Place the milk, 1 cup of the cream, sugar, salt, and coffee beans in a medium saucepan and heat on medium heat until little bubbles form at the edge of the pan and the milk cream mixture is steamy. Remove from heat, cover, and let sit for 1 hour.\nAfter the beans have steeped in the hot milk cream mixture for an hour, strain the mixture and discard the beans.\n2 Chill remaining cream in an ice bath: While the beans are infusing the milk cream mixture, place the remaining 1 cup of cream in a medium metal bowl, set over ice water in a larger bowl. Place a mesh strainer over the the bowl.\n3 Temper the eggs with the hot milk cream mixture: Return the milk cream mixture to the saucepan and heat on medium heat until once again steamy. Do not let boil. Whisk the egg yolks in a separate, medium bowl. While whisking the egg yolks, slowly add to the egg yolks some of the hot milk cream mixture. It helps to use a ladle for this. You'll want to add about half of your milk cream mixture. (This step is to temper the eggs to help prevent curdling.) Pour the egg mixture into the saucepan with the rest of the milk cream mixture.\n4 Heat the ice cream base until it starts to thicken: Slowly heat the custard base on medium heat, stirring with a wooden spoon, until the mixture thickens and coats the back of the spoon. When you can easily run your finger across the back of the spoon and have the mixture not run, take the saucepan off the heat.\n5 Strain mixture into chilled cream: Immediately pour the hot custard mixture through the strainer over the rest of the cream in the ice bath. This will help cool down the mixture quickly. Some curdles may have formed, if so the strainer will catch them.\n6 Chill several hours: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for several hours (preferably overnight) until well chilled.\n7 Stir in bourbon and vanilla: When ready to process in your ice cream maker, stir in the bourbon and the vanilla extract. Do not use more than 2 1/2 tablespoons of bourbon or your ice cream will not get firm. (Use no more than 3 Tbsp of bourbon, or the ice cream will have a hard time freezing.)\n8 Process in ice cream maker: Process in your ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's instructions.\n9 Add chocolate chips: Once processed, stir in the chocolate chips and place in a container into the freezer. Let freeze for several hours (to firm) before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPork Chops with Mushroom Bourbon Cream Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\nMushroom Cream Sauce:\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 pound sliced button or cremini mushrooms\n1/4 cup chopped onions\n2 large garlic cloves, chopped\n1/2 cup dry white wine (e.g. Sauvignon Blanc)\n1 cup chicken stock\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n1/4 cup bourbon whisky\nSalt and pepper\nPork Chops:\n1 large egg\n2 tablespoons water\n4 6-7 oz center-cut pork chops\nAll purpose flour\n2 cups fresh bread crumbs\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons minced fresh basil\nMETHOD\n1 Make the mushroom bourbon cream sauce: Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, and mushrooms in 2 Tbsp of olive oil in a large wide skillet on medium high heat until the mushrooms are browned - about 10-15 minutes.\nAdd the wine, increase the heat to high, and boil down until the liquid is reduced to almost a glaze, about 4 minutes.\nAdd the chicken stock and bourbon, boil until reduced by two thirds.\nAdd the cream and simmer several minutes until the sauce thickens.\n2 Dredge the chops: Whisk an egg and 2 Tbsp of water in a shallow baking dish. Sprinkle both sides of pork chops with salt and pepper. Dip chops into the flour, then egg mixture, then breadcrumbs, coating completely.\n3 Cook the chops on both sides: Heat olive or canola oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the pork chops and cook until brown, about 4 minutes per side. If your pork chops are thin cuts, this may be all the cooking they need. If thicker, lower the heat to low and cover the pot. Cook for a few minutes more until the chops are just cooked through, about 145\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Finish the sauce: When about to serve the pork, bring the sauce to a simmer and add the chopped basil to it. Season to taste with salt and freshly ground black pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nGrilled Spicy Citrus Ribs with Bourbon Glaze Recipe\nYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\nRibs\n2 racks of ribs (about 4 pounds), St. Louis-cut spareribs or baby back ribs*\n2 1/2 cups spicy citrus brine\nOil for the grill grate\n1 cup spicy bourbon syrup\n* St. Louis Style ribs are spareribs that have been trimmed of skirt meat and excess cartilage. More meaty than baby back ribs. Baby back ribs are smaller and leaner than St. Louis Style ribs and may cook more quickly (and dry out more easily).\nSpicy Citrus Brine\n1 1/4 cup freshly squeezed orange juice (about 3 oranges)\n1/2 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice (about 2 lemons)\n1/4 cup freshly squeezed lime juice (1-2 limes)\n1/4 cup water\n2 Tbsp Kosher salt\n1 teaspoon dried thyme\n1 Tbsp crushed red pepper flakes\nSpicy Bourbon Glaze\n1 cup bourbon whiskey\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 teaspoon black pepper\n2 Tbsp butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the brine: Combine the juices and water and measure in a measuring cup. You should have exactly 2 1/2 cups liquid. If you have less, add enough water so that you have 2 1/2 cups of liquid, if you have more, discard the excess. The correct ratio of liquid to salt is important for the brine to work properly.\nPlace liquids in a medium sized bowl, add other brine ingredients\xe2\x80\x94salt, thyme, and red pepper flakes. Stir for half a minute until the salt has completely dissolved.\n2 Prepare the ribs: If you want, remove the thin membrane that lines the concave side of each rib rack. This will make it easier for the brine and spices to penetrate as well as easier to cut and eat when the ribs are done. Insert a dull knife edge between the membrane and ribs to loosen. Grip the loosened membrane and pull away to remove.\nCut the racks in half. Put in a plastic ziplock freezer bag. Add the brine to the bag. Squeeze the excess air out of the bag and seal the bag. Massage the brine into the ribs. Place the bag of brine and ribs into a bowl (in case there is leakage) and place into the refrigerator.\nRefrigerate in the brine for 3-6 hours. Note that brining too long can over-saturate the meat with the brine. So stick within the 3-6 hour time frame.\n3 Prepare bourbon glaze: Heat bourbon with sugar, peppers, and salt. Whisk in butter until melted. Set aside or refrigerate for up to 2 weeks. Warm before using. You can also prepare while the meat is cooking in the next step.\n4 Prepare the grill for indirect heat: On a gas grill, heat the grill to medium heat 300-325\xc2\xb0F with the middle burners turned off (if a 3 or 4 burner grill) or one burner turned off (if a 2 burner grill).\nFor a kettle grill with charcoal, use 3-4 pounds of briquets pushed to one side of the grill. An aluminum disposable drip pan set next to the briquets, underneath where the meat will be, will help keep your grill easier to clean. (I forgot this time, notice no drip pan in the photo, and now the grill's a mess.)\n5 Place ribs on grill, adjust vents, maintain low heat: Remove the ribs from the brining bag. Pat dry the ribs with paper towels. Brush grill grates with olive oil or canola oil. Place the ribs on the side of the grill away from the source of heat, either gas or briquets. Cover the grill.\nIf you are using a gas grill, lower the burners so that you are maintaining a temperature of about 300\xc2\xb0F-325\xc2\xb0F in the grill.\nIf you are charcoal grilling, cover the grill so that the air vent on the kettle top is directly over the ribs. This way smoke from the charcoal will waft its way over the ribs on the way out of the grill.\nAdjust the vents so that the air flow is much reduced. Reducing the size of the air vents is a way to help control the temperature in the grill and keep it low. Fire lives off of oxygen, so if you reduce the oxygen, you reduce the amount of burning and heat. If you close the vents too much, the charcoals will put out too little heat, so the trick is to maintain a balance - enough air flow to keep the coals alive, but not too much or the grill will run too hot and your ribs will overcook.\nTry to maintain a temperature of about 300\xc2\xb0F-325\xc2\xb0F in the grill. If you are using a charcoal grill that doesn't have a built-in thermometer, you can put a meat thermometer through the grill air vent to take a reading of the temp.\n6 Flip ribs over, check for doneness: After 20-25 minutes of cooking, use tongs to flip the rib racks over. If you are charcoal grilling, shift the ends of the ribs as well so that the end that was facing the coals now faces the edge of the grill.\nCheck for doneness using a meat thermometer after 15-20 more minutes. They are done and ready to pull off at 155\xc2\xb0F, but you want to get to them 10 minutes or so before they are done to apply the glaze.\n7 Apply bourbon glaze: At about 145\xc2\xb0F start applying the spicy bourbon glaze. Brush the ribs with the glaze syrup, turning and basting the ribs until the syrup has been used up. When an instant read thermometer, inserted into the thickest part of the ribs reads 155\xc2\xb0F, the ribs are ready to take off the grill.\nNote that depending on the amount of heat in the grill and the size of your ribs, the ribs could be done in as little as 45 minutes or as long as 1 1/2 hours. If the grill temperature stays more at about 350\xc2\xb0F, then the ribs will be done faster. It's hard to maintain a charcoal grill lower than 350\xc2\xb0F, though ideally for these ribs you do want the temp lower, closer to 300\xc2\xb0F. Also note again that baby backs are smaller than St. Louis style and will cook faster.\n8 Remove the ribs to a large serving platter and cut into 1 or 2-rib sections.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nMint Julep Ice Cream Recipe\nYield: Makes about 1 quart\nINGREDIENTS\n2 ounces of mint leaves (spearmint)\n1 1/2 cups of milk\n1 1/2 cups of cream\n6 egg yolks, whisked together\n3/4 cup of sugar\n1/4 teaspoon of kosher salt\n1/4 cup of bourbon\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steep mint in hot cream: Bruise the leaves with a wooden spoon so they'll release their essential oils and flavors. Place them in a saucepan with the milk and 3/4 cup of the cream. Bring just to a simmer, then remove from heat and cover to steep for 30 minutes.\n  2 Prepare sieve over bowl with cream, over ice bath: Fill a large bowl with ice water and set another bowl with the remaining cream in it with a fine mesh sieve over the cream. In a separate bowl whisk together the egg yolks.\n3 Strain mint cream, add sugar, salt, then heat until steamy: Pour the steeped cream mixture through a strainer and toss the mint leaves. Return the milk/cream mixture to the saucepan and add the sugar and salt. Set over medium heat and heat until steaming (not boiling).\n  4 Temper eggs, return to milk mixture: Slowly pour some of the heated milk mixture into the egg yolks, whisking constantly so that the egg yolks are tempered by the heated milk, but not cooked by it. Pour the egg yolk mixture back into the saucepan.\n5 Heat until thickened: Stir the mixture over medium heat with a wooden spoon, constantly scraping the bottom of the pan as you stir. When the mixture thickens up and coats the back of the spoon so that you can run your finger across the coating and have the coating not run. This can take between 3 and 10 minutes depending on the heat of your burner.\n  6 Strain through sieve, add bourbon and vanilla, chill: Pour the mixture through the sieve into the chilled bowl of cream. Mix in the bourbon and vanilla. Cover and place in the refrigerator until the mixture is chilled, 6 hours to overnight.\n7 Process in ice cream maker: Process in an ice cream machine per the manufacturer's instructions.\n8 Store in freezer: Store ice cream in an airtight contained in the freezer for several hours before serving to harden the mixture up a bit. The ice cream will be quite soft straight out of the ice cream machine and will need to harden up a bit for proper ice cream consistency. If you leave it in the freezer too long, just let it sit a few minutes before serving.\n*Note: You cannot substitute anything for the bourbon in this recipe. Otherwise, it's not a mint julep. That said, you can make a simple mint ice cream, if you don't want to use alcohol. Check out the mint chocolate chip recipe on the site.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nWhiskey Sour Cocktail Recipe\nPrep time: 2 minutesYield: 1 cocktail\nINGREDIENTS\n2 ounces whiskey\n3/4 ounce fresh-squeezed lemon juice\n1/2 ounce simple syrup\n1 egg white\nIce\n2-3 drops Angostura bitters, optional\nSpecial equipment:\nCocktail shaker\nMETHOD\n1 Combine ingredients and shake without ice: Add the whiskey, lemon juice, and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker, then add the egg white. (I like to break off a small portion of the top of the egg, and then use that as a sort of strainer to hold the yolk in while pouring the white into the shaker.) Shake, without ice, for 60 seconds.\n2 Add ice, shake again, then strain: Add ice to the shaker and shake again for 30 seconds. Strain into a cocktail glass and drop the bitters on the top. Serve!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'

Heat the mixture over medium-low heat and bring it to a simmer, about 10 minutes.\n3 Pour cider into mug: Strain the cider into the mug and stir. Fill the glass with ice, and stir to combine. (My favorite stirrer for a single cocktail? This cake tester!) Add bourbon or rye and stir for about 30 seconds to chill and dilute. b"Print\nBourbon BBQ Meatloaf Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 medium red or yellow onion, roughly chopped\n1 medium carrot, roughly chopped\n1 stalk celery, roughly chopped\n1/4 red bell pepper, roughly chopped\n3 cloves garlic\n2 pounds ground beef (90/10 blend)\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n2 large eggs\n1 cup breadcrumbs\n1/4 cup fresh parsley, minced\n2 teaspoons salt\nFor the Bourbon BBQ Glaze:\n1 cup BBQ sauce, homemade or store-bought (I like Stubb\xe2\x80\x99s)\n1/4 cup bourbon\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n1 tablespoon honey\nSpecial equipment:\n9x5 loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook the vegetables: Add chopped onion, carrot, celery, red pepper, and garlic to a food processor and pulse until minced. Transfer the veggies to a large skillet with olive oil.\nCook over medium heat for 5 to 6 minutes until veggies are soft and most of the liquid has cooked out of them.\nLet veggies cool briefly before combining with meatloaf ingredients. The cooler the mixture, the easier it will be to handle; plus, if it's too hot, you might accidentally end up with scrambled eggs when you add the eggs in!\n3 Mix and shape the meatloaf: Add the cooked vegetables to a large bowl with all the other meatloaf ingredients and mix well with your hands. Then press the mixture in a 9x5 loaf pan.\n4 Bake the meatloaf: Bake the meatloaf at 350\xc2\xb0F for 60 minutes, or until the internal temperature of the meatloaf reaches 160\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Make the glaze while the meatloaf bakes: Add glaze ingredients to a small saucepan and bring to a simmer over low heat. Simmer for 4 to 5 minutes until mixture forms big bubbles and is thick enough to coat the back of a spatula or spoon. It will continue to thicken as it cools.\n6 Glaze the meatloaf: When the meatloaf has about five minutes left of baking, add 1/4 cup of glaze to the top of the meatloaf and let it finish cooking.\n7 Serve: Let the loaf cool in the pan for 5 minutes, then unmold and serve (or serve from the pan). Serve the rest of the glaze on the side for people to drizzle onto their slices.\nLeftovers can be kept in the fridge for a few days. If you want to freeze this meatloaf, I recommend slicing it and freezing individually wrapped slices, rather than freezing the entire loaf, which will be difficult to defrost later. Reheat slices in a medium-heat skillet with a drizzle of oil until warmed through, 4 to 5 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBourbon Maple Glazed Chicken Wings Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes 15 to 20 pieces\nIf you buy whole chicken wings, cut away and discard the wing tips (or save for stock), and separate the drumettes from the rest of the wing with a cleaver or a sharp knife. Single segment wing pieces are much easier to eat as finger food.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds chicken wings\n1 Tbsp butter\n2 Tbsp grated onion (use small hole grater)\n1/2 cup bourbon whisky\n3/4 cup maple syrup (grade A)\n2 Tbsp tomato paste\n2-inch sprig fresh rosemary (or 1 teaspoon dry)\n1 1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco (more or less to taste)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the bourbon maple glaze: Melt butter in a medium saucepan on medium heat. Add the grated onion and cook for 2 to 3 minutes.\nAdd the bourbon whisky, the maple syrup, tomato paste, rosemary, salt, pepper, and Tabasco. Whisk to combine. Bring to a low simmer. Simmer for 5 minutes.\n  2 (Optional) Marinate the wings in the glaze: If you want you can marinate the wings for an hour, or overnight in the glaze. Just let the glaze cool for a few minutes, then toss half of the glaze mixture in a bowl with the wings, cover with plastic wrap and chill. Reserve the remaining half of the glaze mixture to glaze the wings at the end.\n3 Coat wings with glaze and arrange on roasting pan: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. If you haven't marinated the wings, place them in a bowl and pour half of the bourbon maple sauce over the wings, returning the remaining sauce to the stovetop.\nToss the wings with the sauce to coat.\nArrange the wings on an oiled, foil-lined baking pan, with space between each wing.\n4 Roast the wings: Roast the wings at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20 minutes, then turn the wings over and roast them an additional 15 to 25 minutes, or until nicely browned. Lower the heat or remove from oven if the wings start getting too dark.\n5 Boil remaining glaze until thickened: While the wings are roasting, boil the remaining sauce until it thickens slightly and can coat the back of a spoon, then remove from heat.\nIf it is taking too long for the sauce to reduce, pour it into a wide shallow pan and bring to a boil. The wider pan will make sauce evaporate more easily.\n6 Coat cooked wings in glaze: When wings are done, remove them to a bowl and toss with the remaining sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBoursin Stuffed Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Makes 24 servings\nIf Boursin is not available, try mixing 1/2 cup of cream cheese (or 1/2 cup drained ricotta) with a minced clove of garlic, and a tablespoon of minced fresh herbs such as parsley and chives.\nYou can easily double, triple, or quadruple the recipe. You can stuff the mushrooms in advance, but only cook them right before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n24 cremini mushroom caps, about 1 1/2 inches wide (with stems about 3/4  pound total)\n5 ounces Boursin garlic and herb cheese at room temperature\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon of smoked paprika\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Remove stems from mushrooms: Brush any dirt off the mushrooms and remove the stems.\n2 Stuff caps with cheese: Use a spoon to stuff the mushrooms with the cheese mixture, so that it mounds a little in the center.\n3 Sprinkle with paprika: Place the mushrooms on a rimmed baking pan (to prevent the mushrooms from rolling off the pan). Sprinkle the tops with a little smoked paprika.\n4 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) for 8 minutes, or until a pool of water forms at the base of each mushroom as the mushrooms sweat out their moisture.\nRemove and cool a minute or two, then serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nStuffed Herbed Chicken with Boursin Cheese Recipe\nYield: Serves 2-4\nWe are using chicken breasts instead of already cut chicken cutlets for this recipe because when we pound the breasts thin, they will spread out sufficiently for us to roll them up.\nINGREDIENTS\nIngredients\n2 skinless, boneless chicken breasts, 1/2-pound each\nFresh basil leaves (or other green - beet green, swiss chard, spinach), enough to cover each chicken breast\n2 Tbsp finely chopped toasted walnuts\n2.5 oz Boursin garlic and herb cheese (or 2.5 oz of herbed cream cheese recipe, see below), room temperature\n1/3 cup breadcrumbs\n3 Tbsp grated Parmesan cheese\n1 egg, beaten well\nSalt\nPepper\nHerbed Cheese\n2.5 oz cream cheese, softened\n1 garlic clove, minced\n3 teaspoons fresh parsley, minced\n3 teaspoons fresh chives, minced\nA pinch of cayenne\n1/4 teaspoon freshly cracked black peppercorns\nA pinch salt\nMETHOD\n1 Pound the chicken breasts to 1/4 inch thickness: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Put each chicken breast between two layers of plastic wrap, on a chopping board, and use a meat mallet to pound until 1/4-inch thick.\n2 Blanch the basil: Dip each basil (or other bitter green) leaf in boiling water, drain and set aside.\n3 Mix walnuts into Boursin or cheese mixture: If you are not starting with Boursin herbed cheese, make your own by mixing together the Herbed Cheese ingredients mentioned above. Mix the walnuts into the cheese mixture, set aside.\n4 Layer chicken with cheese and basil, roll up: Lay the chicken breasts flat, season each side with salt and pepper. Spread the cheese-walnut mixture over each breast, covering the surface of the breasts. Layer on the basil leaves. Starting at the shortest end of the chicken breast, roll up as tightly as possible and tuck in the ends to form a neat roll. Secure each breast with 2 toothpicks.\n5 Dredge in flour, egg, and breadcrumbs: Put flour, beaten egg, and breadcrumbs combined with the Parmesan cheese on to 3 separate flat dishes. Dredge each chicken breast roll first in the flour, then the egg, and finally the Parmesan bread crumbs. (Skip this step if you are going low carb and/or gluten-free.)\n6 Bake: Transfer chicken breasts to a greased baking dish, seam side down. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 40-50 minutes, depending on the size of the breast, until the internal temperature is 165\xc2\xb0F, the juices run clear, and the chicken is slightly browned.\nLet rest for 5 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nTomatoes on Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 4 as a snack\nIf you don't have Boursin cheese, you can use goat cheese with some chopped fresh herbs mixed in. You will find the Boursin easiest to spread if it has been sitting at room temp for 10 minutes or so.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 to 4 slices of French or Italian loaf bread\nHerbed Boursin cheese, about 2 Tbsp per slice of bread\n1 medium to large vine-ripened tomato\nCoarse salt (like fleur de sel or even just Kosher salt)\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the bread.\n2 While the bread is toasting, slice the tomato into 1/4-inch slices.\n3 Once the bread is lightly toasted, spread one side with Boursin cheese. Top with a couple slices of tomato, overlapping if necessary. Sprinkle with coarse salt and freshly ground black pepper.\nEat immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nBerry Cobbler with Coconut Walnut Streusel Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling\n4 cups mixed berries (i.e. blackberries, raspberries, blueberries, boysenberries, strawberries), fresh or frozen\n1/4 cup plus 1 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp instant tapioca\n1 Tbsp fresh lemon juice\nTopping\n1/2 cup flour\n1/2 cup shredded coconut\n1/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup chopped walnuts\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\nPinch of salt\n4 Tbsp (1/4 cup) cold, unsalted butter, cut into cubes\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Butter a 9x9 inch baking dish.\n2 In a large bowl, mix together the filling ingredients - berries, sugar, tapioca, and lemon juice. Pour into the baking dish.\n3 In a medium sized bowl, stir together the flour, coconut, sugar, walnuts, baking powder and salt from the topping ingredients. Use your fingers to mix in the cubes of butter. Rub the butter into the other ingredients until the mixture looks like coarse crumbs.\n4 Sprinkle the topping over the filling. Bake for 35-40 minutes, until the topping is golden brown and crispy, and the filling is bubbling.\n5 Let cool for at least an hour. Serve with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBlackberry Frozen Yogurt Recipe\nYield: Makes a little more than a quart\nThe berries release a lot of water when cooked, which is why I add cream to the mix. The additional fat helps keep the frozen yogurt from getting too icy. The brandy will help the frozen yogurt from getting too icy too, but you can leave it out if you want.\nINGREDIENTS\n3-4 cups blackberries or boysenberries (fresh or frozen)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 cup sugar\n2 cardamom pods, crushed\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 cups whole milk yogurt\n2 Tbsp heavy whipping cream\n2 Tbsp brandy (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer blackberries, sugar, zest, spices: Place blackberries, lemon zest, cardamom, cinnamon, and sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, stirring to help break up the berries and release their juice. Simmer for 10 minutes, then remove from heat to cool for 15 minutes.\n2 Push berry mixture through sieve: Place a sieve over a bowl. Push the berries through the sieve to capture the concentrated syrup below. Use the back of a spoon or a rubber spatula to help press the berries against the side of the sieve. Discard the berries in the sieve, save the syrup.\n3 Stir in yogurt and cream, then chill: Stir the yogurt and cream into the berry syrup. Cover with plastic wrap and chill for several hours.\n4 Add brandy, process in ice cream maker: Right before processing in your ice cream maker, add the brandy if using. Process in your ice cream maker according to the maker's instructions. Then either eat while still rather soft, or scoop into a container and freeze for several hours until firm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nBerry Almond Crumble Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6\nRecipe by Melissa Clark of The New York Times.\nInstant tapioca is needed as a thickener. You can make this without it, but it will be quite runny. If you don't have instant tapioca, you can try substituting corn starch.\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling:\n8 cups mixed fresh berries: blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, strawberries\n1 Tbsp quick-cooking tapioca\n2 to 3 tablespoons granulated sugar, depending upon sweetness of berries\n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest\nCrumble Topping:\n1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour\n1/3 cup dark brown sugar\n1/3 cup granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\nA pinch of salt\n1/2 cup melted butter\n1/2 cup finely chopped almonds.\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Mix berries with tapioca, sugar, zest: In a large bowl put berries and mix with tapioca, sugar and lemon zest. (Without tapioca, crumble will be very runny.) Set aside.\n3 Make the topping: Whisk together the flour, sugars, spices and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the melted butter and almonds until coarse crumbs form.\n4 Assemble: Pour the filling into a 9-inch square or round pan (do not grease first). Using your fingers, form topping mixture into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch crumbs and spread over cake.\n5 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until filling bubbles and topping is light golden, about 45-55 minutes.\nLet cool at least half an hour. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nApricot Berry Cobbler Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nINGREDIENTS\nCobbler Filling:\n5 cups pitted, quartered apricots (Blenheims if you can get a hold of some)\n3 cups blackberries (or boysenberries or blueberries)\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n2 Tbsp flour (for thickening)\nCobbler Topping:\n2 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick or 4 ounces) butter softened plus 1/4 cup melted butter\n1 cup buttermilk\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n2 Tbsp brown sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss the apricots with sugar and flour, place in baking dish: In medium bowl toss the apricots, berries, 1 cup white sugar, and 2 Tbsp flour together.\nPlace filling into baking dish (one 9x13x2 baking dish, or two smaller baking dishes).\n2 Whisk flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, sugar, then work in butter: Whisk together the 2 cups of flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, 1 Tbsp white sugar in a medium bowl.\nCut the butter into small cubes and toss into the flour mixture. Work the butter with your fingers to smear it and crumble it into the flour, until the mixture resembles a coarse cornmeal.\nTip: at this point, if you briefly heat the apricot berry mixture in the microwave or oven, until it is warm, it will help the biscuit topping to rise.\n3 Add almond extract and buttermilk: Add almond extract to the buttermilk, then form a well in the middle of the flour mixture and pour in the buttermilk.\nGently mix (with wooden spoon or your hands) until the dough just comes together. Do not over-mix.\n4 Form "cobblestone" shapes of the dough and arrange on the top of the apricot berry mixture. (You can also just crumble the dough over the top.) Sprinkle brown sugar over the top of the dough. Drizzle melted butter over the top (aim for the fruit more than the biscuits).\n5 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Let the cobbler sit and rise for 10-20 minutes before baking.\n6 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 10-15 minutes or until the top is just beginning to brown, then reduce the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cook for an additional 30 to 40 more minutes, until the center fruit is thickened and bubbly.\nCheck during cooking, if the topping is getting too brown, cover it with foil and turn the heat down to 325\xc2\xb0F.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nEasy Beef Brisket Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 pounds of a brisket cut of beef\n3/4 cup barbecue sauce\n1/4 cup soy sauce\n1 cup of water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 300\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Make the sauce: In a bowl, mix together the barbecue sauce, soy sauce, and water.\n3 Roast the brisket in the oven (2 methods):\nFoil method: Place a large piece of aluminum foil in a roasting pan. Add the brisket and spread the BBQ sauce mixture generously over meat. Wrap the brisket in the aluminum foil so it's well sealed, like a package.\nBake for 3 hours for a 3 pound roast and 1 more hour for every additional pound of meat.\nOR, instead of foil, you can use an oven roasting bag:\nOven roasting bag method: Place the barbecue sauce and the brisket in an oven roasting bag. Sprinkle a teaspoon of flour into the bag. Poke a couple small holes in the bag. Place the bag in a roasting pan. You may find that the cooking time is faster with this method, or you can reduce the oven temperature to 275\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Let the brisket rest: Remove from oven and let rest in the foil for 30 minutes before serving.\n5 Slice across the grain of the meat: The easiest way to serve the roast is to first cut it in half along the grain of the meat (poke the meat with the tip of a knife or tines of a fork to see which way the grain or lines of the muscles are going if you can't see it from the surface).\nThen make 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch thick cuts across the grain to serve. (Cutting the meat across the grain will make it much easier to eat, as the cuts break up the muscle tissue.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBraised Beef Short Ribs Recipe\nCook time: 4 hoursChill overnight time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n12 beef short ribs, bone-in\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 yellow onion, peeled and chopped\n1 stalk celery, chopped\n1 carrot, peeled and chopped\n1 750-ml bottle good dry red wine (we used a zinfandel)\n6 cups veal stock (can substitute beef stock)\nMETHOD\n1 Brown the ribs: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Season ribs to taste with the salt and pepper. Heat oil in a large, heavy bottomed ovenproof pan over high heat. Add ribs and brown on all sides. Work in batches if you need to so that the ribs don't get crowded (this will help with browning).\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 vegetables: Transfer ribs to a plate. Pour off the excess fat (do not put down the drain or you will clog your sink!). Add the onions, celery, and carrots to the pan and saut\xc3\xa9, stirring often, until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Remove the vegetables from the pan, set aside.\n3 Deglaze pan with wine, then reduce sauce: Add the wine to the pan, deglazing the pan, scraping off any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Reduce the wine by three-quarters until thick and slightly syrupy, about 15 minutes on high heat.\n4 Braise ribs in oven: Return the ribs to the pan, add the veal stock and enough water to cover the ribs. Bring to a boil, cover with foil, and place in the oven. Braise, cooking in the oven, until the meat is fork-tender, 2 to 2 1/2 hours.\nDuring the last 1/2 hour of cooking, add back in the vegetables.\n5 Chill overnight: Allow the ribs to cool in the liquid, then cover and refrigerate overnight.\n6 Remove excess fat: The next day, remove the excess fat that has solidified at the top from the overnight chilling.\n7 Reduce sauce with ribs: Place the pan with the ribs and cooking liquid over medium heat, uncovered. Cook until the liquid has reduced by three-quarters, about 1 hour. Continue to cook, spooning the sauce over the ribs, until the sauce is thick and ribs are glazed. Take care not to burn the glaze; move the ribs around in the pan to keep them from burning.\nServe over mashed potatoes, egg noodles, or rice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nItalian Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 4 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 to 4 pound rump or chuck beef roast\n1 teaspoon salt plus more to taste\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 large carrot, diced (about 1 cup)\n1 large celery stalk, diced (about 1 cup)\n1 medium red onion, diced (1 to 1 1/2 cups)\n2 garlic cloves, finely minced\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley\n1 bay leaf\n1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh sage\n3 cups medium-bodied Italian red wine (we used a Barbera)\n1 28-ounce can Italian plum tomatoes, put through a food mill to remove the seeds\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the roast: Trim some of the fat from the meat. Pat dry with paper towels. Season generously with the salt and pepper. Heat the oil in a large, heavy pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat.\nWhen the oil is hot, shimmering but not smoking, add the roast and cook, turning it a few times, until it is nicely browned on all sides, 10-12 minutes.\nTransfer the meat to a platter.\n2 Add vegetables: Reduce the heat to medium. Add the carrot, celery, and onion. Cook, stirring occasionally until the vegetables are golden brown and begin to stick to the bottom of the pan, 10-12 minutes.\nAdd the garlic, parsley, and sage, and stir until the herbs are lightly colored and fragrant, about 1 minute.\n3 Deglaze the pan with wine, return meat to the pan: Add 1 cup of the wine and stir quickly, lifting up the richly browned caramelized vegetables that stick to the bottom of the pan.\nWhen the wine is almost all evaporated and thickly coats the vegetables, return the meat to the pan and turn it over a few times to coat it with the savory base.\n4 Add remaining ingredients, simmer until tender: Raise the heat to high, adding the remaining wine, the bay leaf, and the tomatoes, and bring to a boil. Cover the pot, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, turning and basting the meat every half hour or so, until the meat is very tender and flakes away when pierced with a fork, 3-4 hours.\n5 Turn off the heat and let the roast sit in its juices for an hour. (You can also put the pot into a 300\xc2\xb0F oven and turn the roast every hour.)\n6 Remove meat, reduce sauce: Remove the meat from the pot and place it on a cutting board, covered loosely with aluminum foil. If the sauce is too thin, bring it to a fast boil and reduce it until it has a medium-thick consistency. Taste and adjust seasoning.\n7 Cut the meat into thick slices (it will probably fall apart), and place on warm serving dishes. Spoon the sauce over the meat and serve hot. Serve with rice, mashed potatoes, or polenta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBeef Roast Braised in Red Wine Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (3 1/2 pound) chuck roast, boneless\nSalt and ground black pepper\n4 oz pancetta, cut into 1/4-inch cubes\n2 medium onions, chopped medium (about 2 cups)\n2 medium carrots, chopped medium (about 1 cup)\n2 ribs celery, chopped medium (1 cup)\n1 Tbsp tomato paste\n3 medium cloves garlic, minced or pressed through garlic press (about 1 tablespoon)\n1 (750 ml) bottle Zinfandel wine (can substitute Cabernet Sauvignon, or other full bodied red wine)\n1 can (14 1/2 ounces) diced tomatoes, drained\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh oregano\n1 teaspoon minced fresh rosemary\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt the roast and let sit at room temp while you prep the vegetables: If your roast is very fatty, trim some of the fat. But it is important to keep some fat, as this will keep the roast moist while braising. In many supermarkets chuck roasts will already be properly trimmed.\nSalt the roast well and set aside at room temperature while you prepare all the other vegetables.\n2 Render fat and crisp the pancetta: Pour a little water into a Dutch oven or other heavy, lidded pot. Set the pot over medium heat and add the diced pancetta. As soon as the water begins to simmer, lower the heat to medium-low and slowly crisp up the pancetta; the water allows some of the fat in the pork to render out without charring the pancetta.\nWhen the pancetta is crispy and brown, remove it with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n3 Brown the roast on all sides: Preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F. Pat the beef roast dry with a paper towel, increase the heat to medium and brown all sides in the pot.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the chopped vegetables: Once the meat has browned remove it to a bowl and add the onions, carrot and celery. Sprinkle salt over the vegetables while they cook. Increase the heat to medium-high and saut\xc3\xa9 for 2-3 minutes.\nAdd the tomato paste and stir well, saut\xc3\xa9 for another 1-2 minutes. Add the garlic and cook a minute more.\n5 Add tomatoes, pancetta, herbs, wine, and the roast. Cover and cook: Increase the heat to high and add the tomatoes, the pancetta, herbs and red wine. Nestle the beef roast into the pot, cover, place in the 300\xc2\xb0F oven and cook for 3 hours. At the halfway point, use tongs to turn the beef roast over.\n6 Strain and reduce the sauce: Remove the pot from oven and transfer beef to a large bowl; tent with foil to keep warm. Allow the liquid to settle in the pot for a few minutes, if you'd like, skim off some of the fat with a wide shallow spoon. If you have an immersion blender, use it to blend the contents of the pot. If you don't, use a whisk to help break down the vegetables.\nBoil the sauce until it is reduced to about 3 1/2 cups. Strain liquid through large fine-mesh strainer, pressing on solids with spatula to extract as much liquid as possible; you should have a couple cups strained sauce.\nAdd any accumulated juices from the bowl you have the beef in. Boil the sauce again until it has reduced to 1 1/2 cups. Season sauce to taste with salt and pepper.\n7 Slice the meat and serve with the sauce: Cut the meat into roughly 1/2-inch-thick slices and pour the sauce over them. Serve with a bold red wine and crusty bread or mashed potatoes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBraised BBQ Beef Sandwich Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Makes enough for 12 sandwiches.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 3-pound chuck roast, rinsed and dried\n2 medium onions, chopped\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 28-ounce can whole tomatoes (preferably plum tomatoes)\n1 18-ounce bottle of your favorite barbecue sauce (or 2 1/4 cups of your favorite homemade barbecue sauce)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\n12 sandwich or hamburger buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make sauce with onions, tomatoes, BBQ sauce: In a large, heavy pot, heat olive oil on medium heat. Add the onions and cook until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes, roughly chopping them in the pot. Add the barbecue sauce, increase heat to medium high and simmer for 10 minutes.\n2 Add the beef roast, simmer on low for 3 hours: Add the chuck roast. Bring to a low simmer, cover and slow cook until meat is very tender, stirring occasionally, about 3 hours.\n3 Separate meat into small pieces: Remove the meat from the pot. Use a fork and knife to separate the roast into small pieces. Set aside.\n4 Reduce liquid in sauce: Increase the heat on the pot to medium/medium-high, uncover, and reduce the liquid until thick. Stir often to prevent burning.\n5 Return meat to sauce: Return the meat to the liquid in the pan. Warm both thoroughly. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nServe on buns.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nVeal Goulash with Sauerkraut Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter or rendered beef fat\n2 pounds of veal, cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes\n1 1/2 cups sliced onions, sliced root to tip, 1/4-inch thick slices\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 cup canned crushed tomatoes, or chopped fresh ripe tomatoes\n1 cup full-fat sour cream\n2 teaspoons paprika\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds, chopped or crushed in a mortar with pestle\n2 28-30 ounce jars sauerkraut (we recommend Bubbies, in the refrigerated section of the grocery store)\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Lightly brown the veal: Heat butter or beef fat in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Pat dry the cubed veal. Sprinkle with salt and add to pan. Working in batches, saut\xc3\xa9 the meat until the meat is just beginning to brown.\n2 Add onions, then garlic: Add the onions to the pan with the veal, cook for another 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for another minute.\n3 Add a teaspoon of salt, a half teaspoon of black pepper, and the tomatoes. Add enough water to just barely cover the meat, about 2 cups or so, depending on the size and shape of your pan.\n4 Simmer about 30 minutes: Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a simmer, then lower the heat to maintain a low simmer, uncovered. Cook until the meat is almost cooked through, about 30 minutes.\n5 Remove veal, reduce the sauce: Use a slotted spoon to remove the veal from the pan to a bowl to temporarily set aside. Increase the heat to high and let the liquid boil until it is reduced by half. Lower the heat to medium.\nAdd the meat back to the pan.\n6 Add the sour cream, paprika, and crushed caraway seeds, and simmer uncovered for another 20 minutes.\n7 Heat the sauerkraut in a medium pot on medium heat until hot.\nTo serve, strain the sauerkraut. Place the sauerkraut in a serving dish and top with the goulash.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nChicken Normandy Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIn this recipe we brown the chicken on the stovetop, then braise the chicken in the oven, and then finish on the stovetop.\nYou can make the whole dish on the stovetop if you wish. In step 6 just simmer the chicken on the stovetop (uncovered if skin-on, covered if using skinless chicken pieces), until cooked through and tender, 15-30 minutes. The reason to do it in the oven is to produce a crispy skin.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons butter\n2 cooking apples (Fuji or Jonagold are perfect for this dish, do NOT use a red delicious), cored and sliced into wedges (you can peel or not)\nFlour for dredging\n4 whole chicken legs (with thighs)\nSalt\n1 large onion, peeled, sliced lengthwise (root to top) into wedges\n1/2 cup (120 ml) brandy (apple brandy or Calvados if you have it)\n2 cups (475 ml) apple cider (the cloudy type)\n1 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/2 cup cream\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sprinkle chicken with salt: Sprinkle salt over the chicken pieces and let sit for 20 minutes at room temperature while you prep the other ingredients and saut\xc3\xa9 the apples in the next step.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 apple slices: Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C). Heat 2 Tbsp of the butter in a large, oven-proof saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat. Add the apple slices and saut\xc3\xa9 until they turn a little brown around the edges, turning occasionally.\nSprinkle the apple slices with a little salt. Remove from pan and aside on paper towels to drain.\n3 Dredge chicken in flour, brown in pan: Dredge the chicken in flour and place the pieces in the saut\xc3\xa9 pan, skin side down. Add the remaining 2 Tbsp of butter.\nFry until golden, about 3-5 minutes on medium to medium-high heat on each side. Remove from pan and set aside.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 onion slices: Add the onions and increase the heat to medium-high. Spread the onion slices out in an even layer to cover the pan. As the onions cook they will release moisture that will help deglaze the pan of the browned bits from the chicken.\nSaut\xc3\xa9 the onions, stirring occasionally, until they just being to brown, about 5-8 minutes.\n5 Deglaze pan with brandy: Add the brandy to the pan. Using a wooden spoon, scrape any remaining browned bits off the bottom of the pan.\n6 Add apple cider: Let the brandy boil until it has reduced by about half. Add the apple cider and bring it to a boil. Sprinkle in the thyme. Add just a pinch of salt to the cider.\n7 Place chicken on onions, and roast in oven: Arrange the chicken legs in the pan so the skin faces up and is not submerged by the cider-brandy mixture. Place in the oven and cook at 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C), uncovered, for 30 minutes.\n\n8 Remove chicken, add apples, reduce sauce: Remove the pan from the oven. (Watch out for the hot handle! I like to run an ice cube over the handle as soon as I remove the pan, to help bring the handle temp down quickly and prevent a bad burn if I forget the handle is hot.) Remove the chicken pieces from the pan and set aside.\nPlace the pan back on a stovetop burner on high heat. Add the apples and boil down the sauce by half.\n9 Add cream, salt, pepper: When the sauce reduces to the point where it's a little syrupy, add the cream and turn down the heat. Taste for salt and add some if needed.\nTo serve, spoon some apples and onions on the plate, top with sauce and a piece of chicken.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBrandied Cranberries Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Makes 2 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (12-ounce) bag of fresh or frozen cranberries\n1 1/2 cups sugar\n1/3 to 1/2 cup brandy\n2 Tbsp finely shredded orange zest (use microplane zester)\nMETHOD\n1 Sort and discard bad cranberries: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Sort through cranberries and discard any that are soft or decayed.\n2 Mix cranberries, sugar, brandy, and orange zest in a 2-quart baking dish.\n3 Bake: Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F uncovered, until most of the liquid has evaporated, 1 to 1 1/4 hours, stirring occasionally.\nChill up to one week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
