b"Print\nBrandy Alexander Cocktail Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 1 cocktail\nA little freshly-grated nutmeg dusted over the top of this drink really helps to take things to the next level.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 ounces brandy or Cognac\n1 ounce cr\xc3\xa8me de cacao\n1 ounce heavy cream\nIce\nGrated nutmeg, preferably fresh\nMETHOD\n1 Make the cocktail: Add liquid ingredients to a cocktail shaker. Add ice, shake for about 30 seconds, and then strain into a cocktail glass. Double strain using a tea strainer, or a fine cocktail strainer if you're picky about having bits of ice in your cocktail.\nGrate fresh nutmeg over the top and enjoy.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nSpiced Mulled Wine Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nThe key to mulled wine is to warm the wine without boiling it, which would cook off the alcohol. When your kitchen smells so achingly good that you're dying to try a cup of this masterpiece, you'll know it's done.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 orange\n15 whole cloves\n1 bottle red wine (inexpensive Cabernet or Malbec)\n1/4 cup sugar (turbinado is nice)\n3 cinnamon sticks\n2 teaspoons ground ginger\n1/4 cup brandy\nSpecial equipment:\nLarge pot or slow cooker\nMETHOD\n1 Stud the cloves into the orange, then cut the orange: Push the cloves into the orange (see this picture for reference), then cut the orange into half circles. (Studding the cloves into the orange means you won't have to worry about floating cloves in your drink.)\nAlternatively, cut the orange into half circles and add it and the cloves to the wine separately.\n2 Add ingredients to the pot: Add all the ingredients to a pot or a slow cooker.\n3 Heat the wine: On the stovetop, simmer the wine for 20\xe2\x80\x9325 minutes over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally to mix ingredients and dissolve sugar. If you're using a slow cooker, heat the wine on low heat for 1 1/2 hours or on high for 45 minutes, until warm.\nWhen the mulled wine smells amazing, tastes spicy, and is hot (but not boiling), it's done. Serve and enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBoozy Chai-Spiced Apple Cider Punch Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 7 cups or approximately 10 servings, enough to fill an average-sized pitcher\nThis punch is on the tart side. To make it sweeter, start with two tablespoons honey or simple syrup and add more until you reach your desired sweetness.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to fill a large punch bowl or countertop drink dispenser, I recommend doubling or even tripling the recipe.\nThe punch can be made a day or so ahead of time and kept it in the fridge until needed. Hold off on garnishing until you're ready to serve since the apples can get a bit dodgy.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 bags chai tea or 3 teaspoons loose chai (I like Republic of Tea)\n1 1/2 cups water\n2 cups brandy\n1 1/2 cups apple cider\n3/4 cups fresh squeezed lemon juice\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nHoney or simple syrup, as needed\nLemon wheels or clove-studded apple slices, for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Make the tea: Add 2 tea bags or 3 teaspoons loose chai tea to 1 1/2 cups of water. Steep for 5 minutes. Let cool to room temperature.\n2 Combine all ingredients: Add the cooled brewed tea, brandy, apple cider, lemon juice, and vanilla extract to a pitcher. Add several handfuls of ice cubes or one large ice mold. Stir, and then garnish with lemon wheels and apple slices studded with cloves.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nGrilled Branzino with Rosemary Vinaigrette Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Serves 2\nIf branzino is not available, try this with walleye, Pacific rock cod, or a large Atlantic black seabass.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons minced onion\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 teaspoon salt\n3 tablespoons white wine vinegar\n1 large garlic clove, chopped\n1 heaping tablespoon of minced fresh rosemary\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 whole branzino\nOlive oil\nSalt, preferably sea salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the rosemary vinaigrette: Put the minced onion, mustard, salt, vinegar, garlic and rosemary into a blender and pulse it for about 30 seconds. Use a spatula to scrape down the sides of the blender and pur\xc3\xa9e it again for 10-20 seconds. Scrape the sides down again.\nTurn the blender on low and take the removable cap off the lid. Hold your hand over the hole, as it might spit a little. Pour the olive oil in slowly and put the cap back on.\nTurn the blender off and scrape the sides down one more time. Turn the blender back on low, then high for 60 seconds.\n2 Prepare the fish: Rinse the fish under cold water. Now make sure its gills and scales are all removed; your fishmonger is not always so diligent about this task, and no one wants a scale on his plate. Gills can impart a bitter taste to the fish, so they need to go, too.\n3 Make cuts on the sides of the fish: Use a very sharp knife and make several slashes on the sides of the fish, maybe every inch or so. Make the cuts at an angle to the side of the fish, and slice down until you feel the spine. Do not sever the spine, however. These cuts will help the fish cook faster. Rub olive oil all over the fish and set it aside.\n4 Prepare the grill for high, direct heat. Scrape down the grates well and close the lid. Salt the fish well. Now grab a paper towel, a set of tongs, and some cheap vegetable oil. Bring all of this out to the grill.\nFold the paper towel over several times, moisten it with the vegetable oil, and hold it with tongs to wipe down the grill grates.\n5 Grill the fish: Lay the fish down on the grill and close the lid. Let this cook for 5 minutes without touching it.\nOpen the lid and, using tongs, gently see if you can lift the fish off the grates cleanly. Don\xe2\x80\x99t actually do this, but check for sticky spots. If you have some, get a metal spatula. Use the spatula to dislodge the fish from the sticky spots.\nUsing tongs in one hand, and the spatula in another, gently flip the fish over. If it sticks, no biggie. It happens sometimes.\n    7  Finish grilling the fish: Once the fish has been flipped, let it cook another 3-5 minutes. Again, test for sticky spots with the tongs and spatula. Dislodge them gently and gently lift the fish onto a plate.\nIf the fish is too long or seems like it might break in half, use two metal spatulas instead of the tongs-and-spatula set-up.\n8 Drizzle the vinaigrette over the fish and serve at once. Goes well with crusty bread and a glass of pilsner beer or white wine.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBrazilian Salmon Stew (Moqueca) Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 45 minutesMarinating time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade:\nThe cloves from 1/2 head of garlic, peeled, crushed, minced\n2 Tablespoons of fresh lime juice\n3/4 teaspoon of coarse salt\n1 Tablespoon of sweet paprika\n2 1/2 teaspoons of ground cumin\n1 1/2 teaspoons of freshly ground black pepper\nOther:\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds of salmon, cut into 2-inch pieces (largish-bite sized pieces)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n2 medium onions, sliced\n1 large green bell pepper, seeded, de-stemmed, and sliced\n2 medium tomatoes, sliced\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\n1 14-ounce can regular (not light) coconut milk\n1 large bunch fresh cilantro, chopped, 1-2 cups\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate salmon: Mix together the marinade ingredients. Let the salmon marinate in this paste for at least 2 hours. The longer, the better.\n2 Layer ingredients in a large pot: In a large pan (large covered skillet or Dutch oven), coat the bottom of the pan with a couple tablespoons of olive oil. Add a layer of sliced onions, and then a layer of sliced bell peppers, and a layer of sliced tomatoes.\nPlace the fish pieces, with the marinade, on top of everything, and start layering again\xe2\x80\x94onions, bell peppers, and tomatoes.\n3 Top with cilantro, coconut milk, olive oil: Sprinkle generously with salt and pepper. Add about half of your fresh cilantro to the top.\nPour coconut milk over the top. Drizzle generously with olive oil over the top (several tablespoons).\n4 Simmer: Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, cover and let simmer for 30 minutes to an hour, until the vegetables are cooked through.\nGarnish with remaining cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSt. Lucia Saffron Buns Recipe\nPrep time: 2 hours, 30 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Makes 12 to 14 buns\nThis recipe makes 12 to 14 good sized buns. You can easily double the recipe. Note the cardamom is optional. I\'ve made these buns with and without a little cardamom and I  prefer them with. I\'m guessing it\'s more traditional without.\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup milk (175 ml)\n1/2 teaspoon saffron threads\n1 teaspoon plus 1/4 cup (50 g) white, granulated sugar\nOne 1/4-ounce packet active dry yeast (check the expiration date on the package to make sure it\'s still good!)\n3 1/2 to 4 cups (490 g to 570 g) all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nThe seeds from 3 cardamom pods, ground (optional)\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick, 4 Tbsp, 56 g) unsalted butter, softened\n1/4 cup of sour cream (or quark if available)\n2 large eggs\nRaisins\nGlaze\n1 egg, beaten\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat milk, saffron, sugar: In a small pot, heat the milk, saffron, and 1 teaspoon of sugar together until the milk is steamy. Remove from heat and stir to dissolve the sugar. Let cool until about 115\xc2\xb0F, or warm to the touch, but not hot.\n2 Sprinkle the yeast over the warm saffron-infused milk and let sit for 5 to 10 minutes until foamy.\n3 Whisk flour, sugar, salt, cardamom: In the bowl of a stand-up mixer* whisk together 3 1/2cups (490 g) of the flour, remaining 1/4 cup of sugar, salt and ground cardamom (if using).\n*You can make this recipe without a mixer, for me it\'s just a bit easier with one.\n4 Make a well in the center of the flour and add the yeast milk saffron mixture, the eggs, the butter, and the sour cream. Mix the ingredients until well incorporated.\n5 Knead the dough: Switch to the dough hook of your mixer (if using, otherwise knead by hand). On low speed start to knead the dough. Slowly add additional flour, a tablespoon at a time, kneading to incorporate after each addition. Do this until the dough is still a little sticky to the touch, but does not completely stick to your hands when you handle it.\n6 Let dough rise: Shape the dough into a ball and place in a large bowl. Cover with plastic wrap. (Note at this point you can make ahead and refrigerate overnight if you wish.)\nLet sit in a warm place for 1 to 2 hours, until the dough has doubled in size. (One way to tell that the dough is ready is that you poke your finger in it and it takes quite a bit of time for the indentation left by your finger to go away.)\n7 Form dough into S shapes: When the dough has doubled in size, gently press it down and knead it a couple of times. Break off a piece and form it into a ball about 2 inches wide (60 to 70 grams if you are weighing). Roll the ball out into a snake, about 14 inches long.\nThen Curl the ends in opposite directions, forming an "S" with spirals at each end. Place on a lined baking sheet and repeat with the rest of the dough.\n8 Let sit for second rise:  Cover with plastic wrap and place in a warm spot until the dough shapes double in size, 30 minutes to an hour.\n9 Brush with egg wash, place raisins on buns: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C). Using a pastry brush, brush some beaten egg over the tops and sides of the uncooked buns. Place raisins in the centers of the "S" spirals.\n10 Bake: Place in the oven and bake at400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C) for about 10 to 11 minutes (turning halfway through cooking to ensure even browning), until the buns are golden brown.\nRemove from oven and let cool for 5 minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nSouthern Cornbread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nWhite cornmeal is used in most Southern cornbreads, but we could not find any here in California, so we used yellow cornmeal. If you can find white cornmeal, by all means use it.\nThe egg is optional, though without it the cornbread will be very crumbly.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon bacon drippings\n2 cups cornmeal OR 1 1/2 cups cornmeal and 1/2 cup flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon sugar (optional)\n1 large egg (optional)\n1 1/4 cups buttermilk\n6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat pan with bacon drippings: Put the bacon drippings in a 9 or 10-inch well-seasoned cast iron skillet and put the skillet into the oven. Then preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F with the skillet inside. (If you don't have an iron skillet, you can use an uncovered Dutch oven or a metal cake pan.)\n2 Make the batter: Whisk together all the dry ingredients (cornmeal, baking soda, salt, sugar if using) in a large bowl. In another bowl, beat the egg (if using) and buttermilk until combined, then mix that into the bowl of dry ingredients. Stir in the melted butter.\n3 Pour batter into hot skillet and bake: When the oven is hot, take out the skillet (carefully, as the handle will be hot!). Add the cornbread batter and make sure it is evenly distributed in the skillet.\nBake at 400\xc2\xb0F for about 20 minutes, or until the edges are beginning to brown and a toothpick inserted in the center of the bread comes out clean.\n4 Rest bread in skillet, then serve: Let the bread rest for 10 to 30 minutes in the skillet before cutting it into wedges and serving.\nTo store, let the cornbread cool, then remove from pan and wrap in plastic wrap or transfer to an airtight container. Store at room temp for 2 to 3 days\nTo avoid burning your hand because you've forgotten the pan is hot, I recommend placing a pot holder on the pan's handle while the cornbread is resting, or cooling the handle down a bit with an ice cube.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCaraway Soda Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes one loaf\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour (1 pound)\n1 Tbsp sugar\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds\n4 Tbsp butter (1/2 stick) room temp\n1 1/2 cups buttermilk*\n*If necessary, you can substitute buttermilk with a half cup of plain yogurt mixed in with a cup of plain milk and a tablespoon of white vinegar.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, salt, baking soda, and caraway seeds.\n2 Using your fingers (or a fork) work the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\n3 Make a well in the center of the flour. Pour the buttermilk into the center and using either your hands or a wooden spoon, fold the flour over the buttermilk and gently mix until just combined.\nThe dough should be neither too wet or too dry, so if it is a little too dry to work with, add a little more buttermilk. If too wet, add a little more flour. Roughly shape into a ball and place on a floured surface. Knead just a few times to shape it into a round loaf. Do not over-knead or the bread will be tough.\n4 Place dough loaf onto a lightly greased baking sheet (or cast iron pan). Make 1 1/2-inch deep cuts, forming a cross, from side to side on the loaf. The scoring helps the heat get to the center of the loaf while cooking.\n5 Place in oven, cook for 15 minutes at 450\xc2\xb0F, then lower the heat to 400\xc2\xb0F and cook for 25 more minutes. One way to test for doneness is to take it out of the oven, turn it over and knock on the bottom. If it sounds hollow, it's done. You can also use a skewer inserted into the center.\nLet bread sit on the baking sheet for 5-10 minutes to cool. Then remove it to a rack to cool a little bit longer. I think the bread is best when it is still warm and just baked. Quick breads like this, which rely on baking soda for leavening, are generally best eaten soon after they're baked.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHow to Make Naan\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesRise time: 6 hoursYield: 16 naan\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup lukewarm milk\n1 1/2 teaspoons active dry yeast\n2 teaspoons sugar\n4 cups all-purpose flour + extra for dusting\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\n2 tablespoons olive oil or canola oil + extra for greasing the bowl\n1/2 cup plain yogurt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare a bowl: Lightly grease a large bowl with a little bit of oil. You will put your dough in this bowl to let it rise. Set the bowl aside.\n2 Prepare the dough: In a Pyrex liquid measuring cup or a small mixing bowl, combine the lukewarm milk, sugar, and active dry yeast. The milk should be just warm to the touch. If it\xe2\x80\x99s too hot you can kill the yeast. Let it sit for 5 minutes.\nIn another large mixing bowl, whisk the flour and salt together. Add yogurt, oil and milk-yeast mixture. Use a wooden spoon or your hands to combine the dough. The dough should be soft and sticky at this point.\n3 Knead the dough: Dust your countertop with flour. Transfer the dough to the counter. Knead together until a soft dough forms, about 5 minutes. If the dough feels dry and is too tough to knead, add about 1-2 tablespoons of water, a little bit at a time, until the dough is easier to work with.\n4 Let the dough rise: Transfer the dough to the greased bowl. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a damp towel. Place in a dark, warm, dry place. I place it in my oven (it\xe2\x80\x99s not on) to let it rise, but your countertop is fine. Let the dough rise for 3-4 hours or until it more than doubles in size.\n5 Punch down the dough and let it rise again: Punch the risen dough down. Knead for another minute. Return the dough to the bowl, cover it again and let it rise for another 45 minutes to 1 hour.\n6 Divide the dough: Dust your countertop with flour. Turn the dough out onto the counter and knead it for another minute or two until its smooth. Divide the dough into 16 smaller balls of equal size (about 2 ounces each).\nUsing a rolling pin, roll the balls into a teardrop shape. About 2-3 inches wide, 6-7 inches long, and about 1/8 inch thick. They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to be perfectly uniform.\n7 Cook the naan: If using herbs or spices, sprinkle one side of the bread with those now. Brush the other side with water. Set a medium-sized heavy pan or cast iron skillet with a lid over medium-high heat.\nCheck the heat of the pan by flicking water on it. If it evaporates on contact, it\xe2\x80\x99s ready. Once the pan is hot, place the naan wet side down into the skillet.\nCover it with a lid. Let it cook for about 30 seconds or until you see bubbles on it. Flip the naan, brush it with butter or ghee, and cook it uncovered for another 10 seconds. Serve it hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Brazilian Cheese Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Enough batter for 16 - 20 mini muffin sized cheese breads\nThe recipe as presented is fairly basic. Feel free to dress it up a bit with herbs or spices of your choice.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large egg*\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2/3 cup milk\n1 1/2 cups (170 grams) tapioca flour\n1/2 cup (packed, about 66 grams) grated cheese, your preference, we get good results with feta cheese (no need to grate), or fresh farmer's cheese (if using fresh farmer's cheese, you may want to add another 1/2 teaspoon of salt)\n1 teaspoon of salt (or more to taste)\n*It helps when baking with eggs to start with eggs at room temperature. If you don't plan ahead (that would be me, usually) you can put the egg in a bowl of warm water for a few minutes to gently take off the chill of the fridge.\nSpecial equipment:\nOne 24-well or or two 12-well mini muffin tins. Mini muffin tins are about half the size of a regular muffin pan. The muffin openings are about 1-inch deep, and 1 3/4 inch wide at the top.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pre-heat oven, prepare mini-muffin tin: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Spread a small amount olive oil around the insides of each well of a mini-muffin tin.\n2 Blend ingredients: Put all of the ingredients into a blender and pulse until smooth. You may need to use a spatula to scrape down the sides of the blender so that everything gets blended well. At this point you can store the batter in the refrigerator for up to a week.\n3 Pour into mini-muffin tin: Pour batter into prepared mini-muffin tin, not quite to the top; leave about 1/8 inch from the top.\n4 Bake: Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F in the oven for 15-20 minutes, until all puffy and nicely browned. Remove from oven and let cool on a rack for a few minutes.\nEat while warm or save to reheat later.\nNote that Brazilian cheese bread is very chewy, a lot like Japanese mochi.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCranberry Orange Nut Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups flour\n1 1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 cup chopped fresh cranberries\n3/4 cup coarsely chopped walnuts\n3/4 cup orange juice\n3/4 cup granulated sugar\n1/4 cup butter, melted\n1 egg, beaten\n1 Tbsp orange zest\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pre-heat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Combine dry ingredients: Whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the chopped cranberries and walnuts to coat with the flour mixture. (Coating with flour will help suspend the nuts and cranberries in the dough and keep them from sinking.)\n3 Combine wet ingredients: In a separate bowl combine the orange juice, sugar, melted butter, egg, and orange zest.\n4 Add wet ingredients into dry: Pour the orange juice sugar mixture into the flour nut cranberry mixture and fold until just blended. (Don't over-mix!)\n5 Bake: Transfer dough into a well buttered 8x4 or 9x5 loaf pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 50 to 55 minutes or until done (a tester inserted into the center comes out clean).\n6 Cool: Cool in pan for 10 minutes. Remove from pan and cool on a wire rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nSwedish Coffee Bread (Tea Ring) Recipe\nYield: Makes 2 wreaths\nIt's best to start with whole cardamom pods - peel the pods (helps to crush them first) to release the seeds. Crush the seeds with a mortar and pestle or use a rolling pin to grind them.\nINGREDIENTS\nBread:\n1 cup whole milk\n1/2 cup (100g) white sugar\n1/2 cup (4 oz) butter\n2-pkg active yeast dissolved in 1/4 cup warm water\nAbout 4 cups (560g) all-purpose flour\n1 large egg\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon ground cardamom\nFilling:\n2 tablespoons melted butter\n1/4 cup (54g)  brown sugar, packed\n1 tablespoon white sugar\n2 teaspoons cinnamon\n1 cup golden raisins (optional)\n1/2 cup slivered almonds (optional)\n1/4 cup almond paste (optional)\nEgg glaze:\n2 egg yolks\n2 tablespoon cream\nSugar glaze:\n1 cup (115g) powdered sugar\n1 tablespoon water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMake the Dough:\n1 Put milk into a small saucepan and heat on medium heat until steamy (but not boiling). Remove from heat. Stir in the butter and sugar until the butter has melted and the sugar dissolved. Pour into a mixing bowl. Mix in yeast mixture and egg.\n2 Mix in salt and cardamom. Slowly add in 2 cups of the flour. After the first two cups of flour gradually add more flour until a soft dough starts to form a ball and pull away from the sides of the bowl.\n3 Turn out onto a floured surface and knead dough for 7 to 10 minutes until smooth, OR use a dough hook in a stand-up mixer and knead the dough that way for 7 to 10 minutes, adding more flour as needed to keep the dough from being too sticky. Note that the dough should remain soft, so take care not to add too much flour.\nLet the Dough Rise:\n4 Place the dough in an oiled bowl, covered with a clean tea-towel or with plastic wrap. Let rise for an hour or until the dough has doubled in size.\nAt this point you can make a simple braided bread if you want (2 loaves), by punching the dough down, dividing the dough in half, and then dividing each half into three equal parts, rolling the dough pieces into ropes, braiding them, and tucking the ends under.\nOr you can get more fancy, which is what we've done here, with a filling, and forming the dough into a wreath shape. The following directions are for the wreath form.\nMake the Wreath Form:\n5 Press the dough down to deflate it a bit. Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Take one part (saving the other for wreath number 2) and use your fingers to spread it into a 8-inch by 16-inch rectangle on a lightly floured, clean, flat surface.\nIf you are having difficulty getting the dough to keep its shape, just do what you can and let it sit for 5 minutes before trying again. Like pizza dough, the dough needs time to relax while you are forming it.\nBrush the dough with melted butter, leaving at least a half inch border on the edges so the dough will stick together when rolled. Mix together the brown and white sugar and the cinnamon and sprinkle the dough with half of the mixture (saving the other half for the second batch of dough).\nSprinkle on more fillings, as you like, such as raisins, slivered almonds, or almond paste. You could even sprinkle on some cream cheese for a creamier filling.\n6 Carefully roll the dough up lengthwise, with the seam on the bottom. Carefully transfer to a greased baking sheet. Form a circle with the dough on the baking sheet, connecting the ends together.\n7 Using scissors, cut most of the way through the dough, cutting on a slant. Work your way around the dough circle. After each cut, pull out the dough segment either to the right or to the left, alternating as you go around the circle. The dough circle will look like a wreath when you are done.\nRepeat steps 5, 7, and 8 with the rest of the dough, to form a second wreath.\nThe Second Rise:\n8 Cover lightly with plastic wrap and set in a warm area for a second rise. Let rise for about 40 minutes to an hour; the dough should again puff up in size.\nBake:\n9 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Whisk together the egg yolks and cream. Use a pastry brush to brush over the dough. Bake in the oven for 25-30 minutes. After the first 15 minutes of baking, if the top is getting well browned, tent with some aluminum foil.\n10 Remove from oven and let cool completely. Whisk together powdered sugar and water to create a final glaze (optional). Add more water if the glaze is too thick to drizzle, add more powdered sugar if the glaze is too runny. Drizzle the glaze in a back and forth motion over the pastry.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nChocolate Zucchini Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Makes 2 loaves\nThis recipe makes 2 loaves; you can easily divide the recipe in half to make just one loaf.\nThe recipe calls for 4 cups of grated zucchini, which will yield particularly moist loaves. I've made it with 3 cups, which was also very good, just not as sublime as with 4 cups.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups grated zucchini (from about a pound and a half of zucchini)\n2 1/2 cups all purpose flour\n1/2 cup unsweetened cocoa (use natural unsweetened cocoa, NOT Dutch processed)\n2 teaspoons baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 1/2 cups granulated white sugar\n2 eggs\n3/4 cup unsalted butter (12 Tbsp or 1 1/2 sticks), melted\n1/2 teaspoon instant coffee granules\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Drain excess moisture from grated zucchini: Place the freshly grated zucchini in a sieve over a bowl to catch any excess moisture as it drains, while you work on prepping the other ingredients and preparing the recipe.\nIf for some reason your zucchini is on the dry side, hydrate the shredded zucchini by soaking it in water first, and then place in sieve.\n2 Preheat oven, prepare loaf pans: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F, with a rack in the middle. Grease two 9x5-inch loaf pans with baking spray or butter.\n3 Whisk together flour, cocoa, baking soda, salt, cinnamon: Vigorously whisk together the flour, unsweetened cocoa, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon in a large bowl. Whisk until there are no more clumps and the ingredients are well combined.\n4 Beat sugar and eggs, add melted butter, instant coffee granules, almond extract: In a separate large bowl, beat together the sugar and eggs until smooth, about a minute. You can do this with an electric mixer on medium speed, or by hand with a wooden spoon. (I'm lazy and use a mixer but it's easy enough to do by hand.)\nAdd the melted butter, instant coffee granules, and almond extract and beat until smooth.\n5 Stir zucchini into sugar egg mixture, add flour mixture: Mix the shredded zucchini into the sugar egg mixture.\nAdd the flour to the zucchini mixture in 3 additions, stirring to combine after each addition.\n6 Divide batter into pans and bake: Work quickly, and divide the batter between the two prepared loaf pans. (Work quickly because once the dry ingredients have mixed with the wet ingredients, the leavening has begun.)\nPlace into the oven. Bake for 50 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F, or until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean and easily.\n7 Cool: Remove to a rack. Let cool in the pan for 5 minutes, then run a blunt knife around the edges to separate the bread from the pan. Remove from the loaf pans and let cool completely on a rack.\nNote that if you try to slice the chocolate zucchini bread before it has completely cooled, it will be rather crumbly. It's also easiest to slice with a bread knife.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBoston Brown Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nDo your best to find the rye flour. It adds a lot to the flavor of the finished bread.\nINGREDIENTS\nButter for greasing loaf pans or coffee cans\n1/2 cup (heaping) all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup (heaping) rye flour\n1/2 cup (heaping) finely ground corn meal (must be finely ground)\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon allspice\n1/2 cup molasses (any kind)\n1 cup buttermilk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract (optional)\n1/2 cup raisins (optional)\nOne metal 6-inch tall by 4-inch diameter coffee can, or a 4x8 loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare for either stovetop or oven methods: You can either make the bread on the stovetop with a coffee can, or you can make it in the oven with a coffee can or loaf pan.\nStovetop: If you are using the stovetop method, set the steamer rack inside a tall stockpot and fill the pot with enough water to come 1/3 of the way up the sides of your coffee can. Turn the burner on to medium as you work.\nOven: If you are using the oven method, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F and bring a large pot of water to a boil.\n2 Grease pan: Grease a coffee can or small loaf pan with butter.\n3 Mix dry ingredients:  In a large bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, rye flour, corn meal, baking powder and soda, salt and allspice. Add the raisins if using.\n4 Mix wet ingredients, combine with dry: In another bowl, mix together the buttermilk and vanilla extract if using. Whisk in the molasses.\nPour the wet ingredients into the dry and stir well with a spoon.\n5 Pour batter into can or pan, cover with foil: Pour the batter into the coffee can or loaf pan taking care that the batter not reach higher than 2/3 up the sides of the container.\nCover the loaf pan or coffee can tightly with foil.\n6 Prepare steam environment on stovetop or oven:\nStovetop: If you are using the stovetop method, set the can in the pot on the steamer rack. Make sure there is enough water in the pot to come up 1/3 of the way up the sides of your coffee can or loaf pan. Cover the pot and turn the heat to high.\nOven: If you are using the oven method, find a high-sided roasting pan that can hold the coffee can or loaf pan. Pour the boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches one third up the side of the coffee can or loaf pan. Put the roasting pan into the 325\xc2\xb0F oven.\n7 Steam the bread: Steam the bread on the stovetop or in the oven for at least 2 hours and 15 minutes.\nCheck to see if the bread is done by inserting a toothpick into it. If the toothpick comes out clean, you're ready. If not, re-cover the pan and cook for up to another 45 minutes.\n8 Allow bread to cool: Remove from the stovetop or oven and let cool for 10 minutes before putting on a rack. Let the bread cool for 1 hour before turning out of the container.\nSlice and eat plain, or toast in a little butter in a frying pan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCheesy Skillet Cornbread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nMake sure your baking powder is fresh. Baking powder over 6 months old tends to lose its leavening power.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup cornmeal\n1/2 cup flour\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 cup shredded medium or sharp cheddar cheese\n1/4 cup chopped onion\n1 cup milk\n3 tablespoons bacon drippings (warmed to liquid), plus 1 teaspoon to grease the pan\n1 egg, beaten\n3/4 cup of cooked corn, either fresh, defrosted frozen corn, or drained from a can\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat pan in oven: Place a 9 or 10-inch cast iron pan in the oven and preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the batter: In a large bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, flour, baking powder, sugar, garlic powder, and salt. Add remaining ingredients, and stir until just combined.\n3 Grease hot pan, add batter: Carefully remove the hot pan from the oven (remember the handle is hot!). Place a teaspoon of bacon fat in the bottom of the hot pan and swirl it around until it is all melted and coating the bottom of the pan. Pour the batter from the mixing bowl into the pan. Remember to put a pot holder over the hot handle of the pan and return it to the oven.\n4 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 40 minutes or until golden brown. Remove from oven and let the cornbread cool in the pan. Remember that the handle is hot and will stay hot for quite some time. I recommend rubbing an ice cube over the handle to cool it down, just to avoid someone burning their hand if they attempt to move the pan before it has cooled down enough.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHomemade Potato Bread Recipe\nYield: Makes 2 loaves\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large russet potato (about a 12 oz potato)\n2 cups (475 ml) milk\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 teaspoon sugar\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 packet instant yeast (2 1/4 teaspoons)\n5 cups (680g) all purpose flour\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook, peel, mash the potato: You will need 6-8 ounces of mashed potato for this potato bread recipe. That's between 3/4 cup and one cup of mashed potatoes.\nThe easiest way to cook the potato is to poke it all over with the tines of a fork and microwave it 4 minutes on one side, 4 minutes on the other side, on high. Let it cool, then peel it, and mash it with a fork.\nOr, you can boil the potato. Peel the potato, cut it into large chunks, cover it with water in a pot, bring to a simmer, and cook for 10 minutes or so until a fork easily goes through the potatoes, drain, cool, and mash.\n2 Heat the milk, whisk in mashed potato: Put two cups of milk into a medium saucepan with the salt and sugar. Heat on medium heat until the milk starts to bubble at the edges, then remove from heat. Stir to dissolve the salt and sugar. Whisk in the olive oil and the mashed potato.\nPour into the mixing bowl of a standing mixer (or just a large bowl if you don't have a mixer), and let cool until it is still warm, but not hot, to the touch. (If the mixture is too hot, it will kill the yeast in the next step.)\n3 Add yeast and 2 cups of flour: Stir in the yeast. Stir in 2 cups (264 g) of the flour. Use a standing mixer such as a KitchenAid (recommended), attach the mixing paddle, and mix on medium high speed for 4 minutes. This will help break up any potato lumps and help incorporate the mashed potatoes into the dough.\n(If you are using a bread machine, put the milk potato mixture, the yeast, and all of the flour into the bread machine and knead for 8 minutes, skip the next step and proceed to step 5.)\n4 Add the remaining flour and knead: Swap out the mixing paddle for the dough hook on your mixer. Add the remaining 3 cups (416 g) of flour and mix on medium low speed for 8 minutes. The dough should be rather loose and a little tacky.\n5 Put dough into a large bowl, let dough rise: Rub the inside of a large bowl with some olive oil. Transfer the dough from the mixing bowl and put it into this large bowl (can use your mixing bowl if you clean it, and coat the inside with oil). Gently coat the top of the dough with a little olive oil.\nCover the bowl with plastic wrap or a dampened towel (to prevent the dough from drying out). Place in a warm spot for 2 hours or in the refrigerator overnight.\nThe dough should at least double in size. You'll know when it has risen sufficiently when you press into the top with your fingertip and the indentation remains for a while.\n6 Punch down the dough, place in loaf pans: Press down on the dough with your hand to deflate it. Turn it out onto a clean lightly floured surface and knead a couple of times. Cut the dough into two halves (a pastry scraper comes in handy for this).\nRub a little olive oil inside of two 8x4-inch loaf pans. Place a dough half in each and press the dough into the bottom of the pans.\n7 Let dough rise again: Coat the top of the loaves with a little olive oil. Cover the loaf pans with plastic wrap and put in a warm place for 45 minutes to an hour or longer, until the dough has doubled in size.\n8 Bake: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Remove the plastic wrap from the loaf pans and gently place the loaf pans in the oven in the middle rack. Bake for 35 minutes until the crust is golden brown and the internal temperature is between 190 and 200\xc2\xb0F.\nWhile the bread is still warm in the pan, use a dull dinner knife and run along the edge of the pan between the pan and the bread to loosen the bread from the pan. Turn out of the loaf pans on to a rack, let cool completely before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHomemade Rye Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 40 minutesTotal Rising time: 2 to 2 1/2 hoursYield: Makes 2 loaves\nINGREDIENTS\n2 packages active dry yeast (4 1/2 teaspoons or 16 grams)\n2 1/2 cups warm water (just barely warm to the touch)\n2/3 cup molasses (regular unsulphured; not blackstrap)\n2 tablespoons caraway seeds (optional)\n1 tablespoon salt\n1/4 cup vegetable oil\n1/4 cup cocoa powder (unsweetened)\n2 cups rye flour\n5 cups bread flour\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Dissolve the yeast: Dissolve the yeast in the warm water with the molasses. Put yeast mixture into a large metal bowl.\n2 Make the dough: Add the caraway seeds, salt, vegetable oil, cocoa powder, 2 cups of rye flour and then 2 cups of bread flour, mixing into the yeast mixture after each addition with a wooden spoon.\nAdd more bread flour, a cup at a time, until the dough is not so sticky and it is too hard to mix it with the wooden spoon. At that point, spread a half cupful of flour onto a large, clean, flat surface and put the dough onto the surface.\n3 Knead the dough: Knead the dough by pressing down with the heel of your hand, stretching it, turning the dough a quarter-turn, pulling the dough back toward you and then pressing and stretching again. Knead additional bread flour into the dough until it reaches the right consistency. Knead for 5-7 minutes, or until the dough is smooth and elastic.\n4 Let the dough rise: Spread some vegetable oil around a large bowl and place the dough in it, turning it so it gets coated in the oil.\nCover the bowl with plastic wrap or a damp cloth. Let rise at room temperature until it has doubled in size, 1 to 1 1/2 hours.\n5 Divide the dough: Gently press down on the risen dough so some of its air is released. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface, knead the dough a few turns and then divide it by cutting it in half with a sharp knife.\n6 Shape the loaves: Shape each half into loaf. Place dough loafs into either oiled 8x4-inch bread loaf pans, or onto a flat baking sheet or peel that has been sprinkled with corn meal, depending if you want to cook the loaves in pans or directly on a baking stone. Cover with plastic or a damp cloth.\n7 Let the loaves rise: Let the bread rise again, this time not doubling in volume, but rising by about half of its volume, about 30 to 45 minutes, half as long as the first rising. The dough should be peeking over the top of the loaf pan if using a loaf pan.\n8 Heat the oven: If you are using a baking stone, place the stone in the oven. Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F for at least half an hour before baking.\n9 Bake the loaves: If baking on a stone and not in the pan, score the loaves a few times on the top of the dough right before putting it in the oven.\nPut loaves in the oven. If you have a mister, mist the dough with a little water the first 10 minutes of baking. Bake for 40-50 minutes, or until done. The bread should sound hollow when tapped.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nYankee Cornbread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 18 squares\nIf you can find it, use stoneground cornmeal in this recipe. It adds a deliciously nutty flavor and texture to the bread.\nINGREDIENTS\nButter (for the pan)\nFlour (for the pan)\n3 large eggs\n1 cup canola oil\n2 cups plain Greek yogurt\n1/2 cup sugar\n2 cups yellow cornmeal, preferably stoneground\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13-inch baking pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 375F. Butter a 9x13-inch baking pan. Line the bottom with parchment paper and butter the paper. Dust the pan with flour, tapping out the excess.\n2 Prepare the batter: In a bowl large enough to hold all the ingredients, stir together the eggs, canola oil, and yogurt until smooth. Stir in the sugar followed by the cornmeal, flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Keep stirring until no pockets of dry ingredients show.\n3 Bake the cornbread: Pour the batter into the pan and use an offset spatula or regular spatula to smooth the top. Bake the cornbread for 35 minutes, or until it is uniformly golden brown on top and firm in the middle. Set on a rack to cool for 10 minutes.\n4 Slice the cornbread: Make 2 vertical slices and 5 horizontal slices to form 18 squares. Lift them from the pan and serve with butter.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nDinner Potato Rolls {Buttery & Fluffy Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesInactive rising time: 2 hoursYield: 16 to 20 rolls\nIf you're not already making mashed potatoes for your meal, roast or boil one large (12 ounce) russet potato to use in this recipe.\nI usually make this recipe with unseasoned mashed potatoes that haven't been mixed with butter or dairy, but have also made them with leftover seasoned mashed potatoes. With seasoned mashed potatoes, you may end up needing to use a little extra flour.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the rolls:\n1/2 cup water, room temperature\n2 1/4 teaspoon (1 packet) active-dry or instant yeast\n1 teaspoon plus 1/3 cup sugar, divided\n1 cup mashed potatoes\n1/4 cup milk\n6 tablespoons regular salted butter, melted and cooled\n2 large eggs\n2 1/2 teaspoons minced fresh rosemary leaves\n1 1/2 teaspoon salt\n4 1/2 to 5 cups all-purpose flour\nFor honey butter topping:\n1/4 cup regular salted butter, room temperature\n2 tablespoon honey\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Proof the yeast: In the bowl of a stand mixer, combine the water, the yeast, and 1 teaspoon of the sugar. Set aside for about 5 minutes, or until the mixture looks bubbly. If the mixture doesn't start to bubble, then your yeast has likely expired and it's best to start over with new yeast.\n2 Mix the dough: Add the remaining sugar, mashed potatoes, milk, butter, eggs, rosemary, and salt to the bowl with the yeast mixture and stir with a spatula until smooth. Add 4 1/2 cups of the flour and mix until you form a shaggy dough.\n3 Knead the dough: With a dough hook attachment (or on the counter, if kneading by hand) knead on medium-low for 5 to 7 minutes until the dough is smooth, forms a ball around the dough hook, and pulls away from the sides of the bowl (it's fine if the dough sticks to the bottom of the bowl). If the dough is still sticking to the sides after few minutes of kneading, add in a little more flour 2 tablespoons at a time.\n4 Let the dough rise: Place the dough in a lightly greased bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and place somewhere warm for about 1 hour, or until the dough doubles in size.\n5 Shape the dough into rolls: Line a 13x9-inch baking pan with parchment paper and lightly grease. Turn the dough the out onto lightly floured surface and cut into 16 to 20 equal pieces. Roll the dough into small balls, and place seam side down in the baking dish.\n6 Cover and let the rolls rise until puffed and nearly doubled in size, about 1 hour. About 15 minutes before the rolls are ready, heat the oven to 350F.\n7 Bake for the rolls for 20 to 25 minutes, or until the rolls are golden brown on top and register 200F on the inside when tested with an instant-read thermometer.\n8 Brush the rolls with honey butter: In a small dish, mix together 1/4 cup room temperature butter and 2 tablespoons honey until smooth. Brush tops of baked rolls with mixture, then sprinkle with salt. Allow to cool slightly before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nZucchini Bread with Pineapple Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Makes 2 loaves\nThe original recipe called for 2 cups of zucchini, but I like to make it with 3, just because I have so much zucchini that needs to be used up. More zucchini yields a moister loaf.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups all purpose flour\n1 teaspoons baking soda\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n2 teaspoons cinnamon\n3/4 teaspoon nutmeg\n3 eggs\n1 3/4 cups sugar\n1 cup olive oil\n2 teaspoons vanilla\n2 to 3 cups coarsely grated zucchini\n1 can (8oz) crushed pineapple, drained\n1 cup chopped walnuts (optional)\n1 cup golden raisins (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Drain zucchini of excess moisture: Put the shredded zucchini in a colander or sieve placed over a bowl to drain any excess moisture.\n2 Prepare the oven and pans: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Prepare 2 buttered 5 by 9 inch loaf pans.\n3 Whisk together dry ingredients: In a medium sized bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg.\n4 Mix wet ingredients and sugar: In a mixer, beat eggs on medium speed for one minute.\nAdd the sugar and beat for one more minute.\nAdd the oil and vanilla; continue beating mixture until thick and foamy.\n5 Stir in grated zucchini and pineapple: Remove the bowl from the mixer and with a spoon, stir in the zucchini and pineapple.\n6 Combine dry ingredients with wet: A third at a time, add dry ingredients into wet and gently stir (by hand) after each addition.\n7 Add the walnuts and raisins, blend gently.\n8 Bake: Divide the batter equally between the two loaf pans. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 55 minutes or until a wooden pick inserted in to the center comes out clean.\nCool in pans for 10 minutes. Turn out onto wire racks to cool thoroughly.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nEasiest Ever Garlic Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 3 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\n1 to 4 slices of rustic bread\nA drizzle of extra virgin olive oil for each slice\nOne large fresh garlic clove\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast one or two slices of bread.\n2 Drizzle or brush a little olive oil over one side of the toasted bread.\n3 Cut a garlic clove (peel still on) in half, on the diagonal. Gently rub the cut side of the garlic clove over the olive oil-brushed toasted bread.\nAlternatively, you can brush the toast with the garlic first, and then drizzle with olive oil or spread with butter. Both ways work.\nTip: If you have leftover slices of garlic bread, cut them up into squares for croutons. Store in an airtight bag or jar at room temp for a day or two. You can also process them in a blender or food processor for garlicky breadcrumbs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b'Print\nCinnamon Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 1 minuteCook time: 2 minutesYield: Makes two slices of cinnamon toast (and lots of smiles).\nFeel free to play with the ratio of cinnamon to sugar to get it to how you like it. Some people like 1:3 cinnamon to sugar, some 1:12, and some in between.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 slices of sliced bread\n2 pads of butter, softened or room temp\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\nMETHOD\nIn a small bowl or jar, stir together the cinnamon and sugar so they are well mixed. Toast your bread. Slather the toast with butter. Sprinkle the cinnamon sugar over the buttered toast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nWhole Wheat Bread\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesRise time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: 2 loaves\nIf you are lactose intolerant, it's fine to substitute water for the milk.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups warm 2% milk\n1 packet Active Dry Yeast (about 3 teaspoons)\n3 1/3 cups (395g) bread flour plus more for dusting\n3 1/3 cups (410g) whole wheat flour\n1 tablespoon Kosher salt\n2 1/2 tablespoons butter, plus more for brushing loaves\n2 1/2 tablespoons honey\nSpecial equipment:\nTwo 9x5-inch loaf pans (You can use 8.5x4.5-inch pans, but your loaves will be quite a bit taller.)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the pans: Butter a large bowl and two 9x5-inch loaf pans and set aside. (You can use 8.5x4.5-inch pans, but your loaves will be quite a bit taller.)\n2 Proof the yeast: Warm the 2 1/2 cups of milk in the microwave in 30 second bursts, stirring in between, just to take the chill off. The milk should feel tepid to the touch, NOT hot. (Hot milk will kill the yeast.)\nStir the yeast into to the warm milk and let it hang out for about 5 minutes. The yeast should mostly dissolve and you should see some small bubbles on the surface of the milk.\n3 Meanwhile, whisk together the dry ingredients and melt the butter: In a large bowl, whisk whole wheat flour, bread flour, and salt. Make a well in the center.\nIn a small, microwave-safe bowl, warm the butter in 30 second bursts in the microwave until just melted. Add honey. Let it cool until no longer hot.\n4 Mix the dough: Pour the milk and yeast mixture into well in the flour. Add the butter and honey mixture.\nStir with a wooden spoon until a shaggy dough forms. Most of the flour should be incorporated, but it\xe2\x80\x99s ok if you still have some loose flour in the bowl.\n5 Knead the dough: To knead by hand: Turn the dough and any loose flour onto a countertop and knead for 10 minutes. Start by bringing the dough together with your fingers then smooshing it with the heel of your hand. Pull the dough back over itself with your fingers, rotate the dough a quarter turn. Smoosh with the heel of your hand and repeat.\nAs you knead, the dough should feel soft, pliable, and a little tacky. Dust with additional bread flour as needed, 1 tablespoon at a time, if it sticks to the counter or your hands.\nTo knead in a stand mixer: In a stand mixer fit with a dough hook attachment, knead the dough on the lowest speed for 5 to 7 minutes.\nWhen finished kneading, the dough should be tacky but not sticky. Form the dough into a ball. It should be smooth on top, and feel elastic.\n6 Let the dough rise: Place the ball of dough into the buttered bowl. Use your fingers to gently spread a thin layer of softened butter on top of the dough ball.\nCover with plastic wrap or a clean dish towel and let it sit on the counter until it has just about doubled in size. This should take 45 to 60 minutes.\n7 Shape the loaves: Gently punch the dough down two or three times. Take the dough out of the bowl and form it into a ball. Divide the dough into equal halves.\nShape each half into a loaf: Gently flatten the dough with the tips of your fingers to form a puffy oval roughly the width of your baking pan. Starting from a short end, gently roll it up and pinch the seam closed. Roll it over so the seam-side is down and transfer to the prepared baking pan.\nRepeat with the second loaf.\n8 Let the loaves rise: Cover with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel. Let rise for 45 to 60 minutes, or until the bread rises just above the lip of the pan.\nThe dough is ready for the oven once it has puffed up, but it maintains its structure. You should be able to press a fingertip gently onto the top of it, and the dimple should slowly fill back in.\n9 Halfway through this second rise, preheat your oven to 375-degrees. Melt additional butter for brushing over the tops of the loaves.\n10 Bake the loaves: Slash a shallow line down the center of the dough with serrated knife. Brush the tops with the melted butter. (The top layer of dough might bubble a little when you baste it with the warm butter. That\xe2\x80\x99s ok. Just pop the bubbles with your knife.)\nPlace the loaves in the oven and bake for approximately 40 minutes until loaves are golden brown, have risen, and make a hollow sound when the bottoms are tapped.\n11 Cool the loaves: When the loaves have finished baking, remove from oven and baste the tops with butter one more time.\nTurn the loaves out onto a wire rack and let cool. Do not let the bread cool in the loaf pans. If you do, the bread will get soggy.\n12 Store and enjoy! Once the bread has cooled, store it on the countertop in a plastic bag or a cloth bread bag.\nThe bread will stay fresh for 4 days, which isn\xe2\x80\x99t to say it goes bad by day 5, just that it will start to dry out a bit. Rather than using the bread to make a fresh turkey sandwich on day 5 make grilled sandwiches or toast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nRosemary Focaccia Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 20 minutesTotal Rising time: 4 hoursYield: Makes a large loaf and a small loaf of 1 1/2 to 2 inches thick.\nThe bread takes on the flavor of the olive oil so use a good quality extra virgin olive oil.\nRecipe adapted from The Italian Baker by Carol Field.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 package (2 1/4 teaspoons) dry yeast\n1/3 cup warm water, about 100 degrees\n2 1/4 cups tepid water\n2 tablespoons good quality extra virgin olive oil, plus more for the pan and to paint on top of the bread\n3 cups bread flour\n4 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1 tablespoon salt, plus coarse salt (fleur de sel if you have it, otherwise Kosher salt) for sprinkling over the top\n2-3 tablespoons finely chopped fresh rosemary (can use sage or other herbs such as thyme or oregano, but whatever herb you use, do use fresh herbs, do not use dried)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Proof the yeast: Stir the yeast into the 1/3 cup of slightly warm-to-the-touch water and let it rest for 10 minutes.\n2 Add olive oil to water, then add yeast: In a large bowl, pour in 2 1/4 cups of tepid water and 2 tablespoons olive oil. After the yeast has rested for 10 minutes and has begun to froth, pour it into the water-oil mixture.\n3 Add flour and rosemary: Whisk in 2 cups of flour (either the bread flour or the all purpose, at this stage it doesn't matter which) and the tablespoon of salt. Add the rosemary.\nCup by cup, whisk in the rest of the flour (both the bread flour and all-purpose). As the mixture goes from a batter to a thick dough, you'll want to switch from a whisk to a wooden spoon.\n4 Knead the dough: By the time you get to adding the last cup of flour, you will be able to work the dough with your hands. Begin to knead it in the bowl \xe2\x80\x93 try to incorporate all the flour stuck to the sides and bottom of the bowl as you begin kneading.\nOnce the bowl is pretty clean, turn the dough out onto a board and knead it well for 8 minutes. You might need some extra flour if the dough is sticky.\nNote that a KitchenAid mixer (or some other brand of upright electric mixer) works well for the mixing and kneading of the bread dough. About the time you add the last cup of flour you'll want to switch from the standard mixer attachment to the dough hook attachment.\nJust knead the dough using the dough hook on low speed for 8 minutes. If after a few minutes the dough is still a little sticky, add a little sprinkling of flour to it.\n5 First rise: In a large clean bowl, pour in about a tablespoon of oil and put the dough on top of it. Spread the oil all over the dough.\nCover the bowl with plastic wrap and set aside to rise (in a relatively warm spot or at room temp) for an hour and a half. It should just about double in size.\n6 Spread dough in baking pan: Spread a little olive oil in your baking pan or baking sheet (will make it easier to remove the bread). Place the dough in your baking pans or form it into free-form rounds on a baking sheet.\nThis recipe will make two nice-sized loaves or one big one and a little one. Cover the breads and set aside for another 30 minutes.\n7 Dimple the bread: Dimple the breads with your thumb. Push in to about the end of your thumbnail, roughly 1/2-inch.\n8 Second rise: Cover the dough again and leave it to rise for its final rise, about 2 hours.\n9 Preheat oven: With 30 minutes to go before the rise finishes, preheat your oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. If you have a pizza stone put it in.\n10 Brush with olive oil, sprinkle with salt: Once the dough has done its final rise, gently paint the top with olive oil \xe2\x80\x94 as much as you want.\nThen sprinkle the coarse salt on top from about a foot over the bread; this lets the salt spread out better on its way down and helps reduce clumps of salt.\n11 Bake: Put the bread in the oven. If you are doing free-form breads, put it right on the pizza stone. Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F for a total of 20-25 minutes.\nIf you have a water spritzer bottle, spritz a little water in the oven right before you put the bread in to create steam, and then a couple of times while the bread is baking.\n12 Cool and serve: When the bread comes out of the oven, turn it out onto a rack within 3-5 minutes; this way you'll keep the bottom of the bread crispy. Let cool on a rack for 10 minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCheesy Jalape\xc3\xb1o Pull Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 rustic loaf of bread, unsliced, either Italian or French\n12 ounces shredded Monterey Jack cheese\n1/4 cup (less or more to taste) chopped pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os\n1/4 cup chopped green onions, including greens\n1/4 cup (4 Tbsp) butter, melted\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slice bread in cross hatch pattern: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Slice the bread almost all the way through (not all the way) in a cross hatch pattern, spacing an inch between the slices.\n2 Make cheese mixture: Place the shredded cheese in a large bowl. Toss with the green onions and jalape\xc3\xb1os. Pour over with melted butter and use your clean hands to toss, to distribute the butter evenly through the cheese.\n3 Stuff bread with cheese mixture: Place the bread on a large sheet of aluminum foil (large enough to wrap the bread) on a baking sheet. Stuff every crevasse with the cheese mixture.\nWrap with the aluminum foil. At this point you can make ahead and refrigerate until ready to bake.\n4 Bake: Bake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 15 minutes. Then uncover the foil from the bread and cook for 10 minutes more, until all of the cheese has melted.\nPlace on a serving board or plate to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nIrish Brown Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes 1 large or 2 small loaves\nLook for bran and stone ground whole wheat flour with the specialty flours in the baking section of your grocery store. Two good brands are Bob's Red Mill and Arrowhead Mills, both of which can also be ordered online.\nINGREDIENTS\nVegetable oil spray (for the loaf pan)\n1 1/2 cups (350g) warm water (about 100\xc2\xb0F)\n2 tablespoons milk\n2 tablespoons molasses\n2 teaspoons active dry yeast (slightly less than one package)\n1/2 cup (25 grams) coarse wheat bran, plus more for sprinkling\n2 teaspoons salt\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened\n3 1/2 cups (450g) stoneground whole wheat flour\n1 teaspoon vegetable oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan(s): Generously spray a 9-inch loaf pan (or two 8 by 3 3/4-inch loaf pans\xe2\x80\x94disposable aluminum pans are the perfect size) with non-stick spray.\n2 Mix and knead the dough by hand: In a large bowl, stir the warm water, milk, molasses and yeast together and let stand until the mixture starts to bubble, about 5 minutes. Add the wheat bran, salt, butter and 2 cups of the flour.  Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon in the same direction for 1 minute.\nAdd enough of the remaining flour, 1/2 cup at a time, until the dough is difficult to stir with a wooden spoon and pulls away from the side of the bowl.\nUsing one hand to hold the bowl, use your other hand to knead the dough in the bowl for a minute or two. The dough will stick to your hands but should pull away from the side of the bowl after about a minute. If necessary, add more flour, 1 tablespoon at a time. While the dough will be damp, it should not feel muddy.\nAlternatively, mix with a stand mixer on medium speed with the paddle attachment, beating for about 1 minute until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl.\n3 Shape the loaf: On a lightly floured work surface, pat the dough into an oval shape approximately 9 inches long with the long side of the oval parallel to the edge of the work surface. Starting with the long side closest to you, roll the dough into a tight cylinder. Pinch the seam closed.\nFlip the loaf over, so it's seam-side down. Tuck the ends under so the loaf is uniform and even. Place the dough in the pan with the seam side down.\n(To make 2 small loaves, divide the dough in half and shape as above, making the oval 7 inches long.)\n4 Let the dough rise: Drizzle the vegetable oil on top of the dough and smooth it over the dough as you pat it into the corners of the pan. Sprinkle with extra bran, if you like. Cover the pan loosely with plastic wrap and let rise for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, or until the dough rises about 1 inch above the top of the pan,\n5 Heat the oven: About 20 minutes before the loaf is ready to be baked, position a rack in the lower third of the oven and preheat it to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n6 Bake the loaf: Place the loaf in the oven and immediately reduce the heat to 375\xc2\xb0F. Bake for 35 minutes for a large loaf, or 25 to 30 minutes for 2 small loaves, or until the loaf sounds hollow when tapped on the bottom.\n7 Harden the crust: Remove the bread from the oven and immediately turn it out of the pan. Place it directly on the oven rack and continue to bake for 7 to 10 minutes, or until the crust browns.\n8 Cool the loaf: Remove and set on a wire rack to cool. When thoroughly cool, store the loaves in plastic bags.\nThe bread is best eaten on the day it\xe2\x80\x99s made, but after a day or two it is still good toasted for breakfast or tea. Well-wrapped in plastic and then foil, the bread may be stored in the freezer for up to a month.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nPanzanella Bread Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nAs you cut the tomatoes, remove some of the seeds and liquid. Your panzanella will be juicy enough. Leave the crusts on the bread chunks; they will stay chewier and give the panzanella more substance.\nIf you don't have stale bread sitting around, you can take fresh crusty bread, cut it into big cubes, lay the cubes out on a baking sheet, and put in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 5-10 minutes, until the outer edges have dried out a bit (not toasted, just dried). If you use fresh bread without doing this, the bread may disintegrate into mush in the salad.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups tomatoes, cut into large chunks\n4 cups day old (somewhat dry and hard) crusty bread (Italian or French loaf), cut into chunks the same size as the tomatoes (see Recipe Note)\n1 cucumber, skinned and seeded, cut into large chunks\n1/2 red onion, chopped\n1 bunch fresh basil, torn into little pieces\n1/4 to 1/2 cup high quality extra virgin olive oil\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHOD\nMix everything together and let marinate, covered, at room temperature for at least 30 minutes.\nIf refrigerating, let come to room temperature before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nLemon Rosemary Zucchini Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes 2 loaves\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups (390 grams) flour\n2 teaspoons baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n2 Tbsp minced fresh rosemary\n2 eggs\n1/2 cup melted unsalted butter\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1/2 teaspoons salt (omit if using salted butter)\n1 1/4 cup sugar\n1 Tbsp lemon zest\n3 cups grated zucchini (from about 1 pound of zucchini)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350F. Prepare two 4x9-inch loaf pans, either coating with butter or spraying with baking spray.\n2 In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and rosemary.\n3 Beat the eggs in a mixer (or by hand) until frothy. Beat in the sugar. Beat in the melted butter and olive oil. Stir in the lemon zest and grated zucchini.\n4 Add the dry ingredients to the wet, a third at a time, stirring after each incorporation.\n5 Divide batter/dough into two loaf pans. Bake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 45 to 50 minutes. Test after 40 minutes. If you gently press down on the surface of the loaf, it should bounce back, and a bamboo skewer inserted into the center should come out clean.\n6 Remove from the oven. Let cool for a few minutes and then remove the loaves from their pans to cool on a rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nParker House Rolls Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 18 minutesRising time: 1 hourYield: 3 dozen rolls\nNote that the rolls do not rise a second time once shaped.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/4 teaspoons (1 envelope) active dry yeast\n3 tablespoons lukewarm water\n1 1/2 cups (355 ml) whole milk\n3 tablespoons butter, cut into chunks\n3 tablespoons sugar\n2 teaspoons salt\n4 1/2 cups (630 g) flour, plus more if needed\n6 tablespoons melted unsalted butter, for brushing the rolls\nSpecial equipment:\n2 1/2-inch plain round cutter\nPastry brush\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Dissolve the yeast: In a bowl large enough to hold all the dough, sprinkle the yeast over the water and let it dissolve, about 5 minutes.\n2 Warm the milk: In a saucepan over low heat, combine the milk, 3 tablespoons cut-up butter, sugar, and salt. Heat just until the butter melts and the milk feels warm to the touch of a fingertip. If the milk gets too hot, remove from the heat and let it cool to lukewarm.\n3 Mix the dough: Stir the yeast mixture with a wooden spoon to mix the dissolved yeast and water. Tip in the milk mixture, still stirring, until smooth. Add 2 cups of the flour and stir again until the mixture is almost smooth, with just a few lumps.\nContinue stirring in flour, 1 cup at a time, until the mixture forms a dough. It will be very soft.\n4 Knead the dough: Turn the dough out onto a floured counter and knead for a few minutes until the dough is smooth, adding more flour as needed if the dough is very sticky.\n5 Let the dough rise: Clean and dry the bowl, then grease lightly with a little vegetable oil. Set the dough in the bowl and turn it all around so it is oiled all over.\nCover with a clean, damp kitchen towel or plastic wrap, and set in a warm place to rise for 1 hour, or until it is puffy (it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to double in bulk).\n6 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n7 Shape the rolls: Punch the dough down in the bowl, then transfer it to a lightly floured counter or pastry board. Knead until all the air is out.\nRoll the dough to a 1/4-inch thickness. If it springs back as you try to roll it, let it rest for 5 minutes and then try again.\nUse a 2 1/2-inch round biscuit or cookie cutter to stamp out rounds. Dip the cutter in flour often to avoid sticking, and stamp the rounds as close to each other as possible.\nPress the back of a butter knife down the center of each round to form a crease; this is where you will fold the rolls in half. Dip the knife in flour if it starts to stick to the dough.\nBrush the rounds with melted butter. Fold each round in half to make half-moon shapes and press the edges together lightly to seal them. Gather and reroll the scraps to make more rolls.\nTransfer the rolls to the baking sheets, leaving 2-inches between rolls. Brush with more melted butter.\n8 Bake the rolls: Transfer the baking sheets to the oven and bake for 15 to 18 minutes, rotating the sheets halfway through baking, until the rolls are puffed and golden. They're best served warm and fresh, but leftovers will keep for a few days in an airtight container at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nTomato and Bread Soup (Pappa al Pomodoro) Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6\nGiven that the primary ingredient in this soup is tomato, the quality of tomatoes you use is vital to the taste of the soup. Use a good quality canned tomato such as a San Marzano or Muir Glen. If using fresh tomatoes, use very ripe, in-season tomatoes.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups diced yellow onion\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, divided 2 Tbsp and 2 Tbsp\n5 cloves garlic, minced\n2 28-ounce cans whole peeled tomatoes (or about 4 pounds of fresh, ripe tomatoes, that are blanched, peeled, and chopped*)\n3 bay leaves\n2 cups of chicken stock\n1 1/2 cups of cubed rustic bread, 1 1/2-inch cubes (about 2 to 3 thick slices of Italian loaf), day old is best\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon salt, less or more to taste\nFreshly grated Parmesan cheese and chopped fresh basil or parsley for garnish\n*To prepare fresh tomatoes for this recipe, cut out the stem end, score the bottoms with a sharp knife. Put into boiling water and boil for 1 minute. Place in ice water to quickly cool. Peel back the tomato peels and discard. Chop the tomatoes, saving as much of the juice as you can. Add the chopped tomatoes and the juice in place of the canned tomatoes in step 2.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic: Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil on medium heat in a 5 to 6-quart thick-bottomed pot. Add the diced onions and cook slowly until softened and beginning to color, about 10-12 minutes.\nAdd minced garlic and cook a minute more.\n2 Add tomatoes, stock, bay leaves, oregano, then simmer: Add tomatoes to the pot with the onions, crushing them by hand as you put them in the pot. Discard any hard stem ends or stray tomato skins. Add chicken stock, bay leaves, and dried oregano.\nHeat to a simmer and reduce heat to maintain a low simmer. Cook for 20 minutes.\nAs you are cooking the tomato soup base, prepare the bread croutons in the next step.\n3 Toast croutons on stovetop: Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil in a saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Once the oil is hot, add the cubed bread to the pan. Toss to coat with the oil and spread the cubes out in a single layer.\nLet sit in pan without moving until one side is golden browned, then use tongs to turn over to another side. Once at least two sides have browned, remove from heat.\n4 Add croutons to soup: Once the tomatoes have cooked for 20 minutes, add the lightly browned croutons to the soup. Cook for 5 minutes. Turn off the heat and cover the pan. Let sit for 10-15 minutes.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e: Remove the bay leaves. Use an immersion blender or upright blender to roughly pur\xc3\xa9e the soup (about half of the soup, leave some chunky bits).\nGarnish with freshly grated Parmesan and chopped fresh basil or parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nGuinness Bread with Molasses Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Makes one loaf\nThis is fantastic eaten fresh, and nearly as good the next day toasted with some more butter. Do not use stale beer for this recipe, you want the carbonation.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups self-rising flour*\n1/2 cup white sugar\n1/3 cup unsulfured molasses\nA pinch of salt (roughly 1/8 teaspoon)\n12 ounces of Guinness extra stout\nButter for greasing the pan and painting the top, about 3 tablespoons\n* If you don't have self-rising flour, you can substitute using a ratio of 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 1/4 teaspoon baking powder, plus 1/8 teaspoon of salt, for every cup of self-rising flour. Have made both ways though and got better results from the self-rising flour.\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven and prepare loaf pan: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease a 9x5-inch loaf pan well with butter.\n2 Whisk together the flour, salt and sugar in a large bowl.\n3 Slowly add Guinness to the flour, add molasses: Slowly pour the Guinness into the flour mixture. (The \xe2\x80\x9cpub cans\xe2\x80\x9d are larger than 12 ounces, but they have better carbonation, so I pour most of it out and leave a swig to drink. This has never failed me, but if you are a stickler, use a 12-ounce bottle of Guinness instead.)\nStart stirring the beer into the dry ingredients, and when you are about halfway done, add the molasses. Mix well, just to combine.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t work the heck out of the batter \xe2\x80\x93 because that\xe2\x80\x99s what it\xe2\x80\x99ll look like \xe2\x80\x93 but you don\xe2\x80\x99t want lumps, either.\n4 Bake: Pour into the loaf pan to no more than 2/3 full. Pop into the oven immediately and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 50 minutes. Since ovens can vary, check the bread after 40 minutes and see if a tester inserted into the deepest part of the loaf comes out clean. If it does, you\xe2\x80\x99re done.\n5 Cool and paint with butter: Let the loaf cool a bit, maybe 5 minutes, and then turn it out onto a rack. Paint it with lots of soft butter, which will melt as you go.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nFattoush Bread Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pita chips:\n2 rounds pita bread (8- to 12-inches)\nOlive oil (for toasting the pita)\nSalt and pepper, to taste\nFor the salad:\n4 Persian, pickling, or other small cucumbers, thinly sliced (or 1 English cucumber, trimmed, halved vertically, and thinly sliced)\n4 radishes, trimmed and thinly sliced\n2 large tomatoes, cored and cut into 1-inch pieces\n1/2 pint cherry tomatoes, halved\n1/4 red onion, very thinly sliced\n1/4 cup sliced scallions, white and light green parts\nFor the dressing:\nJuice of 1 lemon, or more to taste\n4 tablespoons olive oil\nLarge handful fresh mint leaves, coarsely chopped\nLarge handful fresh parsley leaves, coarsely chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare pita chips: Set the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. With kitchen shears, cut the pita round into 1-inch pieces. In a bowl, sprinkle the pita with just enough olive oil so a drop lands on each piece. Toss well. Sprinkle with salt and toss again.\n2 Toast the pita chips: Spread the pieces out on a rimmed baking sheet. It's fine if the pieces overlap or cluster together. Bake for 2 minutes, then toss the chips. Bake another 2 minutes and toss again. Remove any pieces that are starting to look crisp and golden. Continue baking another 1 to 2 minutes until all the pieces are crisp and golden. Set aside to cool.\n3 Prepare the vegetables: In a large bowl combine the cucumbers, radishes, large and cherry tomatoes, scallions, and red onion.\n4 Dress the salad just before serving: Sprinkle the lemon juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper over the vegetables and toss gently but thoroughly. Add the mint and parsley and toss again. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like. Add the pita chips and toss gently to avoid crushing them. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBread Soup (Panade) with Onions, Chard, and Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nThis soup really shines with homemade stock, especially homemade vegetable stock.
