Pour the egg milk mixture evenly over the bread and cheese.\n4 Cover and chill, if making ahead: At this point, the casserole can be covered and chilled in the fridge until ready to bake and serve, up to overnight.\nIf baking immediately, let the casserole sit for 10 minutes before putting in the oven (to give the bread a chance to absorb the milk-egg mixture.\n5 Bake the casserole: When ready to cook, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Bake uncovered for about one hour. Tent with foil if the top begins to brown too quickly.\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before serving. Leftovers will keep in the refrigerator for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nThe ingredient proportions are estimates. The more eggs, the firmer and less likely to deflate the casserole will be.\nMushrooms tend to hold a lot of moisture, so if you use a lot of them, you may want to saut\xc3\xa9 them first to release some of their water.\nDon't have day-old bread? Put slices of fresh bread into a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the breakfast casserole base:\n6 to 10 large eggs\n2 to 3 cups grated cheddar cheese\n6 slices day-old bread, cut into 3/4-inch to 1-inch-wide cubes\n2 cups milk\nSalt\nPepper\nFor the possible additions: \n1 cup corn (cooked or frozen)\n1/2 cup chopped broccoli (cooked or raw, raw will turn out crunchier)\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup sliced green onions\n1 cup cubed ham and/or cooked Italian sausage\nA few slices cooked bacon, chopped\n1 teaspoon Herbes de Provence, or other dried herbs, (or 1 tablespoon of fresh chopped herbs such as basil, rosemary, or thyme)\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of cumin or curry powder\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13 inch casserole dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Beat eggs, add milk and cheese: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the milk and cheese.\n2 Add the bread and carefully stir until all pieces of bread are moistened (don't over mix or the bread may disintegrate).\n3 Add the additions: Add salt and pepper to taste (if using Italian sausage, you won't need either.) If you have a lot of additions, you might need a couple more eggs to make sure that everything is at least touching some egg mixture. Just whisk in 2 tablespoons of milk for every beaten egg you add.\n4 Bake: Butter a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Pour the mixture into the casserole dish.\nBake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 50 minutes to an hour, until the top is browned and the center springs back when touched.\nRemove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nTater Tot Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n12 ounces ground pork breakfast sausage\n6 ounces (1 1/2 cups) shredded cheddar cheese, plus extra to sprinkle over top\n8 large eggs\n1/2 cup (whole) milk\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\nOne 32-ounce bag frozen tater tots\nThinly sliced chives, for serving\nSpecial equipment:\n12-inch cast iron skillet, or other oven-safe skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xcb\x9aF.\n2 Cook the sausage: Warm a 12-inch oven-safe skillet over medium heat, and add the sausage. Cook, breaking it apart with a wooden spoon, until browned and cooked through, 5 to 7 minutes. Remove the pan from heat.\n3 Assemble the casserole: Whisk together the eggs, milk, salt and pepper in a medium bowl.\nSpread the sausage into an even layer over the bottom of the skillet. Sprinkle with the shredded cheese, and pour the egg mixture over the top.\nArrange the frozen tater tots over the egg mixture in concentric circles, starting with a row around the rim of the pan and working your way in, or vice versa. (You won't use the entire bag; reserve remaining tater tots for another use.)\n4 Bake the casserole. Bake until the eggs have fully set and the cheese has melted, 35 to 40 minutes. If desired, sprinkle some additional cheese over top and bake an extra minute or two, until the cheese has melted.\n5 Serve: Let the casserole cool slightly before cutting into wedges. Sprinkle with some sliced chives and serve. Leftovers will keep for about 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBagel Breakfast Casserole with Sausage, Egg, and Cheese Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n6 (20-ounce package) everything bagels\n7 large eggs\n2 1/2 cups half-and-half\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 tablespoon vegetable oil\n1 pound breakfast sausage (I used sage-flavored)\n1 red bell pepper, diced (about 1 cup)\n1 small yellow onion, peeled and diced (about 1 cup)\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley, divided\n3 cups (8 ounces) sharp cheddar cheese, shredded and divided\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the oven: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F, then lightly grease or butter a 13\xe2\x80\x9dx 9\xe2\x80\x9d casserole dish.\n2 Prep the bagels: Using a serrated bread knife, cut each bagel into bite-size pieces. I like to cut the bagel in half (from top to bottom) and then cut each half into fourths. Try to cut the bagel into pieces that are no larger than an inch.\n3 Make the egg mix and combine with the bagels: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the eggs, half-and-half, salt, and pepper until no yolk is visible and the mixture is smooth.\nAdd the cut bagels to the egg mixture and, using a large spoon or spatula, toss to coat the bread in the liquid. Set this to the side to allow the bread to soak while you brown the sausage.\n3 Cook the sausage, onion, and pepper: Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until it begins to shimmer (this should take about a minute).\nAdd the breakfast sausage to the pan and begin to brown it. Break up the sausage into small chunks with a wooden spoon until the sausage is about the size of pistachios. It should not look minced.\nOnce the sausage has cooked through and browned (about 5 minutes), create a well in the center of the pan using your spoon. Add the diced peppers and the onions. Stir them with the sausage and cook the mixture for an additional 3 to 4 minutes, or until the veggies are glossy and soft.\nDrain any excess fat by straining the mixture in a colander, then allow the mixture to cool for 5 minutes. This is a great time to shred your cheese if you haven\xe2\x80\x99t already.\n4 Combine the sausage, bagel and egg mixture. Once your sausage mix has cooled slightly, add it to the bagel and egg mixture. Add 1 tablespoon of the parsley and 2 cups of the cheddar cheese. Toss the ingredients together to combine evenly.\n5 Assemble the casserole: Pour the mixture into the prepared casserole dish and cover with aluminum foil.\nMake-ahead step: At this point, you can place the dish into the refrigerator overnight and bake in the morning. Once you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to bake, remove the casserole dish twenty minutes prior to baking, then proceed as follows.\n6 Bake the casserole: Bake, covered with foil, in the preheated oven for 20 minutes and then carefully remove the pan from the oven and remove the foil.\nReturn the pan to the oven and bake for an additional 25 minutes or until the middle is no longer jiggling, and the surface has browned.\n7 Cool and serve: Remove the pan from the oven and immediately top with the remaining cheese and parsley. Allow the casserole to cool for 10 minutes prior to serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nZucchini Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes 6-8 portions\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 eggs\n1 cup ricotta cheese (about 245 g)\n1 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese (130 g)\n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce or other hot chili sauce\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n3 cups grated zucchini (from 2-3 fresh zucchinis, about 390 g)\n1 1/2 cups chopped plum tomatoes (from 4-5 fresh tomatoes, about 370 g),\n1/2 cup sliced fresh basil (from about 20 leaves)*\n4 cups cubed day-old bread (from about 4 slices, rustic French or Italian bread works best)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n*Chiffonade basil by stacking a few leaves on top of each other, roll them up like a cigar, slice thin, starting at one end of the cigar and working your way down.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the egg cheese base: In a large bowl beat the eggs. Add the ricotta and beat until smooth. Mix in the grated Parmesan cheese, Tabasco, salt and pepper.\n2 Prep the vegetables and bread, add to egg mixture: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Prepare the vegetables and bread. Once you chop the tomatoes, squeeze excess moisture out of them by pressing them in a sieve, or wrapping in paper towels and squeezing. Add the tomatoes, basil, and zucchini to the egg mixture.\nMoisten the bread cubes with a little water then squeeze out any excess moisture using paper towels. Mix the bread cubes into the egg mixture.\n3 Bake: Coat the bottom and sides of a 9x13 baking dish generously with olive oil. Pour the egg vegetable mixture into the baking pan and even it out in the pan. Place in the middle rack of the oven.\nBake for 30 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). The casserole should puff up and brown lightly. If it hasn't browned enough after 30 minutes at that temp, increase the heat to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C) and cook for 5-10 minutes further.\nRemove from oven and let cool on a rack for 10 minutes before cutting into squares to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBaked Blueberry French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesChilling time: 30 minutes up to overnight time: Yield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound loaf rustic bread, cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups of cubes)\n1 1/2 (or 2) cups blueberries, frozen or fresh\n5 large eggs\n2 cups milk (whole or 2%)\n1 cup heavy cream\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n8 tablespoons sugar, divided\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, diced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Assemble the dry ingredients: Butter a 9x13 (or other 3-quart) baking dish. Spread half of the bread cubes in an even layer in the prepared pan. Top with 2/3 of the blueberries, followed by the remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\nIf using frozen blueberries, add them to the casserole while still frozen (do not thaw). This helps prevent the berries from coloring the casserole too much.\n  2 Whisk the liquids: Beat the eggs, milk, cream, vanilla, 6 tablespoons of the sugar, lemon zest, and the salt together. Pour the mixture over the bread cubes, pressing down gently (so you don\xe2\x80\x99t burst the berries) to make sure the egg mixture is absorbed.\n3 Soak at least 30 minutes, or overnight: If soaking overnight, cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F about 15 minutes before you plan to bake the casserole.\n5 Bake the casserole: Just before baking, sprinkle the top of the casserole with the remaining sugar and dot with the diced butter. Bake for 45 minutes, until slightly puffed and golden brown. (Casserole that chilled overnight might take a few minutes longer.)\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before cutting. Serve with a dusting of powdered sugar over top or a drizzle of maple syrup.\nLeftovers will keep, refrigerated, for about a week and can be reheated in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHam and Cheese Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourChilling time: 12 to 48 hoursYield: 10 servings\nLook for loaves of bread at the store marked "toasting." These are generally firmer than other loaves of white sandwich bread. (And if you can\'t find toasting bread, just buy sandwich bread that seems fairly firm and substantial.)\nIf the tomatoes at the store don\'t look ripe, it\'s fine to skip them for this recipe.\nYou can substitute another melting cheese in place of the cheddar, if you want, like Swiss cheese or Monterey jack.\nINGREDIENTS\nButter (for the dish)\n1 loaf sliced white toasting bread\n3/4 pound mild cheddar, grated\n8 small tomatoes, or 16 cherry tomatoes, thinly sliced\n1 thick slice (3/4 pound) flavorful baked ham, cut into 1/4-inch dice (About 2 1/2 cups diced)\n10 large eggs\n3 cups whole milk\nSalt and pepper, to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the bread: Butter a deep 9-by-13-inch baking dish. Cut the bread slices on a diagonal to make large triangles. Fit as many triangles as you can in the bottom of the dish, cutting smaller pieces to wedge between the larger ones, if necessary, to completely cover the bottom.\n2 Begin layering the casserole: Sprinkle the bottom layer of bread with half the cheese. Lay half the tomato slices here and there over top, and sprinkle with half the ham. Add another layer of bread, again cutting smaller pieces, if necessary, to make a solid layer. Sprinkle with all but 2 tablespoons of the remaining cheese, and the remaining tomatoes and ham. Cover with a third layer of bread. (You may have a few slices of bread leftover.)\n3 Whisk together the eggs and milk: In a bowl, beat the eggs, milk, and a generous pinch of salt and pepper. Pour the mixture carefully over the bread. With your hands, press the bread into the egg mixture. Sprinkle the remaining 2 tablespoons cheese over top.\n4 Cover and refrigerate. Refrigerate for at least 12 hours, or for up to 48 hours.\n5 When ready to bake, let the dish sit at room temperature for 30 minutes. Heat the oven to 375F. Remove the plastic wrap from the dish and set it on a large rimmed baking sheet to catch any drips.\n6 Bake the casserole for 55 to 60 minutes, or until it is puffed and golden brown and cooked through in the middle. A thermometer inserted into the center of the dish should register 160F. If the casserole needs to cook longer, cover it loosely with foil and continue cooking for 5 to 10 minutes.\n7 Let the casserole sit for 5 minutes before cutting into squares.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nAsparagus Artichoke Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n6 cups of 1 to 1 1/2-inch cubed rustic bread (about half a loaf), or 6 slices of bread\n2 ounces bacon (2 to 3 thick-cut slices), roughly chopped\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1 pound of asparagus, trimmed of tough bottoms, spears sliced on the diagonal, in 1-inch long pieces\n1 15-ounce can of artichoke hearts (packed in water), drained, chopped\n2 Tbsp minced chives or green onion greens\n6 eggs\n2 cups milk\n8 ounces cheddar cheese, grated\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Dry cubed bread in oven: Place cubed bread on a baking sheet, put in a 200\xc2\xb0F for 10 to 15 minutes, until somewhat dry. OR you can use stale bread that is no longer soft. Drying the bread in the oven will help keep it from falling apart when you add the egg mixture later.\n2 Cook the chopped bacon: Place bacon in medium skillet on medium high heat. Cook until bacon is lightly browned and much of the fat rendered. Remove bacon from pan with a slotted spoon, place on a paper towel lined plate to drain. Pour off all but enough bacon fat to coat the bottom of the pan (do not put down the drain, it will clog your pipes).\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions: Add chopped onions to the pan with bacon fat. Cook on medium high heat until lightly browned, about 5 to 6 minutes. Add the bacon back to the pan with the onions, stir, remove from heat.\n4 Blanch the asparagus: While the onions are cooking, bring a small pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add the asparagus and blanch for 2 minutes. Drain and shock the asparagus in ice water to stop the cooking.\n5 Mix eggs, milk, cheese: In a large bowl, beat the eggs with a fork or whisk. Whisk in the milk. Stir in the 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Stir in the grated cheddar cheese.\n6 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n7 Place bread in egg milk mixture, fold in bacon and vegetables: Place the cubed bread in the egg milk mixture and press down with your hands so that the bread cubes absorb most of the egg milk mixture. Gently fold in the onions, bacon, asparagus, chopped artichoke hearts, and chives. (Be gentle as to not break up the bread.)\n8 Assemble the casserole: Generously butter the inside of a 2 1/2 to 3 quart (8 x 13 inch) casserole dish. Gently pour the bread egg milk vegetable mixture into the casserole dish and spread out in an even layer.\nAt this point you can make up to a day ahead. Cover and refrigerate until ready to cook.\n9 Bake: Bake uncovered at 350\xc2\xb0F for 4o minutes. If the casserole starts to get too browned while cooking, cover with foil. Remove from oven and let rest for 5 minutes before serving.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBreakfast Casserole with Leeks and Asparagus Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nPro tip: raw bacon is much easier to slice if it is frozen. So keep your bacon chilled until you are ready to cut it, or put it in the freezer for several minutes before slicing.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 slices thick-sliced bacon (about 3 ounces), cut into 1/2-inch pieces\n1 pound of asparagus, trimmed of woody ends, cut into 1/2-inch diagonal pieces\n6 slices of bread, cut into 1 1/2 inch wide square pieces, including crusts\n2 leeks, cleaned, cut in half lengthwise, sliced crosswise into 1/2-inch pieces, white and light green parts only, about 2 cups total\n2 Tbsp butter, divided 1 Tbsp and 1 Tbsp\n1/2 cup of crumbled feta cheese\n8 eggs\n2 cups milk\n1/2 teaspoon of dried herbes de provence (can sub dried tarragon or thyme)\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup of freshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Place bacon in a medium skillet on medium heat. Gently cook, turning occasionally, until the bacon pieces are lightly browned and much of the bacon fat has been rendered, about 10-12 minutes. Remove cooked bacon from the pan with a slotted spoon, leaving the rendered bacon fat in the pan.\n2 While the bacon is cooking, cut up the bread. If the bread is a little stale, great. If it is fresh, then spread it out on a baking sheet and heat it in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for about 10-15 minutes to help it dry out a bit. This will help the keep the bread from disintegrating when mixed with the eggs later.\n3 Bring a small pot of water to a boil. Add the cut asparagus and blanch for 1 minute. Remove the asparagus from the pot to a bowl of ice water. Let cool in the ice water and then drain.\n4 Once the bacon is done and removed from the pan add a tablespoon of butter to the pan with the remaining bacon fat. Add the leeks and gently cook on medium to medium low heat for 10-12 minutes until the leeks are softened, but not browned. Do not let brown.\n5 In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, crumbled feta cheese, herbes de provence, salt, and pepper.\n6 Place the bread pieces into the egg milk mixture and press down so that the bread becomes completely saturated with the mixture. Add the asparagus and leeks and gently mix to combine, taking care to not break up the bread.\n7 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. With the remaining tablespoon of butter, butter the insides of a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Sprinkle the bacon over the bottom of the dish. Gently pour the filling mixture into the casserole. Top with Parmesan cheese. Push the grated Parmesan down a bit into to the top of the casserole so that it gets moistened. (At this point you can make the night before, refrigerate and bake the next morning.)\n8 Bake, uncovered, for 45 minutes or until the top is lightly browned and the custard is cooked through. If the top is getting too brown before the custard is done, you can tent it with foil. Remove from oven and let cool for 5 minutes before cutting to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBaked Cherry French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesResting time: 20 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings\nAdapted from Northwest Cherry Growers\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the casserole:\nButter (for the baking dish)\n6 large eggs\n1 3/4 cups whole milk\n1/4 cup honey\nGrated zest of 1 lemon (about 1 tablespoon)\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon pure almond extract, or 1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1 1-pound loaf good quality, sturdy bread (such as French Pullman, sourdough, or ciabatta), cut into 3/4-inch cubes\n2 cups (8 ounces) frozen pitted dark cherries, cut in half\nTopping:\n4 tablespoons (1/2 stick) unsalted butter, melted\n3 tablespoons sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons cinnamon\n1/3 cup sliced almonds\nFor the cherry sauce:\n2 cups (8 ounces) frozen pitted dark cherries (left whole)\n1/4 cup sugar\n2/3 cup orange juice\n1 tablespoon cornstarch\n2 tablespoons water\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare the pan: Set an oven rack in the middle position. (If making this casserole ahead, wait to heat the oven until you're ready to bake; see Step 3.)\nPreheat the oven to 350\xc2\xbaF. Butter a shallow 3-quart baking dish.\n2 Assemble the casserole: In a large bowl, whisk the eggs, milk, honey, lemon zest, cinnamon, almond extract or vanilla, and salt until well combined. Add the bread cubes and toss to coat them.\nTransfer half of the cubes to the baking dish. Distribute the halved cherries over the bread. Top with the remaining bread cubes. Pour excess egg mixture over the top if there is any. Gently press the bread down into the egg mixture with the flat of one hand.\n3 Let the casserole rest: Set the casserole aside for about 20 minutes to allow the bread to absorb the egg mixture. Before baking, gently press the bread into the custard one more time.\nAlternatively, the casserole can be covered with plastic wrap and refrigerated overnight. Preheat the oven as directed in step 1 before baking.\n4 Make the topping: In a small bowl, stir together the melted butter, sugar, cinnamon and almonds for the topping. Spoon the mixture evenly over the casserole just before baking.\n5 Bake the casserole: Set the casserole on a rimmed baking sheet and bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the eggs are set and the top is golden and crunchy. (Add a few extra minutes if the casserole was refrigerated before baking.)\n6 While the casserole bakes, make the cherry sauce: In a medium saucepan, stir together the cherries, sugar, and orange juice. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring often.\nIn a small bowl, stir the cornstarch with the water until smooth. Add to the cherries and cook, stirring, for 1 minute, or until the sauce thickens. Serve warm or cold.\n7 To serve: With a large spoon, scoop a serving of the French toast into a shallow bowl. Surround with the sauce and enjoy.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nSlow Cooker Chocolate Milk French Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 50 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 45 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: 8 servings\nThe way you slice the bread is important here: cutting it into one-inch cubes is ideal to allow the chocolate milk custard to soak into it fully. \nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound challah, brioche, or sweet Hawaiian bread, cut into 1 to 1 1/2 inch cubes\n2 tablespoons light brown sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1 1/2 teaspoons orange zest (from one small naval orange)\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n5 large eggs\n2 cups whole chocolate milk\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter, softened\n4 ounces (110 grams) semi-sweet chocolate, chopped (or chocolate chips), divided\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast the challah: Preheat your oven to 300\xc2\xb0F. Arrange the cubes of challah in a single layer on a half sheet pan.\nToast the bread for 15 minutes, tossing once half-way through the toasting time. Remove the pan from the oven and let the bread cool while you prepare the chocolate milk custard.\n2 Mix the custard: In a large mixing bowl, combine the brown sugar, cinnamon, orange zest, salt, and eggs. Whisk the ingredients together until smooth. \nCombine the chocolate milk and heavy cream and add them to the egg mixture. Whisk until the custard is no longer clumpy. \n3 Assemble the casserole: Grease the ceramic insert of your slow cooker with the butter.\nAdd half of the bread cubes to the insert and top with a quarter of the chocolate pieces.\nAdd the remaining bread cubes and sprinkle on another quarter of the chocolate chunks. Reserve the rest of the chocolate for sprinkling on the finished casserole. \n4 Soak the casserole: Pour all of the chocolate milk custard over the bread. Use a large spoon to toss the bread in the custard before covering with the lid and refrigerating for at least 2 or up to 24 hours. \n5 Warm the ceramic insert: Before cooking the casserole, set the ceramic insert on the countertop for 30 minutes to take some of the chill off of it. This will keep it from shattering when it\xe2\x80\x99s heated. \n6 Cook the casserole: Place the insert into the slow cooker and cook the casserole on high for 2 1/2 hours. The internal temperature of the fully-cooked casserole should be 160-165\xc2\xb0F\n7 Cool and serve: Once the casserole is cooked, sprinkle the remaining chocolate chunks over the casserole. Cool briefly, then spoon the casserole into individual plates and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nCheesy Grits Souffl\xc3\xa9 Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nUse regular grocery store grits, like Arrowhead Mills brand. Do not use quick grits or artisan grits. Quick grits don\xe2\x80\x99t have a good texture, and artisan or heirloom grits can take hours to cook.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups water\n2 cups whole or 2% milk\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup grits (I prefer yellow, but white grits are fine)\n2 to 4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n2 cups grated cheddar cheese\n1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 cup thinly sliced scallions or chives, optional\n3 large eggs\n1/2 cup sour cream\nSpecial equipment:\n2-quart casserole or 9 x 13-inch baking dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven: Adjust the oven rack to the middle position. Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook the grits: In a medium saucepan, bring the water and milk to a boil. Add the salt, then gradually whisk in the grits (this keeps them from clumping). Cook over medium heat, whisking frequently, until creamy and thickened, about 20 minutes.\nRemove from heat. Add the butter, cheese, cayenne, black pepper, and scallions or chives, if using. Switch to a spatula and stir until the butter and cheese are melted. Cover to keep warm and set aside.\n3 Separate the eggs: Separate the egg yolks from the egg whites. Put the whites in a large, grease-free bowl.\nIn a separate, medium bowl, stir the egg yolks and sour cream until combined.\n4 Beat the egg whites: With electric beaters or the largest whisk you have, beat the egg whites until they are fluffy and pillowy-soft, like clouds. They should mostly hold their shape but not be completely stiff.\n5 Stir the yolks into the grits: Working quickly, stir the sour cream and yolk mixture into the grits with a large spatula.\n6 Fold the egg whites into the grits: Push the egg whites to the side of the bowl, and dump the hot grits mixture on the emptier side. Still using the spatula, fold the egg whites into the grits until you see no (or very few) streaks of egg white.\n7 Bake the casserole: Scrape the mixture into the baking dish. Bake until the top is puffy and golden-brown, 35 to 45 minutes. Let sit 5 minutes before serving. Leftovers will keep, covered and refrigerated, for up to 4 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Baked Brie in Puff Pastry Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large sheet of puff pastry dough or 1 tube of refrigerated crescent dinner rolls\n1 round or wedge of Brie cheese (do not remove rind)\n2 tablespoons raspberry jam, or other sweet jam\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n1/4 cup of maple syrup\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). \n2 Slice the top off the brie: If you want, start with chilled brie and use a sharp knife to carefully cut off the thin top rind of the cheese. This may help the crust stay with the cheese when served. The rind is edible so you don't have to do this step if you don't want to.\n3 Place brie on puff pastry: On a lined baking sheet, lay out the puff pastry or the crescent rolls flat. Place the brie round or wedge on top of the puff pastry.\n4 Spread jam on top, fold dough over brie: Spread jam on brie, fold dough over top, cutting off excess dough. Drizzle maple syrup and sprinkle brown sugar on top.\n5 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xbaF (175\xc2\xb0C) for 30 minutes, pastry should be golden brown. Let cool for 10 minutes before serving.\nServe with crackers or apple slices.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCaramelized Onion Tart with Gorgonzola and Brie Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Makes 9 to 12 appetizer sized pieces.\nTarragon is a summer herb, if you can't find any, you may crush a few fennel seeds (maybe half a teaspoon) and sprinkle over the tart. Or top with fresh chopped fennel fronds, after the tart has been taken out of the oven.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n4 cups of sliced onions, sliced root-to-top into 1/4-inch thick slices (about 2-3 med onions)\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon pepper\n8 oz frozen puff pastry (defrosted a couple hours in the fridge)\n2 oz chilled Brie cheese, rind removed and diced\n2 oz Gorgonzola or other blue cheese, diced\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh tarragon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Caramelize the onions: Heat oil in a large deep pan on medium-high heat. Add onions and cook for about 10 minutes or until wilted and starting to brown. Add sugar, vinegar, salt and pepper.\nReduce heat and cook gently, uncovered for 20-25 minutes or until richly caramelized. Add a little water if the onions look like they are starting to dry out. Cool.\n2 Roll pastry into a 10-to-14-inch rectangle (or whatever shape you want). Place pastry on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Prick with a fork at a couple inch increments to prevent the pastry from forming big bubbles while baking.\n3 Spread onions over pastry, all the way to the edges of the pastry. Dot with cheese. Sprinkle with tarragon. Refrigerate if not baking immediately.\n4 Bake in a preheated oven at 400\xc2\xb0F for 18-20 minutes or until cheese has melted and pastry is crispy. Cool for 5 minutes. Cut into wedges or squares and enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHoney Hazelnut Baked Brie Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf starting with raw hazelnuts, toast them by spreading them out on a sheet pan and roasting them in a 350\xc2\xb0F for 15 minutes, or until the skins start to split. Remove from oven and place in a clean dish towel, rub to remove the outer skins.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (8-ounce, 225 g) round of brie (we recommend President brand, it melts well)\n1/4 cup toasted hazelnuts (skins removed), lightly chopped\n1/2 cup (120 ml) sherry vinegar or apple cider vinegar\n5 Tbsp honey\nPinch of salt\n1 small sprig rosemary\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the sauce: Place the vinegar, honey, salt, and 5 or 6 needles from the rosemary sprig into a small saucepan. Stir to combine. Heat on medium high heat until simmering. Then lower the heat to low and simmer until the mixture starts to darken in color and the consistency thickens to a thin syrup, about 5 to 10 minutes. (Note if you find that you have over-reduced the sauce, resulting in hard candy not syrup, you can add water to it and heat it again.)\nRemove from heat and stir in the hazelnuts.\n2 Bake the brie: While the sauce is simmering, start on the brie. Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Use a serrated knife to slice off the very top of the brie round, exposing the cheese on one side. Place on a parchment paper or Silpat lined baking sheet (cut side up). Bake until just soft and bubbly, about 15 minutes. (Jiggle the pan to see if the cheese has melted all the way through.)\n3 Drizzle the brie with sauce: Remove the brie from the oven and let it cool for a minute or two. Use a metal spatula (or two) to carefully transfer it to a serving dish. Drizzle the honey vinegar hazelnut sauce over the brie. Garnish with the sprig of rosemary.\nServe with sliced tart apples.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nPasta with Tomato, Spinach, Basil, and Brie Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 as a side\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 pound chopped fresh, ripe tomatoes (about 2 medium tomatoes)\n6 ounces brie cheese, rind removed, cheese cut into small chunks\nZest and juice of one lemon (about 1 teaspoon zest and 3 Tbsp juice)\nA handful of basil leaves, chiffonade or sliced thin\n5 ounces baby spinach, rinsed, patted dry\n1/2 to 3/4 pound of linguine or fettuccine pasta\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan\nSalt and pepper taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the pasta: Heat a large pot of salted water for making the pasta (1 tablespoon of salt for every 2 quarts of water). While the water is heating, prep the ingredients.  Once water is boiling, add the pasta and cook until al dente (cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite).\n2 Heat brie with tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, lemon, in microwave: While the pasta is cooking, place the garlic, olive oil, chopped tomatoes, chunks of brie (make sure to cut away the white rind!), lemon zest, and lemon juice into a large, microwave safe bowl.\nMicrowave for 2-3 minutes, or until the brie is melty and soft. (If you don't have a microwave, place the ingredients in a bowl and let sit for an hour or two, so the brie softens.)\n3 Toss cooked pasta with tomatoes and brie, add spinach and basil: Once the pasta is done, drain it and place it in the bowl with the cheese and tomatoes. Add the basil and baby spinach.\nToss together so that the spinach, basil, cheese, and tomatoes are well dispersed through the pasta. Break up or smash any large pieces of cheese.\n4 Sprinkle with grated Parmesan cheese and freshly ground black pepper, and toss more to incorporate. Add more salt to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHome Cured Corned Beef\nPrep time: 5 daysCook time: 3 hours\nThe spice mix with the gallon of brine makes easily enough curing brine for a 5 pound brisket, cured in a somewhat large-ish container. If you were to use a 2-gallon freezer bag or marinating bag, you would likely need just half (or less) of the amount of brine and brine spices.\nPink curing salt, or sodium nitrite, goes by many names, such as Prague Powder #1 or DQ Curing Salt #1, and is available online and may be available at your local specialty market or butcher shop. If you don\'t have it, you can still make corned beef, but it is necessary for that vibrant pink color we associate with corned beef. And it adds flavor too. Without it the corned beef will be a dull grey color.\nNote that pink curing salt is NOT Himalayan pink salt. Pink curing salt is toxic and can be deadly if ingested directly, which is why it is colored pink, so consumers do not mistake it for table salt.\nINGREDIENTS\nPickling spices:\n1 tablespoon whole allspice berries\n1 tablespoon whole mustard seeds (brown or yellow)\n1 tablespoon coriander seeds\n1 tablespoon red pepper flakes\n1 tablespoon whole black peppercorns\n2 teaspoons whole cloves\n9 whole cardamom pods\n6 large bay leaves, crumbled\n2 teaspoons ground ginger\n1/2 stick cinnamon\nBrine:\n1 gallon (3.8 liters) water\n300 g Kosher salt (2 cups of Diamond Crystal brand Kosher Salt OR 1 cup 3 1/2 tablespoons of Morton\'s Kosher Salt)\n5 teaspoons pink curing salt (optional, see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons pickling spices\n1/2 cup (90 g) brown sugar\nBrisket:\n1 5-pound beef brisket\n1 tablespoon pickling spices\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast and crush spices: You can either used store-bought pickling spices or you can make your own. To make your own, toast the allspice berries, mustard seeds, coriander seeds, red pepper flakes, peppercorns, cloves, and cardamom pods in a small frying pan on medium heat until fragrant. Note that it is pretty easy to burn spices; you want enough heat to release their flavors, not so much that they get burned.\nRemove from heat and place in a small bowl. Use a mortar and pestle to crush the spices a little (or the back of a spoon or the side of a knife on a flat surface). Add to a small bowl and stir in the crumbled bay leaves and ground ginger.\n2 Make curing brine: Add about 3 Tbsp of the spice mix (reserve the rest for cooking the corned beef after it has cured), plus the half stick of cinnamon, to a gallon of water in a large pot, along with the Kosher salt, pink salt (if using), and brown sugar. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. Then refrigerate until well chilled.\n3 Brine the brisket for 5-7 days: Place the brisket in a large, flat container or pan, and cover with the brine. The brine should cover the meat. The meat may float in which case you may want to weigh it down with a plate.\nAlternatively you can use a 2-gallon freezer bag (placed in a container so if it leaks it doesn\'t leak all over your refrigerator), place the brisket in the freezer bag and about 2 quarts of brine, squeezing out the air from the bag before sealing.\nPlace in the refrigerator and chill from 5-7 days. Every day flip the brisket over, so that all sides get brined equally.\n4 Cook the corned beef: At the end of the cure, remove the brisket from the brine and rinse off the brine with cold water. Place the brisket in a large pot that just fits around the brisket and cover with at least one inch of water. If you want your brisket less salty, add another inch of water to the pot.\nAdd a tablespoon of the pickling spices to the pot. Bring to a boil, reduce to a very low simmer (barely bubbling), and cook 3-4 hours, until the corned beef is fork tender. (At this point you can store in the fridge for up to a week.)\n5 Cut across the grain: Remove the meat to a cutting board. (You can use the spiced cooking liquid to cook vegetables for boiled dinner or corned beef and cabbage.) Notice the visible lines on the meat; this is the "grain" of the meat, or the direction of the muscle fibers.\nTo make the meat easier to cut, cut it first in half, along the grain of the meat. Then make thin crosswise cuts, across the grain to cut the meat to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nNew England Boiled Dinner Recipe\nCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nCorned beef can be pretty salty, so if you are making boiled dinner with corned beef you may want to put it in a pot, cover with cold water, bring to a boil, and then discard the water before starting the recipe. If the broth ends up being too salty, you can serve just the meat and vegetables, without the broth, or add water to the broth to dilute it.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds corned beef brisket or plain beef brisket\n15 peppercorns\n8 whole cloves\n1 bay leaf\nSalt, if using plain brisket\n2 medium sized turnips, peeled and quartered\n4 red new potatoes, peeled and quartered\n3 large carrots, cut into thirds and the thickest pieces quartered lengthwise\n1 small head cabbage, cut into fourths\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put corned beef in a pot, cover with water, add seasonings, simmer: Put the brisket in a 5 or 6 quart Dutch oven and cover with an inch of water.\nIf you are using corned beef brisket and it does not come already packed in seasoning, add peppercorns, cloves, and a bay leaf to the pot.\nIf using plain brisket, add a teaspoon of salt for every quart of water.\nBring to a simmer and then cover, lower the heat until it is barely simmering. Keep at a low simmer for four hours or until the meat is tender (a fork goes through easily).\n2 Remove meat, add vegetables, simmer: Remove the meat and set aside, keeping the meat warm. Add the vegetables to the pot. Check the broth for taste. If it is too salty, add a little more water to taste.\nRaise the temperature and bring the soup to a high simmer. Cook at a high simmer until done, about 15-30 minutes longer, depending on the size of the cut of your vegetables.\n\n3 Slice meat across the grain: Slice the meat in thin slices across the grain. You may find it easier to slice if you first cut the roast in half along the same direction as the grain of the meat. Then slice smaller lengths across the grain.\n\nServe in bowls, a few pieces of meat in each, add some of the vegetables and some broth. Serve with horseradish or mustard or both.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Beef Brisket Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 pounds of a brisket cut of beef\n3/4 cup barbecue sauce\n1/4 cup soy sauce\n1 cup of water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 300\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Make the sauce: In a bowl, mix together the barbecue sauce, soy sauce, and water.\n3 Roast the brisket in the oven (2 methods):\nFoil method: Place a large piece of aluminum foil in a roasting pan. Add the brisket and spread the BBQ sauce mixture generously over meat. Wrap the brisket in the aluminum foil so it's well sealed, like a package.\nBake for 3 hours for a 3 pound roast and 1 more hour for every additional pound of meat.\nOR, instead of foil, you can use an oven roasting bag:\nOven roasting bag method: Place the barbecue sauce and the brisket in an oven roasting bag. Sprinkle a teaspoon of flour into the bag. Poke a couple small holes in the bag. Place the bag in a roasting pan. You may find that the cooking time is faster with this method, or you can reduce the oven temperature to 275\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Let the brisket rest: Remove from oven and let rest in the foil for 30 minutes before serving.\n5 Slice across the grain of the meat: The easiest way to serve the roast is to first cut it in half along the grain of the meat (poke the meat with the tip of a knife or tines of a fork to see which way the grain or lines of the muscles are going if you can't see it from the surface).\nThen make 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch thick cuts across the grain to serve. (Cutting the meat across the grain will make it much easier to eat, as the cuts break up the muscle tissue.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBeef Brisket Pot Roast Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 4 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 8-12\nINGREDIENTS\n4 to 5 pound (about 2 kg) beef brisket, flat cut or point cut\nSalt\n1 to 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 large onions, sliced\n5 to 6 garlic cloves, minced\n1 sprig thyme\n1 sprig rosemary\n3 to 4 bay leaves\n2 cups beef stock\n2 to 3 large carrots, peeled and cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces\n1 tablespoon mustard (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the brisket: On one side of the brisket there should be a layer of fat, which you want. If there are any large chunks of fat, cut them off and discard them. Large pieces of fat will not be able to render out completely.\nUsing a sharp knife, score the fat in parallel lines, about 3/4-inch apart. Slice through the fat, not the beef. Repeat in the opposite direction to make a cross-hatch pattern.\nSalt the brisket well and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n2 Sear the brisket: You\'ll need an ovenproof, thick-bottomed pot with a cover, or Dutch oven, that is just wide enough to hold the brisket roast with a little room for the onions.\nPat the brisket dry and place it, fatty side down, into the pot and place it on medium high heat. Cook for 5 to 8 minutes, lightly sizzling, until the fat side is nicely browned. (If the roast seems to be cooking too fast, turn the heat down to medium. You want a steady sizzle, not a raging sear.)\nTurn the brisket over and cook for a few minutes more to brown the other side.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and garlic: When the brisket has browned, remove it from the pot and set aside. There should be a couple tablespoons of fat rendered in the pot. If not, add some olive oil.\nAdd the chopped onions and increase the heat to high. Sprinkle a little salt on the onions. Saut\xc3\xa9, stirring often, until the onions are lightly browned, 5 to 8 minutes. Stir in the garlic and cook 1 to 2 more minutes.\n4 Simmer the brisket and roast it: Preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C). Use kitchen twine to tie together the bay leaves, rosemary and thyme.\nMove the onions and garlic to the sides of the pot and nestle the brisket inside. Add the beef stock and the tied-up herbs. Bring the stock to a boil on the stovetop. Cover the pot, then place in the 300\xc2\xb0F (150\xc2\xb0C) oven. Cook for 3 hours. Carefully flip the brisket every hour so it cooks evenly.\n5 Add carrots, continue to cook: After 3 hours, add the carrots. Cover the pot and cook for 1 hour more, or until the carrots are cooked through and the brisket is falling-apart tender.\n6 Remove brisket: When the brisket is falling-apart tender, take the pot out of the oven and remove the brisket to a cutting board. Cover it with foil. Pull out and discard the herbs.\n7 Make sauce (optional): At this point you have two options. You can serve as is, or you can make a sauce with the drippings and some of the onions. If you serve as is, skip this step.\nTo make a sauce, remove the carrots and half of the onions, set aside and cover them with foil. Pour the ingredients that are remaining into a blender, and pur\xc3\xa9e until smooth. If you want, add 1 tablespoon of mustard to the mix. Put into a small pot and keep warm.\n8 Slice and serve: Notice the lines of the muscle fibers of the roast. This is the "grain" of the meat. Slice the meat perpendicular to these lines, or across the grain (cutting this way further tenderizes the meat), in 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch slices. (A sturdy bread knife works great for slicing roasts.)\nServe with the onions, carrots and gravy. Serve with mashed, roasted or boiled potatoes, egg noodles, or polenta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nInstant Pot Beef Brisket Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings\nOven-cooking Instructions: Using a Dutch oven or other heavy pot with a lid placed over medium-high heat, follow the instructions for searing the brisket, cooking the onions, and mixing in the other ingredients as described in the pressure cooker recipe. Make sure the fat cap is facing up when you add the brisket back to the pan. Cover the pot and transfer to a 325F oven to cook for 3 hours, until the brisket is tender.\nMake-ahead Instructions: Cook the brisket as indicated, allow it to cool, and refrigerate on its own. Refrigerate the strained onions and garlic separately. Transfer the cooking liquid to a storage container and refrigerate separately. The next day, scrape the solidified fat from the top of the liquid and discard. Warm the cooking liquid, onions, and garlic in the pressure cooker or in a medium saucepan. With an immersion blender or in a blender, blend the cooking liquid, onions and garlic into a thick gravy. Warm the brisket in the gravy before serving.\n  INGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 to 3 1/2 pounds beef brisket (certified kosher, if needed)\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt, divided\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n3 medium yellow onions, sliced\n3 large garlic cloves, peeled\n1/2 cup water\n1/2 cup dry red wine\n1/4 cup ketchup\n1 teaspoon dried rosemary\n1 teaspoon dried thyme leaves\n1 teaspoon paprika\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric or stovetop pressure cooker, or larger (like an Instant Pot)\nImmersion blender, or regular blender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the brisket: Rinse the brisket and pat it dry with paper towels. If your brisket has more than 1/4-inch layer of fat, trim off the excess. Season it on both sides with 1 teaspoon of the salt and the ground pepper.\n2 Sear the brisket: Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d program on your pressure cooker, adjust it to its highest heat setting, and add the oil to the pot. (If you are using a stovetop pressure cooker, heat the oil over medium high heat.)\nUse a pair of tongs to lower the brisket into the pot with the side with the most fat facing down, and let it sear for 6 minutes. Turn it over and sear it for 6 more minutes. Both sides should be a rich, dark brown color.\nTransfer the seared brisket to a plate.\n3 Cook the onions and garlic: Adjust your pressure cooker to its medium "Saut\xc3\xa9" setting. (If you are using a stovetop pressure cooker, lower the heat to medium.) There should be plenty of fat left in the pan after searing the brisket; if not, add another teaspoon or two of olive oil to cook the onions.\nAdd the onions, garlic, and the remaining 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Cook, stirring frequently, until the onions are soft and beginning to brown, about 10 minutes. Scrape the bottom of the pot as you stir the onions to help release all of the browned bits from the bottom of the pot.\n4 Stir the water, wine, ketchup, and spices into the onions and garlic.\n5 Cook the brisket: Use a pair of tongs to lower the seared brisket back into the pressure cooker, with the side with the most fat facing up. Place the lid on your pressure cooker. Make sure that the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nSelect the \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d program, then set the time to 50 minutes at high pressure. (For stovetop pressure cookers, cook for 45 minutes at high pressure.)\nIt will take about 10 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the actual cooking will begin. Total time from the time you seal the pressure cooker to the finished dish is about 60 minutes.\n6 Release the pressure: You can either perform a quick pressure release by moving the vent from \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cVenting,\xe2\x80\x9d or you can let the pot depressurize naturally (this takes about 20 minutes). (For stovetop pressure cookers, perform a quick pressure release.)\n7 Separate the brisket, onions, and cooking liquid: Use tongs to transfer the brisket to a plate or carving board. Strain the cooking liquid into a fat separator, collecting the cooked onions and garlic in the strainer.\n8 Make the gravy: Return the drained onions and garlic to the pressure cooker pot. Pour the cooking liquid from the fat separator back into the pot, discarding the fat that is left behind. (If you don\'t have a fat separator, wait for the fat to rise to the top of the liquid, then skim off as much as you can.)\nWith an immersion blender, blend the cooking liquid, onions and garlic into a thick gravy. (Alternatively, transfer the liquid, onions, and garlic to a blender to puree. Don\'t fill the blender more than halfway, and be careful of the steam when opening the blender pitcher.\n9 To serve: Slice the brisket against the grain into thin (1/4-inch) slices. Pour the gravy over the brisket and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nChicken Tikka Masala Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nLeftover chicken tikka masala tastes phenomenal the next day because the spices develop more flavor overnight.\nAvoid using Greek yogurt if possible for this recipe. If it's all you can find, buy the Greek yogurt with the highest fat content you can find and mix it with a little whole milk to get the consistency of regular yogurt. This will give the sauce some insurance against separating.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/4 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts, thighs, or a mix\n6 tablespoons plain whole milk yogurt\n1/2 tablespoon grated ginger\n3 cloves of garlic, minced\n1 teaspoon cumin\n1 teaspoon paprika\n1 1/4 teaspoons salt\nFor the tikka masala sauce:\n2 tablespoons canola oil, divided\n1 small onion, thinly sliced (about 5 ounces, or 1 1/2 cups sliced)\n2 teaspoons grated ginger\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n1 tablespoon ground coriander\n2 teaspoons paprika\n1 teaspoon garam masala\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 (14-ounce) can crushed fire-roasted tomatoes (regular crushed tomatoes work, too)\n6 tablespoons plain whole milk yogurt\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nCooked rice, to serve\nCilantro, to garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the chicken: Trim chicken thighs of any extra fat. Chop into bite-sized pieces about 1/2 to 1-inch wide. Place the chicken thigh pieces to a medium bowl.\nAdd the yogurt, ginger, garlic, cumin, paprika and salt. Using your hands, combine the chicken with the spices until the chicken is evenly coated.\n2 Marinate the chicken: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let the chicken marinate in the fridge for at least 45 minutes or as long as overnight. (Marinating for 4 to 6 hours is perfect.)\n3 Cook the chicken: In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of canola oil over medium-high heat. Add the chicken thigh pieces and cook for about 6 to 7 minutes, until they\xe2\x80\x99re cooked through. Transfer to a plate and set aside.\n4 Toast the spices: Wipe down the pan you used to cook the chicken. Heat remaining canola oil over medium heat. Add the onions and cook for 5 minutes, until softened, stirring often.\nAdd the grated ginger, minced garlic, coriander, paprika, garam masala, turmeric, black pepper, salt, and cayenne. Let the spices cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds to a minute.\n5 Make the sauce: Add the crushed tomatoes to the pan with the spices and let everything cook for 4 minutes, stirring often. Add the yogurt and stir to combine.\n6 Simmer the sauce: Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the sauce simmer for another 4 minutes. Add the chicken pieces to the pan and coat with sauce.\n7 Serve: Serve over cooked basmati rice and garnish with cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nClassic English Toad-in-the-Hole Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cup  (180 g) of all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nPinch of freshly ground black pepper\n3 eggs, beaten\n1 1/2 cup (350 ml) milk\n2 tablespoons melted butter\n1 tablespoon vegetable oil\n1 pound (450 g) of bangers (an English sausage made with pork and breadcrumbs), or good quality pork or beef sausage links (in casings)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make batter: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour with the salt and a pinch of pepper. Make a well in the center of the flour. Pour in the eggs, milk, and melted butter into the well and whisk into the flour until smooth. Cover and let stand 30 minutes.\n2 Pre-heat baking dish: Coat the bottom and sides of an 8x12 or 9x9 ceramic or metal casserole dish with vegetable oil. Place a rack in the bottom third of the oven. Put the empty dish on the rack. Preheat the oven with the dish in it to 425\xc2\xb0F(220\xc2\xb0C).\n3 Brown the sausages: While the oven is coming to temperature, heat a tablespoon of vegetable oil in a skillet on medium high. Add the sausages and brown them on at least a couple sides.\n4 Pour batter over sausages: When the sausages have browned, and the dish in the oven hot, pull the oven rack out a bit, put the sausages in the casserole dish, and pour the batter over the sausages.\n5 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F(220\xc2\xb0C) for about 20-30 minutes or until the batter is risen and golden.\nServe at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChicken Mulligatawny Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons butter\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, chopped (about 2 cups)\n2 ribs celery, chopped (about 1 cup)\n2 carrots, chopped (about 1 cup)\n2 bay leaves\n4 teaspoon yellow curry powder\n1 1/4 pound (570 g) boneless, skinless chicken thighs, trimmed of visible fat\n2 cups (475 ml) chicken stock\n2 cups (475 ml) water\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt (or 1 teaspoon sea salt)\n1/4 cup uncooked basmati rice\n2 tart apples, cored, peeled, and chopped (about 2 cups)\n1/4  (60 ml) cup heavy whipping cream\n1/4 cup (60 ml) plain yogurt for garnish\n1 tablespoon minced chives for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, celery, carrots in olive oil and butter, add bay leaves, curry powder: Heat butter and olive oil on medium high heat in a large (4 to 5 quart), thick-bottomed pot. Add the onions, celery, and carrots. Cook for 5 minutes until just starting to soften. Add the bay leaves. Add the curry powder and mix to coat.\n2 Add chicken, stock, salt: Add the chicken thighs and stir to coat with the curry mixture. Add the stock and water to the pot. Add the salt. Bring to a simmer and reduce the heat to maintain a simmer. Cover and cook for 20 minutes.\n3 Remove chicken, let cool to touch: Remove the chicken pieces from the pot. (They should be just cooked through. If not, return them to the pot for another 5 minutes or so, until they are cooked through.) Place on a cutting board and allow to cool to the touch.\n4 Add rice, apples: Add the rice and the chopped apples to the soup. Return to a simmer on high heat, then lower the heat to maintain a low simmer. Cover and cook for 15 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through.\n5 Shred the chicken, return to soup, add cream: While the apples and rice are cooking in the soup, shred the chicken, discarding any tough bits. Once the rice and apples in the soup are cooked, add the chicken back to the pot. Heat for 5 minutes more. Then stir in the cream.\nServe with yogurt and chives.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nQueen Elizabeth\xe2\x80\x99s Drop Scones Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes about 16 American-sized pancakes.\nI've changed the method just a little from the Queen's original, by adding the wet ingredients to the dry, instead of the dry to the wet.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups (400 g) all-purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking soda*\n3 teaspoons cream of tartar*\n1/4 teaspoon salt**\n2 eggs\n1/4 cup of superfine sugar, or a heaping 1/4 cup white, granulated sugar\n1 1/2 cup (350 ml) of whole milk (and maybe a little more if needed)\n2 tablespoons butter, melted\n*If you don't have cream of tartar, substitute the 2 teaspoons of baking soda and the 3 teaspoons of cream of tartar with 5 teaspoons of baking powder (make sure your baking powder is less than 6 months old or it may be flat and unable to provide leavening).\n**If using salted butter, skip the added salt.\nMETHOD\n1 Whisk together the flour, baking soda, cream of tartar, and salt in a large bowl.\n2 In a separate medium sized bowl, whisk together the eggs and sugar. Then whisk in most of the milk.\n3 Make a well in the middle of the flour and pour in the milk egg mixture. Whisk until smooth, adding more milk until you get the right consistency - thin enough to spread on the pan, but not so thin as to run. Fold in the melted butter.\n4 Heat a griddle or large cast iron pan on medium to medium low heat. Coat the pan with a little butter, spreading it with a folded over paper towel. Drop large spoonfuls of batter on the griddle to form pancakes. When bubbles start to appear on the surface (after 2 to 3 minutes), use a metal spatula to flip the pancakes over. Cook for another minute, until lightly browned. Remove to a plate and cover with a clean tea towel to keep warm while you cook the rest of the drop scones.\nServe with butter, jam, or golden syrup (Americans sub maple syrup).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nSheet Pan Fish and Chips Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf the fish still has the skin attached on one side, you can ask the fish monger to remove it for you. They will do this free of charge.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 tablespoons olive oil, or more if needed\n2 1/2 pounds Yukon Gold or other yellow potatoes (3 large or 6 medium), unpeeled\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 cup Panko, or other unseasoned dry white breadcrumbs\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 pounds firm-fleshed white fish fillets, skins removed, such as haddock, halibut, pollock, flounder, whiting, redfish, cod, or other fish in your region\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley\n1 lemon, cut into wedges, to serve\nTartar sauce, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 450F. Arrange 2 oven racks in the top and bottom third of the oven. Line 2 baking sheets with foil and coat with olive oil (about 1 tablespoon per baking sheet) or with nonstick cooking spray.\n2 Prepare the potatoes: Quarter the potatoes lengthwise, then cut each quarter in half again so you get 8 spears from each potato. In a bowl, toss the potatoes with 2 tablespoons of the oil and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Spread the potatoes on one of the baking sheets with their wedges pointing up, if possible, so the cut sides are exposed (some may not stand; that\xe2\x80\x99s OK).\n3 Roast the potatoes: Roast the spears on the lower rack in the oven for 40 minutes. Rotate the pan partway through (after 20 minutes of cooking) and use a wide metal spatula to stir the potatoes. At this point, it\'s fine if the potatoes fall on their sides; the sides touching the pan will become extra-crispy and golden.\n4 Toast the panko: Once the potatoes are in the oven, start on the panko and the fish. To toast the panko, warm a heavy skillet over medium high heat. Add the panko (no oil needed), and lower the heat to medium. Slowly toast the panko, stirring frequently, for 10 to 15 minutes or until a deep golden brown.\nRemove the skillet from heat. Stir 1 tablespoon of olive oil, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper into the panko breadcrumbs until they are well coated. Transfer the crumbs to a shallow bowl.\n5 Prepare the fish: Cut the fish into large strips ("fingers") or big 3-inch pieces, however you prefer. Rub all the pieces with the remaining tablespoon of olive oil.\n6 Coat the fish with panko: Press the fish into the panko so the pieces are coated all over. Set the fish on the second baking sheet, spaced slightly apart.\n7 When the potatoes are 15 to 20 minutes away from being done, bake the fish:  Cook thick (2-inch) fish fillets for 15 to 18 minutes and thinner (1 1/2-inch or thinner) fillets for 10 to 13 minutes, or until the fish is firm and the coating is starting to brown. Err on the side of caution and do not over-bake.\n7 Serve the fish and chips: Arrange fish and potato spears on plates, sprinkle with parsley, serve with lemon and tartar sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSheet Pan English Breakfast Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 servings\nTotal cooking time is about 45 minutes with ingredients added to the sheet pan progressively. Ingredients can be grouped together or mixed; whichever feels easiest to you as you make the dish.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds pork or chicken sausage (preferably links weighing 6-8 ounces each)\n1 cup grape tomatoes, halved\n8 to 10 ounces baby cremini mushrooms, halved\n3 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 (15-ounce) can pinto beans\n1 tablespoon packed brown sugar\n1 tablespoon ketchup\n1 tablespoon barbecue sauce\n4 large eggs\nSalt and pepper\n3 whole sprigs fresh thyme\nToast, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Rub sheet pan with 1 tablespoon of olive oil to prevent the food from sticking.\n2 Begin cooking the sausage: Arrange sausage links on the sheet pan and cook for 15 minutes.\n3 Flip the sausage and add the tomatoes: Remove sheet pan from the oven and using tongs. Add the grape tomatoes, cut side up and season with a pinch of salt and pepper. Return to oven and bake for another 15 minutes.\n4 Meanwhile, prep the remaining ingredients. Toss the mushrooms with 1 tablespoon olive oil and a pinch of salt and pepper, and set aside. Drain and rinse pinto beans and stir them together with brown sugar, ketchup, and barbecue sauce. Transfer beans to a small oven-safe skillet or dish.\n5 Pour off liquid and add the mushrooms. Remove the sheet pan from the oven (at this point, the sausages have been cooking for 30 minutes and the tomatoes for 15 minutes). If there is a lot of liquid on the sheet pan, carefully pour off the liquid; do not stir the tomatoes (they tend to fall apart if stirred and are better left alone).\nAdd prepared mushrooms to the sheet pan and return to the oven.\n6 Add the beans and the eggs. After 15 more minutes (40-45 total minutes of baking), remove the sheet pan and again drain off any excess liquid. Flip the sausages again, but the other ingredients can be left alone.\nClear a little space on the sheet pan and nestle the dish of beans inside. (Alternatively, if you\xe2\x80\x99re running out of space, you can bake the beans on a separate oven rack.)\nMake four little pockets of space on the sheet pan for the eggs. Drizzle a tiny amount of oil in each area and crack in eggs. Place the fresh thyme sprigs here and there over the ingredients.\n7 Bake the eggs: Bake for a final 5 minutes, just until the whites of the eggs set. (If you want the eggs cooked through with hard yolks, bake them for 8 minutes total.)\nWhile the eggs bake, make the toast.\n8 Season and serve: Remove sheet pan from the oven and allow to cool briefly. Sprinkle everything with salt and pepper. Slice sausage and divide between plates. Serve with beans, roasted tomatoes and mushrooms, eggs, and crispy toast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSavory Scones with Goat Cheese and Chives Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 scones\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick) chilled butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n1/4 cup to 1/2 cup of freshly chopped chives (can also use chopped green onions)\n1 5-ounce log soft fresh goat cheese, crumbled\n1 cup buttermilk (plus an extra tablespoon for finish)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Line 2 heavy baking sheets with silpat or parchment paper.\n2 Make the dough: Whisk flour, baking powder, sugar, baking soda, salt and pepper in a large bowl. Using fingertips, rub butter into dry ingredients until coarse meal forms.\nStir in the chives. Add cheese and buttermilk; stir with fork just until a sticky dough forms (bits of cheese will be visible in dough).\n3 Knead the dough and form into rounds, cut into wedges: Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead gently 8 times with floured hands. Do not over-knead!\nForm into a round, about 3/4-inch to an inch thick. Cut the round into 8 wedges.\n4 Use a pastry brush to brush on some extra buttermilk over the surface of the wedges.\n5 Bake: Arrange wedges about 1/2 inch apart on an un-greased large baking sheet and bake at 400\xc2\xb0F in the middle of the oven until golden brown, about 20 minutes.\nCool on a rack.\nBest eaten just baked and warm, with a little butter.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nClassic Shortbread Cookies\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 3 dozen\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (256g) all-purpose flour\n1 cup (115g) powdered sugar\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (227g) unsalted butter, room temp and cut into pieces\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven and prepare the baking sheets: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F and line 3 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n2 Combine all the ingredients: Place the flour, powdered sugar, salt, and butter into the bowl of a food processor and pulse until all of the butter is incorporated, about 10 to 15 one-second pulses, but could be more depending upon your food processor.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s ready when the mixture looks like wet sand and clumps together when pressed. Stop when the mixture begins to climb up the bowl.\n3 Bring the dough together: Dump everything onto the counter and gently press it together into a crumbly mound. I use a flexible bowl scraper to scoop and press the mound together at first, then knead the dough a few times and form it into a square shape.\n4 Roll and cut the dough: Roll the dough out on a well-floured surface to 1/4- to 1/2-inch thickness (depending on how thick you like your cookies) and either use a knife to cut out rectangles or use a cutter to make shapes.\n5 Transfer and chill the cookies: Transfer the cookies to one of the parchment-lined baking sheets. Chill the cookies on the sheet pan in the freezer for 15 minutes or until the cookies are solid to the touch.\nTransfer the frozen cookies, in batches, onto the other baking sheets, leaving about 1/2 inch between each cookie.\n6 Bake the cookies: Bake the cookies, one pan at a time, for 15-18 minutes, or until the cookies are dry to the touch and the bottoms just begin to turn golden.\n7 Cool and store: Remove from the oven and cool on a rack before transferring to a container for storage. The baked and cooled cookies can be stored in an airtight container for several days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBanoffee Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 40 minutesCook time: 1 hourCooling and Chilling time: 16 hoursYield: 12 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the toffee sauce:\n3/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, sliced\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (197 g) packed light brown sugar\n3 tablespoons dark corn syrup\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the banoffee cheesecake:\n2 (5-ounce) packages Walker\xe2\x80\x99s shortbread cookies\n1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar, divided\n3 tablespoons melted unsalted butter\n4 (8-ounce) packages cream cheese, at room temperature\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n4 large eggs\n3 ripe bananas, peeled and mashed\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon banana extract\n1/3 cup cornstarch\nTo garnish:\nToffee sauce\nWhipped cream\nDried banana chips\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the toffee sauce: Warm the heavy cream in the microwave for one minute, or on the stovetop over medium heat. The cream should steam, but not boil. Set this aside.\nIn a 4-quart saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the salt, brown sugar, and corn syrup. Whisking frequently, heat until the sugar has dissolved and the syrup bubbles gently. This should take anywhere from 3 to 5 minutes.\nTurn the stove off and whisk in the warmed cream\xe2\x80\x94be careful, as the sugar will bubble and steam once the cream is poured in. Add the vanilla extract to the sauce and set the pan back over medium heat.\nCook for another 5 minutes, or until the syrup is thick. Transfer the sauce to a glass jar and store in the refrigerator until ready to use, up to one week in advance.\n2 Prep the oven and the pan: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Wrap a 10-inch springform pan in heavy duty aluminum foil and set aside; be very careful not to tear or puncture the foil.\n3 Make the shortbread crust: Use a food processor to pulse the shortbread cookies into fine crumbs. Add 1/4 cup of granulated sugar and the melted butter to the food processor bowl and pulse until the crumbs hold together.\nSqueeze a handful of crumbs in the palm of your hand. If the mixture doesn\xe2\x80\x99t hold together, add another tablespoon of melted butter, and re-mix.\n4 Pre-bake the crust: Press the shortbread mixture onto the bottom and an inch or so up the sides of the springform pan. Bake the crust for 10 minutes. Remove the pan from the oven and allow it to cool while you prepare the cheesecake filling.\n5 Heat water: While the crust bakes, heat 4 or 5 cups of water to boiling for the water bath.\n6 Prepare the banana cheesecake: In the bowl of a stand mixer with a paddle attachment (or in a large mixing bowl), blend together the cream cheese, the remaining 3/4 cup sugar, and the salt until smooth.\nAdd the eggs, one at a time, to the cream cheese mixture, stopping to scrape down the sides after each addition. Mix on low speed for an additional minute.\nAdd the banana puree and both extracts. Blend on low for another minute. Scrape down the mixing bowl and add the cornstarch. Blend on the lowest speed for 30 seconds, or until no lumps of cornstarch are visible, being careful not to over-mix. \n7 Bake the cheesecake: Pour the batter into the prepared pan and set the foil-wrapped springform pan into a larger pan. Add enough hot water to reach halfway up the sides of the springform pan and carefully place the pan into the oven.\nBake the cheesecake for 55 minutes to an 1 hour, or until the top is a light golden brown and the cheesecake jiggles slightly when shaken. Turn the oven off and open the door a crack to allow the cheesecake to cool in the oven for 30 minutes.\n8 Cool the cheesecake completely: Once the cheesecake has cooled in the oven, carefully take it out of the oven and remove the foil. Cool the cheesecake on the countertop for an hour, then transfer it to the refrigerator to cool completely, at least 12 hours or up to 24 hours.\n9 Decorate the cheesecake: Once the cheesecake is cold, remove the collar from the springform pan. Warm the toffee sauce slightly so that it's pourable but not runny (I set it in a dish of warm water), then drizzle one cup of the toffee sauce over the top of the cheesecake. Use a piping bag to pipe rosettes of whipped cream around the cheesecake and garnish each rosette with a banana chip.\nKeep the cheesecake refrigerated until ready to serve, and be sure to keep leftovers chilled, too.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nSesame Brittle Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Makes about 10 ounces of brittle\nAdding a small amount of baking soda to the hot mixture right before pouring it out will cause the mixture to foam up a bit, as the baking soda reacts with the acid from the caramelization of the sugar. This creates bubbles of carbon dioxide which helps produce a slightly lighter, more porous texture for the brittle, making it easier to eat.\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup honey\nPinch of salt\n1/4 teaspoon of ground nutmeg\n1 Tbsp water\n1 cup raw sesame seeds\n1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n2 teaspoons butter\n1/4 teaspoon of baking soda\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat sugar, honey, water, salt, nutmeg: Put the sugar, honey, salt, nutmeg, and water into a small (1 1/2 quart), thick-bottomed saucepan. Heat on medium heat and stir until a smooth slurry is formed.\n2 Stir in the raw sesame seeds.\n3 Cook the sesame seed mixture, stirring often, until the mixture turns an amber caramel color, about 5 to 10 minutes.\nIf you have a candy thermometer, the temp should be 300\xc2\xb0F. At this point, remove the pan from the heat. Stir in the vanilla extract and the butter.\nOnce the butter has completely melted into the mixture, stir in the baking soda. The mixture will foam up a bit after you stir in the baking soda, as the baking soda reacts with the acid from the caramelization of the sugar.\n4 Pour the mixture out onto a Silpat-lined baking sheet. (If you don't have Silpat, no worries, pour directly onto a buttered metal baking sheet and use a metal spatula to separate brittle from the pan once cooled.)\n5 Once completely cooled and hardened (about 15-20 minutes), break into pieces.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nHow to Steam Broccoli Perfectly Every Time\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2-4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 bunch of broccoli\nMany options here:\nOlive oil, butter, or mayonnaise (use olive oil if cooking vegan)\nFreshly ground black pepper\nLemon zest or juice, balsamic vinegar, seasoned rice vinegar\nToasted almonds, toasted sesame seeds\nMETHOD\n1 Prep the broccoli crowns and stems: Cut the crowns away from the large stems of the broccoli. Break the crown up into bite-sized florets. Rinse the broccoli florets thoroughly.\nPeel and discard the thick outer skin of the stems. Slice the stems or cut them into quarters lengthwise.\n2 Bring steamer water to a boil: Place 3/4 to 1 inch of water in a saucepan with a steamer and bring to a boil. (Note that is you don't have a steamer, you can simply put the broccoli directly into an inch of boiling water.)\n3 Add broccoli, steam 5 to 6 min: Add the broccoli to the steamer and cover; reduce heat to medium and let cook for 5-6 minutes. The broccoli is done when you can pierce it with a fork. As soon as it is pierce-able, remove from heat, place in serving dish.\nNote that green vegetables like broccoli will turn from vibrant green to drab olive green at about the 7 minute mark of cooking.
