All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBrown Butter Chocolate Chunk Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes about 3 dozen cookies\nWe brown the butter first in this recipe because brown butter adds wonderful flavor to the dough. If you are short on time or don't want to bother, you can skip browning the butter, just start with room temperature butter.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (2 sticks, 8 ounces, 225 g) unsalted butter\n2 1/2 cups all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 cup brown sugar, packed\n1/2 cup white sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n9 ounces milk chocolate (or semi-sweet or dark if you prefer) bars, roughly chopped into chunks, about 2 cups\n1 cup chopped walnuts or pecans (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Brown the butter: Melt the butter in a medium sized, thick-bottomed, stainless steel saucepan (use stainless steel so you can tell when the butter has browned) on medium heat.\nContinue to cook while the butter goes through various stages of bubbling up and releasing its moisture.  Whisk frequently over several minutes.\nWhen you start to smell the nutty aroma of the butter browning, and you can whisk aside some of the foam to see small browned bits at the bottom of the pan, remove from heat and pour off into a bowl. Do not dawdle at this point as it is easy for the butter to go from browned to burnt.\n3 Whisk together dry ingredients: Place the flour, salt, baking soda, and cinnamon in a bowl and vigorously whisk together.\n4 Beat brown butter and sugars, then add eggs and vanilla: Pour browned butter into the bowl of a stand-up mixer (if you don't have a mixer, you can just beat by hand). Add the sugars and beat until smooth. Add the eggs, beating after each addition.  Add the vanilla extract and beat for 3 more minutes.\n5 Add flour mixture to wet ingredients, then stir in chocolate chunks: Stir the flour mixture into the butter sugar mixture a third at a time. Stir in the chocolate chunks and the nuts (if using).\nUp to this point you can make ahead a day or two and store the cookie dough in the refrigerator until ready to cook.\n6 Spoon out cookie dough to lined baking sheet: Line cookie sheets with Silpat or parchment paper (or just lightly butter) rimmed cookie sheets.\nSpoon out heaping tablespoon hunks of batter onto the cookie sheets, separated by at least 2 inches, allowing room for the cookies to spread as they cook.  You may need to work in batches.\n6 Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for about 12 minutes, the edges of the cookies should be just a little browned. Remove from the oven, let cool on the cookie sheet for 5 minutes. Then remove the cookies to cool completely on a rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nSeared Scallops with Brown Butter Caper Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nWhen shopping for scallops, choose only scallops that have a fresh, sweet smell. If they smell fishy, they\'re not fresh and they won\'t taste good.\nIf you have a choice, look for "dry pack" instead of "wet pack" scallops. The dry pack scallops will sear well. The wet pack ones are almost impossible to sear.\nThe trick to cooking scallops is to sear them on very high heat. If the heat isn\'t high enough, the scallops will take too long to brown, and get overcooked and rubbery.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 tablespoons (3 ounces) unsalted butter\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil or canola oil\n1 pound sea scallops (about a dozen)*\n3/4 cup dry white wine\n2 tablespoons capers, drained\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\n*Sea scallops are the large scallops (about 1 1/2 inches wide), different from their much smaller cousins, bay scallops.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the butter: Cut up the butter into pieces (a tablespoon each or so) and place in a stainless steel saucepan. Melt the butter on medium heat. Allow the butter to foam up and recede. Watch carefully. After a few minutes, the milk solids will form and sink to the bottom.\nOnce the milk solids begin to turn caramel-colored brown, the butter will have a lovely nutty aroma.\nRemove from heat and pour the browned butter into a separate bowl to stop the cooking. (Pay attention! If you wait too long, you\'ll have blackened butter, not browned butter.) Set aside.\n2 Remove "foot" and pat dry scallops: Remove the "foot" of the scallop from each scallop. (The foot is a small tough piece of meat that attaches the scallop to the shell.) Pat dry the scallops.\n3 Sear the scallops on both sides on high heat: Heat the oil in a cast iron pan or hard-anodized aluminum saut\xc3\xa9 pan on high heat.\nWhen the oil is shimmery hot, pat dry the scallops again and carefully place them in the pan, flat side down.\nYou may need to work in batches so you don\'t crowd the pan.\nOnce you\'ve placed the scallops in the pan, do not move them. Allow them to sear.\nOnce you can see that the edges of the scallops touching the pan have browned, use tongs to turn the scallops over and sear the other side. Depending on the size of the scallops and the heat of your burner, this should take 3 to 4 minutes per side.\nOnce both sides are browned, remove the scallops to a warm plate, and turn off the burner.\n4 Deglaze pan with white wine: Pour out the remaining oil from the pan, leaving any browned bits in the pan. Add the white wine to the pan and return the pan to the burner on high heat.\nLet the wine boil and reduce until you have 2 tablespoons of liquid left in the pan.\n5 Add capers, lemon zest, brown butter: Then turn off the heat, add the capers, lemon zest, and brown butter to the pan. Swirl to combine.\n6 Serve scallops with sauce: Place scallops on serving plates and pour sauce over them. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBroiled Lobster Tail with Brown Butter Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 2\nIf starting with frozen lobster tails, prepare a bowl with 2 quarts of cold water and 1 Tbsp salt. Stir to dissolve the salt. Place the lobster tails in the water. Add a few ice cubes. Let sit for half hour to an hour until defrosted.\nThis recipe calls for lobster tails that are 6 to 8 ounces each. If you are cooking smaller or larger lobster tails, you'll need to adjust the broiling time down or up. For example, a 3 ounce lobster tail should take 3 to 4 minutes to broil.\nThe trickiest part of working with lobster tails is opening the shell and loosening the meat enough to pull it through the cut you've made in the shell. Depending on at what point of the lobster's molting cycle the lobster was caught, the shell can be either really thick and strong, or thin and easy to manipulate.\nTake care if working with an especially hard shell so you don't cut yourself, and use a strong hand. (I recommend watching this video for a good explanation of the technique.)\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup unsalted raw hazelnuts\n8 tablespoons unsalted butter\n2 tablespoons minced shallots\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh parsley\n1/4 teaspoon grated lemon zest\nPinch of salt\n2 lobster tails (6 to 8 ounces each), fresh or frozen\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nIf starting with frozen lobster tails, while the lobster tails are defrosting, prepare the hazelnut brown butter sauce to save time.\n1 Toast the hazelnuts: Toast hazelnuts in a small skillet on medium to medium high heat. When fragrant and lightly browned, remove hazelnuts from pan and place in the center a dry, clean dish towel.\nRub the hazelnuts together inside of the dish towel to remove as much of the papery dark skins as you can. Coarsely chop them and set aside.\n2 Brown the butter: In a small stainless steel saucepan, melt the butter on medium heat. (Use stainless so you will easily be able to tell when the butter is browning.)\nAfter the butter melts, it will foam up, and recede. The milk solids will fall to the bottom of the pan.\nContinue to heat and the milk solids will start to brown giving the melted butter a wonderful nutty aroma.\nLet most of the milk solids brown and then remove from heat and strain through a fine mesh strainer into a bowl, to remove the browned milk solids.\nRemove 2 tablespoons of the melted brown butter and set aside (they will be brushed on to the lobster tails before broiling. (See more details in How to Brown Butter.)\n3 Complete the sauce: To the remaining brown butter, add the chopped hazelnuts, parsley, shallots, lemon zest and salt. Set aside.\n4 Prepare lobster tails for broiling: Place rack in medium position in oven. Preheat broiler. Place a layer of foil over a broiling pan or roasting pan.\nUsing kitchen shears or strong scissors, cut the top side of the lobster tail shells lengthwise, from open end to the base of the tail.\nTo help make the shell easier to deal with, put the tail upside-down in the palm of your hand and squeeze to break the translucent bottom shell (see this useful video I found on YouTube).\nGrip the sides of the shell and pull open by about an inch or two.\nUsing your finger, carefully wiggle between the lobster meat and the shell and separate the meat from the shell.\nThen gently pull the meat up through the crack you've created, keeping the meat attached to the tail, and let the lobster meat sit on top of the shell. Place the tails on the foil-lined broiling pan.\n5 Brush lobster tails with browned butter and broil: Pull back the lobster meat to expose as much of it as possible. Brush the exposed lobster meat with the unadorned browned butter you set aside in step 2.\nBroil for 7 to 10 minutes until the meat is cooked through (less time for smaller lobster tails), and the shells are bright red.\nI recommend using a meat thermometer, which should read 145\xc2\xb0F when the lobster is done.\n6 Serve with browned butter hazelnut sauce: When the lobster tails are done, remove from oven and place on serving plates. Spoon the browned butter hazelnut sauce over the lobster meat of the lobster tails to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCauliflower Mashed \xe2\x80\x9cPotatoes\xe2\x80\x9d with Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nCauliflowers vary in size. If you are working with a cauliflower that is larger or smaller than 1 1/4 pounds, increase or decrease the amount of butter and sour cream to add.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large cauliflower (about 1 1/4 pound or 565 g), core removed, cut into large florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1 cup (235 ml) water\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons butter\n4 tablespoons (60 ml) sour cream\nChopped chives, green onions, and/or parsley for garnish\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steam/boil the cauliflower: Place 1 cup water in a medium saucepan. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Add the cauliflower florets.\nBring to a boil on high heat. Lower the heat to a simmer.\nCover and let the cauliflower cook for 10-14 minutes, until very tender.\n2 Brown the butter: While the cauliflower is cooking, melt the butter in a small saucepan (easier to use a stainless steel pan so that you can see the browning occur) on medium heat.\nOnce the butter melts, it will begin to foam up a bit. When the foam subsides, look for amber colored bits forming at the bottom of the pan.\nWhen the butter begins to brown, smell it. It will have a lovely nutty aroma.\nWhen you can see lots of flecks of browned bits, and the melted butter smells wonderful, remove it from the heat and pour into a bowl (glass or metal).\nButter can quickly go from browned to burnt, so keep an eye on it and work quickly when the butter starts to brown! (See our more detailed instructions on How to Brown Butter.)\n3 Strain the cooked cauliflower: When the cauliflower is cooked through and tender enough to mash with a fork, strain out all but a tablespoon or two of the remaining water.\n4 Mash with a potato masher and stir in the brown butter and sour cream. (Make sure to scrape in all the browned bits from the butter; that's where the flavor is!)\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e to desired consistency: Use an immersion blender or a standing blender and blend the mashed potatoes to as smooth a consistency as you would like. Or just mash more with a potato masher if you like a chunky consistency.\nAdd salt and pepper to taste. Top with chopped chives, green onions, or parsley to serve.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPasta with Spinach, Mushrooms, and Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nAny kind of mushrooms can be used in this recipe, like white mushrooms, cremini, Portobello or shitake. Use a mix, or just use a single variety.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 1/2 pounds mushrooms, sliced (See Recipe Note)\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 pound small shaped pasta, such as orecchiette, bowties, campanelle, or shells\n5 ounces (4 to 5 large handfuls) baby spinach leaves\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\nFinely grated zest of 1 lemon\n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan (for garnish)\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley (for garnish)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Cook for 8 to 10 minutes, or until al dente (check the package for specific times for your chosen pasta).\nScoop out 1 cup of the pasta cooking water and drain the pasta in a colander. Set aside.\n2 Meanwhile, make the brown butter: In a small stainless steel or other light-colored skillet over medium heat, melt the butter. Cook, stirring constantly, until the butter solids on the bottom turn light brown and the butter smells nutty. Immediately remove the pan from the heat and set aside.\nFor a full tutorial on making brown butter, see this post.\n  3 Cook the mushrooms: In a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat the oil. Add the mushrooms, and cook, stirring often, for 10 minutes, or until the mushrooms release their juices and turn golden brown. Sprinkle with salt and pepper.\n4 Finish the pasta: Add the drained pasta to the skillet with the mushrooms and toss over medium-high heat. Stir in half the spinach and 1/4 cup of the pasta water into the pasta and cook until the spinach begins to wilt. Add the remaining spinach, and stir until all the spinach wilts. If the pasta seems dry, stir in 1 to 2 tablespoons of the remaining pasta cooking water.\nStir in the browned butter, lemon juice and lemon zest and toss. Taste and add more salt and pepper, if you like.\n5 Serve the pasta: Spoon the pasta into shallow bowls and sprinkle the parsley and Parmesan on top. Grind a little fresh black pepper over each bowl.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nPasta with Butternut Squash, Bacon, and Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound butternut squash, cut into 1/2-inch cubes (about 4 cups)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon Morton\xe2\x80\x99s kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper\n1 pound pasta, such as penne, rigatoni, or other short-shaped pasta\n8 ounces bacon (7 to 8 slices, depending on how thickly they are cut)\n1/4 cup sliced shallots\n1 stick unsalted butter (4 ounces/8 tablespoons)\n4 to 5 sage leaves\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the squash: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. On a rimmed baking sheet, combine the squash with olive oil, salt, and pepper on a rimmed baking sheet, and toss to coat.\nRoast for 20 minutes, tossing half way through to evenly brown. When it\xe2\x80\x99s ready, the squash will be soft and some of the edges will have browned.\n2 Cook the pasta: Meanwhile, bring a large pot of salted water to boil and cook the pasta to al dente, or according to package directions. Drain well and set aside.\n3 Fry the bacon: In a large, deep skillet (I used cast iron), put the bacon in a cold pan and cook over medium heat until crispy. Remove from the skillet and drain on paper towels.\n4 Cook the shallots: Place the skillet back on the stove, but with the heat turned off. Drain all but about 2 tablespoons of the bacon grease.\nAdd the shallots and cook in the residual heat from the skillet; this helps prevent the shallots from burning. If they don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be cooking fast enough, turn the heat to medium-low and cook for just a couple of minutes until they start to soften and become aromatic. Transfer the cooked shallots to a large bowl.\n  5 Combine the bacon, shallots, squash and pasta: After the bacon cools, cut it into small pieces using kitchen scissors (or using a chef's knife), and combine with the shallots in a large bowl\xe2\x80\x94or you can use the stockpot you cooked the pasta in (I like to do this if it's just me and the boys).\nAdd the pasta and toss to combine. When the squash comes out of the oven, add the squash to this bowl and toss gently together.\n  6 Brown the butter: In a small saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir it constantly and keep an eye on it so it does not burn. (See here for full instructions on how to brown butter.) It will start to crackle, foam, and smell nutty. The color will deepen to a caramel/amber hue.\nAround when the butter stops foaming\xe2\x80\x94or at least it starts to subside\xe2\x80\x94and the butter turns slightly brown, add the sage leaves.\nRemove the saucepan from the heat as soon as the sage leaves start to curl. Pour the butter and the sage leaves into the bowl with the rest of the ingredients.\n  7 Combine all ingredients and serve: Toss everything gently together with a wooden spoon. Taste and add salt and/or pepper if needed. Serve immediately with freshly grated cheese over the top.\nIf you are feeling extra decadent, add a chunk of unsalted butter or a splash of extra virgin olive oil on top when you toss, or some of the reserved bacon grease.\nLeftovers keep for about 2 to 3 days and reheat fairly well. I like to add a bit of olive oil or water to the pot when I reheat it over low heat. (I try to avoid microwaving leftover pasta because it just makes it gummy.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nSquid Ink Pasta with Pumpkin, Sage and Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nSquid ink pasta typically comes as either spaghetti or linguine; either will work fine.\nWe dust the insides of the pumpkin with a little sugar, just to accentuate the sweetness of the pumpkin. You can use either brown or white sugar, or skip it all together.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 small sugar pumpkins, each about 1 pound to 1 1/2 pound\nSalt\n2 to 4 teaspoons of white sugar, or 2 to 4 Tbsp of brown sugar (to taste)\n1 pound squid ink pasta\n6 tablespoons butter\n1/4 cup thinly sliced fresh sage leaves (with a few small whole leaves for garnish)\nA splash of apple cider vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare and bake the pumpkin shells: Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Slice off the top quarter of each pumpkin and scoop out the insides. (Save the seeds to make toasted pumpkin seeds.)\nUsing a strong metal spoon or a small sharp knife, scrape all the fibrous insides out of the pumpkins. Sprinkle the insides of the pumpkins with salt and sugar.\nSet the pumpkins on a baking sheet and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 1 hour, or until a fork easily pierces the flesh and the edges are lightly browned.\n2 Start cooking the pasta: Prepare the pasta water while the pumpkins are cooking. Bring a large pot of well salted water (it should taste like the sea) to a boil. When the pumpkins have about 10 minutes to go before they're done, add the pasta to the boiling water.\nWhen the pumpkins are cooked remove them from the oven to a serving dish or plates.\n3 Make the brown butter sauce with sage: While the pasta is cooking, prepare the brown butter sauce. Heat the butter in a saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat. Add the sage leaves and cook until browned bits begin to form in the butter and there is a lovely nutty aroma.\nRemove any whole sage leaves you are using for garnish.\nRemove the pan from the heat and pour the brown butter into a large serving bowl (this will stop the butter from cooking further). Browned butter can easily turn to blackened butter, which is not the flavor you want for this recipe.\n4 Stir in the pasta into the brown butter sauce, add vinegar, salt: When the pasta is ready (al dente, slightly firm, but cooked through), use tongs to remove the pasta from the pot to the large bowl with the brown butter.\nAllow some of the water from the pasta to drip into the bowl, it will help with the sauce. Toss the pasta with the brown butter.\nSplash a little cider vinegar over it. Taste for salt, it will likely need a bit more, especially if you've used unsalted butter. Add more if needed.\n5 Serve: Serve the pasta in the baked pumpkin shells. Garnish with reserved whole sage leaves that you had cooked with the sliced sage in the butter.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nMashed Potatoes with Brown Butter, Goat Cheese, and Sage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds yukon gold potatoes, peeled and quartered\n1 teaspoon salt\n3 Tbsp butter\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh sage\n4 ounces goat cheese\n3 Tbsp milk\nPepper\nMETHOD\n1 Boil the potatoes: Place the potatoes and salt in a pot and fill the pot with cold water until the potatoes are covered.\nBring to a boil over high heat, then lower the heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until a fork easily pierces the potatoes.\nDrain the water from the potatoes.\n2 Brown the butter: Place the butter in a small saucepan over low heat. (Use a stainless steel saucepan so you can see the butter browning.) Let the butter melt and continue to watch it as it cooks. The butter will foam for a bit and then calm down.\nAfter a few minutes, flecks of brown will appear at the bottom of the pan. When you see this, and the melted butter takes on a nutty aroma, take it off the heat. (See How to Brown Butter.)\n3 Add sage and pour over potatoes: Add the chopped sage to the butter (it may cause some foaming). Pour over the potatoes.\n4 Add the goat cheese and milk and mash the potatoes with a potato masher until smooth and all ingredients are well incorporated. Salt and pepper to taste and serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBrownie in a Mug Recipe\nPrep time: 3 minutesCook time: 2 minutesYield: Makes one serving\nSome mugs don't microwave well because there is metal in their ceramic glaze. They'll work but they may get very hot. Best to use a plain old everyday un-fancy mug. A regular 12 to 16 ounce mug will do fine.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup flour (30 g)\n1/4 cup sugar (50 g)\n2 tablespoons (13 g) cocoa (natural, unsweetened)\nPinch of salt\nTiny pinch of cinnamon\n1/4 cup water (60 ml)\n2 tablespoons (30 ml) melted butter, or neutral oil\n1/8 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 small scoop of ice cream or 1 or 2 teaspoons heavy whipping cream to serve\nMETHOD\n1 Add the dry ingredients to the mug and stir: Place flour, sugar, cocoa, salt, and cinnamon in a microwave safe ceramic mug. Stir with a fork or spoon to mix well and break up any clumps.\n2 Add the wet ingredients and stir: Add the butter or oil, water, and vanilla to the cup and stir until the mixture is smooth and there are no lumps.\n3 Zap in microwave: Place in microwave and heat on high until the mixture is cooked through, about a 1 minute and 40 seconds for a 1000 watt microwave, or 1 minute 10 seconds on a 1650 watt microwave.\nYou may have to experiment and adjust the time for less or more powerful microwaves. If you don't know the power level on your microwave, start with 60 seconds and increase until the brownie is done. It should still be moist when cooked through, not dry.\n4 Top with ice cream! Let cool for a minute and serve with a scoop of vanilla ice cream or a teaspoon or two of whipping cream poured over.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBest Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 16 to 25 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n10 tablespoons (1 1/4 sticks, 140 g) unsalted butter\n1 1/4 cups (250 g) granulated sugar\n3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (85 g) unsweetened cocoa powder (natural or Dutch-process)\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n2 cold large eggs\n1/2 cup (65 g) all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup (90 g) pecan pieces\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven and line baking pan: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C), with a rack in the lower third of the oven.\nLine the bottom of an 8-inch square baking pan with foil or parchment paper in such a way as there is an overhang on two opposite sides to make it easy to lift the brownies out when they're done.\n2 Heat butter, cocoa, sugar, salt in a bowl over simmering water: Place the butter, cocoa, sugar, and salt in a medium-sized metal bowl. Fill a large skillet halfway with water and bring to a bare simmer. Set the bowl of the butter cocoa mixture in skillet of simmering water.\nStir the butter cocoa mixture until the butter has melted and the mixture is smooth and hot to touch.\nRemove the bowl from the skillet and let it cool down a bit, from hot to warm.\n3 Stir in almond extract, eggs, flour, beat with spoon, add pecans: Stir in the almond extract. Stir in the eggs, one at a time, beating strongly after each addition.\nOnce the batter is well mixed and shiny and thick, stir in the flour. Beat for 40 strokes with a wooden spoon.\nMix in the pecans.\n4 Pour batter into lined pan: Pour the batter into the prepared lined pan and smooth the surface evenly.\n5 Bake: Bake 20 to 25 minutes at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C), until a bamboo skewer or toothpick inserted into the center comes out still a little moist with the brownie batter. Cool completely on a rack.\n6 Cut: When cooled, lift up the sides of the foil or parchment liner to remove the brownies from the pan. Place them on a cutting board and cut into 16 to 25 squares or rectangles.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nFudgy Gluten-Free Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesCooling Time: 2 hours time: Yield: 16 small, 2-inch square brownies\nIf you\'ve never baked gluten-free before, we highly recommend using Bob\'s Red Mill 1:1 Gluten Free Baking Flour Blend for this recipe.\nIf you\'re using a different blend, double check the ingredients. If it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t contain xanthan gum (or another binding ingredient like guar gum or psyllium husks), we recommend adding 1/2 teaspoon of xanthan gum to ensure success.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons ground flax\n1 cup (148 grams) gluten-free flour blend, like Bob\'s Red Mill\n1/2 cup (40 grams) dairy-free cocoa powder\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 cup coconut oil at room temperature, plus more for the pan\n5 ounces (140g) bittersweet dairy-free chocolate, chopped\n1 1/2 cups (300 grams) sugar\n1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F and prepare the pan: Line an 8\xc3\x978 square baking pan with parchment paper, and grease the parchment paper and pan with a little coconut oil.\n2 Prepare the flax "egg": Combine the flax with 8 tablespoons of water in a small bowl. Let stand for 7 to 10 minutes to thicken. (This will be used as an egg replacer in this recipe.)\n3 Whisk dry ingredients: In a small mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt.\n4 Melt the coconut oil and chocolate: In a small saucepan over low heat, warm the coconut oil and chopped chocolate, stirring until the chocolate is completely melted, about 2 minutes.\n5 Add the sugar and vanilla: Whisk the sugar and vanilla into the chocolate mixture, stirring vigorously until combined. The mixture will be a little grainy at this point, which is perfectly okay.\n6 Make the batter: Pour the chocolate mixture into a large mixing bowl, scraping everything from the pan. Fold in the flax eggs.\nAdd the dry ingredients and stir well with a wooden spoon or rubber spatula until well combined. The batter will be quite thick and will gather into a ball\xe2\x80\x94it won\xe2\x80\x99t be loose and thin like many traditional brownie batters.\n7 Scoop the batter into the prepared pan, and use a rubber spatula or the palm of your hand to press it into the pan in an even layer.\n8 Bake the brownies for 30 to 35 minutes, or until the edges are set and no longer jiggly. The tops of the brownies will still feel very soft and may even be bubbling a little; they\xe2\x80\x99ll firm up as they cool.\n9 Cool: Let the brownies cool completely before slicing, at least 2 to 3 hours. Because these are so fudgy, they really will slice best if you allow them to fully cool.\n10 Slice, serve, and store: Using the parchment paper as a handle, lift the cooled brownies up out of the pan and onto a cutting board. Slice into a 4x4 grid (making 16 small squares). Leftover brownies can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nPeanut Butter Swirl Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 34 minutesYield: 16 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n6 ounces semisweet chocolate chips\n8 tablespoons (1 stick, 4 ounces) unsalted butter\n2 large eggs\n1/2 cup granulated sugar\n1/2 cup dark brown sugar\n1 tablespoon instant espresso coffee powder\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2/3 cup all-purpose flour\n2/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 cup smooth peanut butter\n2 tablespoons powdered sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xcb\x9aF. Line an 8-inch square baking dish with parchment paper; set aside.\n2 Melt the chocolate and butter: Set the chocolate and butter in a heat-proof bowl over a pot of simmering water\xe2\x80\x94the bottom of the bowl should not touch the water. Stir until the chocolate has melted. Remove from heat.\n  3 Make the batter: Whisk together the eggs, both sugars, coffee powder, and vanilla extract. Add in the flour, cocoa powder, salt, baking powder, and melted butter-chocolate mixture and stir until evenly combined. (The batter will be very thick, but don't worry! That's how it's supposed to be.)\nPress the brownie batter into the prepared baking dish in an even layer.\n   4 Add the peanut butter swirl. Warm the peanut butter in the microwave until it's loosened enough to drizzle, about 30 seconds on high. Stir the powdered sugar into the peanut butter, then drizzle over the top of the brownie batter.\nUse a butter knife to swirl the peanut butter mixture into the top of the brownie batter. Be careful not to over mix the peanut butter into the brownie mixture.\n5 Bake the brownies: Bake the brownies until a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out mostly clean, about 35 minutes. (The peanut butter will probably stick to the toothpick a little bit; that's fine.) Transfer to a wire rack to cool.\n6 Cool and slice: Let the brownies cool completely to room temperature before cutting them. For cleaner slicing with fewer crumbs, pop the pan in the freezer for a few minutes once it's cooled to room temperature to help with slicing to help keep them from sticking to the knife.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBrookies (Chocolate Chip Brownie Cookies) Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: 40 to 45 cookies\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cookie dough:\n2 cups (241g) all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n10 tablespoons (143g) unsalted butter\n1 1/4 cup (225g) packed brown sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/2 cup (100g) chocolate chips\nFor the brownie dough:\n8 ounces (227g) chopped dark chocolate (chips are okay, too)\n6 tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter\n1 cup (200g) packed brown sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n3/4 cup (98g) all-purpose flour\n2 tablespoons Dutch cocoa powder, sifted\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 cup (100g) chocolate chips\nSea salt, to finish\nSpecial equipment:\nSmall cookie scoop measuring two rounded teaspoons, or tablespoon measure\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the baking sheets: Line two baking sheets with parchment paper and set to the side.\n2 Make the cookie dough: Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl and set aside. In the bowl of a stand mixer, beat the butter and brown sugar together until just combined.\nOn medium speed, beat in the eggs one at a time, scraping the bowl after each addition, followed by the vanilla extract. The dough will be soft, but that\xe2\x80\x99s what we want. On low speed, beat in the flour mixture all at once, until just combined. Mix in the chocolate chips by hand, or with the mixer on low speed.\nTransfer the dough to a piece of plastic wrap and form into a flat rectangle (this will help the dough chill faster). Wrap the plastic wrap around the dough and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.\n3 Make the brownie dough. In a large, microwave-safe mixing bowl melt the chocolate and butter together in 30-second intervals, stirring between each, until the chocolate is melted and the mixture is smooth. Whisk in the brown sugar, followed by the eggs and vanilla extract.\nUsing a spatula, fold in the flour, sifted cocoa powder, baking powder, salt, and chocolate chips to form a very soft dough.\nTransfer the dough to a piece of plastic wrap and form into a flat rectangle (this will help the dough chill faster). Wrap the plastic wrap around the dough and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.\n4 Shape the brookies: Once both doughs have chilled, use a small cookie scoop to measure about 1 tablespoon of each dough. Using your palms, roll the two doughs gently together to form a ball and place on the parchment-lined baking sheet.\nPlace all the dough balls on one of the baking sheets (it's ok to crowd them), cover with plastic wrap, and chill for at least 30 minutes while the oven preheats or up to overnight.\n5 Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F for 30 minutes with an oven rack in the center position.\n6 Bake the brookies:  Rearrange the chilled cookie dough balls between two sheet pans so they are spaced a few inches apart. (If you have more than will fit comfortably, transfer the extras to a dinner plate and place back in the fridge). Sprinkle lightly with sea salt.\nBake one sheet at a time for 10 to 12 minutes. Let the cookies cool on the sheet pan for 3 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Repeat with the remaining dough.\nStore the cookies in an airtight container on the counter. They will keep for about 3 to 4 days before starting to dry out.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nFudgy Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 16 regular brownies or 25 brownie bites\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup (105 grams) all-purpose flour\n1/8 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n6 tablespoons (3 ounces) unsalted butter, cut up\n2 ounces unsweetened chocolate, broken into 1-inch pieces\n1 cup (200 grams) granulated sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 cup (6 ounces) mini bittersweet-chocolate chips, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n8x8 baking pan\nMedium saucepan, 2-quarts or larger\nHeatproof spatula\nWire cooling rack\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 350F and prepare the pan: Line an 8x8 baking pan with a sling of parchment, long enough so that the parchment hangs over the sides of the pan. Coat the exposed sides of the pan with cooking spray (also, a little cooking spray under the parchment will help it stick in place, if needed).\n2 Combine the dry ingredients: In a bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.\n3 Melt the chocolate and butter: In a medium saucepan over medium-low heat, melt the butter. It should not brown at the edges.\nAdd the chocolate and let it melt, stirring occasionally with a heatproof spatula, until the mixture is smooth.\n4 Set the pan on a cooling rack to cool until you can touch the bottom of with your hand comfortably.\n5 Make the batter: Using a rubber spatula, stir the sugar into the chocolate mixture until it combined. The mixture may look crumbly or smooth after mixing; either is fine.\nAdd the eggs, one at a time, followed by the vanilla. Add the flour mixture, and stir until no more white patches show. Stir in the chips until well distributed.\n6 Pour the batter into the pan. Use a spatula to spread it to the edges of the pan and smooth the top. Tap the pan once or twice hard on the counter to settle any air pockets; you can also poke the air pockets with the tip of a paring knife.\n7 Bake the brownies: Transfer the pan to the oven and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the top is slightly puffed and just set. If in doubt, it's better to under-bake these brownies a touch rather than over-bake. (The toothpick test doesn't work well for these brownies because the chocolate chips get melty!)\n8 Cool the brownies completely: Set the pan on a wire rack until completely cooled.\n9 Once cool, cover the pan and refrigerate for several hours or until firm and cold. This makes the brownies easier to slice cleanly.\nIf you're eager for brownies and can't wait for them to chill, skip this chilling step and serve them warm or just-cooled! They will be a little crumbly when you cut them.)\n6 Cut the squares: Run a thin knife around the edge of the pan to make sure the block of brownies is loose, then lift from the pan using the parchment paper sling. On a cutting board, slice the brownies into a 4x4 grid (to make 16 squares) or into a 5x5 grid (to make 25 mini-brownies).\nBrownies can be served right away. Leftovers can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for at least a week. (They will keep for longer, but may start getting dry and crumbly after a while.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nGuinness Chocolate Brownies Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Makes 16 to 25 brownies\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (240 ml) Guinness Extra Stout\n10 Tbsp (1 1/4 sticks, 140 g) unsalted butter\n1 1/4 cup (250 g) sugar\n3/4 cup plus 2 Tbsp (85 g) unsweetened natural cocoa\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 teaspoons vanilla\n2 large eggs, lightly beaten\n3/4 cup (96 g) flour\n2/3 cup  (90 g) chopped pecans, optional\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line an 8x8 square baking pan with parchment paper or foil in a way that there is overhang over two sides of the dish making it easy to remove the brownies once they are baked. Brush with a little butter or baking spray.\n2 Boil Guinness, reduce by half: Place the Guinness stout in a medium saucepan (2-quart) and bring to a boil. Watch out for the stout bubbling up too much. Boil until the liquid reduces by half.\n3 Progressively add butter, sugar, cocoa, salt, cinnamon to the Guinness, then let cool: Stir the butter into the reduced Guinness until melted. Add the sugar and whisk until dissolved. Whisk in the cocoa, salt, and cinnamon.\nWhisk until smooth. Remove from heat and let cool until just lightly warm to the touch.\n4 Stir in the vanilla, eggs, flour, nuts: When the mixture has cooled until just lightly warm to the touch, stir in the vanilla extract and eggs. Stir in the flour until smooth. Stir in the nuts.\n5 Bake: Pour into the prepared lined baking pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 30 minutes. Cool on a rack. When completely cool lift the brownies out of the pan. Cut into 16 to 25 squares or rectangles.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nKahl\xc3\xbaa Brownies Recipe\nINGREDIENTS\n1 \xc2\xbd pounds of 60% cacao chocolate\n1 cup of butter, cut into pieces and at room temperature\n6 eggs, room temperature\n2 cups of sugar\n1/4 teaspoon of salt\n1 tablespoon plus 1/4 teaspoon of Kahl\xc3\xbaa\n1/4 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 1/2 cups of all purpose flour\nMETHOD\n1 Lightly grease a 9x13 pan. Preheat the oven to 350 F.\n2 In a double boiler or using a bowl over a pot of simmering water, melt the chocolate and butter together.\n3 With an electric mixer, beat together the eggs, sugar and salt. Add the chocolate mixture and the vanilla extract and Kahl\xc3\xbaa. Mix until smooth.\n4 Slowly sift in the flour.\n5 Bake for 45-55 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. Place on a wire rack to cool for thirty minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nSpeculoos Brownie Cake + First Look at Baker\xe2\x80\x99s Royale Cookbook Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesCooling time time: 1 hourYield: 6 to 8 servings\nSpeculoos is a thick butter-like spread made from ground spice cookies. It's readily available at most well-stocked grocery stores or online, or you can make your own (check out this article on Serious Eats!).\nReprinted with permission from BAKER\xe2\x80\x99S ROYALE \xc2\xa9 2017 by Naomi Robinson, Running Press\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the brownie cake\nNonstick cooking spray\n1/2 cup (113 g) unsalted butter\n31/2 ounces (100 g) bittersweet chocolate, chopped\n11/3 cups (270 g) lightly packed light brown sugar\n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract\n1/2 teaspoon instant espresso powder\n3 large eggs, at room temperature\n1/2 cup (60 g) all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFor the speculoos frosting\n3/4 cup (205 g) speculoos cookie butter\n6 tablespoons (85 g) unsalted butter, at room temperature\n2/3 cup (70 g) confectioners\xe2\x80\x99 sugar\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons heavy whipping cream\nChocolate shavings, for garnish\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Get ready to bake: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (180\xc2\xb0C). Lightly coat a 9-inch/23 cm springform pan with nonstick cooking spray.\n2 Make the brownie batter: In a medium saucepan over medium heat, melt the butter. Remove the pan from the heat, add the bittersweet chocolate, and let sit for about 30 seconds, then whisk it all together until smooth and glossy.\nAdd the brown sugar, vanilla, and espresso powder and whisk until smooth. Whisk in the eggs, 1 at a time, then sprinkle in the flour, baking powder, and salt. Use a sturdy spatula to fold it all together until there is no flour visible.\n3 Bake the brownie cake: Spread the brownie mixture in the prepared springform pan and bake for 20 to 25 minutes, or until the cake has puffed slightly and the top is shiny and just barely cracked.\nTransfer to a wire rack to cool completely before removing the sides of the springform pan. In the meantime, make the speculoos frosting.\n4 Make the speculoos frosting: In a large bowl, using an electric mixer on medium speed, mix together the speculoos and butter for a full minute so it\xe2\x80\x99s light and fluffy. Add the confectioners\xe2\x80\x99 sugar, salt, and cream and beat for another minute, or until the mixture is fluffy and spreadable.\n5 Finish the cake and serve: Spread the frosting on the cake, garnish with chocolate shavings, and cut into wedges to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nClassic Ice Cream Sandwiches Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 6 rectangle ice cream sandwiches\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1 stick (1/2 cup) unsalted butter\n4 ounces semisweet chocolate, chopped\n1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 cup firmly packed brown sugar\n1/4 cup granulated sugar\n2 large eggs\n1/2 gallon vanilla ice cream in a paper, rectangle container\nSpecial equipment:\nHalf-sheet Jelly Roll Pan Sheet Pan, roughly 15x11-inch\nOffset spatula\nParchment paper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the oven and pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Butter the bottom of the jelly roll pan, then line it with parchment, leaving enough to hang over the sides. The butter will help the parchment stick to the pan when you spread the batter. The jelly roll pan should be about 15x11, give or take a little on either side.\n2 Combine dry ingredients: In a small bowl, whisk together the flour and baking powder. Set aside.\n3 Make the chocolate sauce: In a medium sauce pan set over low heat, slowly melt the butter, chocolate, vanilla, and salt together, stirring constantly. Once melted, remove from heat.\n4 Finish the batter: Stir the brown and white sugar into the chocolate mixture. Add the eggs one at a time, stirring until well combined. Fold in the flour mixture.\n5 Spread the batter in the pan: Using an offset spatula or standard spatula, spread the batter into a thin, even layer on the prepared baking sheet. Bake for 15 minutes. When finished, the brownie should have puffed up just a little, and the top should look dry.\n6 Cool and cut the cookies: Let cool completely. Once cool, use the parchment sides to lift the cookie out of the pan. Transfer to a large cutting board.\nUse a ruler to trim about 1/4 of an inch off each side so you have smooth even edges. Measure the trimmed cookie. Then use the ruler to measure\xe2\x80\x94and a long knife to cut\xe2\x80\x946 long strips the same width. Each strip should be about 2 to 2 1/2 inches wide. Measure the long strips to find the halfway point, and cut them across the center. Once cut, you should have 12 thin, rectangular brownies.\nUse an offset spatula or knife and run it between one of the rectangular brownies and the parchment. Put one brownie on top of the next just to make sure the tops are the same size as the bottoms. Trim if necessary. Take the top brownie off, and put it back where it was. Lift up the parchment and slide the cookies to the side.\n7 Assemble the ice cream sandwiches: Get a piece of plastic wrap ready. Take the half-gallon of ice cream out of the freezer. Remove the cardboard container either by unfolding it or removing the lid. Cut it down the middle like a T, and then around the bottom, and set the block of ice cream on a cutting board.\nSlice it longways into 1-inch thick slabs. Do this one slab at a time. Place your slab on a cutting board. Your slabs will be larger than the brownie. Place one brownie on top of the ice cream slab. Cut the ice cream to size.\nLift the ice cream and brownie up; place it brownie down on the plastic wrap; put the other brownie on top of the ice cream. Then, wrap the ice cream sandwich in plastic wrap. Repeat this until all the sandwiches are made and wrapped. Freeze until you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to enjoy.\nYou probably won\xe2\x80\x99t use all the ice cream. Scoop what remains into a Tupperware container and freeze for another day.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSausage Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nBread that is a little bit dry will hold up better in the casserole and provide more structure, which is why breakfast casseroles tend to call for "day old" bread. If your bread is fresh or soft, after you cube it, spread it out on a sheet pan and put it in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 to 12 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Italian pork sausage\n10 large eggs, beaten\n4 cups whole milk\n1 teaspoon dry mustard\n1/4 teaspoon onion powder\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nFresh ground pepper to taste\n5 cups cubed day old bread (we recommend rustic French or Italian loaf), cut into 3/4-inch to 1 inch-wide cubes\n2 cups shredded sharp cheddar cheese\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms (optional)\n1/2 cup peeled, cored, chopped tomatoes (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the sausage: Heat a skillet on medium. Break up the sausage into chunks and cook, working in batches if need be, until cooked on all sides. As you cook the sausage, you can break up the larger chunks into smaller crumbles (which are easier to distribute evenly over the casserole).\nWhen lightly browned, remove from pan to a paper towel lined plate to absorb any excess fat.\n2 In a large bowl whisk together the eggs, milk, dry mustard, onion powder, salt and pepper.\n3 Assemble the casserole: Place the cubed bread in a well-buttered 9x13 inch baking pan. Sprinkle with cheese. Sprinkle with chopped tomatoes and mushrooms, if using. Top with the browned crumbled sausage, distributing it evenly. Pour the egg milk mixture evenly over the bread and cheese.\n4 Cover and chill, if making ahead: At this point, the casserole can be covered and chilled in the fridge until ready to bake and serve, up to overnight.\nIf baking immediately, let the casserole sit for 10 minutes before putting in the oven (to give the bread a chance to absorb the milk-egg mixture.\n5 Bake the casserole: When ready to cook, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Bake uncovered for about one hour. Tent with foil if the top begins to brown too quickly.\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before serving. Leftovers will keep in the refrigerator for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nThe ingredient proportions are estimates. The more eggs, the firmer and less likely to deflate the casserole will be.\nMushrooms tend to hold a lot of moisture, so if you use a lot of them, you may want to saut\xc3\xa9 them first to release some of their water.\nDon't have day-old bread? Put slices of fresh bread into a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the breakfast casserole base:\n6 to 10 large eggs\n2 to 3 cups grated cheddar cheese\n6 slices day-old bread, cut into 3/4-inch to 1-inch-wide cubes\n2 cups milk\nSalt\nPepper\nFor the possible additions: \n1 cup corn (cooked or frozen)\n1/2 cup chopped broccoli (cooked or raw, raw will turn out crunchier)\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup sliced green onions\n1 cup cubed ham and/or cooked Italian sausage\nA few slices cooked bacon, chopped\n1 teaspoon Herbes de Provence, or other dried herbs, (or 1 tablespoon of fresh chopped herbs such as basil, rosemary, or thyme)\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of cumin or curry powder\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13 inch casserole dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Beat eggs, add milk and cheese: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the milk and cheese.\n2 Add the bread and carefully stir until all pieces of bread are moistened (don't over mix or the bread may disintegrate).\n3 Add the additions: Add salt and pepper to taste (if using Italian sausage, you won't need either.) If you have a lot of additions, you might need a couple more eggs to make sure that everything is at least touching some egg mixture. Just whisk in 2 tablespoons of milk for every beaten egg you add.\n4 Bake: Butter a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Pour the mixture into the casserole dish.\nBake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 50 minutes to an hour, until the top is browned and the center springs back when touched.\nRemove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nMushroom Quiche Recipe\nYield: Serves 6-8\nThis recipe includes instructions for making the quiche crust. You can easily use an already made, frozen pie crust. If you are using a frozen pie crust, don't defrost it, just proceed to step 2.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 recipe pie dough enough for one bottom crust (see P\xc3\xa2te Bris\xc3\xa9e recipe)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1/3 cup thinly sliced shallots\n1 pound assorted mushrooms, quartered or sliced (include some shiitakes if you want great mushroom flavor)\nKosher salt\nFreshly ground pepper\n1/2 cup milk\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n3 large eggs\nPinch nutmeg\n6 ounces Gruy\xc3\xa8re cheese, grated (1 1/2 cups)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roll-out dough: Roll out dough on a clean, lightly floured surface into a 12-inch circle. Line a 10 by 1 1/2-inch tart pan with the rolled out dough. Trim the edges.\nChill in freezer for 30 minutes. (You need to pre-freeze the raw crust or it will slip down the sides of the pan when it cooks.)\nAt this point, if you are using a pre-frozen pie crust proceed to step 2.\n2 Pre-bake crust: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line the crust with aluminum foil or parchment paper, pushing into the bottom edge. Don't cut the foil or parchment paper too close to the crust, allow for enough room to easily lift it out.\nFill it at least two-thirds with baking weights\xe2\x80\x94dried beans (I keep a bag of pinto beans just to use for pie weights), rice, or aluminum pie weights.\nBake initially for 15 minutes, then remove from oven and let cool a few minutes. Carefully remove parchment paper and weights.\nPoke the bottom of the pie pan with the tines of a fork and return to oven and bake an additional 10 minutes or until lightly golden. (Fork holes are for any air to escape.) Let cool on a rack while you make the filling.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots and mushrooms: Heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium high heat. Saut\xc3\xa9 the shallots for a minute, then add the mushrooms.\nSprinkle with salt and pepper and cook, stirring frequently, until the mushrooms release all of their moisture, and get well browned, about 10 minutes.\n4 Make the egg cream milk filling: Whisk together the cream, milk, and eggs in a medium bowl. Stir in nutmeg, salt and pepper.\n5 Assemble the tart: Place the tart pan on a rimmed baking sheet to catch any run-off or leaks. Sprinkle half of the grated Gruyere over the bottom of the crust. Spread the mushrooms and shallots over the cheese in an even layer, and sprinkle with the remaining cheese.\nPour the egg mixture over the mushrooms and cheese in the crust.\n6 Bake: Put the baking sheet with the tart pan in the oven and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until the center is just set, still a little wiggly, about 30 to 35 minutes.\nRemove to a rack and let cool for 20 minutes before slicing.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCaramelized Onion Quiche Recipe\nYield: Serves 6-8\nNote that although this recipe calls for making a pie crust from scratch, you can easily use an already prepared frozen pie crust. Just pre-bake it using the directions that follow.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 recipe pie dough (see P\xc3\xa2te Bris\xc3\xa9e recipe)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2-3 large red onions (about one pound total), French-cut (see below)\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\n2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\n3/4 cup milk\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n3 large eggs\nPinch nutmeg\n6 ounces Gruy\xc3\xa8re cheese, grated (1 1/2 cups)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nSLICING ONIONS STEM TO ROOT\nTo caramelize onions, you\'ll want to slice them lengthwise, or from stem end to root end. That way the onions will hold their shape better during the long cooking involved in caramelizing. (See How to Slice an Onion for more details.)\n1 First, use a sharp knife, get a firm grip on the onion, and slice off the stem end of the onion, by about a 1/2 inch. Cut about 1/8th of an inch from the root end, cutting off the roots, but leaving the core intact. Then place the onion root side up on the board to stabilize it, and cut it in half, straight through the root end.\n\n2 Peel back the papery skin of the onions. If you want, to keep your cutting area clean, cut off the roots with the skins, but cut only enough to cut off the messy roots. Keep the root end intact. It will make it easier to slice the onion.\n\n3 With an onion half cut-side down on the board to stabilize it, make angled cuts into the onion, from stem end to root end, cutting to, but not through the root end. Work your way around the arc of the onion, aiming your knife\'s blade toward the center of the onion.\n4 Make a "V" cut in the root end of the onion to cut out the tough root end, to release the onion slices.\nPRE-BAKE THE CRUST\n1 Make a frozen tart crust: If you are making your own crust (instead of using an already prepared frozen crust), roll out your dough on a lightly floured surface, into a 12-inch circle. Fit into a 9-by-1 1/2-inch round tart pan (or 9-inch pie dish), pressing dough into corners, extending the edges extra high to allow for shrinkage. Transfer to freezer to chill for 30 minutes.\n2 Line frozen crust with foil and pie weights: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line pastry with aluminum foil, pressing into the corners and edges, allowing extra foil on the sides (they\'ll be your handles when you remove the foil).\nFill at least two-thirds with baking weights\xe2\x80\x94dried beans, rice, copper pennies, or ceramic or metal pie weights.\n3 Bake with weights: Bake first for 15 minutes, remove from oven and let cool a few minutes. Carefully remove aluminum foil and weights.\n4 Remove weights and bake again: Poke the bottom of the pie pan with the tines of a fork and return to oven and bake an additional 10 minutes or until lightly golden. (Fork holes are for any air to escape.) Transfer to a wire rack to cool while making filling.\n  CARAMELIZING THE ONIONS AND PREPARING THE QUICHE\nThe onions will take about an hour to cook on the stovetop before they are ready to go into the quiche. So timing-wise, if you are making the entire quiche from scratch, it makes sense to get started on the onions once you\'ve put the crust into the freezer to chill before pre-baking.\n1 Caramelize the onions: Heat 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the onions and sprinkle a little salt over them. Cook, stirring occasionally for 10 minutes, until the onions have softened and are translucent. Reduce the heat to medium low and cook for an additional 40 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are well browned. (See How to Caramelize Onions for more details.)\nAdd 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar and cook for 10 minutes more, until onions are completely caramelized. Remove from heat.\n2 Assemble the quiche: Place tart pan on a baking sheet to catch any run-off there might be. Sprinkle half the cheese evenly over the bottom of the crust. Spread onions over the cheese and then top with remaining cheese.\nIn a medium bowl, whisk together milk, cream, and eggs. Season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Pour over the tart.\n3 Bake the quiche: Transfer to the 350\xc2\xb0F oven, and bake until just set in the center, 30 to 35 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for about 10-15 minutes before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSmoked Salmon, Dill, and Goat Cheese Quiche Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6\nThe filling recipe makes enough filling for a tall quiche in a 9-inch wide by 2-inch tall tart pan. If you are using a commercial frozen crust, you may find you have enough filling for 2 quiche pies.\nINGREDIENTS\nCrust:\n1 1/4 cups all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n10 tablespoons (1 1/4 stick, 5 ounces) butter\n2 to 2 1/2 tablespoons of water\nOne 9-inch x 2-inch high tart pan with removable bottom (or can use a 10-inch pie pan)\nFilling:\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n4 medium shallots, thinly sliced (about 1/2 cup)\n6 ounces smoked salmon, chopped\n4 ounces goat cheese, crumbled\n6 large eggs\n2 cup milk\n1 cup cream\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh dill\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough: Whisk together the flour and salt in a medium bowl. Cut the butter into cubes and add to the flour. Use your clean hands to work the butter into the flour until you have a mixture that a coarse meal with pieces of butter no bigger than the size of a pea.\nAdd the water a tablespoon at a time, working it into the dough with your hands until the dough can be formed into a ball.\nFlatten the ball into a disk. Wrap with plastic wrap and chill for 1 to 2 hours.\n2 Roll out the dough: When ready to roll out, remove the disk from the refrigerator and let sit for 10 minutes to come closer to room temperature.\nRoll out on a lightly floured clean, flat surface to 1/8-inch thickness to an inch or two wider than your pie  or tart pan. Drape over the tart or pie pan and press the dough into the sides of the pan.\nUse a rolling pin over the top to remove the excess dough and level the dough with the top of the pan. Place in freezer for 30 minutes to an hour.\nIf you want, at this point you can "blind bake" the frozen crust. Blind baking it will help you have a well browned crust on the bottom. I often skip this step because it takes extra time and I don\'t mind having the bottom crust not browned.\nBut, if that is what you want, then line the inside of the frozen crust with aluminum foil and fill to the top with "pie weights", which can be beans, sugar, or rice. The weights are to keep the sides of the pie crust from sliding down when baking.\nBake for 45 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F, then remove the weights and foil, and let cool a bit before adding the filling. (See our detailed instructions on blind baking.)\n3 Prepare the filling: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Heat oil in a small skillet on medium heat. Add the shallots and cook until translucent, a couple minutes, remove from heat.\nWhisk eggs in a medium bowl. Whisk in goat cheese. Whisk in milk, cream, dill, lemon zest, salt, and black pepper. Whisk in the shallots.\n4 Layer the salmon and filling into the quiche crust: Line the bottom of the quiche crust with half of the smoked salmon. Pour half of the egg/cheese/milk/cream mixture over the salmon in the quiche shell.\nLayer down the remaining salmon, and pour the remaining egg/milk/cream mixture over it.\n5 Bake: Place the quiche pan on a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet. Transfer to oven. Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F for 15 minutes.\nThen lower the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F and bake until just set in the center, about 30 to 40 minutes.\nRemove from oven and cool on a wire rack for 15 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBaked Blueberry French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesChilling time: 30 minutes up to overnight time: Yield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound loaf rustic bread, cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups of cubes)\n1 1/2 (or 2) cups blueberries, frozen or fresh\n5 large eggs\n2 cups milk (whole or 2%)\n1 cup heavy cream\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n8 tablespoons sugar, divided\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, diced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Assemble the dry ingredients: Butter a 9x13 (or other 3-quart) baking dish. Spread half of the bread cubes in an even layer in the prepared pan. Top with 2/3 of the blueberries, followed by the remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\nIf using frozen blueberries, add them to the casserole while still frozen (do not thaw). This helps prevent the berries from coloring the casserole too much.\n  2 Whisk the liquids: Beat the eggs, milk, cream, vanilla, 6 tablespoons of the sugar, lemon zest, and the salt together. Pour the mixture over the bread cubes, pressing down gently (so you don\xe2\x80\x99t burst the berries) to make sure the egg mixture is absorbed.\n3 Soak at least 30 minutes, or overnight: If soaking overnight, cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.\n4 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F about 15 minutes before you plan to bake the casserole.\n5 Bake the casserole: Just before baking, sprinkle the top of the casserole with the remaining sugar and dot with the diced butter. Bake for 45 minutes, until slightly puffed and golden brown. (Casserole that chilled overnight might take a few minutes longer.)\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before cutting. Serve with a dusting of powdered sugar over top or a drizzle of maple syrup.\nLeftovers will keep, refrigerated, for about a week and can be reheated in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHam and Asparagus Quiche Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hour, 30 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 recipe pie dough, enough for one bottom crust (see P\xc3\xa2te Bris\xc3\xa9e recipe)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 medium shallots, thinly sliced\n10 ounces asparagus spears, cut on the diagonal into 1-inch long pieces\n1/2 pound ham, cut into 1/4-inch cubes\nFreshly ground pepper\n1/2 cup milk\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n3 large eggs\n6 ounces Gruy\xc3\xa8re cheese, grated (1 1/2 cups)\nSpecial equipment:\n10-inch tart pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roll out dough and fit into tart pan, then freeze: On a lightly floured surface, roll out dough into a 12-inch circle. Fit into a 10-by-1 1/2-inch round tart pan (with or without a removable bottom), pressing dough into corners. Transfer to freezer to chill for 30 minutes.\n2 Pre-bake tart crust: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line pastry with aluminum foil, pressing into the corners and edges. Fill to the top with baking weights \xe2\x80\x94 sugar, dried beans, or rice.\nBake for 45 minutes. Lift sides of aluminum foil to remove pie weights from tart pan. Move pre-baked crust to a wire rack to cool while making filling. (See How to Blind Bake a Pie Crust for more details on this step.)\n3 Cook shallots and asparagus: Heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium high heat. Add shallots, and cook, stirring, until translucent but not brown, about 1 minute.\nAdd asparagus. Cook, stirring frequently, until asparagus are just cooked (al dente), slightly browned, firm, not mushy, 8 to 10 minutes.\n4 Assemble quiche: Increase oven temperature to 375\xc2\xb0F. Place tart pan on a baking sheet to catch any run-off there might be (especially if you are using a pan with a removable bottom.)\nSprinkle half the cheese evenly over the bottom of the crust. Spread asparagus and ham over the cheese and then top with remaining cheese.\nIn a medium bowl, whisk together milk, cream, and eggs. Season with fresh ground pepper. Pour over cheese.\n5 Bake: Transfer to oven, and bake at 375\xc2\xb0F until just set in the center, 30 to 35 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for about 10 minutes before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nLemon Ricotta Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings, about 12 pancakes\nIf you have any leftover pancakes (highly unlikely, but just in case), the pancakes can be frozen. Spread them on a baking sheet between layers of parchment paper and freeze until firm. Then stack them between parchment squares and place in a heavy plastic freezer bag. The pancakes will keep well for about 1 week.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 large eggs\n1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar, divided\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt, plus 1 pinch for beating the egg whites\n1 cup whole milk ricotta\n3 tablespoons lemon juice\n2 teaspoons finely grated lemon zest\n1/2 cup whole or 2% milk\nButter or vegetable oil, for the griddle\nFresh berries, to serve\nMaple syrup, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Separate the eggs: Carefully separate the eggs, placing the yolks and the eggs in separate bowls.\n2 Beat the egg whites: In a squeaky clean mixer bowl, beat the egg whites with a pinch of salt at high speed until very frothy. With the mixer still on high, slowly add 1 tablespoon of sugar. Continue beating until stiff peaks form, about 5 minutes. Set aside.\n3 Mix the dry ingredients: In a bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt until blended. Set aside.\n4 Make the ricotta mixture: In a large bowl, whisk the egg yolks and the remaining 1/3 cup of sugar together. Add the ricotta, lemon zest, and lemon juice and whisk until smooth. Stir in the milk until blended.\n5 Make the batter: Add the flour mixture to the egg yolk mixture and stir with a spatula just until combined. Fold in one-third of the beaten egg whites to lighten the batter. Add the remaining egg whites and gently fold until only a few streaks of white remain.\n6 Cook the pancakes: Set a griddle, cast iron pan, or non-stick skillet over medium-low heat and brush with oil. When the pan is hot enough that a flick of water sizzles on contact, use a 1/2-cup measure to scoop the batter and drop onto the pan. With the back of a spoon, spread the batter of each pancake into a 4- to 5-inch round.\nKeep the temperature of the pan at medium to medium-low. Cook each pancake for 2 to 3 minutes, or until bubbles form on top. Flip and cook for 1 to 2 minutes longer, until the pancakes are cooked through.\nServe each batch immediately or transfer the pancakes to a sheet pan in a warm oven to keep warm until ready to serve.\n7  Serve: Serve warm with butter, maple syrup and fresh berries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nOatmeal Buttermilk Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 12 pancakes\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups old-fashioned rolled oats\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon (optional)\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 large eggs\n1 1/2 to 2 cups buttermilk\n2 tablespoons vegetable oil or melted butter\n2 tablespoons honey\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nVegetable oil (for the skillet)\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Grind the oats: Set aside 1/2 cup of the oats to add to the batter later. In a food processor, grind the remaining 2 1/2 cups oats until the mixture resembles coarse whole-wheat flour, with a few particles of oats.\n2 Make the batter: Add the baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, salt, eggs, 1 1/2 cups of the buttermilk, oil or melted butter, honey, and vanilla to the food processor bowl and pulse a few times, until blended.\nPour the batter into a bowl and stir in the remaining 1/2 cup oats. Let stand for 5 to 10 minutes. The mixture will not be not completely smooth, and it will thicken as it sits. If the batter becomes too thick at any point feel free to thin with some of the remaining buttermilk.\n3 Heat a skillet or griddle: Pour a few drops of oil into the skillet or griddle and spread with a paper towel. Set the pan over medium heat. The pan is hot enough when you drop a few drops of water on it and they sizzle. Turn the heat to medium-low.\n4 Cook the pancakes: Ladle about 1/3 cup of batter for each pancake onto the skillet. With the back of the ladle, spread the batter into 4-inch circles. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes, or until bubbles form on top and the bottoms look brown when you peek under the pancakes with a spatula. Turn them and cook for another 2 minutes, or until browned. Repeat until all the batter is used.\n5 Serve the pancakes: Serve them hot off the griddle or keep them warm in a 325\xc2\xbaF oven on a wire rack set over a baking sheet. Serve with lots of butter, fresh fruit (if you wish), and maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSpicy Bloody Maria Cocktail Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesChill time: At least two hours before servingYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor Bloody Maria mix\n1 quart chilled tomato juice, such as Knudsen\n1 1/2 cups blanco tequila\n3/4 to 1 teaspoon hot sauce, such as Tapatio, or more to taste\n4 teaspoons adobo sauce from canned chipotle in adobo\n1 teaspoon soy sauce\n1/2 teaspoon finely grated orange zest\n1/3 cup fresh lemon juice\n3/4 cup fresh orange juice\nFor serving\n2 chilled 12-ounce cans or bottles pilsner or Mexican pale lager\nOptional garnishes: Cilantro, skewered cocktail onions, pickled carrots, radishes, tomatillos, lemon wedges, orange wedges, additional hot sauce, and beer\nSpecial equipment:\n2 1/2 quart pitcher with lid\nMETHOD\n1 Combine main ingredients and chill: At least 2 and up to 24 hours in advance, combine tomato juice, blanco tequila, hot sauce, adobo sauce, and soy sauce in a 2 1/2-quart pitcher. Stir, seal well, and chill.\n2 Add citrus ingredients and chill: Up to 1 hour before serving, prepare and add orange zest, lemon juice, and orange juice to the pitcher. Stir mixture well and keep refrigerated until ready to use.\n3 Make drinks and serve: To serve, fill pint glasses to the top with ice. Carefully pour in 1/4 cup beer, then top with Bloody Maria mix. Garnish as desired, and serve with additional hot sauce and beer to top off.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBruschetta with Tomato and Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 24 small slices, serves 6-10 as an appetizer\nUse any flavorful, ripe tomato for this recipe. If you use cherry tomatoes, just quarter them, don't bother blanching or peeling them.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 or 7 ripe tomatoes (about 1 1/2 lbs)\n2 cloves garlic, minced (about 2 teaspoons)\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar\n6-8 fresh basil leaves, thinly sliced* or chopped\n3/4 teaspoon sea salt, more or less to taste\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, more or less to taste\n1 baguette French bread or similar Italian bread\n1/4 cup (60 ml) olive oil\n*To thinly slice basil leaves, stack the leaves on top of each other and roll up like a cigar. Then make thin slices from one end of the basil cigar to the other.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch and peel the tomatoes: Bring 2 quarts of water to a boil. As the water is heating make shallow cuts in a cross pattern at the tip ends of the tomatoes (this will make the tomatoes easier to peel).\nOnce the water is boiling, remove the pot from the heat. Put the tomatoes in the hot water and blanch for 1 minute.\nRemove with a slotted spoon and let sit until cool enough to handle. Then gently peel off the tomato skins. Cut out the stem base with a paring knife.\nCut the tomatoes into halves or quarters and squeeze out most of the juices and seeds.\n2 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) with a rack in the top slot of the oven.\n3 Chop tomatoes, toss them with garlic, olive oil, vinegar, basil, salt and pepper: Finely chop the tomatoes and place them in a medium bowl. Mix in the minced garlic, 1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil, and the balsamic vinegar.\nStir in the thinly sliced basil and add salt and freshly ground black pepper, adding more to taste. Note, tomatoes love salt; you may need to add more than you expect.\n4 Toast the baguette slices: Use a bread knife to slice the baguette on the diagonal making half-inch thick slices. Brush one side of each slice with olive oil (a pastry brush helps here) and place olive oil-side down on a baking sheet or roasting pan.\nThe baguette slices will toast best in the top rack of your oven, so you may need to work in batches to toast them all.\nWhen the oven has reached 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) place the slices in the oven on the top rack and toast for 5 to 6 minutes until lightly browned around the edges.\nIf you want you can toast the bread slices without coating them first in olive oil. Toast them until lightly browned on both sides. Then cut a clove of garlic in half and rub over one side of the toast. Then brush with olive oil. (See Easiest Ever Garlic Bread.)\n5 Serve toasted bread with tomato mixture: Arrange the toasted bread on a platter, olive oil side facing up (the olive oil will help create a temporary barrier keeping the bread from getting soggy from the chopped tomatoes).\nEither serve the toasts plain with a bowl of the tomato bruschetta mixture on the side for people to top their own, or use a spoon to gently top each toasted bread slice with some of the tomato mixture. If you top each slice individually, do it right before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCheesy Bruschetta Chicken Cutlets Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 servings\nLook for chicken cutlets or thinly sliced chicken breasts next to the chicken breasts and tenders at the grocery store. If you have trouble finding them, you can also make your own by butterflying chicken breasts in half and pounding them flat. You want them to be only a 1/4-inch thick.\nServe this chicken on top of fettuccine or zucchini noodles or alongside steamed rice and vegetables.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the bruschetta topping:\n1 (14.5 ounce) can diced tomatoes, drained\n1 clove garlic, minced or pressed in a garlic press\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon Italian seasoning or 1/4 teaspoon each dried basil and oregano\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/2 pounds (4 cutlets) chicken breast cutlets or thinly sliced chicken breasts, 1/4-inch thick\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n3/4 cup (3 ounces) shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/4 cup (1 ounce) shredded Parmesan cheese\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat your oven broiler to its highest setting. Place a rack a few inches below the broiler.\n2 Make the bruschetta topping: In a medium mixing bowl, stir together all of the bruschetta topping ingredients. Set aside.\n3 Sear the chicken: Season the chicken cutlets on both sides with the salt and pepper.\nHeat the olive oil in a large (12-inch), oven-safe skillet over medium high heat.
