I like to use either a cast iron or stainless steel skillet -- nonstick and enameled cast iron cookware usually aren't meant to be used above 500\xc2\xbaF, so they aren\xe2\x80\x99t broiler safe.\nWhen the oil is shimmering, sear the chicken cutlets for 3 minutes on one side, just so they get a little bit of color.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s ok if they are not cooked through, since they will finish cooking in the oven.\n4 Flip and season the cutlets: Flip the cutlets over, then spoon on the bruschetta topping and sprinkle with the mozzarella and Parmesan cheese. Let them cook in the pan for 1 1/2 to 2 minutes.\n5 Broil the chicken: Place the skillet under the broiler. Broil until the cheese is bubbly and brown and the chicken is cooked through, about 3 minutes.\nCheck for doneness by cutting into one of the cutlets to see if it\xe2\x80\x99s opaque in the center, or by checking the temperature of one of the cutlets with an instant-read thermometer (the chicken should be 165\xc2\xbaF or higher in the center).\nAt this point, your chicken should be ready, but if you used cutlets that were thicker than 1/4-inch you may have to return it to the stovetop to cook for another 1-3 minutes.\n5 Serve: Sprinkle the parsley on top of the chicken and serve the cutlets hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nRoasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, rinsed, ends trimmed, and rough outer leaves of larger sprouts removed\n1 tablespoon minced garlic (about 3 cloves)\n1 teaspoon lemon juice (can sub apple cider vinegar)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Place the trimmed Brussels sprouts in a large bowl. Toss with garlic and lemon juice. Toss the sprouts with olive oil to coat them well.\nSpread the Brussels sprouts out in a large cast iron frying pan or roasting pan in a single layer with plenty of space between them. Sprinkle generously with salt (at least half a teaspoon) and a few turns of black pepper.\n3 Roast in oven: Put the sprouts in oven on the top rack, roast for 25-30 minutes, stirring the sprouts about halfway through the cooking.\nAdjust the timing depending on the size of the sprouts and your particular oven. When the sprouts are ready, they should be nicely browned and some of the outside leaves crunchy. The interior should be cooked through, so that the sprouts are easily pierced with a fork.\nIf the sprouts look like they are getting too browned (they should be well browned, not burnt), move them to a lower rack or lower the heat.\nIf after cooking for 30 minutes the sprouts aren't browned enough, put them under the broiler (or increase the heat to 500\xc2\xb0F) for 5 minutes.\n4 Sprinkle with Parmesan: Toss with Parmesan (if using) and add more salt to taste to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBrussels Sprouts Gratin Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nThe best way to trim the brussels sprouts is to slice of 1/4-inch from the bottom stem end with a paring knife. This will make it easier to peel off any outer tough leaves. Then when cutting the brussels sprouts in half, place them cut-side down on the cutting board to help stabilize them.\nYou can easily make this dish vegetarian by leaving out the pancetta in step 2. Just add an additional tablespoon of butter in step 3.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds Brussels sprouts, trimmed of outer leaves and sliced in half\nSalt\n2 ounces pancetta, diced\n1 tablespoon butter\n3 shallots, peeled, halved, and sliced\n2 tablespoons all purpose flour\n1 3/4 cup whole milk\nScant pinch of freshly ground nutmeg\nThyme leaves from 2 sprigs of thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dry thyme\n4 ounces of grated Gruyere cheese, divided 3 ounces and 1 ounce\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the Brussels sprouts: Heat a large pot of salted water, 4 quarts of water, 1 tablespoon salt. Blanch the halved Brussels sprouts for 3 to 4 minutes, until just barely tender. Remove from pot, drain, rinse with cold water to stop the cooking, set aside.\n2 Brown the pancetta and render the fat: Place diced pancetta in a large pot on medium low heat. Cook until most of the fat is rendered, about 8 to 10 minutes. Remove the pancetta from the pan, set aside, leaving the rendered fat in the pan.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots: Add butter to the pot and melt on medium heat. Add the shallots and gently cook until softened, about 4 to 5 minutes.\n4 Make roux: Add the flour to the butter shallot mixture to make a roux, whisk for 1 to 2 minutes.\nSlowly add the milk while stirring with a wooden spoon until the roux is incorporated into the milk.\nCook over medium low heat for several minutes, stirring, until the sauce thickens and coats the back of your spoon. Add fresh thyme and sprinkle with nutmeg.\n5 Add cheese, then half of the pancetta to white sauce: Add 3 ounces of grated Gruyere cheese into the white sauce and stir until the cheese is melted and incorporated into the sauce. Add half of  the cooked pancetta back to the sauce. Taste and add more salt if necessary.\n6 Add Brussels sprouts, transfer to gratin dish, sprinkle with pancetta, more cheese, bake: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Butter an 8"x12" gratin dish or casserole . Add the Brussels sprouts into the cheese sauce. Transfer the cheesy Brussels sprouts into the casserole or gratin dish. Sprinkle with the remaining pancetta and the remaining 1 ounce of grated Gruyere cheese.\nBake for 25 minutes until top is lightly browned and bubbly. Remove from oven and let sit for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nRoasted Brussels Sprouts with Pomegranate-Balsamic Glaze Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nThe pomegranate-balsamic glaze can be made ahead and will keep in the refrigerator for up to a month.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the glaze:\n1 cup pomegranate juice\n2/3 cup balsamic vinegar\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\nFor the Brussels sprouts:\n1 1/2 pounds Brussels sprouts\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 to 2/3 cup pomegranate arils\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the glaze: Combine the pomegranate juice, balsamic vinegar, and brown sugar in a saucepan and bring to boil over medium heat. Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the liquid simmer for 25 to 30 minutes, until reduced to a syrupy glaze that coats the spoon. Stir occasionally. You should have about 2/3 cup of pomegranate balsamic glaze when done. (Once cool, store the glaze in the refrigerator for up to a month.)\n2 Preheat oven to 375F. Move the oven racks to the upper third and lower third positions. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n3 Roast the Brussels sprouts: Trim the ends of the Brussels sprouts and slice them in half. Chop very large sprouts into quarters. Toss with the olive oil and a good pinch of salt. Divide the sprouts between 2 baking sheets and roast for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring halfway through.\n4 Toss the sprouts with the glaze: Let the Brussels sprouts cool for a few minutes before tossing them with 2 to 3 tablespoons of the pomegranate balsamic reduction and the pomegranate arils. Taste and add more glaze if you like. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBalsamic Roasted Brussels Sprouts and Shallots Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds Brussels sprouts, tough outer leaves removed, base trimmed, sprouts cut in half\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSeveral large shallots, peeled and thickly sliced, about a cup\n4 cloves garlic, peeled, sliced in half\n2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\nSalt\nPepper\n3/4 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves or 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/2 cup walnuts, toasted (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots in olive oil: Heat the olive oil in an oven-safe saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the shallots, spread them out in an even layer, lower the heat to medium low, and let them cook for 6 to 8 minutes, until softened and lightly browned.\n2 Add Brussels sprouts, garlic, balsamic: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Add the Brussels sprouts and the garlic to the shallots. Cook for 5 to 6 minutes more, until the sprouts begin to brown.\nDrizzle with 2 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Toss to coat.\n3 Bake in oven: Place in oven, uncovered. Roast at 425\xc2\xb0F for 15 to 20 minutes, until cooked through and caramelized on the edges.\n4 Sprinkle with balsamic, thyme, walnuts, salt, pepper: Remove from oven. Sprinkle with remaining 2 teaspoons of balsamic vinegar, the thyme, and toasted walnuts (if using). Stir to combine. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Bacon and Chestnuts Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8 as a side\nChestnuts are delicious, but a major pain to roast and shell (have you ever exploded chestnuts all over your kitchen? I have). Canned (jarred more like it) chestnuts actually work better in recipes than the kind you roast and peel yourself. The texture and moisture content is more consistent. So, we suggest using canned roasted chestnuts for this recipe. You can of course roast and shell your own if you prefer.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts\n1/3 pound thick-sliced bacon or slab bacon, cut into 1/4-inch pieces or batons\n1 red onion, chopped\n20-25 canned roasted chestnuts, quartered or roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chicken stock\nSalt and pepper to taste\nLemon wedges to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Cut the Brussels sprouts in half and slice thinly, starting at the top of the sprout and working back toward the stem. Discard the hard tip of the stem side.\n2 Cook the bacon: Cut the bacon into pieces about 1/4 inch wide and put them in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat.\nWhen the bacon is browned, remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n3 Cook the onions in bacon fat, add back the bacon:  Remove all but 1 tablespoon of the bacon fat (do not put down the drain, see how to render bacon fat). Turn up the heat to high, add the red onions. Cook until the onions begin to brown, add back the bacon.\n5 Add chestnuts, Brussels sprouts, stock: Add the chestnuts and Brussels sprouts to the saut\xc3\xa9 pan with the bacon and onions. Add the chicken stock and toss to combine. Stir in about 1 teaspoon of salt, more or less to taste. Cook over high heat for 3-4 minutes. Add pepper to taste.\nServe hot with lemon wedges. Squeeze a little lemon juice over the sprouts right before you eat them.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Toasted Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb fresh brussels sprouts, trimmed of ragged or old-looking outer leaves\n4-6 Tbsp butter\n1/2 onion, chopped\nSalt and Pepper\n1 teaspoon lemon juice or 1 Tbsp Meyer lemon juice, fresh squeezed\n1/4 cup toasted slivered almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Parboil the brussels sprouts: Bring 2 quarts of salted water (1 Tbsp of salt) to a rolling boil. Add the brussels sprouts and parboil them for 3 minutes or until just tender. (You could also steam them if you prefer.) They should be almost cooked all the way through (split one in half to test).\nRemove the sprouts with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice water for a minute to shock the brussels sprouts and help them retain their bright green color.\nRemove them from the ice water and cut the sprouts into halves.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, then brussels sprouts: Heat 2-3 Tbsp of butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until translucent, about 4-5 minutes.\nAdd 2-3 Tbsp more of butter and the brussels sprouts halves. Increase the heat to medium high and cook for several more minutes. Salt and pepper to taste, while the brussels sprouts are cooking.\nDo not overcook! Overcooked brussels sprouts are bitter and are the main reason why some people don't like them.\n3 Stir in lemon juice, add toasted almonds: Remove the pan from the heat, stir in the lemon juice and half of the toasted almonds. Add salt and pepper to taste. Place in serving dish and garnish with the rest of the toasted almonds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHoney Chipotle Roasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 servings\nThis recipe is easily doubled and while leftovers are okay when you reheat this, the sprouts are best right out of the oven while they are still crispy on the edges.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n2 chipotle peppers, from a can of chipotles in adobo\n1/4 cup honey\n1 tablespoon adobo sauce, from chipotle can\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prepare the sprouts: Cut Brussels sprouts in half through the end and toss with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread out sprouts on an even layer on a baking sheet. Roast for 15 minutes.\n3 Prepare the honey-chipotle sauce: Using a small knife, split chipotle peppers in half and remove seeds. Then mince the peppers and add to a small bowl with honey and one tablespoon of adobo sauce from the can.\n4 Finish the sprouts: Remove the sprouts from the oven and stir to ensure even cooking, then spread them again into an even single layer on the baking sheet. Toss with the honey chipotle mixture, but reserve a few tablespoons for finishing the sprouts. Return to oven and bake for another 10 minutes.\n5 Serve! Drizzle with the remaining few tablespoons of sauce, and serve sprouts while warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nShaved Brussels Sprouts with Lemon Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, tough or wilted outer leaves peeled off and discarded\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n2  extra virgin olive oil\n1 garlic clove, minced\n1 tablespoon mustard seeds\n2 tablespoons dry white wine (or Vermouth)\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Thinly slice the brussels sprouts and toss with lemon juice: Put the lemon juice in a large bowl. Peel off any large wilted outer leaves from the brussels sprouts and cut off the bottoms and discard.\nCut the sprouts in half lengthwise. Then thinly slice the sprouts crosswise. As you slice the sprouts, put the slices into the bowl with the lemon juice. Toss them to separate the leaves and coat with a little of the lemon juice.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 shredded brussels sprouts with garlic and mustard seeds: Heat the oil over high heat in a large skillet. When the skillet is hot, add the brussels sprouts, garlic, mustard seeds.\nSaut\xc3\xa9 them until the shaved sprouts are just lightly wilted and cooked, but still green and firm, about 3 to 4 minutes.\n3 Finish with white wine, salt, pepper, lemon zest: Add the wine to the pan. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Saut\xc3\xa9 a minute more.\nRemove from heat and sprinkle with lemon zest. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nMaple Glazed Roasted Delicata Squash and Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large delicata squash (about 1 1/4 pound)\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, trimmed of ragged outer leaves and stem\n3 large shallots, peeled, cut lengthwise in half or thirds\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 tablespoons pure maple syrup (divided 2 tbsp and 1 tbsp)\n1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar\n1 teaspoon Kosher salt (plus more to taste)\n1/4 cup fresh pomegranate arils\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Seed and slice the squash: Cut the delicata squash in half crosswise, and then in half again lengthwise. Use a metal spoon to scrape out the seeds and strings. Cut the squash into half rounds, about 1/2-inch thick.\n2 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n3 Sprinkle vegetables with olive oil, maple syrup, vinegar, salt: Place the squash, brussels sprouts, and shallots into a large bowl and toss with 2 Tbsp olive oil. Sprinkle on 2 Tbsp of maple syrup and one Tbsp of cider vinegar, and toss to coat. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon of kosher salt.\n4 Spread out on baking sheet and roast: Spread a little olive oil over the bottom of a large baking sheet. Arrange the squash, brussels sprouts and shallots on the baking sheet in a single layer.\nRoast at 400\xc2\xb0F for 30 to 35 minutes, turning the vegetables over after the first 20 minutes. The squash should be lightly browned and the brussels sprouts well browned.\n5 Toss with pomegranate arils and maple syrup to serve: Remove from oven to a serving dish. Gently toss with fresh pomegranate arils and drizzle with the remaining 1 Tbsp maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGolden Beets and Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nThis recipe can easily be scaled up to serve more people.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 medium sized golden beets\n10 Brussels sprouts, trimmed of rough outer leaves and cut in half\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 shallot, peeled and sliced\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 teaspoons fresh thyme, chopped\n2 tablespoons almond slivers, toasted\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Boil or roast the beets: The beets take the longest to cook so start them first. Either boil them in water in a small saucepan for 45 minutes (or how ever long it takes to get them tender), or wrap them in foil and roast them in the oven at 350\xc2\xb0F for an hour fifteen minutes or until done.\nRoasting will give you better flavor, but takes longer and uses a lot more energy (unless you are already cooking something in the oven).\nWhen done, set the beets aside to cool for 10 minutes, then peel and chop them into 1 x 1/2 inch chunks.\n2 Toast the slivered almonds: While beets are cooking toast your almond slivers if you are starting with raw almonds. Just heat a skillet to medium high heat and put in the almonds. Stir frequently with a spatula. When the almonds begin to brown, remove from pan into a small bowl. Let cool, set aside.\n3 Blanch the Brussels sprouts: Also while the beets are cooking, prepare the Brussels sprouts. Bring 1 1/2 quarts of salted water (2 teaspoons salt) in a medium saucepan to a boil. Add the Brussels sprouts to the water and blanch them for 2-3 minutes. They should be almost all the way cooked through.\nDrain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking. Set aside.\n4 Cook the shallots, add beets and Brussels sprouts: In a medium sized skillet heat 1 Tbsp olive oil on medium heat. Add the shallot slices and cook until translucent, a few minutes.\nAdd another tablespoon of olive oil and raise the heat to medium high. Add the sprouts and beets to the pan, along with the thyme and mix well. Salt and pepper to taste.\nCook for 1 minute more, stirring. Remove from heat and serve. Can serve warm or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHoisin Glazed Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 3-4 as a side dish\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, rinsed, any older outer leaves discarded, stems trimmed slightly, sprouts sliced in half through the stem end\n1 Tbsp peanut oil, or other vegetable oil\n1/2 large onion, sliced thinly root to tip\n2 teaspoons minced ginger\n1 garlic clove, minced, about 1 teaspoon\n1 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar\n2 teaspoons soy sauce\n3 Tbsp hoisin sauce\n1 teaspoon dark sesame oil\nSalt to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whisk together the seasoned rice vinegar, soy sauce, and hoisin sauce in a small bowl, set aside.\n2 Pre-steam the brussels sprouts: Place a steamer rack in a medium pot, add an inch of water. Heat the water to a boil, then add the brussels sprouts to the pot. Cover the pot and steam the brussels sprouts for 5 minutes.\nRemove the sprouts from the pot and lay them out on a baking sheet to cool while you cook the onions in the next step.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Heat the peanut oil in a wok or large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over high heat on your most powerful burner until the surface of the oil shimmers. Add the sliced onions and toss to coat with the oil.\nSear over high heat until the edges of the onion slices begin to brown, about 4-5 minutes.\n4 Add the ginger, garlic and brussels sprouts to the pan and toss to combine. Stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until the brussels sprouts begin to brown.\n5 Add the rice vinegar, soy sauce and hoisin sauce mixture to the sprouts and toss to combine. Stir-fry for a minute or two (watch the sides of the pan and turn off the heat if you see any of the sauce scorch on the side of the pan).\nDrizzle with sesame oil and add salt to taste. Serve at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHoney-Mustard Sheet Pan Pork Chops Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, halved or quartered, depending on the size (about 4 cups prepared)\n2 medium sweet potatoes, cut into 1/2-inch cubes (about 3 cups chopped)\n10 sprigs fresh thyme\n2 tablespoons vegetable oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 cloves garlic, grated or finely minced\n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard\n2 tablespoons honey\nFour 1-inch thick center-cut loin pork chops (about 2 1/2 pounds)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 400\xcb\x9aF.\n2 Toss the Brussels sprouts, sweet potatoes, thyme, oil, salt, and pepper together on a rimmed sheet pan. Make sure the vegetables are all evenly coated with oil.\n3 In a small bowl, mix together the garlic, mustard, and honey.\n4 Brush the pork chops with honey-mustard: Nestle the pork chops between the vegetables on the sheet pan. Brush both sides of the pork chops with half of the honey mustard sauce (reserve the remaining) and sprinkle with some salt and pepper.\n5 Bake the pork chops: Bake in the oven for 10 minutes. Brush both sides of the pork chops with the remaining honey-mustard sauce. Cook another 10 to 15 minutes, until the meat is cooked through and has reached an internal temperature of 145\xcb\x9aF.\n6 Serve: Divide the vegetables and pork chops between places and serve while hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Black Bean Garlic Sauce Recipe\nYield: Serves 4\nYou can find black bean garlic sauce in the Asian aisle of most grocery stores. I use the Lee Kum Kee brand and love it.\nIf you're up to it some chopped, cooked bacon is equally tasty when added to this dish.\nNote that the sauce is pretty salty, so no additional salt is needed.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil, grapeseed oil, or safflower oil\nDash of chili pepper flakes\n25 Brussels sprouts\n1 1/2 tablespoons of black bean garlic sauce\nground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Wash the Brussels sprouts well. Trim the stems and discard any of the loose leaves. Quarter them lengthwise.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the Brussels sprouts: Place the oil and chili flakes into a large skillet and place over medium-high heat.\nAdd the Brussels sprouts to the pan and cook for about 3-5 minutes or until the sprouts begin to brown a bit. They may absorb all the oil, if they do just add another 1/2 tablespoon of oil.\n3 Add the black bean garlic sauce and stir until all the Brussels sprouts are well coated.\nAdd a pinch of ground black pepper (the sauce is already salty so you probably won't need any salt).\nCook for about 30 more seconds. Take off heat and serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBuckwheat Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 14 to 15 4-inch pancakes, serves 2-3\nThe egg is optional, we\'ve made the pancakes both ways, with egg and without. With egg results in just a little more structure to the pancake. To make gluten-free buckwheat pancakes, substitute the all-purpose flour with buckwheat flour.\nDon\'t have buttermilk? You can substitute using 2 Tablespoons of white vinegar stirred into enough regular milk to make 2 cups. (After you stir in the vinegar, let the mixture sit for 5 minutes.) Or you can mix together 1 1/2 cups of plain yogurt and 1/2 cup of milk.\nINGREDIENTS\nVegetable oil for coating the pan\n3/4 cup (100g or 3.5 oz) buckwheat flour\n3/4 cup (100g or 3.5 oz) all-purpose flour (can sub with buckwheat flour for a 100% gluten-free buckwheat pancake if you wish)\n3 Tbsp sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n3 Tbsp unsalted butter, melted\n1 egg (optional)\n2 cups (475 ml) buttermilk\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pre-heat skillet: Heat a well-seasoned griddle, cast iron skillet, or stick-free pan on medium heat. The pan or griddle should be ready for the batter as soon as it is mixed.\n2 Make pancake batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the flours, sugar, salt, baking soda\xe2\x80\x94in a large bowl.\nIn Pour the melted butter over the dry ingredients and start stirring.\nBeat the egg with a fork and stir it into half of the buttermilk. Add the buttermilk/egg mixture to the dry ingredients, then slowly add in the rest of the buttermilk as needed to get to the right consistency for your batter (you may not need all of the buttermilk, depending on what type of buttermilk you are using and the brand of flour).\nStir only until everything is combined. Do not over-mix! A few lumps are fine.\n3 Ladle batter onto hot pan: Put a small amount (a half teaspoon) of vegetable oil on the pan or griddle and spread it around with a paper towel to coat.\nLadle the batter onto the hot surface to the desired size, about 4-5 inches wide. (A 1/4 cup measure will ladle about a 4-inch pancake.) Reduce the heat to medium-low. Allow the pancake to cook for 2-3 minutes on this first side.\n4 Flip pancakes over to other side: Watch for bubbles on the surface of the pancake. When air bubbles start to rise to the surface at the center of the pancake, flip the pancake. Cook for another 1-2 minutes, or until nicely browned.\n5 Keep finished pancakes warm: Keep your pancakes warm on a rack in the oven set on "warm," or stack them on a plate and cover with a towel as you make more. Spread more oil on the pan as needed between batches of pancakes.\nServe with butter and maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBuckwheat Waffles Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 to 12 waffles, serves 4 to 5\nThe fluffiness of these waffles is greatly enhanced by whipping the egg whites and folding them into the waffle batter. The whipped egg whites also help to provide structure for the waffles. You can skip this step, but the result will be a little more dense.\nWhen whipping egg whites it's important that everything that touches the egg whites is very clean. Even the smallest amount of fat, butter, or egg yolk can interfere with the whip-ability (is that a word?) of the egg whites. So make sure you separate the eggs carefully, and remove any specks of egg yolk that may have wandered into the whites (it's easiest to do that with a large piece of egg shell).\nYou can substitute the plain yogurt and milk combination with buttermilk.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups buckwheat flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\nPinch of cinnamon\n2 eggs, separated, plus 2 additional egg whites for extra lightness\n2 Tbsp sugar\n1 cup milk (low fat or regular)\n1/4 cup water\n1 cup plain yogurt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, melted\nExtra pats of butter for serving\nHeated maple syrup for serving\nBerries for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Turn on waffle maker, whisk dry ingredients: Turn on your waffle maker, with the setting on medium. In a large bowl, whisk together the buckwheat flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon.\n2 Beat egg whites: Place the egg whites in a medium bowl and beat with a hand mixer or egg beater. Sprinkle in the sugar as you beat the egg whites.  Beat egg whites until you have soft peaks.\n3 In a medium bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, the melted butter, yogurt, milk, and water.\n4 Combine wet and dry ingredients: Pour the yogurt/milk/butter/egg mixture into the buckwheat flour mixture and stir until just combined. It's okay if it's a little lumpy.\n5 Fold in egg whites: Stir a third of the beaten egg whites into the batter until completely incorporated. Gently fold the remaining beaten egg whites into the batter until just combined, and there are no streaks of egg whites. Be gentle so that you do not deflate the egg whites too much.\n6 Make the waffles: When your waffle maker is ready, working in batches, pour or spoon the batter into the wells, until they almost come to the edge. You will know if you've over-filled it because the batter will spill out of the waffle maker. No harm done, but it's a little messy.\nI like to grease the inside of my waffle maker with a little butter, to help make it easy to remove the waffles.\nCook until the waffle maker indicator indicates that the waffles are ready, or wait until steam stops rising out of the waffle maker. Gently pull the waffles out with a fork.\nAs you make the batches, the batter may thicken while it sits. If you want, thin it out a bit with some water.\nGetting the right balance of doneness is key here. Lightly browned means the waffles will be fluffy, but not crisp. Dark brown means the waffles may be crispy, but a little dry inside. It depends on your preference and your waffle maker. You may need to experiment with a few test waffles to see what works best for you.\n7 Serve: Serve with pads of butter, warmed maple syrup, and fresh berries.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
